DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-18. - Regular meetings. 
    The regular meetings of the city council shall be held on alternate Mondays at the hour of 4:30 p.m. at the city hall. If such meeting date should occur on a holiday the meeting shall be held on the day and at the time set by this council. 
(Ord. No. 230, § 1, 5-10-71) 
Sec. 2-19. - Public notice of regular meeting schedule. 
(a)  Public notice of the schedule of regular meetings shall be given at the beginning of each fiscal year and such notice shall state the regular dates, times and places of such meetings. A copy of such notice shall be posted at the city hall. 
(b)  If a change is made in the date of a regular meeting, notice of such change shall be published in a newspaper and posted at the city hall at least ten days prior to the meeting. 
(Ord. No. 230, §§ 2, 3, 5-20-71) 
Sec. 2-20. - Notice of special or rescheduled meeting. 
    Twenty-four-hour notice shall be given of any special meeting or of any rescheduled regular meeting, or of any reconvened meeting. No notice need be given if a meeting is to reconvene within 24 hours of the original meeting. 
(Ord. No. 230, § 4, 5-10-71) 
Secs. 2-21-2-26. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATIVE ASSISTANT 

Sec. 2-27. - Office created. 
    There is hereby created and established an office of the administrative government of the city which shall be known as the administrative assistant to the city council. 
Sec. 2-28. - Appointment; term; supervision by council. 
    The mayor, by and with the advice and consent of the city council, shall appoint the administrative assistant to the council, to serve at the pleasure of the mayor and the council. He shall be under the supervision of the council in all matters pertaining to the general management of the city. 
(Ord. No. 115, § 1, 4-6-64) 
Sec. 2-29. - Qualifications. 
    The administrative assistant to the city council shall be a qualified public administrator, who shall have at least three years' training and experience in financial management. 
(Ord. No. 115, § 2, 4-6-64) 
Sec. 2-30. - Supervisory duties generally. 
    The administrative assistant shall have charge of and supervision over all officers and employees of the city. He shall keep or supervise the keeping of all records, shall oversee the enforcement of the ordinances, shall see to the enforcement of all contracts to which the city is a party. He shall keep the mayor and the city council informed at all times concerning the progress of both departmental and general city affairs. He shall, when necessary, make recommendations to the mayor and council for the improving of the operations of the city. 
(Ord. No. 115, § 3, 4-6-64) 
Sec. 2-31. - Relation to department heads. 
    The administrative assistant, under the supervision of the city council, shall direct all department heads in the day-to-day performance of their duties. The department heads shall report to the administrative assistant and shall keep him informed at all times of the status of departmental operations. 
(Ord. No. 115, § 4, 4-6-64) 
Sec. 2-32. - As purchasing agent. 
    The administrative assistant shall be the purchasing agent for the city, under the supervision of the city council, shall make all purchases for the city. He is hereby authorized to make such purchases as he deems necessary for the operation of the city not to exceed $500.00. He is directed to set up a central purchasing system in accordance with good established municipal practices. 
(Ord. No. 115, § 5, 4-6-64) 
Sec. 2-33. - As personnel officer. 
    The administrative assistant shall be personnel officer of the city. Under the supervision of the city council, he shall administer personnel policy as established by the council and shall from time to time make recommendations to the council for the improvement of the city's personnel practices. 
(Ord. No. 115, § 6, 4-6-64) 
Sec. 2-34. - Attendance at council meetings. 
    The administrative assistant shall attend all city council meetings, regular and special, and be prepared at all times to inform the mayor and the council concerning details of the city's administration. 
(Ord. No. 115, § 7, 4-6-64) 
Sec. 2-35. - Fiscal duties. 
    Under the direction of the mayor and the council and in the name of the mayor, the administrative assistant shall: 
(1)  Before the beginning of each fiscal year, and not later than one month after that date, submit an annual operation budget, a capital program, and a capital budget to the council for its consideration and adoption. 
(2)  Prepare or supervise the preparation of monthly reports on the financial operation of the city. 
(3)  Withhold approval of any spending program of any department office, division, board or commission if such program would seem to endanger the city's financial integrity, or would seem to violate any ordinance or statute. Whenever such approval is withheld, the administrative assistant shall immediately submit the reasons for his actions to the mayor and council. 
(4)  Require the heads of all departments, offices, boards, commissions and other operating agencies to submit estimates to his office of the financial requirements of those agencies for the next ensuing year. These estimates shall be submitted by the first day of April of each year. During the ensuing 30 days the administrative assistant shall consult with the mayor and the various commissioners on the estimates, and shall hold public hearings on the estimates, with agency heads concerned in attendance. 
(Ord. No. 115, § 8, 4-6-64) 
Sec. 2-36. - Reports. 
    The administrative assistant shall make periodic reports, with such recommendations as he deems appropriate, to the mayor and the city council concerning the administrative management of all departments, boards, commissions and agencies of the city. 
(Ord. No. 115, § 9, 4-6-64) 
Secs. 2-37-2-42. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - RULES OF ORDER[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of council to determine its rules of procedure, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 3-11-1. 

Sec. 2-43. - Robert's Rules of Order to govern. 
    As to matters of procedure not specifically covered by these rules of order, Robert's Rules of Order shall govern. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 2-35) 
Sec. 2-44. - Mayor to preside at meetings; compelling attendance. 
    The mayor shall preside at all meetings of the council. In the absence of a quorum the mayor shall at the instance of one commissioner compel the attendance of the absent members. The chief of police shall at the direction of the mayor bring in absentee commissioners. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 2-12) 
Sec. 2-45. - Quorum. 
    A majority of the city council shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 2-13) 
Sec. 2-46. - Order of business. 
    Order of business of the city council shall be as follows: 
(1)  Calling roll of members and noting of absentees. 
(2)  The reading and disposition of the minutes of the last preceding meeting. 
(3)  Unfinished business. 
(4)  Presentation and allowance of accounts. 
(5)  Presentation of petitions (which shall always be in writing), remonstrances and reports of officers. 
(6)  Reports of departments. 
(7)  First reading of ordinances. 
(8)  Second reading of ordinances and action thereon. 
(9)  Resolutions. 
(10)  New business. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 2-14) 
Sec. 2-47. - Action on questions relative to priority of business. 
    All questions as to priority of business shall be decided without debate. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 2-15) 
Sec. 2-48. - Order and decorum at meetings. 
    The mayor shall preserve order and decorum and shall decide all questions of order, subject to an appeal to the council. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 2-16) 
Sec. 2-49. - Recognition of member to speak. 
    When two or more members shall address the mayor he shall decide who is first to speak. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 2-17) 
Sec. 2-50. - Manner of addressing chair. 
    Every member, previous to his speaking, shall address the presiding officer, but shall not proceed until recognized and named by the presiding officer. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 2-18) 
Sec. 2-51. - Personalities to be avoided. 
    No personalities or reflections injurious to the feelings of any member or the harmony of the council shall be tolerated and every person indulging in such personality shall be called to order by the mayor. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 2-19) 
Sec. 2-52. - Procedure when member called to order. 
    A member called to order shall immediately sit down unless permitted by the council to explain. If he appeals the council shall decide the matter without debate. If no appeal be taken the decision of the mayor shall be considered conclusive. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 2-20) 
Sec. 2-53. - Stating question; voting mandatory; exceptions. 
    When a question is stated, every member present shall vote, either for or against the matter under consideration, unless excused by the council, or unless directly or indirectly interested in the question, in which case he shall not be allowed to vote. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 2-21) 
Sec. 2-54. - Questions presented in writing. 
    All motions shall be presented in writing and shall not be considered unless properly seconded. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 2-22) 
Sec. 2-55. - When motion or resolution may be withdrawn. 
    When a motion or resolution has been stated by the mayor, it shall be deemed to be in the possession of the council, but may be withdrawn at any time before a decision or amendment by the commissioner proposing the same. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 2-23) 
Sec. 2-56. - Division of question. 
    If a question under consideration contains more than one distinct proposition it may be divided upon the request of any member of the council. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 2-24) 
Sec. 2-57. - Restriction on motions when question under debate. 
    When a question is under debate no motion shall be received unless for the previous question, to postpone indefinitely, or to adjourn to a certain day, to lay on the table, to amend, or to adjourn the council. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 2-25) 
Sec. 2-58. - Applicability of motion to lay on table. 
    A motion for the "previous question," to lay the question on the table, or to commit it until decided, shall preclude all amendments, or debate of the main question, and a motion to postpone a question indefinitely, or to adjourn to a certain day, shall, until it is decided, preclude all amendments of the main question. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 2-26) 
Sec. 2-59. - Manner of putting previous question. 
    The "previous question" shall be put as follows: "Shall the main question be now put?" 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 2-27) 
Sec. 2-60. - Motion to adjourn. 
    A motion to adjourn shall always be in order. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 2-28) 
Sec. 2-61. - Name of member offering resolution, motion to be recorded. 
    In all cases the name of a member offering a resolution or motion shall be inserted with it upon the journal. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 2-29) 
Sec. 2-62. - When yeas and nays to be taken on question. 
    Upon every vote on any ordinance or resolution, the yeas and nays shall be called and recorded, and every motion, resolution, or ordinance shall be reduced to writing and read before a vote is taken thereon. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 2-30) 
Sec. 2-63. - Repeal or passage of ordinance by majority of council. 
    No ordinance shall be repealed or passed, or contract or appropriation made, unless by a vote of a majority of the council. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 2-31) 
Sec. 2-64. - Report of committees, commissioners to whom subject addressed. 
    Committees or commissioners to whom any subject may be referred shall report in writing addressed to the council. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 2-32) 
Sec. 2-65. - Procedure on passage of ordinance. 
    Every ordinance, excepting ordinances granting a variation in the strict application of Zoning Ordinance No. 234, passed and approved August 2, 1971, as amended, shall receive at least two separate readings and no ordinance, except as otherwise provided, shall be finally passed at the same session of the council at which it was first read, unless the council by a vote of four-fifths of the members present suspends this rule for that special purpose. Any ordinance granting a variation in the strict application of the provisions of said zoning ordinance may be passed after a single reading and at the same session of the council at which such single reading takes place. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 2-33; Ord. No. 377, § 1, 7-24-78) 
Sec. 2-66. - Certain ordinances, resolutions to be made available for public inspection before passage. 
    Every ordinance or resolution appropriating any money or ordering any street improvements or sewer, or making or authorizing the making of any contract or granting any franchise, right or license to occupy or use the streets, alleys, highways, public property or public places, in the city shall remain on file with the city clerk for public inspection, complete in form in which it is finally passed, at least one week before the final passage or adoption thereof. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 2-34) 
Sec. 2-67. - Manner of repealing, amending rules. 
    The foregoing rules, or any of them, shall not be repealed or amended, abridged, modified, or suspended, except by at least a four-fifths vote of the council. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 2-36) 
Secs. 2-68-2-78. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-79. - Governmental departments. 
    The legislative, executive and administrative powers, authority and duties of the city shall be distributed to and performed by departments as prescribed by the laws of the State of Illinois now or hereafter in force, and the heads of the various departments shall have such further duties as the council may from time to time prescribe by resolution. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 3-1) 
Sec. 2-80. - Appointive officers designated; appointments; terms. 
    The council shall on the first Tuesday in May of each fourth year beginning with the year 1951, or as soon thereafter as practicable, appoint the following officers who shall hold office until the first Monday in may of the fourth year following, unless sooner terminated, and until a successor is appointed and qualifies: 
(1)  City clerk. 
(2)  City treasurer. 
(3)  City attorney. 
(4)  Chief of police. 
(5)  Chief of the fire department. 
(6)  Superintendent of the combined waterworks and sewerage department. 
(7)  Combined waterworks and sewerage department collector. 
(8)  Superintendent of streets. 
(9)  City hall and fire station keeper. 
(10)  City engineer. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 3-2) 
State Law reference- Appointment of municipal officers, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 3-7-1 et seq. 
Sec. 2-81. - Oath of office. 
(a)  Before entering upon the duties of their respective offices, all municipal officers, whether elected or appointed, shall take and subscribe to the following oath, which shall then be filed with the city clerk: 
    I, _______, do solemnly swear that I will support the Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of the State of Illinois, and that I will faithfully discharge the duties of the office of _______ according to the best of my ability. 
(b)  The oath of office may be administered by any magistrate or the city clerk. The person taking such oath is charged with the duty of filing it with the city clerk within the time specified by law and ordinance. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 3-6) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat., ch. 24, § 3-14-3. 
Sec. 2-82. - Bond. 
(a)  Each of the officers enumerated below, before entering upon the duties of the office to which he has been appointed or elected, shall execute a bond with security to be approved by the city council. The bond shall be payable to the city, conditioned upon the faithful performance of the duties of the office and the payment of all money received by such officer, according to law and the ordinances of the city, in the respective penal sums as follows: 
(1)  The chief of police ..... $2,000.00 
(2)  The city clerk ..... 5,000.00 
(3)  The mayor ..... 3,000.00 
(4)  The city treasurer ..... 35,000.00 
(5)  The water rent collector ..... 5,000.00 
(b)  Such other city officers shall be bonded in such amounts as the city council shall, from time to time, ordain or otherwise establish. 
(c)  These bonds shall be filed with the city clerk, except the bond of the clerk, which shall be filed with the city treasurer. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 3-6) 
State Law reference- Municipal officers, bonds, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 3-14-3. 
Sec. 2-83. - Authority to increase bond, require additional security or new bond. 
    The corporate authorities, by resolution or ordinance, may at any time direct an increase in the penal sum of any municipal officer's bond or require any municipal officer to provide additional security or a new bond. 
Sec. 2-84. - Signing of bonds; amount and payment of premiums; reimbursement. 
    All official bonds and any other bond required by the council may be signed by any bonding company that is registered with the Secretary of the State of Illinois for that purpose, and the yearly premiums for such bonds shall be paid from the contingent fund or from any appropriation for that purpose. The premium shall not exceed the statutory allowance of one-half of the one per cent per annum for each $1,000.00 of such bond. Where such premium has been advanced by any city official, the official shall be reimbursed on the presentation of the receipt for such premium to the council. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 3-6) 
Sec. 2-85. - Officers to be commissioned by warrant; issuance of certificate of appointment or election. 
    All officers elected or appointed under this Code, except the city clerk, the aldermen and the mayor, shall be commissioned by warrant under the corporate seal, signed by the mayor, acting mayor or mayor pro tem and the city clerk. The mayor shall issue a certificate of appointment or election, under the corporate seal, to the city clerk. 
State Law reference- Commission of municipal officers, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 3-14-2. 
Sec. 2-86. - Issuance and contents of commission. 
    After a bond has been given and approved and after an oath has been filed by an officer pursuant to this article, the city clerk shall issue to such officer a commission reciting the date, title of the office and term of the commission, signed by the mayor, acting mayor or mayor pro tem, countersigned by the city clerk and bearing the seal of the city. Until such commission has been duly issued, no person shall be recognized as an elected or appointed officer. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 3-14-2. 
Sec. 2-87. - Form of commission. 
    The commission to be issued to any elected or appointed officer shall be substantially in the following form: 
COMMISSION 
CITY OF MOUNT CARMEL 
State of Illinois, County of Wabash 
Know all men by these Presents: 
    That whereas _______ on the _____ day of _______ A.D. ___, was duly _______ to the office of _______ of the City of Mount Carmel, in the County of Wabash, and State of Illinois, the said _______ is therefore hereby authorized and commissioned to perform the duties of the said office of _______ from the date hereof until his successor is duly _______ and qualified, unless this commission is sooner revoked. 
    In witness whereof this commission is signed by the Mayor and countersigned by the Clerk of the said City of Mount Carmel, and the corporate seal thereof is hereunto affixed this _____ day of ___ A.D. 19___. 
___________ ___________ City Clerk Mayor  
  
City Seal. 
Sec. 2-88. - Compensation. 
    All officers and employees of the city shall receive such compensation to be paid at such time as the council shall from time to time ordain or otherwise provide. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 3-3) 
Sec. 2-89. - Anti-nepotism policy. 
(a)  Recitals. The foregoing recitals shall be, and are hereby, incorporated into and made a part of this resolution as if fully set forth in this paragraph. 
(b)  Basic principles. It is the policy of the city to prohibit nepotism. Consistent with that policy and the principle that city employees and prospective employees should be evaluated on the basis of individual merit, without reference to any factors not involving personal professional qualifications and performance, the following restrictions, designed to avoid the possibility of favoritism based on family relationship, shall be observed with respect to employment of all city personnel: 
(1)  Immediate family members of the city council and city clerk. Members of the city council's, the city clerk's and any department head's immediate family may not be considered for employment by the city and may not be hired by the city. Immediate family shall be defined herein to mean a spouse (including any analogous relationship recognized by law), parent, child, brother, sister, grandparent, all equivalent step, in-law and half relationships, and any and all guardians and wards of the official. 
(2)  Extended family members of the city council and city clerk. Members of the city council's, the city clerk's and any department head's extended family may not be considered for employment by the city and may not be hired unless all of the following do not apply: (1) a supervisor/subordinate relationship is created between the family members; (2) there is a potential for creating an adverse impact on work performance; and (3) the employment creates either an actual conflict of interest or the appearance of a conflict of interest. Extended family shall be defined herein as any family relation not within the immediate relationship defined above. 
(3)  Family members of staff. Members of any other staff member's immediate or extended family will be considered for employment on the basis of their qualifications. However, immediate family may not be hired, promoted or transferred, if employment, promotion or transfer would: (1) create a supervisor/subordinate relationship between family members; (2) have the potential for creating an adverse impact on work performance; or (3) create either an actual conflict of interest or the appearance of a conflict of interest. 
(4)  Notification. It is the responsibility of every employee to identify to the city clerk any personal relationship which falls under the prohibitions identified in this policy. Employees who fail to disclose personal relationships covered by this policy will be subject to disciplinary action up to and including the termination of employment. 
(5)  Where the terms of this section require an evaluation whether employment, promotion or transfer of a family member could create an adverse impact on work performance, an actual conflict of interest or the appearance of a conflict of interest, such decision shall be made in the reasonable judgment of: (a) in the case of an extended family member of the city clerk or an elected official, the disinterested members of the city council, or (b) in the case of a family member of all other city staff, the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 2010, 4-22-19) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2010, adopted January 2, 2018, added provisions to the Code but did not specify manner of inclusion. Therefore, at the discretion of the editor, said provisions have been included as § 2-89 herein. 
Secs. 2-90-2-94. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - MAYOR[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Election of mayor, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, §§ 3-4-1, 3-4-4 et seq.; function and duties of mayor, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 3-11-1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-95. - General powers and duties. 
    The mayor shall perform all such duties as are or may be prescribed by law or ordinance and shall take care that the laws and ordinances are faithfully executed. 
Cross reference- Board of local improvements, § 2-229; mayor to be president of board of local improvements, § 2-230; mayor as ex officio member of airport commission, § 3-16; mayor to be liquor control commissioner, § 4-27; mayor to appoint director of municipal civil defense organization, § 8-3; mayor to be ex officio member of plan commission, § 17-17. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 3-11-6. 
Sec. 2-96. - Examination of records. 
    The mayor shall have power to examine and inspect the books, records and papers of any agent, employee or officer of this city. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 3-11-3. 
Sec. 2-97. - Duty to inform council and make recommendations. 
    The mayor may, from time to time, and shall annually, give the council information relative to the affairs of the city and may recommend for their consideration such measures as he may deem expedient. 
State Law reference- Messages to council, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 3-11-6. 
Sec. 2-98. - Power to solicit assistance, call out militia. 
    The mayor shall have power, when necessary, to call on every male inhabitant of the city over the age of 18 years to aid in enforcing the laws and ordinances, and to call out the militia to aid in suppressing riots and other disorderly conduct or carrying into effect any law or ordinance, subject to the authority of the governor as commander-in-chief of the militia. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 3-11-4. 
Sec. 2-99. - Presiding officer of council; authority to vote. 
(a)  The mayor shall be the president of the council and preside at its meetings, and shall have the right to vote on all questions coming before the council, pursuant to statute. 
(b)  The commissioner of accounts and finances shall be vice President of the council, shall preside at all meetings in the absence of the mayor, and, in case of a vacancy in the office of mayor or the absence or inability of the mayor, shall perform the duties of the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 404, § 1, 12-10-79) 
Sec. 2-100. - Removal of appointed officers; restoration to office. 
    Except where otherwise provided by law, the mayor may remove any officer appointed by him, under this Code, on any formal charge, whenever he is of the opinion that the interests of the city demand removal, but he shall report the reasons for the removal to the council at a meeting to be held not less than five nor more than ten days after the removal. If the mayor fails or refuses to report to the council the reasons for the removal, or if the council by a two-thirds vote of all its members authorized by law to be elected, disapproves of the removal, the officer thereupon shall be restored to the office from which he was removed. The vote shall be by yeas and nays, which shall be entered upon the council's journal. Upon restoration, the officer shall give a new bond and take a new oath of office. No officer shall be removed a second time for the same offense. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 3-11-1. 
Sec. 2-101. - Temporary appointment to fill vacancy after removal. 
    Pending final action by the council on removal of an appointed officer, the mayor may, in his discretion, appoint a suitable person to perform the duties of the removed officer until the office shall again be filled by reinstatement or new permanent appointment. 
Sec. 2-102. - Duty to sign warrants, licenses, certificates or commissions of election or appointment. 
    The mayor shall sign all warrants drawn on the treasury, all licenses issued by the city, and all certificates or commissions of election. 
Sec. 2-103. - Power to keep peace. 
    The mayor may exercise the powers conferred upon sheriffs when necessary to suppress disorder and keep the peace. 
Sec. 2-104. - Release of prisoners. 
    The mayor may release any person imprisoned for violation of any city ordinance and shall report such release, with the reason therefor, to the council at its first session thereafter. 
(1947 Rev. Ords. § 9-1) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 3-11-2. 
Secs. 2-105-2-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CITY CLERK[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Department of employment, § 2-207. 
State Law reference- City clerk generally, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 3-10-7. 

Sec. 2-111. - General duties. 
    The city clerk shall perform all duties imposed upon him by law or ordinance, and which by usage and custom devolve upon clerks of municipal corporations in the state. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 3-7) 
Cross reference- Clerk to be ex officio clerk of board of health, § 11-20. 
Sec. 2-112. - Administration of oaths. 
    The city clerk shall have power to administer oaths or affirmations for all lawful purposes of his office. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 3-9-3. 
Sec. 2-113. - Duty to attend council meetings, keep record of proceedings. 
    The city clerk shall attend the meetings of the council and shall keep in a suitable book, to be styled the "Journal of the City Council," a full and complete record of its proceedings. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 3-7) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 3-10-7. 
Sec. 2-114. - Preservation and index of documents. 
    The city clerk shall carefully preserve in his office all books, papers and effects of every description belonging to the city and pertaining to his office, and shall properly index the same. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 3-10-7. 
Sec. 2-115. - Duty to prepare commissions, other official documents. 
    The city clerk shall prepare all commissions, licenses, permits and other official documents required by law, this Code and other city ordinances to be issued by him. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 3-7) 
Sec. 2-116. - Custody and use of corporate seal. 
    The city clerk shall be the custodian of the corporate seal of the city, and he shall affix the corporate seal to all commissions or other official documents required to be issued by him, and attest or countersign the same. He shall affix the corporate seal to all official acts of the mayor requiring it, and, if necessary, attest the same. He shall also, when required, certify under the corporate seal copies of any records, ordinances, documents or papers. In no case shall the impression of the corporate seal be binding upon the city unless it be authorized by law or the ordinances of the city. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 3-7) 
Cross reference- Corporate seal, § 2-3. 
State Law reference- Clerk to keep corporate seal, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 3-10-7; Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 3-9-3. 
Sec. 2-117. - Duty to keep register of licenses. 
    The city clerk shall keep a register of all licenses issued, the date thereof, to whom issued and for what purpose. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 3-7) 
Sec. 2-118. - Record and disposition of moneys collected; monthly report to council. 
    The city clerk shall, in a book for that purpose, keep an account of all fees and other monies collected by him, and from whom collected, and shall make a report to the council on the first Monday in each month of the amount so collected during the preceding calendar month and turn the same over to the city treasurer, and present receipt therefor, with his own report. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 3-7) 
Sec. 2-119. - General duties as ex officio collector of special taxes and assessments. 
    The city clerk shall be ex officio collector of special taxes and special assessments and shall copy the assessment rolls for each of the local improvements as soon as he shall receive warrants for the collection of same from the clerk of the court, in which said special tax or assessment has been confirmed, in a well bound register, and shall index the name of each person who has been assessed for the said improvements. When any such special tax has been collected, he shall credit the payment on the assessment roll on each lot, block, tract or parcel of land, by writing the word "paid" opposite the same, together with the name and post office address of the person making the payment and the date of payment. He shall keep a cash book and separate accounts for each improvement in which he shall note the date of payment, the amount, by whom paid and the description of the property, and at the end of each month, he shall report the several amounts received on each installment from each separate local improvement, to the council, and deliver all of the funds so collected to the city treasurer, and he shall file a receipt from the city treasurer with his report. The city clerk shall also give receipts to the parties paying the said taxes. The books of the said collector shall be open to the inspection of any interested party during business hours. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., §§ 3-5, 3-7) 
Cross reference- Taxation, ch. 20. 
Secs. 2-120-2-126. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - CITY TREASURER[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Department of employment, § 2-207. 
State Law reference- Office of city treasurer generally, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 3-4-1 et seq.; general duties of treasurer, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 3-10-1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-127. - Duty to keep monies, books and accounts; inspection by council. 
    The treasurer shall safely keep all monies belonging to the city, with a separate account for each fund or appropriation, and its debits and credits, and shall keep his books and accounts in such manner as may be prescribed by this Code. Such books and accounts shall always be subject to the inspection of any member of the council. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 3-10-1. 
Sec. 2-128. - Receipt for money received. 
    The treasurer shall give every person paying money into the treasury a receipt therefor, specifying the date of payment, and upon what account paid, and he shall also file copies of such receipts with the city clerk at the date of his monthly reports. He shall give a receipt for all dram shop license money paid to him by the person seeking to obtain a license in duplicate, the original of which is to be retained by the person paying the money, and the duplicate thereof to be filed by the person making such payment with the clerk. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 3-10-1. 
Sec. 2-129. - Monthly accounts. 
    The treasurer shall, at the end of each month at each regular meeting of the council, render an account or report showing the state of the treasury at the date of said account and the balance of money in the treasury. He shall also furnish a statement of all moneys received, on what account, together with all warrants redeemed and paid, which warrants and all vouchers held by him shall be delivered to the clerk, and filed with the treasurer's report or account in the clerk's office, upon every such monthly meeting of the council. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 3-10-2. 
Sec. 2-130. - Annual report. 
    The treasurer shall make an annual report to the council and file the same with the clerk between the first and tenth day of April of each year, showing all receipts and expenditures and all his transactions as treasurer during the preceding fiscal year, and the state of the treasury at the time of filing such report, which account the clerk shall immediately cause to be published. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 3-10-5.1. 
Sec. 2-131. - Warrants. 
(a)  All warrants drawn upon the treasury must be signed by the mayor and countersigned by the clerk, stating the particular fund or appropriation to which the same is chargeable and the person to whom payable, and no money shall be otherwise paid than upon such warrants so drawn. 
(b)  The treasurer shall return all warrants paid by him stamped or marked "paid." He shall keep a register of all warrants, which shall describe each warrant, showing its date, amount and number, the fund from which paid, the name of the person to whom paid and when paid. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 8-1-8. 
Sec. 2-132. - General duties relating to special assessments, taxes. 
(a)  The city treasurer shall hold all moneys received on any special assessment, or as special tax as a special fund, to be applied to the payment of the improvement for which the assessment or tax was made, or the bonds outstanding on account of such improvements, and said fund shall be used for no other purpose whatever, unless to reimburse the city for money expended for such improvement. 
(b)  The treasurer shall see to it that funds derived from special taxes or special assessments are paid out only in satisfaction of the obligations for the payment of which such tax or assessment was levied or made. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 3-7) 
Cross reference- Taxation, ch. 20. 
State Law reference- Special assessment funds, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 3-10-6. 
Sec. 2-133. - Books and accounts. 
(a)  The books of the city treasurer shall be furnished by the city and shall belong to the city, and the treasurer shall keep his books and accounts in such manner as to show with entire accuracy all monies received and disbursed by him for the city, stating from whom and on what account received, and to whom and on what account paid out, and in such way that said books and accounts may be readily investigated and understood. 
(b)  Such books and accounts, together with all the files and papers of said office, shall be at all times open to examination by the mayor or any member of the council, or any person authorized by resolution of the council. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 3-7) 
Sec. 2-134. - Lost or destroyed warrants; procedure for payment; bond. 
    When any city warrant shall be lost or destroyed, so that it cannot be presented to the treasurer for payment by the person entitled thereto, such person shall apply by petition to the council for relief, and the council may order the issuing of a duplicate warrant to the person so entitled to payment, upon his filing an affidavit of the loss or destruction of the original, and giving bond and security to the city to refund the amount of such warrant, and pay all costs, in case the original or lost warrant should be presented and said city be compelled to pay the same. 
Sec. 2-135. - Deposit of funds; interest. 
    The city treasurer shall keep all moneys in his hands belonging to the city in some bank or banks to be designated by the council. Interest on deposits shall be the property of the city. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 3-7) 
State Law reference- Deposit of funds-Designation, qualification of bank, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 3-10-3. 
Sec. 2-136. - Personal use of funds. 
(a)  The city treasurer shall keep all monies in his hands belonging to the city separate and distinct from his own; he shall not use, either directly or indirectly, the city money or warrants in his custody or keeping for his own use or benefit, or that of any other person or persons. 
(b)  Violation of this section shall subject the treasurer to removal from office by the council. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 3-7) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 3-10-4. 
Secs. 2-137-2-141. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - CITY INSPECTOR[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Department of employment, § 2-207. 

Sec. 2-142. - Office created; appointment; assistant, acting inspector. 
    There is hereby created the office of city inspector and the executive official shall be known as the city inspector, who shall be appointed by the city council. The city council may appoint an assistant city inspector. If such appointment is not made, then during the temporary absence or disability of the city inspector, the city council shall designate an acting city inspector. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 2-1, 8-22-67) 
Cross reference- City inspector to enforce building code, § 6-22; city inspector to enforce electrical code, § 6-42; city inspector to enforce plumbing code, § 6-63; city inspector to enforce fire prevention code, § 9-17. 
Sec. 2-143. - Qualifications. 
    To be eligible to appointment as city inspector, the candidate for position shall be well qualified from practical experience as an architect, structural engineer or builder, or have such other qualifications as may, in the discretion of the city council, make said candidate suitable for appointment. He shall be in good health, physically capable of making the necessary examinations and inspections. He shall not have an interest directly or indirectly in the sale or manufacture of any material, process or device entering into or used or in connection with building construction, alterations, removal and demolition, nor shall he have an interest in any firm or company in the building or construction or allied business, including, but not limited to, plumbing, heating and cooling, and electrical contractors. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 2-2, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 2-144. - Duties of city inspector. 
(a)  The city inspector shall devote as much time as necessary to perform the duties of his office. He shall receive all applications required by this division or any other provision of this Code relative to zoning, building, housing and fire prevention. He shall also issue permits and furnish the prescribed certificates required by any provision of this Code or other ordinances of the city. He shall examine premises for which permits have been issued and shall make necessary inspections to see that the provisions of law are complied with. He shall enforce all provisions of this Code and any other ordinance adopted by the city council relative to zoning, building, housing and fire prevention. 
(b)  Inspections required under the provisions of this division or any other provisions of this Code or ordinances of the city shall be made by the city inspector. The city inspector may accept reports of inspectors of recognized inspection services after investigation of the qualifications and reliability. No certificate called for by any provision of this division or any other provisions of this Code or ordinances of the city shall be issued on such reports unless the same are in writing and certified to by a responsible officer of such service. 
(c)  He shall, when requested by the city council or when the public interest so requires, make investigations in connection with matters referred to in this division or other provisions of this Code or ordinances of the city, and render written reports on the same. To enforce compliance with law, to remove illegal or unsafe conditions, to secure the necessary safeguards during construction, or to require adequate exit facilities in buildings and structures, he shall issue such notices or orders as may be necessary. 
(d)  The city inspector shall keep comprehensive records of applications, of permits issued, of certificates issued, of inspections made, of reports rendered and of notices or orders issued. He shall retain on file copies of required plans and all documents relating to building work, so long as any part of the building or structure to which they relate may be in existence. 
(e)  All such records shall be open to public inspection for good and sufficient reasons at the stated office hours, but shall not be removed from the office of the city inspector without his written consent. 
(f)  The city inspector shall make written reports to the city council, on forms provided by the city clerk, once each month or oftener if requested, including statements of permits and certificates issued and orders promulgated. 
(Ord. No. 170, §§ 2-3-2-5, 8-22-67) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 6; fire prevention and protection, ch. 9; housing, ch. 12; zoning, App. A. 
Sec. 2-145. - Limitation on powers. 
    Whenever in this chapter or the codes adopted herein it is provided that anything must be done to the approval of, or subject to the direction of, the city inspector or any other official of the city, this shall be construed to give such official only the discretion of determining whether the rules and standards established by this chapter or the codes adopted herein have been complied with, and no such provision shall be construed as giving any officer discretionary powers as to what such regulations or standards shall be or power to require conditions not prescribed by ordinance or to enforce ordinance provisions in an arbitrary or discriminatory manner. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 2-6, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 2-146. - Liability of inspector. 
    The city inspector, or any employee charged with the enforcement of this chapter, acting in good faith and without malice for the city in the discharge of his duties, shall not thereby render himself liable personally and he is hereby relieved from all personal liability for any damage that may accrue to persons or property as a result of any act required or by reason of any act or omission in the discharge of his duties. Any suit brought against the city inspector or employee because of such act or omission performed by him in the enforcement of any provisions of this ordinance shall be defended by the city until final determination of the proceedings. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 2-7, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 2-147. - Authority to enter. 
    The city inspector in the discharge of his official duties and upon proper identification shall have authority to enter any building, structure or premises at any reasonable hour. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 2-9, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 2-148. - Cooperation of other officials with city inspector. 
    The city inspector may request and shall receive, so far as may be necessary in the discharge of his duties, the assistance and cooperation of other officials of the municipality. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 2-8, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 2-149. - Drug and alcohol use, possession and testing policy and procedure. 
    The city hereby adopts the drug and alcohol use, possession and testing policy and procedure attached to Ord. No. 676 as Exhibit A and made a part hereof by this reference, and the drug and alcohol use, possession and testing policy and procedure shall apply to all full-time and part-time employees, volunteers and applicants for employment of the city. All employees of the city shall be notified of such drug and alcohol policy and shall be given a copy of the policy. 
(Ord. No. 676, 6-30-97) 
Secs. 2-150-2-152. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III1/2. - ANNUAL MUNICIPAL BUDGET[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Nonamendatory Ord. No. 451A, §§ 1-6, adopted Mar. 26, 1984, has been included as Art. III1/2, §§ 2-153-2-158, at the editor's discretion. 

Sec. 2-153. - Adoption of annual budget. 
    The City of Mount Carmel, Wabash County, Illinois, hereby adopts Sections 8-2-9.1 through and including Sections 8-2-9.10 of Chapter 24 of the Illinois Revised Statutes, providing for an annual municipal budget in lieu of the passage of an annual appropriation ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 451-A, § 1, 3-26-84) 
Sec. 2-154. - Position of budget officer created; qualifications, appointment, duties, bond. 
    There is hereby created the position of municipal budget officer, who shall be qualified and appointed by the commissioner of finance and accounts; and with the advice and consent of the city council, which municipal budget officer shall have the powers, duties and responsibilities enumerated in the above sections of the Illinois Revised Statutes, as they are now, or may hereafter be amended. The municipal budget officer shall give a bond in such sum as may be required by statute. The duties of said municipal budget officer shall be as provided by the Illinois Revised Statutes and shall include, but not be limited to, the following duties: 
(a)  Prepare and encourage the use of efficient planning, budgeting, auditing, reporting, accounting and other fiscal management procedures. 
(b)  Compile an annual budget in accordance with the ordinances of the city. 
(c)  Examine all books and records of all municipal departments, commissions and boards which relate to monies received by the municipality, municipal departments, commissions, boards and paid out by the municipality, municipal departments, commissions and boards, debits, accounts receivable, amounts owed by or to the municipality, municipal departments, commissions and boards. 
(d)  Obtain such additional information from the municipality, municipal departments, commissions and boards as may be useful for purposes of compiling an annual budget, such information to be furnished by the municipality, municipal departments, commissions and boards in the form required. 
(e)  Establish and maintain such procedures as shall ensure that no expenditures are made by municipal departments, commissions or boards, except as authorized by the budget. 
(Ord. No. 451-A, § 2, 3-26-84) 
Sec. 2-155. - Computation of annual budget. 
    The municipal budget officer shall compile a budget pursuant to the above sections of the Illinois Revised Statutes, as they are now, or may hereafter be amended, containing estimates of the revenues available before the beginning of the fiscal year to which it applies, together with recommended expenditures for the municipality and all of its boards, commissions and departments. Said budget shall be adopted prior to May 1 of each fiscal year. 
(Ord. No. 451-A, § 3, 3-26-84) 
Sec. 2-156. - Reporting relationships. 
    The municipal budget officer shall be generally supervised by the city administrative assistant. The municipal budget officer may supervise duly appointed deputies and employees assigned thereto. 
(Ord. No. 451-A, § 4, 3-26-84) 
Sec. 2-157. - Public inspection; notice and hearing on budget. 
    Copies of the tentative annual budget shall be made available for public inspection in printed or typewritten form in the office of the city clerk for at least ten days prior to the passage of the annual budget. Not less than one week after the budget is available for inspection and prior to final action on the budget, at least one public hearing shall be held on the budget by the city council. Notice of this hearing shall be given by publication in a newspaper having a general circulation in the city, at least one week prior to the time of hearing or as otherwise required by statute. 
(Ord. No. 451-A, § 5, 3-26-84) 
Sec. 2-158. - Revision of annual budget. 
    The city council may delegate authority to heads of municipal departments, boards or commissions to delete, add to or change items previously budgeted to the department, board or commission, subject to such limitation or requirement for prior approval by the municipal budget officer or commissioner of accounts and finance. as the city council, upon a two-thirds vote of the members, may establish. The annual budget may be revised by a vote of two-thirds of the city council by deleting, adding to or changing budgeted items. No revisions of the budget shall be made increasing the budget, in the event funds are not available to effectuate the purpose of the revision. 
(Ord. No. 451-A, § 6, 3-26-84) 
ARTICLE IV. - LEGAL DEPARTMENT 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-159-2-165. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CITY ATTORNEY[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference- Appointment of city attorney, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 3-7-3. 

Sec. 2-166. - Qualifications. 
    The city attorney shall be a licensed attorney in the courts of this state. 
Sec. 2-167. - General duties. 
    The city attorney shall: 
(1)  Act as legal advisor of the city council and city officials in all matters of law wherein the interest of the city is involved; 
(2)  Draw or approve current ordinances, bonds and contracts in the manner designated by the city council or any other proper official; 
(3)  Attend all meetings of the council and, when requested by the mayor or commissioners, attend any meeting of the board of local improvement; 
(4)  Prosecute or defend all suits in which the city is a party or has an interest, in any court and use all necessary and proper means for the enforcement and protection of the rights of the city; 
(5)  When unable, through disability or other cause, to perform the duties of his office or attend council meetings, designate, at his expense and with the approval of the mayor, another person to act for the city, and when, in the opinion of the council, an assistant city attorney is necessary, employ an assistant, with the approval of the council, at the expense of the city; 
(6)  Appeal from the decision of any police magistrate or justice of the peace to the county or circuit court of the county, when so directed by the council; 
(7)  Appeal any case to the appellate court or supreme court when so directed by the council; 
(8)  Adjust or settle pending litigation when so directed or approved by the council; 
(9)  Report to the council, with a recommendation for remedying, any defect in any ordinance, resolution or other official act of the city; 
(10)  Collect all judgments in favor of the city and cause execution to issue therefor if necessary; 
(11)  Examine fee bills of court officers and all expense incidental to any litigation and certify the correctness and liability of the city to pay; 
(12)  Receive from any city officer certified copies of any paper, contract or other document in reference to any matter pertaining to the city and required in the prosecution or defense of any suit or for any other business of the city. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 3-7) 
Sec. 2-168. - Annual report to council required; contents. 
(a)  The city attorney shall annually or at any time when requested by the council, report in writing to the council a detailed statement of all actions in any court, or any matter about to be taken into court wherein the city is interested, giving the names of the parties to the suit, the date of commencement, the facts in said suit and the method of procedure used to bring the matter to final determination, if the matter is determined, if not determined, the course to be followed; shall give a statement of all cases disposed of in any court with all facts concerning the same as might be necessary to keep the council fully advised concerning legal matters. 
(b)  Such reports need not cover police court cases. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 3-7) 
Sec. 2-169. - Copies of official documents. 
    The city attorney shall keep copies of all papers and other documents drawn or approved by him in reference to any city affairs and shall stand ready to deliver any such copies to the council upon request from the mayor or any commissioner. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 3-7) 
Sec. 2-170. - Vexatious, malicious or frivolous matters. 
    The city attorney shall not be required to prosecute any suit when upon investigation he shall be satisfied that the complaint was vexatiously or maliciously instituted and without probable cause, or where in his judgment there is not sufficient evidence to obtain a conviction. He may dismiss any such suit on such terms as he deems necessary and just and shall have the rights and powers generally exercised by attorneys- at-law in such matters. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 3-7) 
Sec. 2-171. - Attorney's fees in court cases. 
    In all cases in the circuit court against any offender for the violation of any of the provisions of this Code or any other ordinances of the city in which the city attorney appears for the city and in which there is a conviction, either after trial or by plea of guilty, or the case is dismissed upon petition of the city attorney, the reasonable and customary attorney fees accrued by the city attorney in the prosecution of such case shall be assessed and taxed as part of the costs, which shall be retained by the city. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 3-7; Ord. No. 727, 10-18-99; Ord. No. 770, 10-1-01) 
Secs. 2-172-2-177. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - ENFORCEMENT OF ORDINANCES 

Sec. 2-178. - Actions in corporate name of city as plaintiff. 
    All actions brought to enforce any fine, imprisonment, penalty or forfeiture under any ordinance of the city shall be brought in the corporate name of the city as plaintiff. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 9-1) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 1-2-7. 
Sec. 2-179. - Civil procedure. 
    The procedure in civil actions for the enforcement of any provision of this Code or other ordinance of the city shall be governed by the state law prescribing procedure in civil actions and by such provisions of the Illinois Municipal Code as may be applicable to such actions. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 9-2) 
Sec. 2-180. - Complaint. 
(a)  Whenever any violation of any provision of this Code or of any other ordinance of the city is alleged to have been committed, any person, with the assent of any police officer of the city, the mayor or any other officer of the city, may file a verified complaint against the alleged offender in such form as may be authorized from time to time by the rules of the circuit court or by applicable state law. 
(b)  No such suit shall be dismissed because of any deficiency in the complaint if the offense charged is alleged with sufficient clarity to advise the defendant of the nature of the complaint against him. 
(c)  If any complaint is found insufficient by the court the same may be amended by the city, either before or after judgment, on its motion, so as to sufficiently allege the offense charged. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., §§ 9-3, 9-6) 
Sec. 2-181. - Summons or warrant; prompt trial. 
(a)  In all actions for violation of any provision of this Code or other ordinance of the city, the first process shall be a summons or a warrant. 
(b)  A warrant for the arrest of an accused person may issue upon the affidavit of any person that such a violation has occurred and that the person making the complaint has reasonable grounds to believe that the party charged is guilty thereof. 
(c)  Every person arrested upon a warrant shall, without unnecessary delay, be taken before the proper official for disposition of the charges. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 9-4) 
Sec. 2-182. - Arrest without warrant; acceptance of bond, cash deposit; warrant on failure to appear. 
(a)  Any officer of the city who is authorized to make arrests may arrest any person who shall commit an offense under the ordinances of the city in his presence. 
(b)  When such officer is informed that a certain person has recently committed an offense, who may escape if not arrested at once, such officer may arrest such person forthwith without a warrant and take him before the circuit court or any judge or associate judge thereof, or if such officer sees fit so to do, he may accept a cash deposit of not less than $25.00 on condition that the offender will appear in the circuit court in which the arresting officer elects to file a complaint at a time to be specified in the receipt, or upon the complaint or citation given by the arresting officer to the offender stating the time and place for the appearance of the alleged offender. The arresting officer shall file a copy of such receipt and complaint with the clerk of the court therein specified and pay the money so specified to such clerk. 
(c)  If the offender fails to appear after making a money deposit as provided in this section, after posting bond under the provisions of any applicable rules of court or of state law, the court shall order such money deposit or bond forfeited and shall issue an appropriate warrant or other process commanding the immediate apprehension of the offender and requiring that such offender be brought before the court forthwith. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 9-5) 
Sec. 2-183. - Trial by jury; waiver. 
    In all cases before any court arising under this Code or other ordinances of the city, either the defendant or the city may on demand before trial, have the case tried by a jury as provided by the statutes of the state. If no jury is called for the parties shall be deemed to have waived a jury. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 9-7) 
Sec. 2-184. - Judgment against person making malicious or vexations complaint. 
    If in any case against an alleged offender in which the complaint is made by some person other than an officer of the city, the accused person shall be acquitted, the court may, if it appears to him that the complaint was maliciously or vexatiously made, or without probable cause, render judgment against such person so signing the complaint for the costs in the case and issue execution for the collection of the same. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 9-8) 
Sec. 2-185. - Judgment for penalty and costs when defendant found guilty. 
    In all cases where a defendant is found guilty of an offense for the violation of any ordinances of the city, a judgment shall be rendered against the offender and in favor of the city for the amount of the penalty and the costs of the suit. Execution may be issued on any such judgment in favor of the city. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 9-9) 
Secs. 2-186-2-196. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - CIVIL SERVICE[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
State Law reference- Civil service generally, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 10-1-1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-197. - Commission created; composition; terms; appointments. 
(a)  There is hereby created in and for the city a municipal civil service commission, which commission may also be known as and referred to as the civil service commission. 
(b)  The civil service commission shall consist of three members who shall be residents of the city. 
(c)  The term of office for each member of the commission shall be for a three-year period, except that upon creation of the commission original appointments shall be made of one member for one year, one member for two years and one member for three years. 
(d)  All appointments to the civil service commission shall be made by the mayor with the approval of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 299, § 1) 
State Law reference- Appointment of commissioners, etc., Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 10-1-1. 
Sec. 2-198. - Removal and replacement of members. 
(a)  The mayor may, with approval of the city council, remove any civil service commission member for incompetence, neglect of duty or malfeasance of office. 
(b)  The successor to any commission member removed from office shall be appointed by the mayor, with the approval of the council, for the unexpired term of office. 
(Ord. No. 299, § 2) 
State Law reference- Removal of commissioners, vacancy, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 10-1-2. 
Sec. 2-199. - Classification of positions. 
    All offices and positions of employment with the city, except those positions described in section 2-206, shall be subject to the rules and regulations of the civil service commission and will constitute the classified civil service of the city. 
(Ord. No. 299, § 3) 
State Law reference- Classification of positions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 10-1-3. 
Sec. 2-200. - Rule-making power; scope of rules. 
(a)  The civil service commission shall make any rules and regulations deemed necessary to perform its function, with the approval of the mayor and city council. 
(b)  Such rules and regulations shall prescribe the manner in which examinations for employment shall be administered, the criteria for employment to any position or office, subject to the provisions of this article, and the manner in which employment may be terminated. 
(Ord. No. 299, § 4) 
State Law reference- Rules-Powers of commission, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 10-1-5. 
Sec. 2-201. - Publication of rules, changes. 
(a)  A copy of all rules and regulations adopted by the civil service commission shall be made available to each employee subject to them. 
(b)  Any changes to these rules and regulations that the commission may from time to time make shall be distributed to all full-time city employees and such changes shall not become effective until ten days after such distribution. 
(Ord. No. 299, § 5) 
State Law reference- Rules-Publication-Notice, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 10-1-6. 
Sec. 2-202. - Examination of applicants for employment generally. 
(a)  All applicants for positions of employment in the classified civil service of the city shall be subject to examination. 
(b)  All such examinations shall be open and public and shall be competitive. They may be subject to specified limits determined by age, health, physical disability, moral character and criminal background, but any limitations so specified for any position of employment shall be made public prior to administration of any examination for such position. 
(c)  Examinations shall be practical in character, shall relate to matters that will fairly test the relative capacity of the applicant to perform the duties of the position for which application is made and may include tests of physical qualifications, health and manual skills. 
(d)  No questions in any examination shall relate to political or religious opinions or affiliations. 
(Ord. No. 299, § 6) 
State Law reference- Examination of applicants, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 10-1-7. 
Sec. 2-203. - Designation and duties of examiner. 
    The commission shall control all examinations and may, whenever an examination is to take place, designate a suitable person to be an examiner. Such examiner shall conduct the necessary examinations and make a complete report of any results to the commission in writing no later than five days following such examination. 
(Ord. No. 299, § 6) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 10-1-7. 
Sec. 2-204. - Notice of examination. 
(a)  A notice of the time, place, scope and fee of any examination to be given for any classified position of employment in the municipal civil service shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation within the city not less than two weeks prior to the examination, and shall also be posted in a conspicuous place in the commission office for two weeks before such examination. 
(b)  Such notice shall include the nature of the position for which the examination is to be administered and the specific limitations for employment to such position. 
(Ord. No. 299, § 7) 
State Law reference- Notice of examinations and fees-Publication, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 10-1-11. 
Sec. 2-205. - Appointments; probationary service; termination during probation. 
(a)  At such time as a position of employment within the classified civil service of the city is to be filled, the commission shall be directed to take the necessary procedures to administer the proper testing for employment to the described position. It shall then be the duty of the commission to provide the mayor and council, as soon as may be practicable, a list of all eligible candidates for the position. 
(b)  Any person employed by the city in a position in the classified civil service shall serve a probationary period of employment not exceeding 30 calendar days immediately upon initial appointment. 
(c)  Any employee's employment may be terminated without cause during such probationary period, and any employee so terminated shall be entitled only to such compensation or benefits which have accrued at the time of such termination. 
(Ord. No. 299, § 8) 
Sec. 2-206. - Exemptions. 
(a)  All full-time employees of the city in positions of employment that have been designated as constituting the classified civil service of the city shall be considered as having met all the requirements of the civil service commission for the position in which they are currently employed and they shall not be required to perform any tests, meet any special limitations or serve any probationary period to maintain such position of employment. 
(b)  Any person employed in any of the following described positions of employment with the city shall be exempt from any of the provisions of the civil service commission rules and regulations, and shall not derive any of the privileges thereof: 
(1)  Full-time salaried police officers. 
(2)  Full-time salaried firemen. 
(3)  Part-time or seasonal employees. For the purposes of this article, part-time or seasonal employment shall not exceed 600 working hours during any calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 299, § 9) 
State Law reference- Exemptions from classified service, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 10-1-17. 
Sec. 2-207. - Departments of employment. 
(a)  For the purposes of this article, the municipal government shall consist of the following departments: 
(1)  Executive department; under the supervision of the city clerk and including the city treasurer, city water rent collector, city inspector, parking meter attendant, custodian, secretaries and clerks. 
(2)  Water and sewer department; under the supervision of the water superintendent and including any machine operators, truck drivers and laborers required to perform the functions of such department. 
(3)  Street department; under the supervision of the street superintendent and including any machine operators, truck drivers and laborers required to perform the functions of such department. 
(4)  Police department; under the supervision of the chief of police and including all full-time police officers, city marshal, deputy city marshals, radio operators and clerks. 
(5)  Fire department; under the supervision of the fire chief and including all full-time firemen, volunteer firemen and auxiliary firemen. 
(6)  Recreation and parks department; under the supervision of the recreation superintendent and including a swimming pool manager, swimming pool lifeguards and park laborers. 
(7)  Golf course department; under the supervision of the golf pro and including the greens keeper and golf course laborers. 
(8)  Cemetery department; under the supervision of the cemetery superintendent and including all full-time laborers required to perform the functions of such department. 
(Ord. No. 299, § 10) 
Cross reference- City clerk, § 2-111 et seq.; city treasurer, § 2-127 et seq.; city inspector, § 2-142 et seq.; cemeteries, ch. 7; fire prevention and protection, ch. 9; police, ch. 18; streets and sidewalks, ch. 19; water and sewers, ch. 21. 
Sec. 2-208. - Removal; suspension; retirement. 
(a)  No person holding a position of employment in the classified civil service of the city may be removed, discharged or suspended for more than five days without pay except for cause, upon written charges and after having had an opportunity to offer a defense in his own behalf before the civil service commission, except as provided in section 2-205(c), subsection (h) of this section or section 2-209(a). 
(b)  The commission shall, upon receipt of written charges, conduct a fair and impartial hearing, which hearing shall be commenced within 30 days after receipt of such written charges. 
(c)  An employee against whom written charges have been filed with the commission shall be notified in writing of the nature of the charges filed against him, the accuser and the date and time of the formal hearing. Such written notice shall be provided to the employee not less than five days prior to the hearing date. 
(d)  Any employee found guilty of the charges presented against him to the commission, subsequent to a formal hearing, may be suspended from his duties without pay for a period of time not to exceed 30 days or have such employment terminated. 
(e)  Upon receipt of written charges, the commission may suspend any employee without pay pending a formal hearing, but such time shall not exceed 30 days. Should the suspended employee be found not guilty of the charges filed against him, he shall be restored to duty immediately and shall be reimbursed for all wages withheld. 
(f)  In the conduct of any formal hearing, each commissioner shall have the power to administer oaths and affirmations and to secure by its subpoena both the attendance and testimony of witnesses and the production of books and papers relevant to the hearing. 
(g)  Each department head or supervisor shall have the authority and power to suspend any employee without pay for any violation of a departmental rule or regulation for a period of time not exceeding five days for any single violation or several violations arising from the same set of circumstances. Upon such suspension, the department head or supervisor shall notify the employee in writing of the period of suspension, the cause for such suspension and the date the suspension is in effect. A copy of such written notification shall be forwarded to the civil service commission and to the council member responsible for the particular department. 
    Any employee so suspended may appeal such suspension to the civil service commission in writing and within five days after receipt of the notice of suspension, may request a formal hearing before the commission as set forth in this section and be subject to any decision of the commission as set forth in this section. 
(h)  An employee in the classified civil service of the city may make written application to the civil service commission and the Illinois Municipal Retirement Fund not later than 60 days prior to his sixty-fifth birthday requesting that he be placed upon a retired status upon the last day of the month in which such sixty-fifth birthday occurs, and further requesting that all such privileges and benefits due him be commenced upon such date. 
(Ord. No. 299, § 11) 
State Law reference- Removal-Suspension-Retirement, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 10-1-18. 
Sec. 2-209. - Abolition of position; reinstatement. 
(a)  When any department with positions in the classified civil service shall reduce the number of employees holding such classified positions or abolish any position in such classified service, then seniority shall prevail and any person so removed because of force reduction or abolition of position shall be considered as being on furlough without pay. 
(b)  If any positions which have been vacated because of reduction in forces or abolition of position are reinstated, such members of that department as are furloughed shall be notified by the commission by registered mail of any reinstatement of positions and shall have priority right to such positions if otherwise qualified, and in all cases seniority shall prevail. Written application for such reinstated position must be made by the furloughed person within 15 days after notification as above provided and such person may be required to submit to examination by the commission to determine that such furloughed person maintains the qualifications required of the reinstated position. 
(Ord. No. 299, § 12) 
Sec. 2-210. - Equal opportunity of employment. 
(a)  Nothing in this article shall be construed to discriminate against any employee or applicant for employment because of race, color, religion, sex, national origin or ancestry. The commission will examine all job classifications to determine if minority persons or women are underutilized and will take appropriate affirmative action to rectify any such underutilization. 
(b)  At such time as a position of employment within the classified civil service of the city is to be filled, the commission shall determine the availability of minorities and women in the area from which it may reasonably recruit and will submit all applicants for employment for each job classification in such a way that minorities and women are not underutilized. 
(c)  All advertisements or notices published for the purpose of eliciting applications for any position with the classified civil service will state that all applicants will be afforded equal opportunity without discrimination because of race, color, sex, religion, national origin or ancestry. 
(Ord. No. 299, § 13) 
Secs. 2-211-2-221. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - BOARDS AND COMMISSION

DIVISION 2. - BOARD OF LOCAL IMPROVEMENT[10]

Sec. 2-229. - Created; composition. 
    There is hereby created a board of local improvements for the city which shall consist of the mayor, the superintendent of streets and the city engineer. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 4-2) 
Cross reference- Mayor generally, § 2-95; general duties of superintendent of streets, § 19-2.

DIVISION 3. - BOARD OF FIRE AND POLICE COMMISSIONERS[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
State Law reference- Board of fire and police commissioners, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 10-2.1-1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-240. - Created; composition. 
    There is hereby created a board of fire and police commissioners for the city which shall consist of three members, as provided by state law. 
(Ord. No. 72, § 1, 8-19-57) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 9. 
Sec. 2-241. - Appointment; terms. 
(a)  The board of fire and police commissioners shall be appointed by the mayor by and with the consent of the city council. 
(b)  The terms of office of the members of the board of fire and police commissioners shall be three years and until their respective successors shall be appointed and qualified; provided, however, that no such appointments shall be made by any mayor within 30 days before the expiration of his term of office; and provided further, that the mayor shall appoint the first members of such board, one of whom is appointed to serve until the end of the current municipal year in which such appointment is made, another shall serve until the end of the municipal year next ensuing, and the third shall serve until the end of the municipal year next ensuing; provided, that each of the first members of the board shall serve until his successor is appointed and qualified. 
(Ord. No. 72, § 2, 8-19-57)

(a)  The members of the board of fire and police commissioners shall have such qualifications as are now, or may hereafter be, required of them by law. 
(b)  Each member of such board shall take an oath or affirmation of office and shall execute and deliver to the city a bond in the sum of $1,000.00 with such sureties as mayor and city council shall approve, conditioned for the faithful performance of the duties of his office. 
(c)  The members of the board shall be subject to removal from office in the same manner as other officers of the city. 
(Ord. No. 72, § 3, 8-19-57)

(Ord. No. 72, § 4, 8-19-57)

    The secretary of the board of fire and police commissioners shall serve without compensation for his services, and the members of such board shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 72, § 5, 8-19-57)

DIVISION 4. - PARK BOARD 

Sec. 2-251. - Created; composition; status of members; terms. 
    There is hereby created a park board and recreation system for the city which shall consist of five members to be appointed by the commissioner of public property, with the approval of the council. The commissioner of public property shall be a member of said board and shall control its actions. The remaining members shall act only in an advisory capacity to the commissioner of public property. Such appointed members shall serve for one year and shall be appointed annually on the second Monday in May of each year. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 4-6)
