ARTICLE II. - MOUNT CARMEL AIRPORT COMMISSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal airport authorities, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 151/2, § 68.1 et seq. 

Sec. 3-16. - Created; membership. 
    There is hereby created the Mount Carmel Airport Commission for the city, to consist of seven members to include the following: 
(a)  The mayor and one member to be designated by the county board of commissioners shall be ex officio members of said airport commission with the power to vote; and 
(b)  Five other citizen members, all being appointed by the mayor on the basis of their particular fitness for their duty on the commission, and subject to the approval of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 281, § 1, 8-28-73) 
State Law reference- Creation of airport authority, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 151/2, § 68.2; board of commissioners, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 151/2, § 68.3; board of commissioners-Appointment, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 151/2, § 68.3a et seq. 
Sec. 3-17. - Terms, compensation of members. 
(a)  The mayor shall serve for the term of his elective office. The member appointed by the county commissioners shall serve for a period of one year, with a reappointment or the appointment of a new member being made annually at the organization meeting of each new board of county commissioners. 
(b)  Of the five appointed citizen members, two shall serve until June 30, 1976, two shall serve until June 30, 1975, and one shall serve until June 30, 1974. Thereafter, such appointed citizen members shall serve for a period of three years. Vacancies shall be filled by appointment for unexpired terms only. 
(c)  All members of the commission shall serve without compensation, except that, if the city council deems it advisable, the secretary may receive such compensation as may be fixed from time to time by the city council and provided for in the appropriation ordinance of the city. 
(Ord. No. 281, § 2, 8-28-73) 
State Law reference- Commissioners' terms and qualifications, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 151/2, § 68.3d. 
Sec. 3-18. - Organization; officers; meetings; records. 
(a)  Immediately following their appointment, the members of the airport commission shall meet and organize by the election of one of their members as chairman and by the election of such other officers as they may deem necessary. 
(b)  The commissioners shall determine the time and place of all official meetings of the commission. 
(c)  The commission shall keep written records of its proceedings which shall be open at all times to public inspection. 
(Ord. No. 281, § 3, 8-28-73) 
State Law reference- Powers of the board, first meeting, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 151/2, § 68.6. 
Sec. 3-19. - General powers and duties. 
    The airport commission shall make and adopt such bylaws, rules and regulations for their own guidance and for the operation, management and use of the Mount Carmel Municipal Airport as may be expedient, not inconsistent with this chapter; implement, administer and enforce such relevant ordinances, rules and regulations as may be adopted by the city council; and, in the name and subject to the approval of the city: 
(a)  To negotiate contracts to establish, construct, enlarge, improve, maintain, equip, manage, operate, regulate and to acquire necessary property for, the Mount Carmel Municipal Airport, air navigation facilities and airport protection facilities which now exist or which may hereafter be acquired. 
(b)  To negotiate a concession agreement or agreements granting the right to conduct fixed base operator business and provide good, prompt and efficient commercial aeronautical services to the public on a fair, equal and nondiscriminatory basis to all users thereof; and in connection therewith to lease space, area or improvements of the airport facility and to grant concessions on airport property for aeronautical purposes, or purposes incidental thereto. 
(c)  To negotiate a farm lease consistent with the airport use plan on that portion of the premises not required for aeronautical use purposes and subject to any such existing lease and subject to requirement of Part 77, Federal Air Regulations. 
(d)  To negotiate a lease of any portion of the premises not required for airport purposes for industrial use, subject to prior written approval of the Federal Aviation Administration. 
(e)  To negotiate an oil and gas lease of any portion of the premises not inconsistent with airport purposes and with the airport use plan, subject to requirements of the Federal Aviation Administration. 
(f)  To prepare, for the consideration by the city, ordinances, rules and regulations relating to: 
(1)  Qualification standards. 
(2)  Standard form agreements. 
(3)  Concession fees. 
(4)  Lease rental rates and use charges for commercial activities and use of airport facilities. 
(g)  To prepare and recommend to the city council from time to time plans or recommendations for specific improvement of airport operation or facilities. 
(h)  To arrange and conduct any form of publicity relative to its activities for the general purpose of public understanding. 
(Ord. No. 281, § 4, 8-28-73) 
State Law reference- Nature and powers, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 251/2, § 68.8 et seq. 
Sec. 3-20. - Approval of council required in exercise of powers. 
    The foregoing powers of the commission shall be exercised only with the full consent and approval of the city council, and no purchase, lease, agreement, contract, expenditure or sale of personal property shall be made without prior general or specific authorization action taken by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 281, § 5, 8-28-73) 
Sec. 3-21. - Annual report. 
(a)  On or before the fifteenth day of May of each year, and before the annual appropriation ordinance is prepared the airport commission shall submit to the city council an annual written report of its estimate as nearly as may be, of the money necessary to defray the expenses of the operation and maintenance of the municipal airport during the current fiscal year. 
(b)  The report shall contain: 
(1)  An itemized statement of the various sums of money received on account of the municipal airport from all sources; 
(2)  An itemized statement of the objects and purposes for which those sums of money have been expended; 
(3)  A statement of the financial requirements of the municipal airport for the ensuing fiscal year for inclusion in the appropriation ordinance of the city; 
(4)  A statement of properties acquired and improvements made during the preceding fiscal year, and the nature of services rendered by the municipal airport; and 
(5)  Any other statistics, information, recommendations and suggestions that may be pertinent or of interest. 
(c)  The commission shall also prepare and present to federal and state agencies and officials such reports as may be required by law, regulation or contract. 
(Ord. No. 281, § 6, 8-28-73) 
Sec. 3-22. - Employment of personnel, technical and professional services; appropriation for compensation. 
    The airport commission may, at the discretion of the city council, employ necessary help whose salaries, wages and other necessary expenses shall be provided for by adequate appropriation made by the city from public funds. If the commission shall deem it advisable to secure technical or legal advice or services, it may be done on specific authority from the city council and appropriations by the council therefor. 
(Ord. No. 281, § 7, 8-28-73) 
Sec. 3-23. - Receipts and disbursements. 
(a)  All monies received on account of the municipal airport shall be deposited by the city treasurer in a special account appropriately titled. All disbursements therefrom shall be made on the recommendation of the airport commission and on proper authorization by the city council as required by law. 
(b)  The commission shall receive from the city treasurer, monthly, or more often if required by the council, a financial statement relative to the aforementioned special account. It shall include: 
(1)  An itemized accounting of receipts, 
(2)  An itemized accounting of disbursements, 
(3)  An itemized statement of the current accounts receivable and current accounts payable, and 
(4)  A statement of the balance on deposit in the special account. 
(Ord. No. 281, § 8, 8-28-73) 
Chapter 4 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of city to regulate all retail sales of alcoholic beverages, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 11-20-2; state regulation of alcoholic beverages, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 43, § 94 et seq.; city control over retail liquor sales established, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 43, § 110 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 4-1. - Definitions. 
(a)  The words and phrases "alcohol," "wine," "beer," "alcoholic liquor," "spirits," "original package," "distributor," "retailer," "sell at retail," "sale," "to sell," and "restaurant," "club," and "hotel," if and when used in this chapter shall have the same meaning as the same now are or may hereafter be defined in chapter 43 of the Illinois Revised Statutes. 
(b)  As used in this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section: 
    Bar means a counter and surrounding area designed with seating or standing areas for patrons and tended by a person who regularly delivers alcoholic liquor to patrons for consumption at such counter. 
    Consumption sales shall mean the sale or offering for sale at retail of any alcoholic liquor for consumption either on or off the licensed premises. 
    Licensed premises shall mean the premises described in the license. 
    Minor, as used in this chapter, shall mean any person under the age of 19 years. 
    Owner or proprietor shall mean and include all persons who are owners, or are in control of any place where the sale or distribution of alcoholic liquor is carried on, whether they be individuals, partners, corporations, joint stock companies, fiduciaries or officers, directors, stockholders of corporations or otherwise. 
    Package sale shall mean the sale or offering for sale at retail of alcoholic liquor, in the original package, and not to be consumed or in fact consumed in whole or in part on the premises where sold. 
    Restaurant means any public place kept, used, maintained, advertised and held out to the public as a place where meals are served, and where meals are actually and regularly served, without sleeping accommodations, such space being provided with adequate and sanitary kitchen and dining room equipment and capacity and having employed therein a sufficient number and kind of employees to prepare, cook and serve suitable food for its guests. In addition, any business claiming to be a "restaurant" must document, upon demand, that 50 percent or more of its purchases are derived from the purchase of food (including non-alcoholic beverages) as distinguished from alcoholic liquor. 
(1947 Rev. Ords, § 15-1; Ord. No. 314, § 1, 8-11-75; Ord. No. 1049, 5-9-16) 
State Law reference- Definitions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 43, § 95 et seq. 
Sec. 4-2. - Medicinal liquor exempt; requirements. 
    Alcoholic liquor may be sold or dispensed without a license by any drugstore upon the prescription of a licensed and practicing physician; provided, however, that the same charge shall be made for the filling of any such prescription as is made in the case of the filling of prescriptions for other medicine, and such charges shall be made in addition to the retail price charged for such alcoholic liquor and provided further, that such prescription may be filled only by a licensed pharmacist, and that a record be kept of each prescription so filled showing the date, person for whom prescription is filled, doctor issuing the prescription and the amount paid for the filling of the prescription, and for the alcoholic liquor sold pursuant thereto. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 15-6) 
Sec. 4-3. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1048, adopted May 9, 2016 repealed § 4-3 which pertained to unobstructed view of premises and derived from the Code of 1947 Rev. Ords., § 15-7. 
Sec. 4-4. - Access from licensed premises. 
    Except in the case of hotels, restaurants as defined by state laws, and clubs, no alcoholic liquor shall be sold at retail upon any premises which has any access which leads from such premises to any other portion of the same building or structure used for dwelling or lodging purposes and which is permitted to be used or kept accessible for use by the public. This provision shall not prevent any connection between such premises and such other portion of the building or structure which is used only by the licensee, his family and personal guests. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 15-8) 
Sec. 4-5. - Aid from manufacturer or distributor prohibited. 
(a)  It is hereby forbidden for any person having a retailer's license or any officer, associate, member, representative or agent of such licensee to accept, receive or borrow money, or anything else of value, or accept or receive credit other than merchandising credit in the ordinary course of business for a period not to exceed 90 days, directly or indirectly from any manufacturer or distributor of alcoholic liquor, or from any person connected with or in any way representing, or from any member of the family of such manufacturer, distributor or wholesaler, or from any stockholders in any corporation engaged in manufacturing, distributing or wholesaling of such liquor, or from any officer, manager, agent or representative of said manufacturer. It is also forbidden for any manufacturer or distributor to give or lend money or anything of value, or otherwise loan or extend credit (except merchandising credit) directly or indirectly to any such licensee or to the manager, representative, agent, officer or director of such licensee. 
(b)  No manufacturer or distributor shall, directly or indirectly, sell, supply, furnish, give or pay for, or loan or lease, any furnishing, fixture or equipment on the premises of a place of business of any licensee under this chapter to sell alcoholic liquor at retail, either for consumption on or off the premises, nor shall he, directly or indirectly, pay for any such license, or advance, furnish, lend or give money for payment of such license, or purchase or become the owner of any note, mortgage, or other evidence of indebtedness of such licensee or any form of security therefor, nor shall such manufacturer, or distributor, directly or indirectly, be interested in the ownership, conduct or operation of the business of any licensee authorized to sell alcoholic liquor at retail, nor shall any manufacturer or distributor be interested directly or indirectly either as owner or part owner of said premises or as lessee or lessor thereof in any premises upon which alcoholic liquor is sold at retail. 
(c)  No person engaged in the business of manufacturing or distributing alcoholic liquors shall, directly or indirectly, pay for, or advance, furnish or lend money for the payment of any license for another, nor shall any licensee accept the same. Any licensee who shall permit or asset, or be a party in any way to any violation or infringement of the provisions of this section shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this chapter. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 15-9) 
State Law reference- Receiving money or credit from manufacturer or distributor, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 43, § 122; manufacturer or distributor furnishing equipment or signs to retailers-Loaning money for payment of licenses, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 43, § 123. 
Sec. 4-6. - Credit sales prohibited. 
    No person shall sell or furnish alcoholic liquor at retail to any person on credit or on a passbook or order on a store, or in exchange for any goods, wares or merchandise, or in payment for any services rendered; provided, however, that nothing herein contained shall be construed to prevent any club from permitting checks or statements for alcoholic liquor to be signed by members or bona fide guests of members and charged to the account of such members or guests in accordance with the by-laws of said club; and provided further, that nothing herein contained shall be construed to prevent any hotel from permitting checks or statements for liquor to be signed by regular guests residing at said hotel and charged to the accounts of said guests. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 15-10) 
State Law reference- Sales on credit, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 43, § 134. 
Sec. 4-7. - Sales to persons under 21 and spend-thrifts, mental incompetents. 
    No licensee nor any officer, associate, member, representative, agent or employee of such licensee shall sell, give or deliver alcoholic liquor to any person under the age of 21 years, or to any intoxicated person or to any person known by him to be an habitual drunkard, spendthrift, insane, mentally ill, mentally deficient or in need of mental treatment. No person, after purchasing or otherwise obtaining alcoholic liquor, shall sell, give or deliver such alcoholic liquor to another person under the age of 21 years, except in the performance of a religious ceremony or service. 
(Rev. Ords. 1947, § 15-11; Ord. No. 288, § 1, 2-11-74; Ord. No. 405, §§ 1, 2, 12-10-79) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 235 ILCS 5/6-16. 
Sec. 4-8. - Purchase by ineligible persons; identification cards. 
(a)  Any person to whom the sale, gift or delivery of any alcoholic liquor is prohibited because of age shall not purchase or accept the gift of alcoholic liquor or have such alcoholic liquor in his possession except in the course of their employment as hereinafter provided. 
(b)  If a licensee or his agents or employees believe or has reason to believe that a sale or delivery of any alcoholic liquor is prohibited because of the nonage of the prospective recipient, he shall, before making such sale or delivery, demand presentation of some form of positive identification containing proof of age issued by a public officer in the performance of his official duties, 
(c)  No person shall transfer, alter or deface such identification card; use the identification card of another; carry or use a forged or failed identification card; or obtain an identification card by means of false information. No person shall purchase, accept delivery or have possession of alcoholic liquor in violation of this section. The consumption of alcoholic liquor by any person under 21 years of age is forbidden. 
(1947 Rev, Ords., § 5-12; Ord. No. 288, § 2, 2-11-74; Ord. No. 405, § 3, 12-10-79; Ord. No. 631, 8-14-95) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 235 ILCS 5/6-20. 
Sec. 4-9. - Certain persons prohibited in taverns. 
(a)  No person to whom the sale, gift or delivery of any alcoholic liquor is prohibited because of age, either alone or accompanied by an adult, shall enter or be suffered to remain in or on the portion of the licensed premises where alcoholic liquor is sold under either a class A, class B or class C license or any room or place adjoining the same where alcoholic liquors are sold or served or suffered to be consumed; provided, however, that this section shall not apply to any licensed premises where the principal business consists of the sale of food and/or other commodities, including a bowling establishment, and services rendered in connection therewith. 
(b)  No minor (under the age of 18) shall draw, pour, or mix any alcoholic liquor as an employee of any licensee; nor shall any minor at any time attend any bar or draw, pour, or mix any alcoholic liquor in any licensed premises except as explicitly provided herein. Waiters and waitresses must be at least 18 years of age, provided, however, busboys, waiters and waitresses under the age of 18 may be employed in establishments which serve alcoholic liquor when such employment involves the serving of meals, but such individuals may not draw, pour, mix or serve any alcoholic beverages. 
(c)  No gambling devices of any kind or nature, games of chance, punchboards, slot machines, dice, or other instruments of gambling shall be permitted or allowed upon any premises licenses for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor except that bingo games, pull tabs and video gaming terminals shall be permitted where the licensee has obtained the necessary permits and licenses from the state and has complied with the Illinois Video Gaming Act for video gaming terminals. 
(Ord. No. 288, § 4, 2-11-74; Ord. No. 631, 8-14-95; Ord. No. 710, 12-28-98; Ord. No. 977, 5-29-12) 
Sec. 4-10. - Notice to unauthorized persons. 
    The licensee of each licensed premises which persons under the age of 21 are forbidden to enter under section 4-9 hereof shall post and keep posted in a conspicuous place on such premises and on the front of such premises so that the same can be read from the outside a notice substantially as follows: 
    "Persons under the age of 21 are forbidden by ordinance under penalty to enter or be on these premises." 
(Ord. No. 288, § 5, 2-11-74; Ord. No. 405, § 4, 12-10-79) 
Sec. 4-11. - Packaging, stamping and labeling. 
    No person shall sell at retail, manufacture or distribute any alcoholic liquor in the corporate limits of the city that does not in all respects conform to the requirements of state and federal laws for the packaging, stamping and labeling of such liquor and it is unlawful for any person to have in his possession in the city any alcoholic liquor that does not conform. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 15-16) 
Sec. 4-12. - Time of opening and closing. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation licensed under this chapter to sell or to offer for sale or to give away any alcoholic liquor in or upon any licensed premises in the city between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. Section 4-12(b) and (c) are hereby repealed in their entirety. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 15-17; Ord. No. 113, § 1, 12-30-63; Ord. No. 277, § 1, 7-30-73; Ord. No. 300, § 1, 1-17-74; Ord. No. 551, § 1, 7-8-91; Ord. No. 901, 8-27-07; Ord. No. 1053, 5-9-16; Ord. No. 1072, 4-24-17) 
Sec. 4-13. - Dancing on licensed premises prohibited, except as provided herein. 
(a)  Dancing in or upon licensed premises, or in, or upon, an upper or lower floor of such premises if connected with the licensed by a stairway or passageway, or in, or upon, adjacent premises connected therewith by a doorway, or passageway, is prohibited, with the exception of licensed clubs and those premises with a class A license. Any licensee allowing dancing shall have a designated dance area on the premises, with the requirement that no alcoholic beverages be allowed on the dance floor. 
(b)  Dancing, as permitted herein, is defined to include only patrons or customers dancing on the designated dance area. It is specifically stated that dancing shall not be deemed to include or allow dancing, or performing, by individuals or groups, whether male or female, when done as an exhibition for patron's or customers' viewing, or otherwise, regardless of where performed. 
(c)  A violation of this section shall subject both the licensee and the person, or persons, so offending to the penalties in this chapter. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 15-18; Ord. No. 429, § 1, 1-18-82; Ord. No. 479, § 1, 12-16-86; Ord. No. 479-A, § 1, 1-12-87; Ord. No. 508, § 1, 10-3-88) 
Sec. 4-14. - Liquor in automobiles. 
    No person shall transport, carry, possess or have any alcoholic liquor in or upon or about any motor vehicle except in the original package and with the seal unbroken. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 15-19) 
Sec. 4-14.1. - Removal from premises prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to remove, take, carry, convey or transport from any licensed premises, any alcoholic liquor not in the original, unopened package. 
(b)  No licensee, his agents, servants or employees shall permit or allow any person to remove, take, carry, convey or transport from the licensed premises any alcoholic liquor except in the original, unopened package. 
(c)  Any alcoholic liquor sold, bartered, exchanged, given, provided, furnished or dispend by any licensee, his agents, servants or employees in other than the original, unopened package, shall be used, consumed or otherwise disposed of only upon the interior of such licensed premises. 
(d)  No licensee, his agents, servants or employees shall sell, barter, exchange, give, provide, furnish or dispense to any person any alcoholic liquor for consumption or use in any place or location except the interior of the licensed premises unless such alcoholic liquor shall be in the original, unopened package. 
(Ord. No. 305, § 4-21-75) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 305, nonamendatory of the Code, has been included as § 4-14.1 at the editor's discretion. 
Sec. 4-14.2. - Sales outside licensed premises. 
    No licensee shall sell, offer for sale, give away or otherwise transfer or deliver any alcoholic liquor to any person or persons not physically present within the principal building constituting the licensed premises, nor shall any licensee sell, offer for sale, give away or otherwise transfer or deliver any alcoholic liquor through any door, window, panel or other opening in or through the said principal building to any person or persons outside said principal building. Holders of class A, B and D Licenses may sell, offer for sale, give away or otherwise transfer or deliver any alcoholic liquor outside the principal building, upon said real estate, provided the said real estate shall be in a secured area, subject to the city council approving such secured area and article I. 
(Ord. No. 380, § 1, 7-24-78; Ord. No. 912, 4-21-08) 
Sec. 4-14.3. - Licensed premises, class A, B, D and G licenses. 
    For the holders of license A, B, D and G liquor licenses, the license premises shall include not only the building, but also the real estate upon which such building is located, including all tracts adjacent to or contiguous to or adjoining such real estate and owned, or leased, by the license holder. 
(Ord. No. 912, 4-21-08; Ord. No. 1054, 5-9-16) 
Sec. 4-15. - Penalties. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine of not less than $100.00 and not more than $500.00, to be imposed and collected in the manner prescribed by law and the ordinances of the city. In the event of a conviction of any licensee, in addition to said fine there shall be assessed against said licensee, reasonable attorney's fees and costs incurred by the city in prosecuting such violation, which shall be added as costs, which shall be imposed and collected in the manner prescribed by law and ordinances of the city. 
(Rev. Ords., § 15-21; Ord. No. 288, § 6, 2-11-74; Ord. No. 451, § 1, 1-16-84; Ord. No. 552, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Sec. 4-16. - Sale or delivery of alcoholic liquor in the Community Room. 
    The city does hereby authorize, pursuant to 235 ILCS 5/6-15, alcoholic liquor to be sold or delivered on the third floor of the city hall building, formerly known as the Elks Building, in connection with various uses of the community room by civic functions, both private and public, provided that the sponsors or users of said community room who desire to sell or dispense alcoholic liquor execute a hold harmless agreement, holding harmless the city from all financial loss, damage or harm and further provided that said sponsors or users provide dram shop liability insurance in the maximum limits so as to save harmless the city from all financial loss, damage or harm. 
(Ord. No. 553, § 1, 6-24-91) 
Sec. 4-17. - Bottle clubs. 
    Bottle clubs and set-up establishments are prohibited. For purposes of this section a set-up establishment means any public or private premises not holding a liquor license pursuant to this chapter which sells, gives away, serves, pours, stores, or otherwise dispenses and/or glasses mixed, ice, water, and soft drinks for the purpose of consumption of alcoholic liquors on the premises. 
(Ord. No. 631, 8-14-95) 
Sec. 4-18 - Municipal sale of alcoholic beverages. 
    The city is authorized to make package sales of beer and wine in the clubhouse at the Mt. Carmel Municipal Golf Course. Such sale shall be during the hours when said golf course is open. 
(Ord. No. 899, 7-2-07) 
Sec. 4-19. - Purchase of alcohol outside golf course. 
    Individuals playing golf and those accompanying those playing golf are prohibited from bringing alcoholic beverages not purchased at the golf course clubhouse into the clubhouse and/or onto the golf course. 
(Ord. No. 899, 7-2-07; Ord. No. 2009, 1-28-19) 
Sec. 4-20. - Penalty. 
    Any person or entity violating section 4-19 will be subject to the penalties setout in sections 1-10 and 1-11. 
(Ord. No. 899, 7-2-07) 
Secs. 4-21-4-26. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LIQUOR CONTROL COMMISSIONER[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Liquor commissioner, 235 ILCS 5/4-2 et seq. 

Sec. 4-27. - Mayor to be liquor control commissioner; enforcement responsibilities. 
    The mayor shall be the liquor control commissioner for the city and shall be charged with the administration within the city of the laws of the state as they relate to liquor licenses within the city, and with the provisions of this Code and other ordinances of the city related to liquor. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 15-1) 
Cross reference- General powers and duties of mayor, § 2-95. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 235 ILCS 5/4-2. 
Sec. 4-28. - Appointment of assistants. 
    The liquor control commissioner may appoint qualified persons to assist him in the exercise of the powers and performance of the duties imposed on him by law and the provisions of this Code or other ordinances of the city. 
(Rev. Ords. 1947, § 15-1) 
State Law reference- Compensation of liquor control commissioner and assistants, 235 ILCS 5/4-2. 
Sec. 4-29. - Compensation. 
    The city council may fix the compensation of the liquor control commissioner and for his assistants and deputies, as may be deemed necessary for the proper performance of the duties vested in him by law. 
State Law reference- Authority of liquor control commissioner to appoint assistants, 235 ILCS 5/4-3. 
Sec. 4-30. - Powers. 
    The liquor control commissioner shall have the following powers, functions and duties with respect to licenses, other than licenses of manufacturers, importing distributors, distributors, nonbeverage users, railroads, airplanes and boats: 
(1)  To grant and/or suspend or revoke for cause all local licenses issued to persons for premises within the city and in the event of a suspension, to suspend licenses for not more than seven days for the first offense, not more than 15 days for the second offense, and not more than 30 days for the third offense and each subsequent offense and to revoke licenses for cause. In lieu of a suspension, the commissioner may impose a fine of not more than $1,000.00 for each violation. The maximum fine that may be imposed upon any licensee from the period of the license shall not exceed $10,000.00. As used herein "cause" shall include, but shall not be limited to, any violation of city ordinances and state and federal laws and regulations. 
(2)  To enter or to authorize any law enforcing officer to enter at any time upon any premises licensed pursuant to this chapter to determine whether any of the provisions of this chapter or state law, or any rules or regulations adopted by him or by the state commission have been or are being violated, and at such time to examine said premises of the licensee in connection therewith. 
(3)  To receive complaints from any citizen within the city that any of the provisions of the state law or this chapter, or any rules or regulations adopted pursuant hereto have been or are being violated and to act upon such complaints in the manner prescribed in this chapter. 
(4)  To require every licensee to keep and maintain books and records pertaining to all business conducted at the licensed premises, and upon violation of any of the provisions of this Chapter 4, to require the licensee to make such books and records available upon reasonable notice for the purpose of investigation and control by the Liquor Control Commission, which books and records must be maintained in the State of Illinois. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., §§ 15-1, 15-2; Ord. No. 631, 8-14-95) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 235 ILCS 5/4-4. 
Sec. 4-31. - Authority to examine licensees and applicants for liquor licenses. 
    The liquor control commissioner shall have the right to examine, or cause to be examined, under oath, any applicant for a license required by this chapter, or for a renewal thereof, or any licensee upon whom notice of revocation or suspension has been served in the manner provided in this chapter, and to examine and cause to be examined, the books and records of any such applicant or licensee; to hear testimony and take proof for his information in the performance of his duties, and for such purpose to issue subpoenas which shall be effective in any part of the state. For the purpose of obtaining any of the information desired by the liquor control commissioner under this section, he may authorize his agent to act on his behalf. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 235 ILCS 5/4-5. 
Secs. 4-32-4-42. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LICENSES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of the city to license the retail sale of liquor, 235 ILCS 5/4-1; state liquor licenses, 235 ILCS 5/5-1. 

Sec. 4-43. - Required. 
    No person shall either sell at retail or have in his possession for sale, or offer for sale at retail, alcoholic liquor within the corporate limits of the city without first having obtained a license so to do as provided by this chapter. 
    No person shall manufacture alcoholic liquor or sell the same as a distributor in the city unless he shall be licensed so to do by the state. 
    A copy of the licensee's state liquor license must be provided within 60 days of making application to the city for a liquor license. 
    A separate license must be obtained for each premise at which an applicant or license holder offers to sell at retail or sells as retail, alcoholic liquor. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 15-3; Ord. No. 339, § 1, 1-10-77; Ord. No. 1052, 5-9-16) 
Cross reference- Licenses generally, ch. 14. 
Sec. 4-44. - Application. 
    Applications for such licenses shall be made to the city clerk in writing, signed by the applicant, if an individual, or by a duly authorized agent thereof if a club or corporation, verified by oath or affidavit, and shall further contain the following information and statements: 
(1)  The name, age and address of the applicant in the case of an individual; in the case of a copartnership, the persons entitled to share in the profits thereof, and in the case of a corporation for profit, or a club, the date of incorporation, the objects for which it was organized, the name and addresses of the officers and directors, and if a majority in interest of the stock of such corporation is owned by one person or his nominees, the name and address of such person; 
(2)  The citizenship of the applicant, his place of birth, and if a naturalized citizen, the time and place of his naturalization; 
(3)  The character of business of the applicant; and in case of a corporation, the objects for which it was formed; 
(4)  The length of time that the applicant has been in business of that character, or in the case of a corporation, the date on which its charter was issued; 
(5)  The location and description of the premises or place of business, together with all the entrances thereto, which is to be operated under such license; 
(6)  A statement whether the applicant has made similar application for a similar other license on premises other than described in this application, and the disposition of such application; 
(7)  A statement that the applicant has never been convicted of a felony and is not disqualified to receive a license by reason of any matter or thing contained in this chapter, laws of this state or the ordinances of this city; 
(8)  Whether a previous license by any state or subdivision thereof, or by the federal government has been revoked, and the reasons therefor; 
(9)  A statement that the applicant will not violate any of the laws of the State of Illinois or of the United States, or any ordinance of the city in the conduct of his place of business. 
(10)  Applicant shall submit evidence of dram shop liability insurance in the form of a certificate of insurance issued by an insurance company licensed to do business in the state. The certificate shall insure applicant and owner or lessor of the premises in an amount not less than $100,000.00. 
(11)  Whenever five percent or more of the stock ownership of a corporation holding a liquor license hereunder is transferred to a new individual, then such transfer shall be reported to the city, setting forth the name, address, telephone number and Social Security number of such new owner. Such report shall be filed with the city within 30 days after said transfer. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 15-4; Ord. No. 753, 3-5-01) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 235 ILCS 5/7-1. 
Sec. 4-45. - Bond. 
(a)  Each applicant for a license shall file with his petition a joint and several bond executed by the applicant with not less than two good and sufficient sureties residing in the state, or in lieu thereof a surety company licensed to do business in the state, to be approved by the liquor control commission in the penal sum of $1,000.00, conditioned for the faithful observance by the licensee of the laws of the state and of the United States relating to the sale of alcoholic liquors, and the provisions of this Code and other ordinances of the city relative to such sale. 
(b)  If a licensee shall be convicted of the violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, or of violating any law of this state or of the United States relating to the sale of intoxicating liquor, or if his license shall be revoked and no appeal is taken from said order of revocation, or if any appeal taken therefrom shall be decided adversely to the licensee, said bond may thereupon be declared forfeited by the liquor control commission, and the city shall be entitled to recover the penalty of such bond by appropriate action in any court having jurisdiction. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 15-4) 
Sec. 4-46. - Persons not to be licensed. 
    No such license shall be issued to: 
(1)  A person who does not reside in the city at the time of granting a license and in regard to a corporation, such corporation does not have its principal place of business or registered agent in the city, or does not have a manager, officer, shareholder, or director of such corporation residing in the city at the time of granting of a license. 
(2)  A person who is not of good character and reputation in the community in which he resides. 
(3)  A person who is not a citizen of the United States. 
(4)  A person who has been convicted of a felony under the laws of the state, or of any other state or of the United States. 
(5)  A person who has been convicted of being the keeper or is keeping a house of ill fame. 
(6)  A person who has been convicted of pandering or other crime or misdemeanor opposed to decency and morality. 
(7)  A person whose license issued under this chapter has been revoked for cause. 
(8)  A person who at the time of application for renewal of any license issued hereunder would not be eligible for such license upon a first application. 
(9)  A copartnership, unless all of the members of such copartnership shall be qualified to obtain a license. 
(10)  A corporation, if any officer, manager or director thereof or any stockholder or stockholders owning in the aggregate more than five percent of the stock of such corporation, would not be eligible to receive a license hereunder for any reason other than citizenship and residence within the political subdivision. 
(11)  A person whose place of business is conducted by a manager or agent unless the manager or agent possesses the same qualifications required of the licensee. 
(12)  A person who has been convicted of a violation of any federal or state law concerning the manufacture, possession or sale of alcoholic liquor, subsequent to the passage of this chapter, or shall have forfeited his bond to appear in court to answer charges for any such violation. 
(13)  A person who does not own the premises for which a license is sought, or does not have a lease thereon for the full period for which the license is to be issued. 
(14)  Any law enforcing public official, any mayor, alderman or member of the city council; and no such official shall be interested in any way, either directly or indirectly, in the manufacture, sale or distribution of alcoholic liquor. 
(15)  Any persons, association or corporation not eligible for a state retail liquor dealer's license. 
(16)  Reserved. 
(17)  No license shall be issued to any premises which sells or dispenses gasoline, diesel, petroleum fuels, or other fuels for motor vehicles as defined within the Illinois Vehicle Code. 
(18)  No license shall be issued to any person for the sale at retail of any alcoholic liquor at army store or other place of business where the majority of the customers are minors of school age or where the principal business transacted consists of school books, school supplies, food, lunches or drinks for such minors. 
(19)  When a license has been revoked for any cause, no license shall be granted to any person for a period of up to one year thereafter for the conduct of business for selling alcohol liquor at retail on the premises described in the revoked license. 
(Ord. No. 631, 8-14-96; Ord. No. 685, 10-20-97; Ord. No. 692, 2-23-98; Ord. No. 901, 8-27-07) 
State Law reference- Persons ineligible to receive state license, 235 ILCS 5/6-2. 
Sec. 4-47. - Classification. 
    Licenses issued under provisions of this chapter shall be of seven classes: 
(1)  A class A license shall entitle the licensee to make consumption sales at retail of alcoholic liquor of all kinds, either in the original packages or in broken packages or by the drink. However, such licensee shall make no package sales, as defined in this chapter, of any alcoholic liquor in any package or container, the content of which exceeds one liter; nor shall any such single package sale of any alcoholic liquor, other than beer, consist of more than one such package or container. A single such package sale of beer shall not exceed six containers, commonly known as a six-pack. 
(2)  A class B license shall entitle the licensee to make consumption sales at retail of beer and wine, or either, in either the original package or in broken packages or by the drink. However, such licensee shall make no package sale, as defined in this chapter, of any beer or wine in any package or container, the content of which exceeds one pint; nor shall any such single package sale of wine be in a quantity exceeding one such package. A single such package sale of beer shall not exceed six containers of the size herein prescribed. 
(3)  A class C license shall entitle the licensee to make package sales on the licensed premises of alcoholic liquor at retail, which are not for consumption on its licensed premises or on any premises connected therewith, but may, with proper video gaming license, be permitted to sell alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises. This license shall be issued only to businesses that operate primarily for the purpose of package sales with the majority of the revenue coming from package sales. 
(4)  A class D license shall be issued to a "club," as defined by state law, and shall entitle such club to make package sales and consumption sales of such liquor and to serve alcoholic liquor to its bona fide club members and their families and guests introduced by a member but not the public generally. 
(5)  A class E license shall entitle the licensee to sell consumption sales of alcoholic liquor, of all kinds, on a limited time basis at a special event. The time, place and condition of such sale shall be determined by the liquor control commissioner. A fee of $50.00 per day shall be charged for such special event license. 
(6)  A class M (municipal) license shall entitle the licensee to make package sales of beer and wine on the licensed premises at retail. 
(7)  A class F license shall entitle the licensee to make unrefrigerated package sales on the premises, of beer and wine, at retail, which are not for consumption on its licensed premises, or on any premises connected therewith. 
The holder of a class F license shall provide a secure segregated area for placement of beer and wine. Such segregated area shall not be accessible by anyone under the age of 21. There shall be only one gate or turnstile for ingress and egress in and out of such segregated area. There shall be prominent signage stating that anyone under the age of 21 is prohibited from entering such segregated area. There shall be no advertising or display of beer and wine outside the segregated area and no beer or wine advertising visible from the outside of the building. 
(8)  A class G license shall authorize the sale of alcoholic liquor only at retail on the premises specified for consumption on the premises only if such sale is secondary to and related to retail sale of prepared food within a restaurant. The licensee shall make no package sales. Upon application for a license, the applicant shall submit the following information for the most recently available three consecutive months: (a) ST-1 sales and use tax returns filed with the Illinois department of revenue, and (b) invoices from the applicant's food vendors. The amount of food purchases shall be 50 percent or more of the total purchases during any three-month period. Restaurants shall be subject to audit by the liquor control commission for the purpose of verifying compliance. A restaurant with a class G license may have a bar as defined in this chapter. 
(9)  A class H license shall authorize the sale of alcoholic liquor at retail on the premises specified for consumption on the premises only if such sale is secondary to the business of video gaming. This license shall be issued only to businesses that operate primarily for the purpose of video gaming with a majority of the revenue coming from video gaming receipts. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 15-3; Ord. No. 339, § 1, 1-10-77; Ord. No. 427, § 1, 1-18-82; Ord. No. 480, § 1, 12-16-86; Ord. No. 829, 8-30-04; Ord. No. 859, 1-30-06; Ord. No. 899, 7-2-07; Ord. No. 901, 8-27-07; Ord. No. 942, 9-21-09; Ord. No. 1050, 5-9-16; Ord. No. 1051, 5-9-16; Ord. No. 1052, 5-9-16; Ord. No. 1078, 7-3-17) 
State Law reference- Authority to classify licenses, set fees, 235 ILCS 5/3-4. 
Sec. 4-48. - Council to establish fees; determine number of licenses. 
    The city council shall from time to time by resolution, fix the amount of license fees to be paid for licenses of the various classes. The liquor control commission may issue no more than four class A licenses, no more than five class B licenses, no more than four class C licenses, no more than five class D licenses, no more than five class F licenses, no more than one class M license, no more than five class G licenses and no more than five class H licenses. 
(1947 Rev. Ords. § 15-3; Ord. No. 339, § 1, 1-10-77; Ord. No. 428, § 1, 1-18-82; Ord. No. 481, § 1, 12-16-86; Ord. No. 571, § 1, 6-8-92; Ord. No. 583, § 1, 1-18-93; Ord. No. 626, § 1, 5-2-95; Ord. No. 686, 10-20-97; Ord. No. 796, 8-18-03; Ord. No. 899, 7-2-07; Ord. No. 901, 8-27-07; Ord. No. 1055, 5-9-16) 
Sec. 4-49. - Duration; prorating fee. 
    Each license shall expire on the December 31 of the calendar year for which such license was issued. For all licenses issued on or after January 1 of any year, the license fee shall be reduced in proportion to the calendar months which have expired after January 15 prior to the issuance of the license. 
    License, if available, can be issued at any time during the year. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 15-3; Ord. No. 339, § 1, 1-10-77; Ord. No. 1052, 5-9-16) 
Sec. 4-50. - Scope of privilege granted by license. 
    A license shall be purely a personal privilege, good for the term thereof, unless sooner revoked as in this chapter provided, and shall not constitute property. Such license shall not descend by the laws of testate or intestate devolution, but it shall cease upon the death of the licensee, provided that executors or administrators of the estate of any deceased licensee, and the trustee of any insolvent or bankrupt licensee, when such estate consists in part of alcoholic liquor, may continue the business of the sale of alcoholic liquor under order of the appropriate court, and may exercise the privileges of the deceased or insolvent or bankrupt licensee after the death of such decedent, or such insolvency or bankruptcy until the expiration of such license. A license shall not be subject to attachment, garnishment or execution, nor shall it be alienable or transferable, voluntarily or involuntarily, or subject to being encumbered or hypothecated. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 15-4) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 43, § 119. 
Sec. 4-51. - Premises restricted as specified in license; posting of license. 
(a)  All licenses shall specify the location or premises where the privileges granted thereunder shall be exercised, and the right to exercise such privileges are hereby restricted to the premises described in such licenses. The location thereof may be changed with the consent of the liquor control commission. 
(b)  All licenses shall be posted in a conspicuous place on the licensed premises. In case a license is lost or destroyed, a duplicate thereof may be issued by the city clerk at the direction of the liquor control commission upon proof of such loss or destruction. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 15-4) 
Sec. 4-52. - Renewal of licenses. 
(a)  Written applications for renewal of licenses in the form prescribed by the council with bond as prescribed in section 4-45 shall be filed with the city clerk on or before the second Monday of December of the calendar year for which such licenses are issued. The clerk shall report all the names of all applicants for renewals of licenses to the liquor control commissioner at a meeting to be called by the mayor, as liquor control commissioner, within ten days after said second Monday in December, together with the location of the places of business of such applicants, and the amount of fees payable upon the renewal of such licenses, and whether or not any written complaint has been filed as to the manner in which the applicant for such renewal of a license has carried on the business authorized thereby, or protest against the renewal thereof setting forth the grounds of protest. Applicants for the renewal of an existing license who are qualified to receive a license, shall have preference over applicants for a new license. 
(b)  All applications for renewal of licenses shall be referred by the clerk to the liquor control commissioner as to rejection or approval, as in the case of applications for original licenses, and procedure upon such license shall be as in the case of applications for original licenses. 
(c)  An application for renewal of any license upon its expiration shall not be granted if written complaint has been filed with the city clerk or council as to the manner in which the applicant for such renewal has carried on the business authorized by such license, or if a protest as hereinbefore provided has been filed, until hearing has been had on such complaint by the liquor control commissioner for the approval or rejection of such application for renewal. If a complaint or protest, as in this chapter provided, is filed against the renewal of any license, the commissioner shall within ten days after the date when applications for renewal are required to be filed, conduct a hearing after reasonable notice to the applicant at which the complainant and the applicant, and such evidence as the commissioner may desire, may be heard and considered. The granting or rejection of a license after such hearing shall be determined by the commissioner and his decision shall be final. 
(d)  The renewal of any license may be denied by the commissioner with or without cause, or for the purpose of decreasing the number of any class licenses, theretofore granted by the city. 
(e)  An application for renewal must include evidence of a valid state liquor license for the premises. 
(f)  The renewal privilege herein provided for shall not be construed as a vested right which shall in any case prevent the city council from decreasing the number or kind of licenses to be issued within its jurisdiction. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 15-5; Ord. No. 1052, 5-9-16) 
Sec. 4-53. - Revocation; suspension. 
(a)  All licenses or renewals thereof granted pursuant to this article are revocable upon the terms and in the manner prescribed by the laws of the State of Illinois now or hereafter in force. 
(b)  The liquor control commissioner may, if it appears to be to the public interest, suspend any license issued hereunder during the pendency of proceedings properly instituted for the revocation of such license. No licensee shall operate under his license during any period for which license may have been suspended. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 15-20) 
State Law reference- Revocation or suspension by local authorities, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 43, § 149. 
Chapter 5 - ANIMALS AND FOWL 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 5-1. - Pets prohibited in federally subsidized facilities. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for occupants of federally assisted or subsidized facilities in the city to keep dogs, cats, rodents (including rabbits) or other common household animals or pets, or allow others to bring such animals into said facilities, except for any animal, such as a seeing eye dog, or animals of a similar nature for the assistance of handicapped individuals. 
(b)  Any person violating any provision of this section, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined $25.00. 
(Ord. No. 585, 3-29-93) 
Sec. 5-2. - Definitions. 
    "Owner" means any person having a right of property in a dog or other animal, or who keeps or harbors a dog or other animal, or who has it in his care, or acts as its custodian, or who knowingly permits a dog or other domestic animal to remain on or about any premises occupied by him. 
(Ord. No. 585, 3-29-93) 
Sec. 5-3. - Humane treatment of animals. 
    Every owner of any animal shall afford each animal humane treatment by providing therefor; 
(1)  Sufficient quantity of good quality, wholesome food and water. 
(2)  Adequate shelter and protection from the weather. 
(3)  Veterinary care when needed to prevent suffering. 
(Ord. No. 585, 3-29-93) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 510 ILCS 70/3. 
Sec. 5-4. - Cruel treatment. 
    No person, or owner, may beat, cruelly treat, torment, starve, overwork or otherwise abuse any animal. No owner may abandon any animal where it may become a public charge or may suffer injury, hunger or exposure. 
(Ord. No. 585, 3-29-93) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 510 ILCS 70/3.01. 
Secs. 5-5-5-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DOGS 

Secs. 5-16, 5-17. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 585, adopted March 29, 1993, repealed §§ 5-16 and 5-17 which pertained to license fee and tags and derived from 1947 Rev. Ords, §§ 13-1 and 13-2. 
Sec. 5-18. - Running at large prohibited. 
    The running at large of dogs on the streets and in the alleys, in parks, public places or public or private unenclosed places in the city is hereby prohibited. A dog shall be deemed running at large if present or found on any street or alley or in any park, public place or public or private unenclosed places within the city without being securely held or fastened with a leash or otherwise confined. An electronic containment system commonly known as "invisible fence" may be used as a restraint system for animals in the absence of a visible primary enclosure. This system is permitted if all maintenance requirements to keep the "invisible fence" in good working condition are met. 
(1947 Rev. Ords; Ord. No. 463, § 1, 10-21-85; Ord. No. 585, 3-29-93; Ord. No. 1006, 4-14-14) 
Sec. 5-19. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 585, adopted March 29, 1993, repealed § 5-19, which pertained to unlicensed dogs at large and derived from 1947 Rev. Ords., § 13-3. 
Sec. 5-20. - Impoundment of licensed dogs at large. 
    Licensed dogs running at large may be taken up and impounded as hereinafter provided. 
(1947 Rev. Ords; § 13-3; Ord. No. 585, 3-29-93) 
Sec. 5-21. - Permitting dog to run at large. 
    Any person who shall permit or act negligently so as to allow a dog owned by him or a dog in his custody to run at large in the corporate limits of the city shall be deemed guilty of an offense and, upon conviction, shall be subject to the penalties prescribed in section 1-10. At the option of the city attorney, as prescribed in section 1-11, such offense may be prosecuted as a misdemeanor by the filing of an appropriate pleading or by amendment of any prior pleadings. 
(Ord. No. 255, § 1, 10-26-70; Ord. No. 374, § 1, 5-5-78; Ord. No. 463, § 2, 10-21-85; Ord. No. 585, 3-29-93) 
Sec. 5-22. - Authority to take up stray dogs. 
    Any person upon whose premises any dogs is found trespassing may take such dog into custody and turn such dog over to the proper city authority to be dealt with as a stray dog under the provisions of this chapter. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 13-4; Ord. No. 585, 3-29-93) 
Sec. 5-23. - Procedure when danger of rabies exists. 
    Whenever any public health authority, whether state or local, shall determine or declare that rabies exists in the community, or that there is grave danger of rabies, the mayor may by proclamation require that all dogs while in public places shall be securely muzzled during the prescribed period. Any dog not so muzzled shall be deemed a public nuisance and may be taken up by the city and destroyed or otherwise disposed of. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 13-5; Ord. No. 585, 3-29-93) 
Secs. 5-24, 5-25. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 585, adopted March 29, 1993, repealed §§ 5-24 and 5-25, which pertained to impoundment procedure and confinement and treatment of impounded animals and derived from 1947 Rev. Ords., §§ 13-6 and 13-7. 
Sec. 5-26. - Interference with officer enforcing chapter. 
    Any person who shall interfere with, hinder, delay or obstruct any officer or employee of the city in enforcing or endeavoring to enforce the provisions of this chapter, or any of them, shall be deemed guilty of an offense and subject to the penalties prescribed in section 1-11. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 13-10; Ord. No. 585, 3-29-93) 
Sec. 5-27. - Inoculation against rabies required; rabies inoculation tags. 
(a)  Every owner of a dog four months or more of age shall cause such dog to be inoculated against rabies by a licensed veterinarian at such times as required by law. 
(b)  Each dog so inoculated for rabies shall have firmly attached upon a suitable collar, or other device secured to the body of the dog, an inoculation tag issued pursuant to law. 
(Ord. No. 585, 3-29-93) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 510 ILCS 5/8. 
Sec. 5-28. - Impoundment of dogs running at large. 
    Any dog found running at large contrary to provisions of this chapter shall be apprehended and impounded. 
(Ord. No. 585, 3-29-93) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 510 ILCS 5/9. 
Sec. 5-29. - Notice of impoundment; service of notice; redemption of impounded; conditions. 
(a)  When dogs are apprehended and impounded by the animal control warden, he shall give notice of not less than seven days to the owner, if known. Such notice shall be mailed to the last known address of the owner. An affidavit or testimony of the Animal Warden Control, or otherwise authorized authority, who mails such notice, shall be prima facie evidence of the receipt of such notice by the owner of such dog. 
(b)  In the event the owner of any impounded dog desires to make redemption thereof, he or she may do so on the following conditions: 
(1)  Present proof of current rabies inoculation, and registration, if applicable; or 
(2)  Pay for the rabies inoculation of the dog, and registration, if applicable; and 
(3)  Pay for the board of the dog for the period it was impounded; and 
(4)  Pay into the animal control fund an additional impoundment fee as prescribed by the county commissioners as a penalty for the first offense and for each subsequent offense. 
(c)  This shall be in addition to any other penalties invoked under this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 585, 3-29-93) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 510 ILCS 5/10. 
Sec. 5-30. - Dogs not redeemed; humane dispatch; release without spaying or neutering prohibited; adoption. 
(a)  When not redeemed by the owner, a dog which has been impounded for failure to be inoculated and registered, if applicable, in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, shall be humanely dispatched, offered for adoption, or otherwise disposed of as a stray dog in accordance with the laws that exist or may hereafter exist. 
(b)  A dog not redeemed by the owner shall not be released from the pound unless it has been surgically rendered incapable of reproducing by spaying or neutering. 
(c)  A person wishing to adopt any dog prior to the surgical procedures having been performed shall execute a written agreement promising to have such service performed within a specified period of time. Failure to fulfill the terms of the agreement shall result in seizure and impoundment of the dog by the animal control warden, and any monies which have been deposited shall be forfeited. 
(Ord. No. 585, 3-29-93) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 510 ILCS 5/11. 
Sec. 5-31. - Vicious and dangerous dogs. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or maintain any dog which has been found to be a vicious dog, as defined by law, unless such dog is at all times kept in an appropriate enclosure. The only times that a vicious dog may be allowed out of the enclosure are 
(1)  If it necessary for the owner or keeper of the dog to obtain veterinary care for the dog or 
(2)  To comply with the order of a court of competent jurisdiction, 
provided that the dog is securely muzzled and restrained with a chain having a tensile strength of 300 pounds and not exceeding three feet in length, and shall be under the direct control and supervision of the owner or keeper of the dog. 
(b)  Any dog which has been found to be a vicious dog, as defined by law, and which has not been confined to a suitable enclosure shall be impounded by the animal control warden, or other law enforcement officer having jurisdiction in the area. The owner of such dog shall be given proper notice and should such owner fail to appeal such impoundment to the circuit court within seven days, the dog may be humanely dispatched by such dog being turned over to a licensed veterinarian for destruction by lethal injection. 
(c)  No owner or keeper of a vicious dog shall sell or give away the dog. 
(d)  It is unlawful for any person to maintain a public nuisance by permitting any dangerous dog, as defined by law, to leave the premises of its owner when not under control by leash or other recognized control methods. 
(e)  No dog shall be deemed "vicious" if it bites, attacks, or menaces a trespasser on the property of its owner or harms or menaces anyone who has tormented or abused it or is a professionally trained dog for law enforcement or guard duties. Vicious dogs shall not be classified in a manner that is specific as to breed. 
(Ord. No. 585, 3-29-93) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 510 ILCS 5/15. 
Sec. 5-32. - Barking dogs. 
    No person or persons shall keep or maintain any dog or dogs within the city, which disturbs the peace and quiet of any neighborhood or person by frequent and long continued barking and/or howling. 
(Ord. No. 585, 3-29-93) 
Sec. 5-33. - Penalties. 
    Violations of any provision of this chapter, unless otherwise provided, are punishable by fine as prescribed in section 1-10. 
(Ord. No. 585, 3-29-93) 
Secs. 5-34, 5-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CATS 

Sec. 5-36. - Running at large prohibited. 
    The running at large of cats on the streets and in the alleys, in parks, public places or public or private enclosed places in the city is hereby prohibited. A cat shall be deemed "running at large" if present or found on any street or alley or in any public park, public place or public or private enclosed places in the city without being accompanied by some person having charge of such cat. 
(Ord. No. 846, 7-18-05) 
Sec. 5-37. - Reserved. 
Sec. 5-38. - Impoundment of cats running at large. 
    Cats running at large may be taken up and impounded, as hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. No. 846, 7-18-05) 
Sec. 5-39. - Permitting cats to run at large. 
    Any person who shall permit or act negligently so as to allow a cat owned by him, or a cat in his custody, to run at large in the corporate limits of the city shall be deemed guilt of an offense and upon conviction shall be subject to the penalties prescribed herein. At the option of the city attorney, as prescribed herein, such offenses may be prosecuted as a misdemeanor by the filing of an appropriate pleading or by amendment of any prior pleading. 
(Ord. No. 846, 7-18-05) 
Sec. 5-40. - Authority to pick-up stray cats. 
    Any person, upon whose premises any cat is found trespassing, may take such cat into custody and turn such cat over to the proper authorities to be dealt with as a stray cat under the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 846, 7-18-05) 
Sec. 5-41. - Interference with officer enforcing chapter. 
    Any person who shall interfere with, hinder, delay or obstruct the animal control warden or any officer or employee of the city in enforcing or endeavoring to enforce the provisions of this chapter, or any of them, shall be deemed guilty of an offense and subject to penalties prescribed herein. 
(Ord. No. 846, 7-18-05) 
Sec. 5-42. - Inoculation against rabies required; rabies inoculation tag. 
(a)  Every owner of a cat, four months or more of age, shall cause such cat to be inoculated against rabies by a licensed veterinarian. 
(b)  Each cat so inoculated for rabies shall have, firmly attached upon a suitable collar or other device secured to the body of the cat, an inoculation tag. 
(Ord. No. 846, 7-18-05) 
Sec. 5-43. - Impoundment of cats running at large. 
    Any cat running at large, contrary to the provisions of this chapter, shall be apprehended and impounded. 
(Ord. No. 846, 7-18-05) 
Sec. 5-44. - Notice of impoundment; service of notice; redemption of impounded; conditions. 
(a)  When cats are apprehended and impounded by the animal control warden, he shall give notice of not less than seven days to the owner, if known. Such notice shall be mailed to the last know address of the owner. An affidavit or testimony of the animal control warden or other authorized authority who mails such notice shall be prima facie evidence of the receipt of such notice by the owner of such cat. 
(b)  In the event the owner of any impounded cat desires to make redemption thereof, he or she may do so on the following conditions: 
(1)  Present proof of current rabies inoculation; 
(2)  Pay for a rabies inoculation of the cat; 
(3)  Pay for the board of the cat for the period it was impounded; and 
(4)  Pay unto the animal control fund an additional impoundment fee as prescribed by the county commissioners, as a penalty for the first offense and for each subsequent offense. 
(c)  This shall be in addition to any other penalty invoked under this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 846, 7-18-05) 
Sec. 5-45. - Cats not redeemed; humane dispatch; release without spay or neutralizing, prohibited; adoption. 
(a)  When not redeemed by the owner, a cat which has been impounded, in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, shall be humanely dispatched, offered for adoption, or otherwise disposed of as a stray cat in accordance with laws that exist or may hereinafter exist. 
(b)  A cat not redeemed shall not be released from the pound unless it has been surgically rendered incapable of reproducing by spaying or neutralizing. 
(c)  A person wishing to adopt any cat, prior to the surgical procedures having been performed, shall execute a written agreement promising to have such service performed within a specific period of time. Failure to fulfill the terms of the agreement shall result in the seizure and impoundment of the cat by the animal control warden, and any monies, which may have been deposited, shall be forfeited. 
(Ord. No. 846, 7-18-05) 
Sec. 5-46. - Penalties. 
    Violations of any provisions of this chapter are punishable by fine, as prescribed in section 1-10; being not less than $25.00, nor more than $750.00. Each day a willful violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. In addition, the city may collect all court costs and attorneys' fees. 
(Ord. No. 846, 7-18-05) 
Chapter 6 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1]
