ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 6-1. - Fire limits established. 
    There is hereby established an area to be known as the fire limits in the city covering the following described area: 
    Beginning at a point on the north line of Second Street, in the City of Mount Carmel, Illinois, which is 200 feet easterly from the east line of Market Street, thence northerly on a line parallel with the east line of Market Street to the south right-of-way line of the Cleveland, Cincinnati, Chicago and St. Louis Railway Company; thence southwesterly along the southerly line of the said railway right-of-way, to a point that is 200 feet westerly from the westerly line of Market Street, measured at right angles to Market Street; thence southerly on a line parallel with the westerly line of Market Street to the north line of Second Street; thence easterly on the north line of Second Street to the place of beginning. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 11-1) 
Cross reference- Fire protection and prevention, ch. 9. 
Sec. 6-2. - All fees payable to city clerk. 
    The payment of all permit fees, occupancy fees, and inspection fees required by this chapter shall be made to the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 8-1, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 6-3. - Forms. 
    All application forms, notice forms, inspection forms, placards, certificates, permits and other forms required by this chapter shall be uniform and shall be supplied by the city clerk, in the form and manner prescribed and approved by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 8-2, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 6-4. - Appeal from action by city inspector. 
    Whenever the city inspector shall disapprove any application or refuse to grant any permit or certificate provided for in this chapter, or shall revoke same, or when it is claimed that the provisions of this chapter do not apply or that the true intent and meaning of this chapter has been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the applicant may appeal from the decision of the city inspector within 30 days from the date of the decision appealed. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 8-3, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 6-5. - Penalty. 
(a)  Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter or any of the regulations of any of the codes hereby adopted or fail to comply therewith or who shall violate or fail to comply with any order made thereunder or who shall act in violation of any detailed statement of specifications or plans submitted and approved thereunder, or any certificate or permit issued thereunder, and from which no appeal has been taken, or who shall fail to comply with such an order as affirmed or modified by the board of appeals or by a court of competent jurisdiction, within the time fixed herein, shall severally for each and every such violation and noncompliance respectively be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not less than $25.00 nor more than $200.00. The imposition of one penalty for a violation shall not excuse the violation or permit it to continue. All such persons shall be required to correct or remedy such violations or defects within a reasonable time. When not otherwise specified each ten days that prohibited conditions are maintained shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  Application of the above penalties shall not be held to prevent the enforced removal of prohibited conditions. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 8-4, 8-22-67) 
Secs. 6-6-6-16. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BUILDINGS 

Sec. 6-17. - Building code, residential code adopted. 
(a)  That a certain document is on file in the office of the city clerk of the city, being marked and designated as the International Building Code (2006 edition), including appendix chapters, as published by the International Code Council, Inc., be and is hereby adopted as the building code of the city; for the control of building and structures as herein provided; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, conditions and terms of said building code are hereby referred to, adopted and made a part hereof as if fully set out in this section. 
(b)  That a certain document is on file in the office of the city clerk of the city, being marked and designated as International Residential Code (2006 edition), including Appendix Chapters, as published by the International Code Council, be and is hereby adopted as the code of the city for regulating the design, construction, quality of materials, erection, installation, alteration, repair, location, relocation, replacement, addition to, use or maintenance of one- and two-family dwellings and townhouses not more than three stories in height in the city, and providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees therefore; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, conditions and terms of such International Residential Code, 2006 edition, published by the International Code Council on file in the office of the city clerk are hereby referred to, adopted and made a part hereof as if fully set out in this section. 
(Ord. No. 777, § 1, 6-24-02; Ord. No. 778, § 1, 6-24-02; Ord. No. 871, 5-22-06) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 777, § 1, adopted June 24, 2002, has been treated by the editor as repealing former § 6-17, and adding a new § 6-17(a) to read as herein set out. Former § 6-17 pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 170, adopted August 22, 1967; and Ord. No. 491, adopted August 10, 1987. 
State Law reference- Adoption of technical codes by reference, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 1-3-1 et seq. 
Sec. 6-18. - Definitions. 
(a)  Whenever the word "municipality" is used in the building code adopted by this article, it shall be held to mean the City of Mount Carmel, Illinois. 
(b)  Whenever the term "corporation counsel" is used in said building code, it shall be held to mean the city attorney. 
(c)  Whenever the term "building official" is used in said building code, it shall be held to mean the city inspector or any other officer of the city designated by the city council having the duty to enforce regulations relative to zoning, building, housing and fire prevention. 
(d)  Whenever the term "building" is used herein, it shall mean any structure used or intended for supporting or sheltering any use or occupancy. 
(e)  Whenever the term "swimming pool" is used herein, it shall mean any structure intended for swimming or recreational bathing that contains water over 24 inches (610 mm) deep. This includes in-ground, above-ground and on-ground swimming pools, hot tubs and spas. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 3-5, 8-22-67; Ord. No. 904, 10-22-07) 
Sec. 6-19. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 777, § 1, adopted June 24, 2002, has been treated by the editor as repealing former § 6-19. Ord. No. 777 adopted a new building code for the city. Former § 6-19 pertained to amendments to the previous building code, and derived from Ord. No. 170, adopted August 22, 1967; and Ord. No. 491, adopted August 10, 1987. 
Sec. 6-20. - Precedence where building code provisions conflict with other code provisions. 
    Any provisions of the building code adopted by this article which are inconsistent or in conflict with any other provisions of this Code shall yield to and be superseded by such other provisions. 
Sec. 6-21. - Building code not to apply to certain construction, maintenance or alteration. 
    Notwithstanding any provision in the building code adopted by this article to the contrary, such building code shall not apply to the construction of or to any ordinary maintenance or alteration of a dwelling occupied by the owner thereof and of a value not in excess of $1,000.00. 
Sec. 6-22. - City inspector to enforce article. 
    The city inspector shall have the power and duty to enforce the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 3-6, 8-22-67) 
Cross reference- City inspector, § 2-142 et seq. 
Sec. 6-23. - Right of entry of city inspector. 
    The city inspector, in the discharge of his official duties and upon proper identification, shall have authority to enter any building, structure or premises at any reasonable hour. 
Sec. 6-24. - Stop order. 
(a)  Whenever any work is being done in violation of the provisions of this article or in variance with the terms of any permit for such work, the city inspector may order all work on the job stopped until such violation or variance is eliminated and any work or installation made in violation of this ordinance corrected. Such stop order, if oral, shall be followed by a written stop order within 24 hours excluding Saturday, Sunday or holidays. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to do or perform any work in violation of such stop order, except as may be necessary to prevent injury or damage to persons or property, 
(c)  Such stop order may be revoked by the city inspector, the mayor or the city council. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 3-7, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 6-25. - Certificate of occupancy. 
    No certificate of occupancy for any building or structure erected, altered or repaired shall be issued by the city inspector unless such building or structure was erected, altered or repaired in compliance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 3-8, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 6-26. - Standards. 
    All work on the construction, alteration and repair of buildings and other structures shall be performed in a good workmanlike manner, according to the accepted standards and practices in the trade. The provisions in the BOCA Basic National Building Code adopted by this article shall be considered standard and acceptable practice for all matters not specifically covered in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 3-9, 8-22-67; Ord. No. 491, § 3, 8-10-87) 
Sec. 6-27. - Permit-Required. 
    It shall be unlawful to construct any building or structure other than a fence in the city where the cost of such construction exceeds $100.00, or alter or remodel any building or structure so as to change the bearing walls, beams, supports or the roof thereof or construct or install any swimming pool, hot tub or spa, as herein defined, without first having secured a permit for such construction or alteration or installation or in violation of the terms of such permit or in violation of the terms of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 3-1, 8-22-67; Ord. No. 904, 10-22-07) 
Sec. 6-28. - Same-Application. 
    No permit shall be issued for the construction of any building or structure or swimming pool or for the remodeling or repairing affecting bearing walls, roofs, other than resurfacing of chimneys, or for moving a building onto a premises in the city unless an application is filed therefore and said application is accompanied by: 
(1)  A plat or sketch of the proposed location showing lot boundaries, and, 
(2)  Plans and specification showing the work to be done. 
(3)  Plans and specifications submitted for the construction, alteration or addition to any multi-family dwelling, commercial or industrial building or building used for assembly or public purposes must have affixed thereon a seal issued to a State of Illinois licensed structural engineer or architect under the provisions of the state department of professional regulation. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 3-2, 8-22-67; Ord. No. 904, 10-22-07) 
Sec. 6-29. - Fees and costs. 
(a)  No permit or certificate required by this division shall be issued until the fee prescribed herein shall have been paid to the city clerk, nor shall an amendment to a permit be approved until the additional fee, if any, due to an increase in the dimensions of the structure resulting in an increase of the total square footage of the project, shall have been paid. 
(b)  For a permit for the construction, addition or alteration to a building or structure, or for the placement of a manufactured housing unit as defined in appendix A, art. II, subsection 2-1.B.46., the fee shall be at the rate of $2.00 per each $1,000.00 of the calculated value of the proposed construction, addition, or alteration rounded to the nearest dollar amount, except the minimum amount of any permit shall not be less than $25.00 and an accessory or utility building of less than 121 square feet shall not require a building permit nor be assessed a permit fee nor shall an uncovered deck or porch. 
(c)  For a permit for the removal of a building or structure from one lot to another, the fee shall be $20.00. 
(d)  For a permit for the removal of a building or structure to a new location within the same lot, the fee shall be $20.00. 
(e)  Reserved. 
(f)  In case of abandonment or discontinuance, the cost of work performed under a permit may be estimated and adjustment of the fee made and the portion of the fee for uncompleted work returned to the permit holder, provided that no refund of a prescribed minimum fee shall be made. If such discontinuance is due to revocation of permit, a similar adjustment and return may be made, provided that no refund shall be made until all penalties incurred or imposed by due authority have been collected. After such a refund has been made, no work shall be resumed until a new application has been made and a new permit has been issued. 
(g)  The term "calculated value" as used in this section shall be determined by the following: 
Type area × square foot cost = calculated value (CV) 
Type area and square foot cost are determined as follows: 
Type Area Square Foot Cost Habitable, living area $87.00 per s.f. Basement, finished  30.00 per s.f. Basement, unfinished  15.00 per s.f. Garage, attached  35.00 per s.f. Garage, unattached  25.00 per s.f. Accessory building  18.00per s.f. Porch/deck w/roof  18.00 per s.f. Alteration or remodel  18.00 per s.f. Industrial construction/commercial Warehouse/storage area  10.00 per s.f. Office area (within)  25.00 per s.f. Sales/service area  20.00 per s.f. Manufacturing area  15.00 per s.f.  
(h)  For a permit to construct or install a swimming pool, hot tub or spa, the fees shall be as follows: 
(1)  In-ground swimming pool ..... $10.00 
(2)  Above-ground swimming pool ..... 5.00 
(3)  Hot tub or spa ..... 5.00 
(Ord. No. 170, § 3-10, 8-22-67; Ord. No. 729, 2-21-00; Ord. No. 904, 10-22-07; Ord. No. 909, 3-10-08; Ord. No. 930, 1-12-09; Ord. No. 951, 5-3-10) 
Sec. 6-30. - Demolitions. 
(a)  No permit shall be issued for the demolition of any structure, or any building in excess of 180 square feet, unless a complete application, as prescribed in section 6-3 of this chapter, is filed therefore and said application is accompanied by: 
(1)  A surety bond in the amount of S5,000.00 or a cash bond in the amount of $500.00 to be held by the city clerk until such time as the site has been inspected by the city inspector and a certificate of completion is issued by said city inspector after which time the bond shall be released by the city clerk; and 
(2)  Evidence that arrangements have been made to properly collect and dispose of demolition material on a scheduled basis as prescribed herein; and 
(3)  A permit fee of $100.00; and 
(4)  Should the demolition project involve a commercial, industrial or public building, the applicant shall comply with existing federal and state requirements pertaining to the inspection, collection and disposal of asbestos and to the filing of any required notices, records or reports. 
(b)  Any such permit issued shall be for a period not exceeding 60 days after which time the permit shall be null and void and a new permit for the proposed demolition shall be required. However, any such permit issued may be extended for an additional 30-day period by the city inspector for just cause without additional cost. 
(c)  Any waste materials or rubbish derived from the demolition project, whether requiring a permit or not, shall be collected and placed in a proper container, truck, trailer or other approved receptacle within 24 hours and shall be removed from the site and taken to an approved landfill, or other approved location, when such container is loaded to capacity or the demolition project is completed. 
(d)  Prior to issuance of a certificate of completion, the city inspector shall determine that the demolition site has been substantially leveled, that proper fill material has been deposited on the site to fill any basements, excavations or severe depressions, that all tools and equipment, scaffolding and surplus materials have been removed and that the site is free of waste material or rubbish. 
(e)  In the event of abandonment or discontinuance, or at such time as the permit has expired, the city may, following written notice to the permittee, forfeit the posted bond in accordance with existing law, and use the funds therefrom for completion of the demolition and any associated waste or rubbish removal. 
(f)  The penalty for the violation of any of the above conditions shall be punishable under the provision of section 6-5 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 909, 3-10-08; Ord. No. 951, 5-3-10) 
Secs. 6-31-6-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ELECTRICITY[2] 

Footnotes:

Sec. 6-41. - National Electrical Code adopted. 
    That a certain document is on file in the office of the city clerk of the city, being marked and designated as NEC Electrical Code TM (2005 edition), as published by the National Fire Protection Association, be and is hereby adopted as the code of the city for regulating the design, construction, quality of materials, erection, installation, alteration, repair, location, relocation, replacement, addition to, use or maintenance of electrical systems in the city and providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees therefore; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, conditions and terms of such NEC Electrical Code (tm) 2006 edition, published by the National Fire Protection Association, on file in the office of the city clerk are hereby referred to, adopted and made a part hereof as if fully set out in this section. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 4-1, 8-22-67; Ord. No. 779, § 1, 6-24-02; Ord. No. 871, 5-22-06) 
Sec. 6-42. - City inspector to enforce electrical code. 
    The electrical code shall be enforced by the city inspector. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 4-2, 8-22-67) 
Cross reference- City inspector, § 2-152 et seq. 
Sec. 6-43. - Precedence where electrical code provisions conflict with other code provisions. 
    Any provisions of the electrical code adopted by this article which are inconsistent or in conflict with other provisions of this Code shall yield to and be superseded by such other provisions. 
Sec. 6-44. - Electrical code not to apply to certain maintenance or alteration. 
    Notwithstanding any provision in the electrical code adopted by this article to the contrary, such electrical code shall not apply to any ordinary maintenance or to any alteration of a dwelling occupied by the owner thereof and of a value not in excess of $1,000.00. 
Sec. 6-45. - Permit-Required. 
    It shall be unlawful to install, alter or change electrical equipment in the city without having first secured a permit therefor. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 4-3, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 6-46. - Same-Application. 
(a)  Application for a permit to install, alter or change electrical equipment in the city shall be filed with the city inspector on printed forms furnished by the city clerk. 
(b)  The application shall be accompanied by plans and specifications for the proposed work and shall include the following: 
(1)  The name of the owner or lessee of the premises on which the work is to be done. 
(2)  The location of such premises by correct street address or other information by which the premises may be readily located. 
(3)  The purpose or purposes for which the permit is to be issued. 
(4)  Such other information as may be required by the city inspector. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 4-5, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 6-47. - Same-Issuance. 
    Upon approval by the city inspector of an application for a permit under provisions of this article, and upon payment by the applicant of such application fee as shall from time to time be ordained or otherwise established by the city council, the inspector shall issue the permit for which application was made. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 4-5, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 6-48. - Display of permit. 
    All permits issued under provisions of this article shall be posted in plain view on the premises for which the permit was issued. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 4-5(b), 8-22-67) 
Sec. 6-49. - Inspection fees. 
    The following are hereby adopted as reasonable fees to be paid for the inspection by the city inspector of all electrical equipment installed or altered within the city: 
(1)  For initial installation of electrical service: 
(a)  Single-family residence or bungalows, $20.00. 
(b)  Multi-family or apartments: 
First apartment, $20.00. 
Each additional apartment, $10.00. 
(c)  Commercial or industrial: 
Per $1,000.00 of electric contract cost, $5.00. 
(d)  Electrical neon signs, $5.00. 
(e)  Whenever extra inspections are made on account of inaccurate or incorrect information, failure to make necessary reports or faulty construction, a charge of $5.00 per hour shall be made for time consumed for making extra inspections. 
Permit fees and inspection fees shall be paid in advance to the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 4-6, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 6-50. - Scope of inspection authority. 
(a)  The provisions for inspections of work authorized by permits by the city shall not be construed as prohibiting the inspection of any electrical wiring nor apparatus now or whenever installed, whenever the city inspector shall determine that public safety requires. No inspection fee shall be charged for this inspection but in case it is determined necessary to replace any wrong or defective wiring or apparatus upon such inspection, a permit in like manner as the original shall be obtained. 
(b)  Whenever the city inspector shall find any electrical wires or apparatus not conforming to requirements set forth in this article, the inspector is hereby empowered to stop work on any installation being made by any person, firm or corporation to whom or which a license or permit has not been granted or who or which has not paid the required fees or who or which does not otherwise comply to the terms of this article. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 4-7, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 6-51. - Structures on utility easements prohibited. 
    No structure of any kind or nature, including but not limited to buildings and outbuildings, shall be placed upon any utility easement in the city shown or recorded in the public records of Wabash County, Illinois. Such prohibition shall not apply to fences. However, where a fence is located upon a utility easement, there shall be a gate or sufficient opening to allow access to such utility easement. 
    Violation of this section shall cause the landowner of the land upon which such utility easement is located to be subject to a fine of not less than $25.00 nor more than $100.00 for each day of violation of this section. 
    In addition to other penalties prescribed herein, the city may abate such structure or encroachment upon such utility easement by obtaining an order of the circuit court of the second judicial circuit, Wabash County, Illinois, for the removal of such encroachment or structure. The costs incurred by the city, including court costs, attorney's fees and costs of removal, shall be paid by the landowner of the real estate upon which such structure and utility easement are located, and shall become a lien upon such real estate. 
    Any structure currently in violation of this section may be continued, even though a structure may be located upon a utility easement. However, once such structure is moved or removed from upon such easement, there shall be no further encroachments and this section shall apply to any such future placement or encroachment upon a utility easement. 
(Ord. No. 773, 2-19-02) 
Secs. 6-52-6-61. - Reserved.

ARTICLE VIII. - BUILDING CONTRACTORS 

Sec. 6-112. - Registration of building contractor. 
(a)  Definitions; registration required . It shall be unlawful to engage in business in the city as a building contractor without first having registered with the city clerk as hereinafter provided. 
    Building contractor shall mean and include anyone engaged in the business of cement or concrete contracting, either flat, form or wall work, or as a masonry contractor; or as a carpenter contractor; or as a general building contractor; and any person engaged in the construction, alteration, enlargement, repair, demolition, removal, or conversion of buildings or other structures for profit, including, but not limited to, electricians, roofers, plumbers, siding and window installers, heating and air conditioning contractors, dry wallers, painters, and insulators. 
(b)  Subcontractors . Any person doing business as a subcontractor shall be construed as engaged in the business of building contractor for which registration is required by this article. 
(c)  Regulations . It shall be the duty of all building contractors to comply with all ordinances relating to the construction of buildings or other structures, to the construction of streets or sidewalk pavements, and all laws or ordinances pertaining to or regulating the activities engaged in. 
(d)  Registration requirements and fee . Every building contractor shall cause his name, residence and place of business to be registered with the city clerk. A fee of $25.00 shall be paid annually to the city for such registration. 
(e)  Insurance. No person shall be registered with the city clerk as a building contractor unless a certificate or other proof is filed showing that the contractor carries workers' compensation insurance and public liability insurance with the limits of at least $50,000.00 for each person and $100,000.00 for each accident on bodily injury liability and $25,000.00 on property damage liability. If an applicant is a sole proprietorship or partnership and the applicant has no employees, the applicant may not be required to provide proof of worker's compensation insurance or Illinois Unemployment Insurance. 
(f)  Penalties . Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be fined not less than $75.00 nor more than $750.00 for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. 967, 7-25-11) 
ARTICLE IX. - FENCE PERMIT 

Sec. 6-113. - Permit required; application. 
(a)  A fence may not be constructed within the city limits without first having obtained a permit from the city. 
(b)  Anyone desiring to construct a fence within the city shall make an application to the city inspector and such application shall include but not limited to the following requirements: 
(1)  Shall attest that no part of the fence will encroach upon any portion of the adjoining property and is completely located upon the applicant's property. 
(2)  Shall provide a picture of material used to construct the fence. 
(3)  Shall provide an easement sign-off form from the Mt. Carmel Public Utility. 
(4)  Shall provide that no fence shall be constructed in the front yard passed the livable area of the house that will be more than four feet in height. 
(5)  Shall provide detailed drawings of the proposed fence including property lines and distance from property lines. 
(c)  No fence shall be constructed in excess of six feet in height. 
(d)  A fee of $25.00 shall be charged for such fence permit. 
(Ord. No. 1001, 11-12-13) 
Chapter 61/2 - CABLE COMMUNICATIONS ENABLING ORDINANCE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 599, adopted November 8, 1993, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, inclusion herein as ch. 61/2 was at the discretion of the editor. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 61/2-1. - Title. 
    This chapter shall be known as the City of Mount Carmel Cable Communications Enabling Ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 1, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-2. - Short title. 
    This chapter may be cited as the Mount Carmel Cable Ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 1, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-3. - Purposes. 
    The purposes of this chapter are: 
(1)  To establish franchise procedures and standards which encourage the growth and development of cable systems within the city and which assure that cable systems are responsive to the needs and interests of the local community; 
(2)  To establish a local policy concerning cable communications; 
(3)  To establish local authority with respect to the regulation of cable systems; 
(4)  To provide for the development of cable television as a means of communication for and between the citizens and the public institutions of the city; 
(5)  To provide for the payment of fees and other valuable consideration to the city for the use of the city streets and other public ways in the construction and operation of a cable communications system, and to compensate the city for costs both directly related and incidental to the awarding of the cable television franchise; 
(6)  To provide for remedies and to prescribe penalties for violations of this chapter and for any and all franchise agreements granted hereunder; 
(7)  To provide for consumer protection in regard to the construction and operation of a cable system; 
(8)  To provide for consumer protection in regard to the construction and operation of a cable system; 
(9)  To provide for the regulation of rates and fees charged by a grantee under this chapter; and 
(10)  To ensure that cable television subscribers receive the highest quality cable communications transmission available. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 1, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-4. - Authority. 
    This chapter is passed pursuant to the authority set forth in 65 ILCS 5/1-1-10 and 65 ILCS 5/1-2-1 (1992 State Bar Edition) and 65 ILCS 5/11-42-11 (1992 State Bar Edition), as amended, and incorporated herein and made part hereof. 
    This chapter shall also be governed by the Communications Act of 1934, as amended by Public Law 98-549, cited as the "Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984", and as amended by Public Law 102-385, cited as the Cable Television Consumer Protection and Competition Act of 1992, as said Acts may be amended from time to time. 
    Any right, power or duty of the city, or any official of the city under this chapter may be transferred or delegated by ordinance, resolution, or other appropriate action of the council to an appropriate officer, employee, or department of the city, or any other legal authority, including any intergovernmental agency created for the purpose of regulating the operation and development of the cable television system. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 1, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-5. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words, and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein, unless the context clearly indicates that another meaning is intended. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the plural number include the singular number, and words in the singular number include the plural number. The word shall is always mandatory and not merely directory. 
    Act: The Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984 and the Cable Television Consumer Protection and Competition Act of 1992, as amended. 
    Access channels (P.E.G.): The access channels are dedicated channels for specific user groups. The public access (P) channel(s) is for the use of the public. The government access (G) channel(s) is for the use of the city and other identified government agencies as noted in the franchise agreement. The educational access (E) channel(s) is for the use of the schools in the city. 
    Addressable: The ability to signal from the head end, or hub site, in such a way that only the desired subscriber's receiving equipment is affected. By this means it is possible to send a signal to a subscriber and effect changes in the subscriber's level of service. 
    Agent/agency: The person, department, committee, or other agency designated to act in specified matters related to cable television, or the city manager who shall act to regulate operations of the cable system under this chapter and franchise agreement; or in the absence of such designation, the mayor and the city council. 
    Affiliate: When used in relation to any person, means another person who owns, or controls, is owned or controlled by, or is under common ownership of control with, such person. 
    Alternative local access telecommunications: Fiber optic bypass carrier which is interstate, non-switched, or switched access, in a limited area. 
    Applicant: Any person who has submitted an application for a cable television franchise in accordance with all applicable terms, conditions, and fees. 
    Auxiliary services: Any communication service in addition to "regular subscriber services" including, but not limited to, services for which a per program or per-channel charge is made, pay TV, burglar alarm services, data or other electronic transmission services, facsimile reproduction services, meter reading services, home shopping services, interactive two-way services, personal communications networks (services), and any other service utilizing any facility or equipment of a cable television system operating pursuant to a franchise granted under this chapter. 
    Basic cable service: Any service tier which includes the retransmission of local broadcast signals and the public, educational, and government channels, and may include the local origination channel. 
    Bond or surety bond: A bond issued by one party, the surety, guaranteeing that he will perform certain acts promised by another, or pay a stipulated sum, up to the bond limit, in lieu of performance, should the principal fail to perform. 
    Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984: 47 United States Code Section 521 et seq. and as amended. 
    Cable Television Consumer Protection and Competition Act of 1992: amends title VI of the Communications Act of 1934, and amends the Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984. Referred to in this chapter interchangeably with the Communications Policy Act of 1984 and referenced as the "Act," or the "Cable Act." 
    Cable operator: Any person or group of persons: 
(1)  who provides cable service over a cable system and directly or through one or more affiliates owns a significant interest in such cable system, or 
(2)  Who otherwise controls or is responsible for, through any arrangement, the management and operation of such a cable system. 
    Cable system (system): 
(1)  A facility, consisting of a set of closed transmission paths and associated signal generation, reception, and control equipment that is designed to provide cable service which includes video programming and which is provided to multiple subscribers within a community. Exclusions to this definition are found in section 602 of the Act. 
(2)  A facility as described above located within the corporate limits of the franchising authority whether or not the headend to feed said system is located within the corporate limits of the franchising authority; notwithstanding, the headend shall be considered a part of the cable system. 
    Channel: A band of frequencies six megahertz wide in the electro-magnetic spectrum, or as defined in the future as that standard technologically acceptable band width employed, capable of carrying video, audio, voice, and data signals. 
    City: The City of Mount Carmel, II. 
    Commercial business unit: Any commercial building or establishment that is not a dwelling unit as defined hereunder. 
    Converter: An electronic device provided by a grantee which converts signals to a frequency not susceptible to interference within the television receiver of a subscriber, and by an appropriate channel selector also permits a subscriber to view all signals delivered at designated dial location. 
    Corporate authorities: 
(1)  The city council or similar body when the reference is to cities; 
(2)  The board of trustees or similar body when the reference is to villages or incorporated towns; and 
(3)  The council when the reference is to municipalities under the commission form of municipal government. 
    Council: The city elected corporate authorities. 
    Cumulative leakage index (CU): A figure of merit derived mathematically from the number and severity of signal leaks in a cable system. Compliance with FCC regulations requires a CLI figure merit of 64 or less. 
    Customer service: Providing telephone and in-home technical assistance for cable system customers. 
    Customer service representative (CSR): An individual employed by the cable company to answer the telephone, write service and installation orders, answer customers' questions, receive and process payments, and perform other customer service-related activities. 
    Dedicated channel: 
(1)  In cable television, a channel reserved for a particular use; 
(2)  In telephone, a channel that is not switched. 
    Dedicated service: A communications link reserved exclusively for one user, or one purpose. 
    Density: That number of commercial business units or dwelling units, or combination thereof, that when measured by a linear mile meets the numerical requirement established in the this chapter, or the franchise agreement, which requires the operator to provide cable service. 
    Distribution system: Synonymous with trunk and feeder system. 
    Downstream channel: The direction of signal transmission from the headend to the subscriber terminals. 
    Drop cable: The coaxial, or fiber, cable that connects the feeder portion of the distribution system to the subscriber's premises. 
    Dwelling unit: A single-family or multi-family residential building. 
    Educational access channel: A cable television channel, or channels, specifically designated for the use by local education authorities. 
    Fair market value: The price that a willing buyer would pay to a willing seller for a going concern based on the system valuation and the sale multiples prevailing in the industry. 
    Federal Communications Commission (FCC): The present federal agency of that name as constituted by the Communications Act of 1934, or any successor agency created by the United States Congress. 
    Feeder cables: The coaxial, or fiber, cables that take signals from the trunk line to the subscriber area and to which subscriber taps are attached. 
    Fiber optics: The technology of guiding and projecting light for use as a communications medium. Hair thin glass fibers which allow light beams to be bent and reflected with low levels of loss and interferences are known as "glass optical wave guides" or simply optical fibers." 
    Fiber optic urban loop: Provides local transport of telephone service in competition with the local exchange carrier. 
    Franchise: An initial authorization, or renewal thereof, issued by a franchising authority, whether such authorization is designated as a franchise, permit, license, resolution, contract, certificate, agreement, or otherwise, which authorizes the construction and operation of a cable system. 
    Franchise area: That portion of the city for which a franchise is granted under the authority of this chapter. If not otherwise stated in the franchise, the franchise area shall be the corporate limits of the city including all territory thereafter annexed to the city. The nonexclusive rights granted hereunder, or as described in a franchise agreement entered into between the city and a grantee, to construct and operate a cable system along the public ways in the city, or within specified areas in the city, and is not intended to include any license or permit required for the privilege of transacting and carrying on a business within the city as may be required by other ordinances and laws of the city. 
    Franchise fee: Includes any tax, fee, or assessment of any kind imposed by a franchising authority, or other governmental entity, on a cable operator or cable subscriber, or both, solely because of their status as such. The term "franchise fee" does not include: 
(1)  Any tax, fee, or assessment of general applicability (including any such tax, fee or assessment imposed on both utilities and cable operators or their services but not including a tax, fee, or assessment which is unduly discriminatory against cable operators or cable subscribers): 
(2)  Capital costs which are required by the franchise to be incurred by the cable operator for public, educational, or governmental access facilities. 
(3)  Requirements or charges incidental to the awarding or enforcing of the franchise, including payments for bonds, security funds, letters of credit, insurance, indemnification, penalties, or liquidated damages; or 
(4)  Any fee imposed under Title 17, United States Code. 
    Government access channel: That channel, or channels, set aside for the exclusive use of global government as determined by the franchising authority. 
    Grantee: The natural person, partnership, domestic or foreign corporation, association, joint venture, or organization of any kind granted a franchise by the city under this chapter and its lawful successor, transferee or assignee. 
    Grantor: The franchising authority. 
    Ground: The point of reference in an electrical circuit; considered to be at nominal zero potential when other potentials within the circuit are compared to it. 
    Gross revenues: All revenue derived directly or indirectly, excluding interest income, by the grantee, its affiliates, subsidiaries, parents, and any person in which the grantee has a financial interest, from the operation or use of all or part of a cable television system franchised pursuant to this chapter, including but not limited to revenue from regular subscriber service fees, auxiliary service fees, installation and reconnection fees, leased access channel fees, converter rentals, studio rental, production equipment and personnel fees, and advertising revenues, provided, however, that this shall not include any taxes on services furnished by the grantee herein imposed directly upon any subscriber or user by the state, local, or other governmental unit and collected by the grantee on behalf of said governmental unit. 
Gross revenues shall not include revenues as described herein which are attributable to services offered to subscribers outside of the corporate limits of the city, or revenues attributable under another franchise agreement, except when the city and any other governmental unit have entered into an agreement for those revenues to be attributed to the city franchise and the corresponding franchise fee to be collected by the city. 
    Guaranty: An agreement or promise to answer for the debt, default, or miscarriage of another. Secondarily responsible for debt, default, or miscarriage. 
    Headend: The principal center of a cable television system, where incoming signals are amplified, converted, processed and combined into a common cable along with any origination cablecasting, for transmission to subscribers. System usually includes antennas, preamplifiers, frequency converters, demodulators, modulators, processors, and other related equipment. 
    House drop: Cable from the subscriber tap at the utility pole or pedestal to a subscriber's television set. 
    Household: Each separately billed or billable customer subscribing to or being offered video programming services. 
    Hub: A signal distribution point for part of an overall system. Larger cable systems may be served by multiple hub sites with each hub in turn linked to the main headend with a transportation link such as fiber optics, coaxial supertrunk, or microwave. 
    Installation: The connection from system feeder cable to the subscriber's converter or terminal. 
    Interactive: Pertaining to an application in which entry calls forth a response from a system or program. A two-way cable system that has the capability to provide a subscriber with the ability to enter commands or responses on a home terminal and generate responses or stimuli at a remote location. 
    Interconnect: The process whereby two or more cable systems are connected. 
    Institutional network: The network of cables of frequencies (upstream) that connect schools, government agencies, etc. to the cable system headend for transmission downstream to the subscriber network and or a closed non-public network. 
    Local origination channel: A channel which carries programming that is produced by the operator, or a channel which carries programming determined by the operator the content of which reflects the local needs, interests, and concerns of the community served. Carries programming which is local to the state, city, and the county. 
    Letter of credit: A promise by a bank, or other issuer, that it will honor on behalf of one of its customer's demands for payment, upon compliance with specified conditions. 
    Megahertz (MHz): 1,000,000 cycles per second. 
    Modulation: The process whereby original information can be translated and transferred from one medium to another. Information originally carried as a variation in a particular property (such as amplitude) of one process is transferred and carried as a corresponding variation in some possible different property (such as duration) of the new process. 
    Ordinance: The City of Mount Carmel Cable Communications Enabling Ordinance. 
    Outlet: A CATV connection terminal which connects a television receiver through a 75-ohm coaxial cable, using a 75- to 300-ohm matching transformer at the receiver terminals to the cable system. The outlet is usually a wall plate mounted near the television set. 
    Pedestal: An environmental protection device used to house subscriber isolation units, passive distribution amplifiers in underground cable systems. 
    Personal communications network/system (PCN): A telephonic-quality communications system that uses various components of the cable television system to provide voice communications. 
    Persons: Any individual, firm, corporation, cooperative, association, trust, partnership, joint venture, combination or other legally recognized entity. 
    Primary service area: The corporate limits of the city, at any time; or a defined area of the franchise territory in which service to subscribers is initially offered (original service area); and the addition of subsequent service areas to the original service area providing an expanded geographical measurement for the primary service area. The primary service area may be further defined in the franchise agreement. 
    Public way: The surface, the airspace above the surface, and the area below the surface of any public street, highway, lane, path, alley, sidewalk, boulevard, drive, bridge, tunnel, park, parkways, waterways, or other public right-of-way including public utility easements or rights-of-way, and any temporary or permanent fixtures or improvements located thereon now or hereafter held by the city which shall entitle the city and the grantee to the use thereof for the purpose of installing and maintaining the grantee's cable television system. 
    Repeated activity: More than one time or more than one occurrence. 
    Request for proposal (RFP): The formal document initiated by the franchising authority that sets forth the description of services sought for the provision of cable service by an applicant for a franchise agreement. 
    Schools: All public and private elementary and secondary schools, junior colleges, colleges, and universities which have been granted a certificate of recognition by the Illinois State Board of Education, pursuant to Illinois State Statutes. Also includes any satellite or branch facility of same. 
    Subscriber: Any person who legally receives the basic subscriber service and/or any one or more of such other services as may be provided by the grantee's cable television system, and who does not further distribute such service(s). 
    Surety: One who undertakes to pay money or perform other acts in the event that his principal fails to do so. The surety is directly and immediately liable for the debt or performance. 
    Trap: A passive devise used to block a channel or channels from being received by a cable subscriber (negative trap), or used to remove an interfering carrier from a channel that a subscriber wants to receive (positive trap). 
    Trunk (trunk line): The main distribution lines leading from the headend of the cable television system to the various areas where feeder lines (cables) are attached to distribute signals to the subscribers. 
    Two-way service: The subscriber or any other location shall have the capability to choose whether or not to respond immediately or by sequential delay by utilizing any type of terminal equipment whatever, by push button code, dial code, meter, voice, video including but not limited to audio, and video, electrical or mechanically produced signal, display and/or interrogation. 
    Upstream channel: The direction from the subscriber terminals to the headend. 
    Video dial tone: A common carrier access and transport network service for video information. 
    Video compression: The compression of a digitized signal that is transmitted from the satellite uplink to the cable system headend where it is transmitted to the subscriber's converter/terminal. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 2, 11-18-93) 
Secs. 61/2-6-61/2-10. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - GRANT OF AUTHORITY 

Sec. 61/2-11. - Requirement of a franchise. 
    No person shall construct, install, maintain, or operate a cable television system within the city, or within any other public property of the city, unless a franchise has first been obtained pursuant to this chapter, and unless such franchise is in full force and effect. Such franchise shall not take the place of any other license or permit which may be legally required of the grantee in order to conduct such a business, or construct or install buildings, structures, facilities, or equipment within the city. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 2, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-12. - Franchise applications. 
(a)  The application for a cable television franchise, other than an application for a renewal of a cable television franchise, shall be submitted to the city in such written form as may be required by the city. The city may request such facts and information the city deems appropriate in the application form. The application shall include at a minimum: 
(1)  A clear description of the identity of the applicant, including a copy of FCC Registration Statement; 
(2)  Specifications and plans of the proposed cable system, including identification of trunk line locations; 
(3)  A legal description and/or clear identification of the area intended to be serviced by the applicant; 
(4)  Projected financial pro forma for a period of ten years showing system revenue, and costs of operation; 
(5)  Proof of financial support for the system build as evidenced by a letter from the lending institution and/or other financial entity; 
(6)  A list of other franchises held by the applicant identified by state, city and the date of franchise expiration; 
(7)  A detailed description of the customer service and technical support operations; and 
(8)  Representations that the general partner, any principal or partner, or principal stockholder has never been convicted of a crime involving moral turpitude, or is presently under indictment charging such a crime; the applicant and/or its parent corporation is not, nor has been, a party to litigation, or cause of action, in any court of law or proceeding by the Securities and Exchange Commission, the FCC, or any other governmental body, or administrative agency relevant to the holding of any franchise agreement, or actions of the applicant in any business endeavor. 
(b)  (1)  A fee for the analysis of the application shall accompany the application for a franchise agreement. Any money collected in excess of the actual costs of activities to which the fee is applied, shall be refunded to the applicant. The amount of the fee shall be determined by resolution of the city council and may be amended from time to time. 
(2)  Said fee shall be determined in accordance with applicable ordinances of the city which establish similar fees for use and occupation of public property or rights-of-way. 
(c)  After receiving applications for a franchise, the city council, after considering the technical, financial, and legal qualifications of the applicants; and such other information as to the applicant's service performance in other franchise areas, may grant one or more nonexclusive franchises creating a right to construct and operate a cable television system within the public rights-of-way of the city. No provision of this chapter shall be deemed, or construed, as to require the city council to grant a franchise. 
(d)  An applicant to whom the city council grants a nonexclusive franchise shall, in addition to the non-refundable fee specified in subsection (b) above, pay to the city at the time the grantee files the written instrument specified hereinafter, an amount to be determined by the mayor to be used to offset all direct, reasonable, costs incurred by the city in granting the franchise. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 3, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-13. - Grant of franchise. 
(a)  The city may grant a franchise for all or part of any defined portion of the city. The franchise area shall be the entire area defined in the franchise agreement. 
(b)  (1)  In the event that the city shall grant a nonexclusive, revocable franchise to construct, operate, maintain, and reconstruct a system within the franchise area, said franchise shall constitute both a right and an obligation to provide the services of a system as required by the provisions of this chapter and franchise agreement. 
(2)  Any franchise granted under the provisions hereof shall be consistent with federal laws and regulations, state laws and regulations to the extent constitutionally required, local ordinances and regulations, as from time to time enacted and amended. In the event of conflict between the terms and conditions of the franchise agreement and the statutory standards on which the grantor can grant a franchise, the statutory requirements shall, without exception, control interpretation, amplification and clarification of statutory requirements found in the franchise agreement shall not be considered a conflict. 
(3)  In accepting the franchise, the grantee acknowledges that its rights under the ordinance and the franchise are subject to the police power of the city to adopt and enforce general ordinances necessary to the safety and welfare of the public; and the grantee agrees to comply with all applicable general laws and ordinances enacted by the city pursuant to such power. 
(4)  A renewal or transfer of a franchise shall be conducted as stipulated in this chapter under articles V and VI respectively. 
(c)  No system shall be allowed to occupy or use the streets in the franchise area other than in accordance with this chapter and a franchise granted pursuant hereto. 
(d)  A franchise granted pursuant to this chapter may be modified, from time to time, for other than commercial impracticability, at the request of either party so as to provide for enhancements and/or advances in technology that would be of benefit to the residents of the city. Neither party may unreasonably deny a request to consider a modification. Said consideration shall not be considered to be an acceptance of the modification sought. 
(e)  The city may grant one or more franchises or may decline to grant any franchise. 
(f)  The ordinance and franchise agreement shall be administered by the city council, and/or by the city manager, and/or a city designated staff person, and/or an agent or agency as appointed by the city. The city shall notify the grantee of the person responsible for the administration and enforcement of the provisions of the ordinance and franchise agreement upon the signing of the franchise agreement and at such time as the city council appoints another agent or agency. 
(g)  The grant for a cable communications system for the purpose of this chapter and subsequent franchise agreement shall not include authority to provide alternate access local telecommunications service; personal communications networks, or services; commercial fiber optic loop networks, or video dial tone service unless said activities, or services are specifically authorized in the ordinance, or franchise agreement, or by modification of the ordinance or franchise agreement, or by a subsequent ordinance by the franchising authority. The grantor shall not regulate or prohibit services as described herein except to the extent provided under law and as affirmed by the city council. Grantee may apply to provide the services described within this paragraph and the city shall review said application in a nondiscriminatory manner. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 3, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-14. - Term of the franchise. 
    The term of the franchise shall be as established in the franchise agreement and shall take full effect and be in full force from and after acceptance by the franchisee as provided for in this chapter and in the franchise agreement; and the same shall continue in full force and effect for the term specified in the franchise agreement unless otherwise terminated or revoked as allowed pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 3, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-15. - Non-exclusive franchise agreement. 
    No franchise granted pursuant to this chapter shall give an exclusive right to the grantee and every such franchise shall be deemed to reserve the right to grant other franchises to use and occupy the public ways of the city for cable television, or any other purpose, on such terms as the city may then deem appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 3, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-16. - Surety or guaranty agreement required. 
    The city may require that a grantee whose formation is by partnership, be it a limited or general partnership, and where one general partner is the parent corporation or a subsidiary thereof provide a surety or guaranty agreement which establishes that the parent company of one, or all general partners, accepts liability for the debt and performance of the partnership upon the partnership's default. The city may also require a surety where the grantee is a subsidiary company of the parent company. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 3, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-17. - Voluntary surrender of the franchise agreement. 
    In the event that the grantee voluntarily surrenders the franchise agreement, in effect terminating the grant of authority expressed in this article, the city shall assess liquidated damages as provided for in the franchise agreement. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 3, 11-18-93) 
Secs. 61/2-18-61/2-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - NOTICE 

Sec. 61/2-21. - Requirements for notice. 
(a)  Except as provided in Article IV, and sections 61/2-56 and 61/2-91(b), the city shall not take any final action involving the modification, renewal, revocation or termination of the grantee's franchise unless the city has: 
(1)  Called a meeting for such purpose; 
(2)  Advised the grantee in writing, at least 30 days prior to such meeting, as to time, place, and purpose; and 
(3)  Published a notice at least once ten days prior to the meeting in a newspaper of general circulation within the city. 
The grantee and any interested person shall be entitled to be heard at such meeting. 
(b)  Grantor's notice to the grantee for violation of the provisions of this chapter or the franchise agreement shall be in accordance with the requirements under said sections in this chapter and/or the franchise agreement. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 4, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-22. - Service of notice. 
(a)  Grantee shall serve written notices and written responses to the grantor by certified mail. 
(b)  Written notice to the grantee shall be served by the grantor by either certified mail or in accordance with Illinois Public Act 87-574. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 4, 11-18-93) 
Secs. 61/2-23-61/2-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - MODIFICATION OF THE FRANCHISE AGREEMENT 

Sec. 61/2-31. - Modification. 
(a)  The grantor may amend the franchise agreement, upon application of the grantee, under the terms and conditions as set forth in section 625 of the Cable Act of 1984. 
(b)  The grantee may apply to the city for a modification of the requirements in a franchise, on a condition other than the demonstration of commercial impracticability, and the city may consider said request if the grantee can demonstrate that the modification would afford the grantee the opportunity to provide service in a more efficient, effective, or economical manner to the subscribers and the city; and the city may grant said request upon the completions of negotiations between the grantee and the city. Nothing in this provision shall require the city to modify the franchise agreement. 
(c)  The grantor may, with good cause, request that the grantee modify the franchise agreement if the modification sought by the grantor will result in the subscriber and the city being served in a more efficient, effective, or economical manner by the grantee. Upon notice and hearing the grantor may adopt such modifications of the grantee's franchise of a nature that would not result in effectively terminating same, or substantially effecting the integrated franchise agreement. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 5, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-32. - Costs of modification process. 
(a)  The grantee shall assume the reasonable costs and fees associated with a request to the city to modify the franchise agreement and any subsequent modification. 
(b)  The city shall not be liable for any costs and fees incurred by the grantee upon the city's request to the grantee for a modification of the franchise agreement and any subsequent modification. 
(c)  In determining the reasonableness of the costs and fees, the parties shall look to the expertise of the city in determining the legal, technical, and financial impact of the modification. Should the city require professional staff of such expertise which is not employed by the city for its review of the request for modification, the city shall solicit, at minimum, three proposals for service from said professionals. The city shall select responses from proposals received, which the city believes accurately reflect the services requested by the city. The city shall provide the grantee a written summary of the services offered and the corresponding fee for the three final candidates for service. The city shall be solely responsible for the selecting and hiring of the professional(s). The lowest professional service fee of a responsible bidder, when compared to services offered, shall be the reasonable fee for the payment of same by the grantee under this section. Any costs and fees incurred by the city, for other than professional fees, shall be deemed as reasonable and payable as such by the grantee. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 5, 11-18-93) 
Secs. 61/2-33-61/2-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - PERFORMANCE EVALUATION SESSIONS 

Sec. 61/2-41. - Schedule. 
(a)  The city and the grantee may upon election of the city, hold performance evaluation sessions within 60 days of the first, third, and sixth anniversary dates of the signing of the franchise agreement; and thereafter every three years until the expiration of the franchise agreement; or as may be required under state and federal law. The grantee shall be solely responsible for notifying the grantor no later than 30 days prior to the review period that said period is to commence and no notice by the city to the grantee shall be required. The city shall notify the grantee within 15 days of grantee's notice as to the city's intent to conduct the performance evaluation. 
(b)  Special evaluation sessions may be held at any time during the term of the franchise at the request of the city or the grantee upon 30 days' written notice. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 6, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-42. - Provision of information. 
    During a review and evaluation by the city, the grantee shall fully cooperate with the city and shall provide such information and documents as the city may need to reasonably perform its review. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 6, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-43. - Topics. 
    Topics discussed at any scheduled session, or special evaluation session, may include the examination of any condition or requirement of the franchise agreement, judicial and FCC rulings, and the grantee's responsiveness to the community's needs and interests. The city will provide the grantee with a proposal agenda and document list 30 days prior to the session. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 6, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-44. - Notice. 
(a)  (1)  All evaluation sessions shall be open to the public and announced in a newspaper of general circulation in accordance with the notice provisions of section 61/2-21(a) herein. No such newspaper notice shall be required as to any adjourned sessions. 
(2)  The grantee shall notify subscribers of all evaluation sessions by text announcement on the local origination channel and/or access channels of its system, no less than a total of three times between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 12:00 p.m. and 7:00 p.m. and 9:00 p.m. once a week for two weeks. 
(b)  Additionally, the grantee shall make known through an indication on the subscriber's bill, or through a bill stuffer, or through an advertisement in a local newspaper that said sessions will be conducted with said notice providing: 
(1)  The time, date, and location of the session; or 
(2)  Providing the city's phone number to call to secure the information about the performance evaluation. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 6, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-45. - System or component testing required. 
(a)  If at any time during its review, the city determines that reasonable evidence exists of inadequate cable system performance, it may require the grantee to perform tests and analyses directed toward the suspected inadequacies. The grantee shall fully cooperate with the city in performing such testing and shall prepare results and a report, if requested, within 30 days after the notice to test. Such reports shall include the following information: 
(1)  The nature of the complaint or problem which precipitated the special tests; 
(2)  What system component was tested; 
(3)  The equipment used and procedures employed in testing; 
(4)  The method, if any, in which such complaint or problem was resolved; 
(5)  The name and the qualification of the person(s) assigned to conduct the tests; and 
(6)  Any other information pertinent to said tests and analysis which may be required. 
(b)  (1)  The grantee may use its own qualified staff to conduct such tests as may be required herein. The city may reasonably require that the tests be supervised by a technical consultant experienced in cable television. The costs for said supervision shall be borne by the grantee. 
(2)  Should the city determine that the tests be readministered, the city may engage a technical consultant. The costs shall be borne by the city if the tests confirm the results achieved by the grantee; if the results of the tests determine that the grantee is at fault, or that the grantee's tests were not conducted in accordance with industry standards, the grantee shall be responsible for reimbursing the city for the reasonable expense of the technical consultant and the tests performed. 
(c)  The city's rights under this section shall be limited to requiring tests, analysis, and reports covering specific subjects and characteristics based on said complaints or other evidence when and under such circumstances as the city has reasonable grounds to believe that the complaints or other evidence require the tests be performed to protect the public against substandard cable service. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 6, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-46. - Costs for performance evaluation sessions. 
    Each party shall be responsible for their own costs. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 6, 11-18-93) 
Secs. 61/2-47-61/2-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - FRANCHISE RENEWAL 

Sec. 61/2-51. - Notice by grantee. 
(a)  The grantee shall be solely responsible for providing written notice to the city that the grantee wishes to renew the cable television franchise agreement not less than 30 months before the expiration of the franchise agreement. 
(b)  Grantee shall be responsible for the payment of professional and/or other fees in accordance with applicable ordinances of the city which establish similar fees for the use and occupation of public property and rights-of-way. 
(c)  If no request for renewal is received by the city from the grantee, the franchise shall expire according to its terms. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 7, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-52. - Review of the grantee. 
(a)  The city shall conduct a review of the grantee's performance under the present terms and conditions of the franchise agreement, and shall consider the future communication needs and interests of the entire community as expressed for the present and for the future term of the renewed franchise agreement. The city and the grantee shall abide by any federal or state law, that in addition to the local ordinance, governs the conduct of a cable television franchise renewal. 
(b)  The city may require that the grantee respond to an RFP, or provide to the city a proposal that sets out the services and technical specifications to be required during the new franchise term. The grantee shall not submit a formal proposal for service prior to a date determined by the city. A grantee may submit proposals for review under the informal provisions of Section 626 H of the Cable Act and said proposal shall not be considered the formal proposal until the city sets a date for the submission of said proposal. 
(c)  The city may hear any interested persons during a session called for the purpose of determining the renewal of the franchise agreement, and the city may determine whether or not the grantee did reasonably comply with the terms and conditions imposed by the this chapter and franchise agreement. 
(d)  If the city determines that the grantee is in substantial compliance with the terms and conditions of the current franchise agreement, and that the grantee's proposal for future service meets the community's needs and interests, the city may renew the grantee's franchise agreement with any modification the city deems desirable, for a term specific for the renewed franchise agreement. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 8, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-53. - Compliance with terms and conditions. 
    The city may require that any substantial noncompliance issues be resolved to the satisfaction of the city prior to any negotiation of the renewed franchise agreement. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 7, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-54. - Assessment to not renew the franchise agreement. 
    The city may, upon the completion of its investigation, and upon submittal of a proposal from the grantee, issue a preliminary assessment that the franchise should not be renewed. Upon said assessment, the city and the grantee shall follow the procedures in Section 626 of the Cable Act. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 7, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-55. - Recouping of city expenses. 
(a)  Upon determination by the city, or by the grantee, not to renew the franchise, the city shall have the right to recoup from the grantee all direct expenses incurred pursuant to its consideration of renewal of the franchise. Said expenses shall be due and payable to the city by certified check, or other instrument deemed acceptable to the city, within 30 days' notice by the city. 
(b)  Upon determination of renewal, the grantee and the city may agree to a discharge of expenses and costs in the franchise agreement. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 7, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-56. - Modification of more favorable terms and conditions. 
    In the event that the Cable Act of 1984 Is amended to provide renewal procedures more favorable to the city, this article is automatically amended to incorporate such terms and conditions and the city shall provide the grantee notice, within 30 days of incorporation of same, that this chapter has been amended. The city shall furnish the grantee with the amended sections of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 7, 11-18-93) 
Secs. 61/2-57-61/2-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - TRANSFER OF THE FRANCHISE AGREEMENT 

Sec. 61/2-61. - Franchise as a trust and privilege. 
    A franchise granted under this chapter shall be a privilege to be held in personal trust by a grantee. It shall not be assigned, transferred, sold, or disposed of, in whole or in part, by voluntary sale, sale and leaseback, merger, consolidation, exchange of stock, by provision of a management agreement, or otherwise, or by forced or involuntary sale, without prior consent of the city expressed by resolution and then only on such conditions as may herein be prescribed. Such approval shall not be unreasonably withheld. Any sale, transfer, or assignment not made according to the procedures set forth in this chapter shall render the franchise void. The sale, transfer, or assignment in the bulk of the major part of the tangible assets of the grantee's system shall be considered an assignment and shall be subject to the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 8, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-62. - Approval of city required. 
(a)  Prior approval of the city shall be required where ownership, or control of more than 20 per cent of the right of control of the grantee is acquired during the term of the franchise in any transaction, or series of transactions, by a person or group of persons acting in concern, none of whom owned or controlled 20 per cent or more of such right of control, singularly or collectively on the effective date of the franchise. By its acceptance of this franchise, the grantee specifically grants and agrees that any such acquisition occurring without prior approval of the city shall render the franchise void. A change in the general partner of a limited partnership, if the franchise is held by a limited partnership, shall not be considered a transfer provided that the general partner continues to be an affiliate, or subsidiary, or the parent company of the grantee; nonetheless, the city shall still be notified of said change of the general partner 30 days prior to the change. 
(b)  No such consent shall be required for a transfer in trust, mortgage, or other instrument of hypothecation, in whole or in part, to secure an indebtedness except when such hypothecation shall exceed 75 per cent of the fair market value of the property used by the grantee in the operation of its cable television system. Prior consent of the city shall be required, expressed by resolution, for such transfer and said consent shall not be withheld unreasonably. 
(c)  A transfer of stock shall be considered a transfer of the ownership of the company. 
(d)  Grantee shall file annual with the city a copy of the state domestic corporation annual report. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 8, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-63. - Notice. 
    Whenever any transfer subject to city approval under this chapter is hereof proposed, the grantee shall provide the city with reasonable notice of the intent to transfer and shall provide the city with all information requested by the city in its investigation of the transfer. The grantee shall provide to the city complete information setting forth the nature, terms, conditions, and all other pertinent details of such proposed transfer. The grantee shall meet with the city to resolve any violations of the franchise agreement prior to the transfer. Furthermore, no approval of the transfer shall be granted unless all monies accruing to the city as of the date of the transfer, whether by way of fees, penalties, damages or otherwise, have first been paid in full. In the event that any franchise payment, or recomputed amount is not made on or before the date of the transfer, interest shall be charged from such due date at the rate of one and a half (11/2) per cent per month. Upon the full disclosure of information required by the city in the determination of the qualification of the transfer candidate, and the return to compliance with the terms of the franchise agreement by the grantee, the city shall then consider the application for a transfer and within 120 days of said consideration of the application. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 8, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-64. - Information required. 
    The proposed buyer of the cable system shall provide such evidence to the city as to qualify the applicant as being financially, technically, and legally capable. The city may require financial proposals and letters from the lending institution verifying funding for the acquisition and operation of the cable system. The proposed buyer shall agree, in writing, to comply with all the terms and conditions of the franchise agreement and ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 8, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-65. - Surety or guaranty agreement required. 
    The city may require that a grantee whose formation is by partnership, be it limited or general, provide a surety or guaranty agreement which establishes that the parent company of one, or all general partners, accepts liability for the debt and performance of the partnership should the partnership default. This may be required by the city for transfers to nonrelated buyers of the system or to transfers to a subsidiary or affiliate company, corporation, or partnership of the current grantee. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 8, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-66. - Modification and renegotiation. 
    The city maintains the right, at the time of the transfer application, to request modifications to the franchise agreement that the city deems will benefit the needs and interests of the community. Additionally, the city maintains the option to renegotiate those terms and conditions of the franchise relating to customer service, consumer protection, system channel capacity, and the percentage of franchise fee payments, prior to the city's consent to any assignment, sale, transfer, or other change of ownership as noted in the paragraphs above. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 8, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-67. - City rights not waived. 
    The consent of the city to any sale, transfer, lease, trust, mortgage or other instrument of hypothecation shall not constitute a waiver or release of any rights of the city under this chapter and the franchise. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 8, 11-18-93) 
Secs. 61/2-68-61/2-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - FRANCHISE FORFEITURE AND TERMINATION 

Sec. 61/2-71. - Conditions. 
(a)  In addition to all other rights and powers retained by the city under the franchise, or otherwise, the city reserves the right to forfeit and terminate the franchise and all rights and privileges of the grantee hereunder in the event of a substantial breach of its terms and conditions as determined by a preponderance of the evidence. A substantial breach by the grantee shall include, but shall not be limited to the following: 
(1)  Violation of any material provision of the franchise or any material rule, order, regulation or determination of the city made pursuant to the franchise; or 
(2)  Attempt to evade any material provision of the franchise or practice any fraud or deceit upon the cable television system subscribers or upon the city government; or 
(3)  Failure to provide the services defined in the franchise agreement; or
