(4)  Failure to begin or complete system construction or system line extension in accordance with the terms of the franchise agreement; or 
(5)  Willful failure to restore system wide service after 48 consecutive hours of interrupted service, except when approval of said interruption is obtained from the city, or when a natural disaster prevents the restoration of service in a timely manner; or 
(6)  Material misrepresentation of fact in the application for or negotiation of the franchise; or 
(7)  Frequent violations by the grantee of any orders or rulings of any regulatory body having jurisdiction over the grantee relative to its franchise; or 
(8)  Any order is entered in any proceeding against the grantee decreeing the dissolution, or split-up, of the grantee and such order remains in effect for 45 days; or 
(9)  Repeated failure to pay the franchise fee in accordance with section 61/2-92 and in accordance with the terms of the franchise agreement; or 
(10)  The grantee applies to any tribunal for the appointment of a trustee or receiver for any substantial part of the assets of the grantee, or commences any proceedings relating to the grantee under any bankruptcy, reorganization, insolvency, readjustment of debt, dissolution or other liquidation law of any jurisdiction, or any such application is filed, or any such proceeding is commenced, against the grantee, and the grantee indicates it's approval, consent or acquiescence, or an order entered appointing such trustee or receiver or adjudicating the grantee bankrupt or insolvent, or approving the petition in any such proceeding, and such order remains in effect for 45 days. 
(b)  The foregoing shall not constitute a substantial breach if the violation occurs without the fault of the grantee; or occurs as a result of circumstances beyond its direct control such as war, civil disturbance, natural catastrophe and other acts of God; or failure of timely receipt of licenses from utility companies; of if the grantee satisfactorily corrects a franchise violation subsequent to notice from the city. The grantee shall not be excused by mere economic hardship, subject to Cable Act section 625, nor by misfeasance or malfeasance of its directors, officers, or employees. 
(c)  The city may make a written demand that the grantee comply with any such provision, rule, order, or determination under or pursuant to this franchise. If the violation continues for a period of 30 days, or as otherwise stipulated in this chapter or franchise agreement, following such written demand without written proof that the corrective action has taken or is being actively and expeditiously pursued, the city may consider the issue of terminating the cable system franchise provided that the city shall cause to be served upon the grantee a notice, in accordance with article III of this chapter, that the city is to consider the issue of termination, a written notice of intent to request termination and the time and place of the meeting. 
(d)  The city council, or its duly designated representative shall hear and consider the issue and shall hear any person interested therein, and the city council shall determine in its discretion whether or not any violation by the grantee occurred. 
(e)  If the city council shall determine the violation by the grantee was the fault of the grantee and within its control, the council may, by resolution, declare that the franchise of the grantee shall be forfeited and terminated unless there is compliance within such period as the council may fix, such period shall not be less than ten days, provided that no opportunity for compliance need be granted for fraud or misrepresentation. 
(f)  The issue of forfeiture and termination shall automatically be placed upon the council agenda at the expiration of the time set for it for compliance. The council then may terminate the franchise forthwith upon finding that the grantee has failed to achieve compliance or may extend the compliance period at the council's discretion. 
(g)  The council may establish a set time by which the grantee shall remove, or abandon all, or a portion of, the tangible assets of its system from the city's right-of-ways and from subscriber's homes or may direct the grantee to sell the cable system at the fair market value with no value allocated to the franchise itself. If the city revokes the franchise for cause and seeks to acquire ownership of the cable system, or effects to transfer the ownership of the system to another person, it shall due so at an equitable price. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 9, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-72. - Removal of cable plant. 
    The grantee shall apply for and obtain such encroachment permits, licenses, authorizations or approvals and pay such fees and deposit such security as required by the applicable ordinances of the city or by state statute, or as required by the city council, shall conduct and complete the removal in compliance with all such applicable ordinances, and shall restore the streets to the same condition as prior to the work of the removal commenced. The work of removal shall be completed not later than one year following the date of expiration or termination of the franchise, unless some other date has been set the city council in its notice to the grantee; otherwise the city may complete such work through and by its employees or through a contractor selected by the city and charge the expense thereof against the security deposit, letter of credit, and/or construction bond required to be provided by the grantee. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 9, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-73. - Additional rights of the city. 
    The termination or forfeiture of the grantee's rights under a franchise shall in no way affect any other rights the city may have under the franchise or under any provision of law. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 9, 11-18-93) 
Secs. 61/2-74-61/2-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - CONTINUATION OF SERVICE 

Sec. 61/2-81. - Provision of service. 
(a)  For a reasonable time, in the period between expiration, cancellation, revocation, or termination of the franchise and the transfer of the cable system pursuant to this chapter, the grantee shall continue to provide operations service and customers service to the public as if the franchise were still in effect. 
(b)  The grantee shall act as a trustee for its successor in the interest of the cable franchise and provide a financial accounting during the interim period. The grantee shall hold the franchise as a trustee for the success and shall not sell or otherwise dispose of any of the systems' assets nor shall the grantee make any physical, administrative, or operational changes that, without the express written consent of the city, would tend to: 
(1)  Degrade the quality of the service to subscribers, 
(2)  Decrease gross revenues, or 
(3)  Materially increase expenses. 
(c)  In the event the grantee fails or refuses to operate the system in accordance with the terms of the ordinance and franchise agreement, the city shall have the option to institute legal proceedings to name a successor trustee to operate the system. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 10, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-82. - Authority to continue to operate the cable system. 
(a)  In the event of expiration or revocation of the franchise agreement, this section shall not be construed to give the grantee any vested right, or authority of franchise. The right of the grantee under such circumstances shall exist only on a day-to-day basis until the transfer or sale is effected. 
(b)  As full compensation for its ownership interests during this interim period, the grantee shall be entitled to receive a reasonable profit during the period between the expiration or revocation of the franchise, as the case may be, and the transfer of the grantee's assets to the city or a successor. 
(c)  The grantee shall be liable for all the costs of operating and maintaining the system in the event that the city must assume the day-to-day operation of the cable system. Any addition, the city, or its representative, shall place the profit, if any, from the operation of the system during this period in an interest-bearing account until such time as all proceedings against the grantee have been adjudicated. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 10, 11-18-93) 
Secs. 61/2-83-61/2-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - FRANCHISE FEE 

Sec. 61/2-91. - Provision of a franchise fee. 
(a)  As compensation for the franchise granted herein, the grantee shall pay to the city a franchise fee in an annual amount of five per cent of the gross revenues as defined in section 61/2-5. 
(b)  To the extent permitted by law and in accordance therewith, franchise fees in excess of five per cent may be collected by the city after 30 days' written notice to the grantee. The recomputed percentage will be an automatic modification to this section after the expiration of the 30-day notice. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 11, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-92. - Payment of the franchise fee. 
(a)  Franchise fees are to be paid quarterly and not later than 60 days following the last day of the quarter. The franchise fees are to be mailed by certified mail, or may be hand delivered, to the city administrator's office. 
(b)  Each franchise fee payment shall be accompanied by a financial statement, in such manner as attached as an exhibit to the franchise agreement, that clearly defines the subscriber count and gross revenues identified by category of revenue and the total of all gross revenues for the quarter said payment is rendered. The financial statement shall be signed by the grantee's controller, or other employee knowledgeable of the accuracy of the figures used in the computation and the corresponding payment to the city. 
(c)  Any franchise fee which remains unpaid after the date specified in the ordinance shall be delinquent and shall thereafter accrue interest at the maximum rate permitted by law for interest upon judgments, until fully paid. The costs incurred by the city in obtaining a judgment, including attorney's fees and court costs, for the unpaid balance of the franchise fees, as set forth in this section, shall be borne by the grantee. 
(d)  No acceptance of any payment shall be construed as an accord that the amount paid is, in fact, the correct amount, nor shall such acceptance of payment be construed as a release of any claim which the city may have for further or additional sums payable under the provisions of this section. 
(e)  Upon termination of the franchise at the expiration of the term provided thereof, or otherwise, the grantee shall continue to make the quarterly statements and certifications and the annual reports as provided in this section until such time as all payments due the city under this chapter have been paid and accounted for to the reasonable satisfaction of the city. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 11, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-93. - Audit requirements/financial reviews. 
(a)  The grantee shall file with the city an annual audited statement within 120 days after the closing of the grantee's books. The audited report shall be prepared by a certified public accountant and shall clearly show the yearly total gross revenues by category and accumulated total and the number of subscribers upon which the franchise fee was based. 
(b)  The city shall have the right to inspect the grantee's income records, worksheets, journals, general ledgers, notes, financial statements, tax returns, and other such financial records as may be necessary and appropriate to verify the accuracy of the franchise fee payments. The city may use its own personnel or may hire an outside certified public account to conduct an audit or "agreed upon procedures" financial review to recompute and verify the franchise fee payment and compliance with the financial terms of this chapter. 
(c)  The city shall provide the grantee with 30 days' notice of the city's intent to inspect the financial records of the grantee: 
(1)  The grantee shall comply with the city's request and shall make available, at a location acceptable to the city, all the financial records reasonably requested by the city so that the city might complete its investigation; 
(2)  If it is not possible for the grantee to provide certain specified records or documents at a location determined by the city, then the city may send its representative to the location where the grantee houses said records. Said reasonable travel expense shall be borne entirely by the grantee; 
(3)  Any additional amount due to the city as a result of the financial investigation shall be paid within 30 days following written notice to the grantee by the city which notice shall include a copy of the financial report. A delinquent payment of the recomputed amount shall accrue interest in the same manner as a delinquent franchise fee payment; 
(d)  The cost of the financial review, or investigation, shall be borne by the grantee if it is properly determined that the grantee's annual payment due to the city for the preceding year, or the year under investigation, has been underpaid by five per cent or more. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 11, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-94. - Identification of the franchise fee on the subscriber billing statement. 
    At such time as the grantee identifies the franchise fee on the subscriber's billing statement, the grantee shall indicate that said fee is not a new fee, or an increase in the program service fee, that has been imposed by the city. Grantee shall provide a copy of the text to the city prior to its receipt by the public for approval by the city. The franchise fee shall appear as an element of the subscriber's total bill and not as an addition to the subscriber's services on the bill. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 11, 11-18-93) 
Secs. 61/2-95-61/2-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - INSPECTION AND MAINTENANCE OF GRANTEE'S BOOKS AND RECORDS 

Sec. 61/2-101. - Maintenance of records. 
(a)  (1)  All financial records of the grantee with respect to subscribers, subscriber revenues, plant and equipment costs associated with the system facilities shall be maintained as though the system were a separate business enterprise. In the event that the grantee is a partnership, the grantee shall provide separate financial records for all subscriber revenues and may provide an aggregate financial record for franchise plant and equipment costs, providing that; 
a.  The grantee shall identify at the franchise level their costs of franchise requirements, franchise fees, local taxes, and local programming costs; 
b.  The grantee shall identify all direct costs and expenses attributable to the city franchise agreement; 
c.  The grantee shall identify all indirect common costs and revenues passed through to the partnership holding the franchise agreement, or corporate entity holding the franchise agreement, which are aggregated and which are then allocated at the franchise level based on the ratio of the total number of subscribers served at the franchise level to the total number of subscribers served at the partnership, or higher, level; 
d.  The grantee shall identify all common costs and expenses passed through from the parent company, or regional holding company, in total for the partnership and noted as a percentage of the aggregate attributable to the city franchise agreement; and 
e.  Providing that whenever possible, common costs are to be allocated to the origin of the costs themselves. 
(2)  Grantee shall provide a copy of the partnership income statement if the franchise agreement is held by a general partnership or limited partnership. Income statements may also be required of general corporations or limited liability companies, or any other such entity that holds the franchise agreement. 
(b)  All financial, customer service, and operations records of the grantee shall be maintained at the local office, or at a location owned by the grantee that is no more than 75 miles from the central office of the city government. To the extent that the grantor identifies certain records which the grantee may not reasonably maintain at the local office, or at the nearest location within the 75-mile limitation, the grantee may make those records available at another location identified by the grantee, providing that the grantee shall be responsible for all travel costs incurred by the city, or its agent, in the city's inspection of the books and records. 
(c)  The grantee shall maintain the records of subscriber complaints, system outages, telephone system logs or records, system technical tests results, CLI testing results, and other records that will assist the city in its review of the grantee's compliance with the ordinance and franchise agreement until the completion of each of the grantee's performance evaluation sessions. The city may reasonably request that certain documents be held for a longer period upon ten days' written notice to the grantee. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 12, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-102. - Records and reports provided to the city. 
(a)  Subject to the privacy provisions of the Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984, grantee shall maintain records of customer service complaints and technical service logs; and shall provide copies of same to the city, upon the city's exercise of its police powers, in a manner prescribed by the city. 
(b)  The grantee shall notify the city of the resolution of all complaints received by the grantee through a monthly summary report. 
(c)  Upon a historical record of complaints received by the city, or the grantee; or upon a historical record based on the city's own discovery, the grantee shall provide the city with a report of phone statistics for an identified month, for all phone lines for customer service and technical repair. Said reports shall indicate the average number of: Calls received, abandoned calls, hold time, and for the busy signal response time. Upon request of the city, the grantee shall provide, from time to time, a phone report which indicates, by exception, when the grantee is not in compliance with the requirements of ordinance section 61/2-125. 
(d)  The grantee shall prepare semi-annual summary reports of all service calls, technical repair calls, and of system outages. The grantee may provide copies of the actual service and technical report forms in lieu of a summary report by the grantee. The technical service reports shall indicate the nature of the service repair request, the date and time the request was received, disposition of the service call, the corrective action taken, and the time and date thereof. The original service call reports and outage logs completed by the technician shall be retained until the completion of the next performance evaluation session. 
(e)  Grantee shall, upon request of the city, provide a copy of the results of technical tests that are required by the FCC in 47 CFR Part 76 Subpart K, and as it may be amended from time to time. It shall be a requirement under this chapter to conduct such tests in the manner prescribed in the 47 CFR Part 76 Subpart K and no exclusion for the conducting of said tests shall be applicable to the grantee. 
(f)  The city retains the option to reduce, or increase, the reporting timelines provided for herein so as to reasonably accommodate the regulatory duties of the city. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 12, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-103. - Listing of franchise agreements grafted. 
    The grantee shall provide a list of all franchises granted to the grantee in the state and within 50 miles of the city, as of the date the grantee signs the city's franchise agreement and then after provide an updated list at each performance evaluation session. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 12, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-104. - Provision of communications. 
    The grantee shall provide the city with a list of all petitions, documents, applications, reports, and communications filed or submitted by the grantee with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the FCC, or any governmental agency or entity having jurisdiction with respect to the grantee's cable television business affecting the grantee's franchise with the city. At the request of the city, the grantee shall provide the city with a copy of any of the identified documents that the city deems would be in its interest to obtain. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 12, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-105. - Filing of ownership, rules, terms, regulations, and reports. 
(a)  With the filing of the annual financial report, the grantee shall file: 
(1)  A list of the general partners owning five per cent or more interest in the partnership whether directly or indirectly; or if a corporation, the grantee shall file a list of all its directors, officers and shareholders owning directly or indirectly five per cent or more of the stock. 
(2)  Copies of all current rules, regulations, terms, and conditions established, or imposed by the grantee, in connection with the establishment, construction, operation, and maintenance of the cable television system. In the event that there has been no change from the prior year for the documents described herein, the grantee shall be required to file a letter with the city stating there has been no change from the prior year's documents. 
(3)  Form 325," Annual Report of Cable Television System,"-community unit data, physical system data, and operator ownership data to be filed concurrently with the FCC required filing. 
(4)  Copy of subscriber instruction for filing of technical complaints as required under CFR 76.607, as amended from time to time. 
(b)  With a franchise application, or with a request for renewal of a franchise agreement: 
(1)  Registration statement as described in CFR 76.12, as amended from time to time. 
(2)  SEC registration statements. 
(3)  Certification of domestic and/or foreign incorporation. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 12, 11-18-93) 
Secs. 61/2-106-61/2-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - RATES 

Sec. 61/2-111. - Universal rates. 
(a)  Rates for all subscribers of basic cable service of service shall be uniform throughout the franchise area. The grantee may offer bulk billing discounts for cable television programming service the grantee shall not, with regard to fees and rates, discriminate or grant any preference or advantage to any person; provided, however, that the grantee may establish different rates for different classes of subscribers or users based upon cost of service differentials; provided that the grantee not discriminate between any subscribers or users of the same class. Grantee shall not be prohibited from offering discounted rates to senior citizens or other economically disadvantaged subscribers. 
(b)  Rates for cable television service installation shall be classified by categories of residential, residential multifamily, private and non-profit institutional (hospitals, nursing homes, educational, etc.), and commercial if there are different installation charges among these classes. Installation rates in each category must be uniform and a subscriber within any class may not be discriminated against due to the fact that he subscribes to only basic service. 
(c)  The grantee may waive, reduce, or suspend installation fees or cable programming service fees in a nondiscriminatory manner for a reasonable period of time as each segment of the cable system is activated; or during limited promotion (marketing) periods. 
(d)  No grantee shall enter into any agreement with a subscriber which imposes any charge following disconnection of service, except for reconnection and subsequent monthly, or periodic charges, and those charges shall be no greater than charges for new customers. This section shall not prevent a grantee from refusing service to any person because of the grantee's prior accounts with that person remain due and owing. 
(e)  Grantee shall not offer a service which requires more than three months' advance payment. 
(f)  The grantee shall be required to apprise, in writing, each new subscriber of all applicable fees and charges for providing cable television service. 
(g)  The grantee shall, by written correspondence, notify the city and the subscriber of a rate increase 30 days prior to the activation of said increase. Upon request of the city, the grantee shall appear at a city council meeting to apprise the council of the necessity of said rate increase. 
Sec. 61/2-112. - Rates for non-ambulatory, visually, and hearing impaired subscribers. 
    Rates for devices for non-ambulatory, visually impaired, or hearing impaired persons that allow them to receive the cable television service including such devices as, but not limited to, remote controls, closed captioned decoders, braille reading materials and braille channel identification devices, shall be no more than the actual cost of the device, plus a reasonable cost attributable to the grantee's storage of same, plus a reasonable profit. In any event, the rental fee for the device shall be comparable to the same, or similar device, offered to the general cable subscriber. The grantee may offer the non-ambulatory, visually impaired, or hearing impaired subscriber the option of buying the device at the grantee's cost plus a reasonable profit, plus the actual cost of delivery to the subscriber. Charges for the installation of said equipment shall be computed at the same rate as charges for installation of the same, or similar, equipment for other non-disabled subscribers. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 13, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-113. - Regulation of rates and fees. 
(a)  The city shall, pursuant to the notice provisions of article III, hold a hearing to provide appropriate standards for rate regulation. By accepting the franchise granted pursuant to the terms and conditions imposed by this chapter, the grantee agrees that the city shall have the authority and right to cause the grantee's fees and/or rates for basic subscriber service, subscriber equipment, and all other subscriber and user services to the extent permitted by law or FCC rules and regulations, to conform to the provisions set by the city council. The city shall also have the authority and right to fix fees and/or rates and to deny increases or order reduction of fees and/or rates when it deems that in the absence of such action on its part, the grantee's fees and/or rates, or proposed rates and/or fees, do not conform to the stipulations adopted. 
(b)  The grantee may add to its service or installation fees any federal, state, or local taxes or fees directly imposed on subscribers. 
(c)  Rate regulation administration (to be added). 
(d)  A copy of the grantee's subscriber equipment/wiring maintenance contract shall be filed with the city attorney 30 days prior to its implementation by the grantee. If required by the city attorney, the maintenance contract shall be modified accordingly. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 13, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-114. - Collection of user taxes and fees by the grantee. 
    Upon request of the city, the grantee shall list on the billing statement, and collect for the city, any tax or user fee, imposed by the city. The method of collection of the tax or user fee and the payment of the collected tax or user fee back to the city shall be determined by the city in cooperation with the grantee at such time as a tax or user fee is authorized. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 13, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-115. - Option to impose a municipal tax. 
(a)  The city may enact a tax, fee, or assessment of general applicability on the grantee or the grantee's services. 
(b)  The city may impose upon the grantee a tax on the transmission of messages by means of radio magnetic waves or fiber optics at a rate not to exceed five of the gross receipts from such business originating within the corporate limits of the municipality in accordance with Illinois statutes 65 ILCS 5/8-11-2. 
(c)  The city may enact a user tax to be levied upon the recipients of cable services other than basic service. If enacted, such tax would be collected by the grantee on behalf of the city. The grantee would receive a reasonable servicing fee from the city to cover the costs of this billing and collection process. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 13, 11-18-93) 
Secs. 61/2-116-61/2-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIII. - CONSUMER PROTECTION AND CUSTOMER SERVICE PROVISIONS 

Sec. 61/2-121. - Notification to the subscriber. 
    The grantee shall, at the time service is initiated and at least annually thereafter to all subscribers, and at such time as there is an alteration in the information, furnish to each subscriber written information describing the procedure and remedies available to the subscriber in the provision of programming, technical, and customer services. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 14, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-122. - Billing practices. 
    The grantee shall comply with the following billing practices: 
(1)  Subscribers shall receive a monthly statement with a date for payment due. 
(2)  All statements shall clearly denote a postmark or initiated date of bill. 
(3)  All statements shall clearly state a telephone number for billing inquiries and adjustments. 
(4)  All statements shall clearly indicate the dates of service for which the subscriber is being billed and a due date for payment. 
(5)  All statements shall clearly indicate the programming and/or other services subscribed to and the fee for same and any penalty charges. 
(6)  The grantee shall not charge a subscriber for receipt, or issuance of, a billing statement. 
(7)  The grantee shall mail statements in a timely manner providing the subscriber with a minimum of two weeks from the date of posting to make a payment without being delinquent. 
(8)  Upon notification by the subscriber of the loss of service of 24 continuous hours or an aggregate of 24 hours of service in a 30-day period, an adjustment of one day's service of the monthly bill shall be credited for loss of service to any and all convertors, or similar devices which provide cable service to the subscriber, located at the subscriber's home or place of business. The adjustment shall be made no later than one billing cycle after the notification occurs. 
(9)  The charge for late payment of bills and for the processing of NSF checks shall not exceed the actual cost to the grantee to process same. 
(10)  Past due billing statements, or past due notices, shall be delivered in the same manner and method as the regular subscriber statement; and shall not be of a different color envelope as to be distinctive to a non-recipient; nor shall said envelope bear the wording past due notice or other like language. Nothing in this section shall prevent the grantee from sending past due notices in a more frequent manner that the regular subscriber statement; or from adopting rules and procedure for notification of past due accounts. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 14, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-123. - Deposits for service or equipment. 
(a)  Deposits for equipment shall be returned to the subscriber within 30 days of the return of said equipment to the grantee providing that said equipment is in reasonable condition. No interest shall be due to the subscriber unless the deposit is for $100.00 or more, in which case the grantee shall place the deposit in an interest bearing account and refund the deposit and all interest accrued upon return of the equipment in reasonable condition. 
(b)  A deposit for installation of service shall be returned to the subscriber within 30 days after the subscriber cancels his request for installation. If the subscriber does not request a cancellation of the installation, the deposit shall be applied to the first months charge for cable services. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 14, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-124. - Customer service facilities. 
(a)  Grantee shall maintain a customer service facility within the city that is capable of accepting payments, adjusting bills, responding to repairs, receiving converter boxes, complaints, requests for installation, or service calls. The customer service facility shall be open to the general public for a set number of days and hours per week, with a minimum number of evening hours week days and/or partial hours on a Saturday as described in the franchise agreement. 
(b)  Grantee may provide bill payment centers in a retail facility located within the city, or may provide drop boxes for the payment of bills. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 14, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-125. - Telephone service. 
    Grantee shall maintain a toll-free telephone customer service number on a 24-hour basis, with CSRs available during normal business hours. Grantee may employ an answering service or automated response call system, to receive subscriber phone calls after business hours. An answering service shall be held to the same customer service phone standards as the grantee. The grantee shall not use an audiotape recording device to replace an answering service or an automated response call system. 
    Under normal business conditions, the following standards shall apply: 
(1)  All calls shall be answered within four rings by a CSR, or by an answering service or automated response call system; 
(2)  Hold time for all calls, during normal business operations, may be no more than 30 seconds 90 per cent of the time; 
(3)  The abandonment rate for telephone call shall not exceed an abandonment rate of ten per cent of the calls reported as incoming; 
(4)  Not more than three per cent of callers, under normal operating conditions, should receive a busy signal. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 14, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-126. - Identification of customer service representatives and technical service technicians. 
(a)  Customer service representatives (CSRs) and service technicians, including contracted help, shall identify themselves by name. When performing work in the field, a company identification badge shall be displayed on the outer clothing of the technician or contractor. 
(b)  All of the grantee's vehicles, or a sub-contractor's vehicle's, shall be clearly identified as performing work for the grantee. 
(c)  Grantee shall make a reasonable attempt to notify the city police department in advance of any emergency work in residential easements after 4:00 p.m. C.S.T. or 8:00 p.m. C.D.T. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 14, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-127. - Response to subscriber complaints. 
(a)  Grantee shall initiate corrective action to a subscriber's complaint, which has been presented by phone or by walk-in to the customer service facility, as soon as practicable but not later than 24 hours after the receipt of the complaint. 
(b)  Grantee shall initiate corrective action to a subscriber's written complaint within ten days of receiving the complaint. The grantee shall notify the subscriber that the complaint has been received and the grantee is in the process of resolving/investigating the complaint. All written complaints shall be resolved within 30 days after the receipt of the written complaint, excepting unusual circumstances. In no situation, may a complaint remain unresolved after 45 days. 
(c)  If a subscriber is not satisfied with the response to his complaint, and the system manager can not resolve the dissatisfaction, the subscriber is to be given the phone number of the city and the department in which he may register his complaint with the city. He shall also be given the name and address of the grantee's parent company and a person to whom the complaint may be directed. 
(d)  Complaints which remain unresolved at the end of 30 days shall be reported to the city administrator within 15 days of the month's end. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 14, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-128. - Technical service response. 
(a)  Grantee shall establish a maintenance service capable of locating and correcting major system malfunctions promptly which shall be available at all hours, to correct such major system malfunctions affecting a number of subscribers. 
(b)  A listed local, or toll free, telephone number shall be made available to subscribers for technical service calls at any time of the day or night. 
(c)  (1)  Corrective actions shall be initiated in response to all subscriber technical service calls, other than major system outages, within four hours if received by 12:00 p.m. or not later than the next business day if the call is received after 12:00 p.m. Calls on Saturday received after 1:00 p.m. and calls received on Sunday shall be responded to as soon as practicable but in no situation later than the next business day. 
(2)  Grantee shall have technical service hours that provide for day, evening, and Saturday hours so as to provide comprehensive repair response to subscriber service calls. 
(d)  Corrective action of a major system outage, involving three or more subscribers off the same trunk line or feeder line, or amplifier shall be initiated immediately upon grantee's awareness of said condition. Corrective action for system outages shall be completed as promptly as practicable, but in no situation longer than 24 hours after notice without the authorization of the city to extend the time of the service repair. 
(e)  An outage to more than three subscribers in a multi-family unit served off the same tap shall be corrected as in paragraph D above. 
(f)  Subscribers shall be provided with an appointment within a specific four-hour block of time throughout the grantee's normal business hours. An open designation, or a.m./p.m. designation, for a service appointment may be given to a subscriber when the grantee's service schedule for designated time service calls is filled, or shall be given at the subscriber's request. 
(g)  (1)  If the grantee's technician fails to provide the service call within the time frame given to the subscriber thus causing the service call to be incomplete, or to be missed, the grantee shall schedule a service call as soon as practicable but in no event later than 24 hours after the time of the missed service call, unless the subscriber directs the grantee to provide service at a later date or time. 
(2)  If the subscriber misses the service call, the grantee shall reschedule a service call as soon as practicable but in no event later than 72 hours after the time of the missed call. 
(h)  The subscriber shall, when practicable, receive a copy of the service report. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 14, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-129. - Credits and charges for missed service calls. 
(a)  The grantee shall provide a credit equal to one day of service if the grantee's technician misses a scheduled service call, or is unable to complete a scheduled service call due to a late arrival by the technician. 
(b)  The grantee may institute a reasonable service call fee if a subscriber misses a scheduled service call provided that the charge for said missed service call shall not exceed the actual cost to the grantee to redispatch the technician to the subscriber's residence or place of business. In the event that a subscriber who has been issued an open time slot, or all day time slot, for a service call misses the service call, that subscriber shall not be charged a service call fee except that in the event that a singular subscriber misses his open time slot, or all day time slot, more than twice for the same service then the grantee may charge that subscriber a service call fee as described herein. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 14, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-130. - Installation of service. 
    The grantee shall comply with the following standards for installation of service: 
(1)  In an activated portion of the system, all requests for standard installation shall be completed within seven working days of the request by the subscriber. 
(2)  Weather permitting, the grantee shall commence a non-standard installation, an installation requiring more than 125 feet of drop cable or an installation that due to the subscriber's requirements does not meet the specifics of a standard installation, within 60 days of the receipt of the request, providing that the grantee receives all necessary approvals and/or permits in a timely manner. 
(3)  Installation in multi-family units, commercial units, a condominium association building or common area, or in rental units shall be commenced only upon the owner's, or the association's approval of the construction plans for entry of cable drops into the building. In the event that the grantee needs to secure an easement for the delivery of cable television on condominium property, the grantee shall do so in accordance with 765 ILCS 605/14.3 (1992 State Bar Edition). 
(4)  Subscribers shall be provided with either a four-hour time block appointment or an a.m./p.m. designated appointment block. An open designation shall be given only in situations when the a.m./p.m. designation, or a time block appointment is impracticable due to a filled a.m. or p.m. schedule, or shall be given at the subscriber's request. 
(5)  No service contract entered into between the grantee and a subscriber shall require exclusivity of service as a condition to the provision of cable service by the grantee. 
(6)  All temporary service drops, also known as snow drops when laid in the winter, shall be buried accordingly unless the grantee receives permission from the city to delay burial. 
a.  1.  Temporary drops laid after the ground has thawed shall be buried between March and December unless the grantee receives permission from the city to delay burial. 
2.  Weather and ground conditions permitting, temporary drops shall be buried as expeditiously as possible but in no event later than 21 days after placement without the expressed written permission of the city. 
b.  Temporary drops laid after the ground has frozen, "snow drops," shall be buried not later than May 15 of the following season. 
c.  Grantee shall provide a bi-monthly report to the city on the status and location of any temporary drops which remain unburied. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 14, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-131. - System interruptions. 
    The grantee may interrupt system service, on any day except Saturday, or Sunday, or a legal holiday, or during a national sporting event, after 7:00 a.m. and before 1:00 a.m. for routine maintenance and repair only with good cause and for the shortest time possible only after cablecasting notice of service interruption at least 24 hours in advance of the service interruption. Service may be interrupted at anytime for emergency service, but only for the shortest time practicable. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 14, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-132. - Cancellation or suspension of service. 
(a)  A subscriber may disconnect his service at any time without charge. The grantee shall stop the subscriber's billing for the service within 24 hours of receipt of notice from the subscriber and physically disconnect the service within seven days after the subscriber's request. 
(b)  (1)  A subscriber, with an addressable converter, may downgrade his service at any time for a nominal charge not to exceed $2.00. The nominal charge may not exceed the actual costs of providing the downgrade. Subscribers who do not have an addressable convertor can be charged the actual costs of changing tiers. 
(2)  The grantee may charge a slightly higher rate for tier service changes for those subscriber changing service tiers more than twice a year. The exception would be for special promotions in which the subscriber is given an inducement to subscribe to a service and that subscriber cancels the service within 30 days, that subscriber shall be charged no more than the nominal amount, or the amount which is indicated on the promotional marketing literature, whichever is less. 
(3)  If the grantee can demonstrate an unusually high churn rate for his system, he may petition the city for an increase in the change of tier service charge. 
A subscriber may suspend service during vacation periods of two weeks to four months without having to pay an installation fee upon reactivation of service. The grantee may charge the subscriber a reasonable re-activation fee, if that is the grantee's practice. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 14, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-133. - Delinquent accounts and disconnection. 
    The grantee shall use its best efforts to collect on delinquent subscriber accounts. The grantee shall provide the subscriber with two notifications of a past due account, the method in which to clear the account, and the consequences to the subscriber should the account not be cleared. In all cases, the grantee shall provide the subscriber with at least five days' written notice of a final decision to disconnect prior to the disconnection. A subscriber shall not be disconnected if his bill is disputed and the grantee and the subscriber are actively working towards resolution of the dispute over a reasonable period of time. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 14, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-134. - Corrective action. 
    In the event a subscriber does not obtain a satisfactory response or resolution to his request for service, or an adjustment within a reasonable period of time, or is dissatisfied with the resolution of his complaint, he may advise the city in writing, or by telephone, of his dissatisfaction. The city shall have authority to investigate any subscriber complaint and to order corrective action as shall be appropriate. The city may require the grantee to establish rules and procedures regulating complaint resolution in the franchise agreement, or at any time after the acceptance of the franchise agreement. The city shall have the authority to review and amend said rules and procedures upon discussion with the grantee. Nothing herein shall limit the rights of any subscriber, or other person, to bring an action against the grantee in a court of law. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 14, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-135. - Agreements/promotions. 
(a)  A copy of all local, national, and cooperative promotions for subscriber program service or installation shall be filed with the city as soon as practicable, but in no event later than the first mailing to subscribers. 
(b)  The grantee shall not charge a subscriber for any service, or equipment, that the subscriber has not affirmatively requested by name. For the purpose of this chapter, a subscriber's failure to reuse a cable operator's proposal to provide such service, or equipment, shall not be deemed to be an affirmative request for such service or equipment. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 14, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-136. - Rights reserved to the city to adopt standards. 
(a)  The city hereby reserves the right to amend this chapter to incorporate customer service, or consumer protection, standards adopted by the FCC, or the state, if such standards are deemed to be more beneficial, or an additional benefit, to the city's residents. 
(b)  Every franchise award pursuant to this chapter shall be subject to such reserved power whether or not expressly conditioned. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 14, 11-18-93) 
Secs. 61/2-137-61/2-140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIV. - PROGRAM SERVICES 

Sec. 61/2-141. - Broad categories of service. 
(a)  The grantee shall offer broad categories of programming services designed to meet the needs and interests of the public at large, the local government, and subscribers. 
(b)  The grantee shall provide on the basic tier at least one state commercial broadcast television channel (station) that provides the community with state specific news, weather, and information. Grantee shall not be required to comply with this section if prohibited from doing so by the FCC, or if the grantee does not have retransmission consent. This provision of this chapter shall be subject to Sec. 614 of the Cable Act. 
(c)  The grantee shall provide the subscriber and the city with 30 days' advance written notice of any change in channel assignment, or in the video programming service provided over any such channel. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 15, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-142. - Requirement for viewership surveys. 
    Whenever practicable, the grantee shall conduct a survey of the subscribers to ascertain that the grantee is providing program services that meet the community needs and interests. Notwithstanding, the grantee shall conduct a viewership survey during that period of time between the provision of notice for the renewal of the cable television franchise and such time as the grantee and the city enter into negotiation of the franchise agreement. The results of the survey shall be provided to the city. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 15, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-143. - Access programming resource services. 
    The grantee shall reasonably offer to assist the city, the schools, and users of the educational and government access channels in identifying sources for produced programming which may be of benefit to said groups of users. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 15, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-144. - Local origination programming. 
    The grantee shall provide a certain number of hours annually of locally produced local origination programming that provides the subscriber with information about the state, region, the county, or the city. The number of hours shall be specified in the franchise agreement. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 15, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-145. - Emergency management programming. 
(a)  Upon request of the city, the grantee shall provide to the city, for the purpose of the public's health, welfare, and safety, a half-inch VHS videotape copy of selected Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) programming; or upon request of the city, shall provide, or make available, facilities for the reception of said programming, for the city to tape FEMA programming, or to show said programming live, through use of the grantee's cable system. 
(b)  Grantee shall make available to the city, the local law enforcement training network as provided for in the franchise agreement. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 15, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-146. - Personal communication systems/networks. 
    The grantee shall, prior to the activation of a personal communications system/network (PCN), meet with the city to establish such rules and regulations as the city deems necessary and as may be allowed under state, local and federal law. The city may enact an ordinance specific to the operation and construction of a PCN or may elect to modify this chapter for the same. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 15, 11-18-93) 
Secs. 61/2-147-61/2-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XV. - TECHNICAL REQUIREMENTS 

Sec. 61/2-151. - Channel capacity. 
    The system shall be constructed of a fiber trunkline and be engineered for a minimum 750 megahertz (MHz) system with amplifiers spaced to provide for the activation of a 550 MHz system capable of providing 60 channels of cable programming services. The grantee shall provide to the city a technical plan which describes the method the grantee will employ to provide the 750 MHz system by a date agreed to in the franchise agreement. This requirement for minimum MHz capacity shall be reviewed from time to time by the city and may be modified for franchise applicants requesting a grant for a franchise after the signing of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 16, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-152. - Channel activation. 
    Within 12 months of signing the franchise agreement, the grantee shall provide a minimum of 50 activated channels. The grantee shall provide an implementation plan to the city which clearly defines that period of time in which the system will be activated to 60 channels, and/or to the systems technical capacity. The grantee may apply to the city for a waiver of activation of any channels 60 and above and the city shall consider such waiver but shall not be required to waive the activation requirement if the city considers the enhanced activation, or the full activation, of the cable system to be in the best interest of the subscribers. Grantee may seek a reasonable extension of time for activation of the channels, if the grantee's construction is delayed through the unforeseen delay of third parties whose permission, or permit, may be required for the construction, or re-construction of the system. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 16, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-153. - Additional service requirements. 
(a)  The system shall be designed to provide FM service, community isolated P.E.G. access channels, and upstream and downstream channel capacity on the subscriber and institutional network; and may also provide in the franchise agreement for pay-per-view and interactive services. 
(b)  The system shall be engineered to provide for subscribers to purchase premium, or per channel programming, without having to subscribe to a service tier higher than the basic tier in accordance with the Cable Act, Section 623(b)(8). 
(Ord. No. 599, § 16, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-154. - Interconnection of cable systems. 
(a)  The system shall be designed in such a manner as to allow the grantee to interconnect with adjacent cable systems operated by the grantee or by the grantee's parent company, affiliate, or subsidiary. The grantee shall interconnect between said systems, for the purpose of sharing the programming on public, educational, and government access channels, upon one year of notice by the city. 
(b)  When the grantee and the city determine that it is technically and economically feasible for the grantee to interconnect the system to other cable systems adjacent to the city, but not affiliated in any manner with the grantee, the grantee shall commence said interconnect and shall complete the interconnect within one year of the decision to interconnect. 
(c)  Whenever the grantee initiates a commercial interconnect, the grantee shall notify the city that an interconnection exists and offer the city the transmission of services described in paragraph (a) above without charge. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 16, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-155. - Institutional network. 
(a)  The grantee shall provide within one year of the initiation of a franchise agreement, an institutional network that meets the identified needs of the city and that shall connect the government buildings, municipal facilities, and educational institutions identified by the city. Said government buildings may be local government facilities, buildings, and areas and may include other divisions of state and county government located within the city. 
(b)  The grantee may provide an institutional network utilizing the channel capacity of the subscriber network in such a manner so that the channel capacity available to the subscriber does not decrease to less than 50 channels; or the grantee may provide a separate institutional network trunk line. The channels provided over such a network must be secure channels of dedicated service and may not be received on the network trunk line. 
(c)  The grantee shall establish, erect, construct, and maintain the institutional network and its associated system equipment. The city, or other government entity, shall provide, with the exclusion of drops, all equipment to be used within the designated facilities, buildings, or areas to provide a particular service and shall provide for the maintenance of the aforementioned internal equipment. The city may negotiate with the grantee to install said additional equipment within the facilities. 
(d)  In lieu of providing the institutional network, the grantee may, upon approval of the city, provide a sum, agreed to in the franchise agreement, that the city may use to provide an institutional network. In the event that there is more than one franchise area within the corporate limits, all franchisees shall contribute in an equitable manner through construction or monetary funds for the provision of an institutional network. 
(e)  The institutional network shall be capable of carrying voice, full motion video, audio, and data communications. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 16, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-156. - Stereo service. 
    The grantee's cable system shall be capable of retransmitting stereo audio signals produced by commercial broadcast and radio stations and other program distributors carried on the grantee's cable system. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 16, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-157. - FM service. 
    The Grantee's system shall be capable of providing FM stereo service. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 16, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-158. - Pay-per-view. 
    The grantee's system shall be technically capable of providing pay-per-view service as may be required in the franchise agreement. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 16, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-159. - FCC technical requirements. 
    The grantee's cable system shall, at a minimum, meet the FCC's Rules For Cable Television technical standards, provided, however, that nothing contained herein shall be construed to prohibit the grantee from proposing to comply with more rigid technical performance requirements, in which, the grantee's application of said standards shall be incorporated by reference in the franchise agreement, and will be binding on the grantee. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 16, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-160. - Industry and manufacturer technical standards and specifications. 
    The grantee shall make a good faith effort to maintain and operate the cable system within the specifications by the manufacturer for the systems major components; and within cable industry accepted maintenance and operations parameters for like size cable systems. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 16, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-161. - Rights reserved to the city to adopt technical standards. 
(a)  The city hereby reserves the right to amend this chapter to incorporate technical standards which may exceed those established by the FCC, when and if said right is granted to the city through federal or state law. 
(b)  Every franchise award pursuant to this chapter shall be subject to such reserved power whether or not expressly conditioned. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 16, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-162. - Program lock-out device. 
    The grantee's system shall have the capability of allowing the subscriber to lock out a channel, or number of channels, at the discretion of the subscriber. There shall be no charge for this device or its installation. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 16, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-163. - Standby power. 
    The grantee's system shall have standby power at the headend and at the amplifiers located along the system trunk line. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 16, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-164. - Grounding of system components and subscriber drops. 
(a)  Grounding of all cable plant and subscriber drops shall be in accordance with the latest version of the National Electrical Safety Code, the National Electric Code, local ordinance and any additional provision for grounding required by the grantee's pole lease agreements with the utilities. 
(b)  Where service is provided in a mobile home park Article 550 of the National Electrical Code provides the requirements for grounding. Additionally, section 61/2-184(a) applies. 
(c)  In instances where cable television plant has been installed on privately owned poles, the safety provisions of the National Electrical Safety Code provide requirements for grounding. Additionally, section 61/2-184(a) applies. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 16, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-165. - Pole lease agreements. 
(a)  Grantee shall secure pole lease agreements with the utilities where applicable. 
(b)  Grantee shall provide to the city a copy of its pole lease agreements. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 16, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-166. - Twenty-four-hour operation. 
    The system shall be designed and shall be maintained to provide 24-hour continuous operation. 
Sec. 61/2-167. - System tests and monitoring. 
(a)  Not later than 45 days after any new, or substantially rebuilt, portion of the system is made available for service to subscribers, technical performance tests shall be conducted by the grantee to demonstrate compliance with FCC technical standards and the technical requirements of this chapter and franchise granted pursuant to this chapter. 
(b)  System monitoring test points shall be established in the franchise agreement. The city may require periodic testing to be made at the test points. 
(c)  The grantee's system shall be electronically swept at least once a year. 
(d)  The grantee shall comply with the FCC's CLI testing requirements and shall, upon detection of signal leakage above the FCC standard, notify the city of said leakage within 24 hours and provide the city with a time definite to repair said excessive signal leakage. The grantee shall provide the city with a copy of an FCC order that requires the grantee to desist service upon any channel found to be in excess of the signal leakage allowed under FCC rules and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 16, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-168. - Interference with non-subscribers or public safety communications. 
    The system shall be operated in such a manner as to avoid causing interference with reception of off-air television and radio signals, mobile telephones, amateur radio, and public safety communications. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 16, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-169. - Emergency override. 
    The grantee's system shall have an audio emergency override system that can be activated by the city. The override shall be capable of providing an audio signal over all channels of the grantee's system. Additionally, the grantee shall provide and audio/video override for a channel designated in the franchise agreement. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 16, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-170. - Signal/service interruptions. 
    The signal provided over the subscriber network may be interrupted for emergency purposes and may be interrupted for routine maintenance in accordance with the provisions of section 14 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 16, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-171. - Uniform and strong signals. 
    The grantee, through the system, shall provide uniform, strong, signals which are free from any significant distortion and interference. The system shall produce, for reception on subscriber's receivers, which are in good working order, a picture which is free from any significant interference, distortion, or ghosting which would cause any material degradation of video or audio quality. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 16, 11-18-93) 
Secs. 61/2-172-61/2-180. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVI. - PUBLIC, EDUCATION, AND GOVERNMENT ACCESS FACILITIES AND SERVICES 

Sec. 61/2-181. - Access channels. 
    Grantee shall establish and provide dedicated service access channels with a minimum of one channel for the public, one channel for the primary and secondary schools, one channel for the university/college and one channel for the city; or as may be provided in the franchise agreement. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 17, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-182. - Implementation of channels. 
    Grantee shall make the access channels available 30 days after the activation of the cable system, or the signing of the renewed franchise agreement. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 17, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-183. - Use of channels. 
(a)  The public access channel shall be made available to the residents, businesses, and institutions of the city on a first come, first served, nondiscriminatory basis with no charge for the use of the equipment or any facilities. Nothing in this chapter shall prohibit the grantee from establishing rules and regulations for the use of equipment and facilities; or for requiring a minimal deposit for equipment; or for charging a reasonable fee for the duplication of fully produced and completed programming; or for charging for videotape stock used in the provision of the master copy or duplicated copy of a program. 
(b)  The education access channels shall be made available to the schools free of charge. The grantee and a representative from each school seeking to use the education channel shall meet to determine the rules for use of the education channel; and the grantee shall provide the users with information as to sources that are available for securing independently produced programming. 
(c)  The government access channel shall be for the sole use of the city and shall be made available to the city free of charge 24 hours a day. 
(d)  The grantee shall adopt operating rules for the public and education access channels within six months of the activation of said channels. The city shall have the right to review and reasonably amend grantee's access rules and requirements. 
(e)  No access channel may be used for the carriage of commercial or non-commercial programming without the written permission of the city. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 17, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-184. - Access equipment. 
(a)  Production equipment, including field and studio equipment, which may be required for the public access, government access and education access users, shall be provided for in the franchise agreement. 
(b)  Grantee shall provide for the use of the city, at a city office, a modulator and a text insertion device. Grantee shall install and maintain the equipment, and shall provide training and technical assistance. Grantee shall replace such equipment, without charge, when it is not feasible to continue to maintain and repair same. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 17, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-185. - Access facilities. 
(a)  Grantee shall provide, as may be required in the franchise agreement, an access studio and associated television production and editing equipment to allow for the cablecasting of live and taped programming; and provide for automated playback of videotapes. 
(b)  Grantee shall provide a subscriber drop to all schools and government buildings identified in the franchise agreement and sufficient outlets. 
(1)  Grantee shall provide the schools with five outlets in classrooms determined by the school; notwithstanding the school and the grantee may agree to a lessor number or greater number of outlets. The grantee shall, upon the school's request, provide one outlet in the principal's office, or other designated non-public room. The grantee may not charge for the installation of the outlets. The grantee may charge the school for the reasonable and actual costs for internal cable wiring within the school for outlets in excels of those stipulated in this chapter or a lesser amount agreed to in the franchise agreement. Actual costs shall be for actual costs of materials and the grantee's labor. Grantee shall work with the school in determining the design of the installation. 
(2)  Grantee shall provide sufficient subscriber outlets at government facilities identified in the franchise agreement so as to meet the needs of the city. Grantee shall provide and install all outlets free of charge, but may charge the city for the actual costs of the grantee's material and labor for non-standard installation within the building or in remote areas. 
(c)  Grantee shall provide outlets to the institutional network, at no cost and without charge for installation, at all government and school building locations identified by the city. 
(d)  Grantee shall provide equipment for the cablecasting of live programming from those schools and government buildings identified in the franchise agreement. 
(e)  Access facilities shall be made accessible to handicapped individuals and the grantee shall assure that said individual shall be given such technical and physical assistance that provides them the opportunity to fully utilize and take advantage of the access facilities and equipment. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 17, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-186. - Charges for programming services. 
(a)  Grantee shall not charge school or government users a fee for basic subscriber service, institutional network service, or for convertors for said services. Grantee may charge for remote controls devices at the same rate charged other subscribers. 
(b)  Grantee shall provide an open box for the reception of all programming offered by the grantee at a location designated by the city so as to provide the city the opportunity to monitor the grantee's technical performance. 
(c)  Grantee shall provide basic subscriber service to a fire station residence quarters without charge; premium programming may be charged at the grantee's current rate to all subscribers of premium programming. 
(d)  Programming on the education access channel shall be paid for by the user. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 17, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-187. - Alternative provision of access facilities and services. 
    In lieu of providing some or all of the access facilities and services required under this chapter, the grantee may provide a sum agreed to in the franchise agreement for the city to apply towards the provision of service and facilities; however the city shall not be required to accept a sum and thus cause the grantee to be relieved from the provisions of this article of this chapter. In the event that there is more than one franchise area, or more than one cable operator within the corporate limits, all franchisees shall contribute in an equitable manner through construction, provision of equipment, cooperative training efforts, or monetary funds for the provision of access facilities and services, rather than cause a duplication of facilities or services, which the city may deem to be unnecessary. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 17, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-188. - Training of users. 
    Grantee shall provide the initial training of users of the access channels and facilities. Additional staff support may be provided for in the franchise agreement. 
Sec. 61/2-189. - Voluntary monetary contribution to access. 
    Nothing in this chapter shall prohibit the grantee from making voluntary monetary contributions for the provision and support of access in addition to the requirements of this chapter. Such voluntary monetary contributions may be provided for in the franchise agreement. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 17, 11-18-93) 
Secs. 61/2-190-61/2-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVII. - CONSTRUCTION 

Sec. 61/2-201. - Authority to construct. 
(a)  Within 30 days of the acceptance by the grantee of this franchise, the grantee shall register the system with the FCC and apply for contracts for usage of poles from electric, phone, and municipal utilities. Within 30 days after the completion of make-ready survey identifying the routes of the system facilities, the grantee shall apply for all additional licenses from the state, county, or other necessary parties such as railroads for crossing under or over their property. Within 30 days after acceptance of the franchise, the grantee shall begin any necessary microwave frequency studies to determine appropriate microwave paths and locations, and shall file for all necessary approvals from the city and FCC as soon as possible, but not later than ten months after initiation of such surveys. In any event, all necessary applications shall be applied for in a timely fashion so that such filing and processing shall not interfere with or cause delay with the construction schedule as provided in the ordinance or franchise agreement. Failure to make such timely applications and filings shall constitute a substantial violation of this chapter. The city hereby grants the grantee permission to commence construction of the cable communications system authorized herein. 
(b)  Any antenna structure used in the cable communications shall comply with the construction, marking, and lighting of antenna structure standards as required by federal and state law or regulation. 
(c)  The city will not be responsible, or have any duty, to obtain consent, licenses, permission, or easements where the city has no jurisdiction or authority to grant such consent, licenses, permissions, or easements. 
(d)  Grantee shall provide the city with monthly reports of all construction and system activities. Reports will identify the location to which service is proposed, the time at which the construction will be completed, the time for activation of the service line, the date the area has been turned over to marketing, and other information which will assist the city in determining that the grantee is extending service to the entire franchise area. 
(e)  (1)  Grantee shall provide system as built maps to the city as the system is built, or rebuilt. All of the grantee's as built maps shall, at a minimum, identify the location of the grantee's equipment on the utility poles and on the ground; the number of the utility pole passed or attached to; the name of each street; the address of each dwelling or commercial unit on all identified streets; all private roads; all roads existing but without an official name; and the location of all municipal facilities and buildings. Each map shall utilize a north-south and east-west baseline. A copy of the as-built maps shall be provided to the city upon completion of the build, or re-build, of the system. A copy of any section of the map which is modified for reasons of construction, or other changing activity, at a later date shall be filed with the city not more than 60 days after said modification. 
(2)  In addition, the grantee shall note the location of the system's trunk lines upon a city's zoning map. The zoning map may be obtained from the city clerk. The grantee shall provide the maps on an annual basis when construction activity warrants the issuance of new maps. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 18, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-202. - Compliance with construction and technical standards. 
(a)  The grantee shall establish, construct, install, operate, and maintain its system in a manner consistent with all laws, ordinances, construction standards, governmental requirements, FCC technical standards, NESC standards and detailed standards submitted by the grantee as a part of its application for a franchise which standards are incorporated by reference. 
(b)  Construction, installation, and maintenance of cable communications system shall be performed in an orderly and workmanlike manner, in accordance with then current technological standards. All cables and wires shall be installed, where possible, parallel with electric and telephone lines. Multiple cable configurations shall be arranged in parallel and bundled with due respect for engineering considerations. 
(c)  Coaxial, or other cable, installed within halls and rooms in nursing homes, hospitals and schools that connect the grantee's subscriber outlet to the subscriber's television receiver shall be attached to the wall by means of wire molding. The grantee and the subscriber shall determine the appropriate location upon the wall for the attachment of the wire molding. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 18, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-203. - Permits required. 
(a)  No construction, reconstruction, or relocation of the cable communications system, or any part thereof, within the streets shall be commenced unless written permits have been obtained from the proper city officials. In any permit so issued, such officials may impose any condition, restriction or regulation as is necessary for the purpose of protecting any structures, in the streets and for the proper restoration of such streets and structures, and for the protection of the public and the continuity of pedestrian and vehicular traffic. Upon obtaining such permits or other written approval, the grantee shall give the appropriate city official written notice of proposed construction at least 20 days prior to construction, except due to emergency conditions, during which the city engineer, or the city manager, may at his discretion waive said notice requirement. 
(b)  Prior to the erection by the grantee, or installation by the grantee of any towers, poles, underground conduits, or fixtures for use in connection with the installation, construction, maintenance or operation of the cable communications system under this franchise, the grantee shall first submit to the city engineer and other designated parties for approval a concise description of the facilities proposed to be erected or installed, including engineering drawings, if required, together with a map and plans indicating the proposed location of all such facilities. No erection or installation of any tower, pole, underground conduit, or fixture for use in a cable communications system shall be commenced by any person until approval, therefor, has been received from the city engineer provided further, that such approval shall not be unreasonably withheld. Notwithstanding such approval, however, the city shall have the right to inspect all construction or installation work performed subject to the provisions of this franchise and make such inspection as it shall find necessary to insure compliance with the terms of this franchise and other pertinent provisions of law. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 18, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-204. - Contractor qualifications. 
    Any contractor proposed for work of construction, installation, maintenance, and repair of the system must be properly licensed under the laws of the state, and all local ordinances. In addition, the grantee shall evidence a commitment to hiring persons locally for construction, installation, maintenance, and repair of system equipment (P.A. 87-0377). 
Sec. 61/2-205. - Interference with public ways prohibited. 
    The grantee's system and associated equipment erected by the grantee within the city shall be located as to cause minimum interference with the proper use of streets, alleys, and other public ways and places, and to cause minimum interference with the rights and reasonable convenience of property owners who adjoin any of the said streets, alleys, or public ways and places. No pole or other fixtures placed in any public ways by the grantee shall be placed in such a manner as to interfere with the usual travel on such public way. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 18, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-206. - Erection of poles. 
    No poles shall be erected by the grantee without the prior approval of the city engineer with regard to location, height, type and any other pertinent aspect. However, no location of any pole of the grantee shall be a vested right and such poles shall be removed or modified by the grantee at its own expense whenever the city determines that the public convenience would be enhanced thereby. The grantee shall utilize existing poles and conduits, where possible. If the city, or a public utility serving the city desires to make use of the grantee's poles, the grantee shall make every effort to accommodate the needs of the city if the city determines that such use would enhance the public convenience and if such use would not unreasonably interfere with the cable communications system operations of the grantee. Nothing in this chapter shall prohibit the grantee from entering into negotiations with a public utility for pole lease fees. 
(Ord. No. 599, § 18, 11-18-93) 
Sec. 61/2-207. - Underground installation. 
(a)  All installations shall be underground in those areas of the city where public utilities providing both telephone and electric service are underground at the time of installation. In areas where either telephone or electric utility facilities are aboveground at the time of the installation, the grantee may install its service aboveground, provided that at such time as those facilities are required to be placed underground by the city, or are placed underground, the grantee shall likewise place its services underground without additional cost to the city or to the individual subscriber so served. Where not otherwise required to be placed underground, the grantee's system shall be located underground at the request of the adjacent property owners, provided that the excess cost over aerial location shall be borne by the property owner making the request. All cable passing under the roadways shall be installed in conduit.
