(b)  Proprietors or owners shall aid and assist the person making such inspection in so doing and no person shall molest, annoy or interfere with the person so making such inspection, or make or offer any resistance to such inspection being made. 
(c)  Inspectors may take samples of food for testing and examination. Any article of food found not to meet the requirements of this chapter shall, on order of any inspector, be so disposed of as to prevent the use of the same for human consumption. 
(Ord. No. 8, 8-9-48) 
Sec. 10-13. - Penalties. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter or failing to comply with the order of any officer or inspector having power to give such order under this ordinance upon reasonable notice, shall be subject to the penalties provided in section 1-11. 
(Ord. No. 8, 8-9-48) 
Chapter 101/2 - GARBAGE AND TRASH 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 101/2-1-101/2-10. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- At the editor's discretion, Ord. No. 354, nonamendatory of the Code, has been included as art. II. 
Cross reference- Uncovered garbage, § 11-1. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 101/2-11. - System established. 
    There is hereby established a garbage and refuse collection and disposal system for the city, which shall be maintained and operated by the city as a governmental function in its corporate capacity. 
(Ord. No. 354, § 2, 6-27-77) 
Sec. 101/2-12. - System director. 
    The garbage and refuse collection and disposal system shall be under the direction and control of the commissioner of public health and safety; provided, however, that the city may, if the council so determines, collect and dispose of such garbage and refuse by contract. 
(Ord. No. 354, § 3, 6-27-77) 
Sec. 101/2-13. - Rules, regulations. 
    The council shall by resolution adopt from time to time such rules and regulations as it may deem expedient and proper governing the collection and disposal of garbage and refuse under this article. 
(Ord. No. 354, § 4, 6-27-77) 
Sec. 101/2-14. - Garbage tax. 
    The city shall for each year levy a tax against the taxable property in the city in an amount sufficient to raise the money to cover cost for the collection and disposal of garbage and refuse not in excess, however, of the maximum rate authorized by law for such purpose. Such tax, when so levied, shall be in addition to the amount authorized to be levied by the city for its general corporate purposes as authorized by law. 
(Ord. No. 354, § 5, 6-27-77) 
Sec. 101/2-15. - Charges. 
    In addition to the levy of a garbage tax, the city shall finance the collection and disposal of garbage and refuse by service charges to be collected from the persons, firms and corporations receiving service. Such service charges shall be established as can reasonably be expected to yield revenues not to exceed the cost of operation, maintenance and an adequate depreciation fund. The schedule of such charges shall be as follows: 
SCHEDULE A. PICKUP AND DISPOSAL 
A-1: City domestic residents: $13.00 per month. 
A-2: City domestic residents (apartments): Where occupants do not receive individual water bills; same as commercial and requires separate agreement with disposal company. 
A-3: Business and commercial: Separate agreement with disposal company. 
(Ord. No. 354, § 6, 6-27-77; Ord. No. 392, § 1, 2-19-79; Ord. No. 398, § 1, 7-9-79; Ord. No. 412, § 1, 7-14-80; Ord. No. 737, 6-12-00; Ord. No. 793, 7-7-03; Ord. No. 956, 7-12-10; Ord. No. 993, 8-19-13) 
Sec. 101/2-16. - Billing. 
    The city shall mail bills for the collection and disposal of garbage and refuse service charges on a monthly basis, and the city water department is hereby directed and authorized to state the amount due for such services on the same postcards as the monthly water and sewer bill. In the event that the users of garbage and refuse collection and disposal service do not receive a water and sewer bill, charges for such service shall be billed in a manner prescribed by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 354, § 7, 6-27-77) 
Sec. 101/2-17. - Containers. 
(a)  All garbage and refuse for collection by the city shall be placed in containers equipped with a cover or with handles so that the container may be lifted by one man, or shall be placed in a plastic bag and tied securely at top. No container shall have the capacity of more than 30 gallons. All containers shall be removed from the city right-of-way within 24 hours after garbage collection by the city. 
(b)  All garbage or refuse for collection shall only be placed on the city right-of-way within the 48-hour period prior to the normal collection time for garbage pickup at that location. 
(c)  The placement of garbage and refuse hereunder is subject to all of the penalties and conditions as set out in this chapter of the Code. 
(Ord. No. 354, § 8, 6-27-77; Ord. No. 611, 9-26-94) 
Sec. 101/2-18. - Failure to pay charges. 
    When the occupant of any premises, or the owner of any apartment building fails or refuses to pay the service charges as provided herein, the commissioner of public health and safety or such other person as he may designate shall notify the occupant or owner of such fact, and shall refuse further collections and disposal until the required fee is paid. 
(Ord. No. 354, § 9, 6-27-77) 
Sec. 101/2-19. - Dumping prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to dump or place any garbage, refuse, trash, ashes, and junked appliances or vehicles on any premises within the corporate limits. 
(Ord. No. 354, § 10, 6-27-77) 
Sec. 101/2-20. - Penalty; presumption of violation. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this article shall be fined not less than $50.00 nor more than $200.00 for each offense; and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
    The fact that garbage, refuse, trash, ashes, junked appliances or vehicles remain on the premises of any occupant or owner within the city limits in violation of this article, shall be prima facie evidence that the occupant or owner of such premises is responsible for the violation occurring. 
(Ord. No. 354, § 11, 6-27-77; Ord. No. 994, 8-19-13) 
Cross reference- Junked articles as nuisances, § 16-26. 
Sec. 101/2-21. - Copy of charges to be furnished on request. 
    A copy of the schedule of rates set out herein shall be furnished, upon request, to each customer receiving garbage and refuse collection and disposal service. 
(Ord. No. 354, § 12, 6-27-77) 
DIVISION 2. - YARD WASTE 

Sec. 101/2-22. - Placing yard and landscape waste in or among other waste materials prohibited. 
    Commencing July 1, 1990 it shall be prohibited to place yard and landscape waste in or among other waste materials to be collected and disposed of, either by private contractor or by the City of Mt. Carmel. 
(Ord. No. 568, § 1, 3-30-92) 
Sec. 101/2-23. - Yard and landscape waste defined. 
    Yard and landscape waste is hereby defined as grass clippings, leaves, twigs, weeds or other yard and garden waste of such size and nature which is suitable for the city's compost site. Yard and landscape waste shall not include tree limbs, brush and other woody material. 
(Ord. No. 568, § 1, 3-30-92; Ord. No. 586, § 1, 3-1-93) 
Sec. 101/2-24. - Containers. 
(a)  Yard and landscape waste intended for collection and disposal by the city shall be placed in biodegradable plastic bags, water resistant paper bags or rigid containers, none of which shall exceed 32 gallons capacity. 
(b)  During the period between October 1 and December 31, unless otherwise determined by the city council, during operation of the city's fall leaf collection program, loose leaves may be collected along the curbside, or unimproved right-of-way, of any street within the city for collection by the leaf vacuum trucks at no charge. 
(Ord. No. 568, § 1, 3-30-92; Ord. No. 586, § 1, 3-1-93) 
Sec. 101/2-25. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 993, adopted August 19, 2013, amended the Code by repealing former § 101/2-25 in its entirety. Former § 101/2-25 pertained to time of pick up and required sticker, and derived from Ord. No. 568, adopted March 30, 1992; and Ord. No. 386, adopted March 1, 1993. 
Sec. 101/2-26. - Compost site hours. 
    Yard waste, as herein defined, may be disposed of at the collection area of the city compost site during designated hours on Mondays through Fridays, unless otherwise permitted by city council. Such hours of operation shall be clearly posted at the compost site, and materials taken to the collection area of said site will not be required to be placed in containers. It shall be unlawful for any individual to leave or deposit yard waste at the compost site unless there is an attendant at such site to accept and inspect yard waste. 
(Ord. No. 568, § 1, 3-30-92; Ord. No. 720, 8-23-99) 
Sec. 101/2-27. - Disposal of other traditional waste materials other than yard and landscaping waste at compost site prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to place yard and landscape waste in with other traditional waste materials intended for collection and disposal, and further; it shall be unlawful to place any waste except for yard and landscape waste, as herein defined, at the collection area of the city compost site. The penalty for violation of any section of this article is prescribed in section 101/2-20. 
(Ord. No. 568, § 1, 3-30-92) 
Sec. 101/2-27.1. - Trash at city trash collection site on Golden Aces Way. 
    Residents of the city who obtain a dump ticket at city hall from the city, may dispose of trash at the city trash collection site on Golden Aces Way subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  City residents may obtain a dump ticket for the disposal of traditional trash at the city trash collection site. The fee for such dump ticket shall be $20.00 per load for a truck with a bed eight feet or less in length or a trailer eight feet or less in length. A fee of $40.00 per load shall apply to trucks or trailers having a bed or length over eight feet in length and the following sections are hereby so amended; and 
(2)  Such trash may be deposited at the city trash collection site only after obtaining a dump ticket and at such times as an authorized city attendant is present. 
(3)  Any items or appliances containing refrigerants must be properly tagged by an individual properly licensed to perform the removal of refrigerants. 
(4)  A dump ticket shall be valid only one time. 
(5)  The penalty for altering any dump ticket shall be a fine of $100.00. 
(6)  The penalty for violation of this section shall be as proscribed in section 101/2-46 hereof. 
(Ord. No. 752, 2-19-01; Ord. No. 951, 5-3-10) 
ARTICLE III. - TREE LIMBS, BRUSH AND OTHER WOODY MATERIAL 

Sec. 101/2-28. - Tree limbs, brush and other woody material-Disposal. 
    It is prohibited to place tree limbs, brush and other woody material in or among other waste materials to be collected or disposed of either by private contractor or by the city and such woody material shall not be commingled with yard and landscape waste. Such woody material shall be placed at the same location as the pickup for other waste materials collected and disposed of by a private contractor or the city. 
(Ord. No. 586, § 1, 3-1-93; Ord. No. 595, § 1, 8-16-93) 
Sec. 101/2-29. - Same-Generated by private contractors. 
    Tree limbs, brush and other woody material generated by private contractors for hire shall be the responsibility of such private contractors and all such material will be disposed of by said private contractors and the city shall not be responsible or obligated to pickup such material. 
(Ord. No. 586, § 1, 3-1-93; Ord. No. 595, § 1, 8-16-93) 
Secs. 101/2-30-101/2-40. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 993, adopted August 19, 2013, amended the Code by repealing former §§ 101/2-30 and 101/2-31 in their entirety. Former 101/2-30 pertained to the fee for pickup of tree limbs, brush and other woody material, and derived from Ord. No. 586, adopted March 1, 1993; and Ord. No. 595, adopted August 16, 1993. Former § 101/2-31 pertained to fees for use of city dumpster, and derived from Ord. No. 586, adopted March 1, 1993. 
ARTICLE IV. - UNAUTHORIZED COLLECTION OF RECYCLABLE MATERIALS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 530, adopted Oct. 2, 1989, did not specifically amend this Code, hence, inclusion of §§ 1-4 as ch. 101/2, Art. IV, §§ 101/2-41-101/2-44 was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 101/2-41. - Definitions. 
    Authorized recyclable materials scavenger, as used in this article, shall mean K/C Disposal and Recycling, Mt. Carmel, Illinois, or their successor. 
    City, as used in this ordinance, shall mean the City of Mt. Carmel, Illinois. 
    Recyclable materials, as used in this ordinance, shall mean newspapers, cardboard, glass bottles, plastics, aluminum cans and other aluminum products or other designated recyclables. 
(Ord. No. 530, § 1, 10-2-89) 
Sec. 101/2-42. - Recyclable materials property of the city. 
    From the time of placement in the front yard or at the curb line, or alleyway, of any residence or other designated pick up area by any person of recyclable materials for collection by the city, or the authorized recyclables materials scavenger, such recyclable materials shall be and become the property of the city, or its authorized recyclable scavenger. It shall be a violation of this article for any person unauthorized by the authorized recyclable materials scavenger to collect or pick up, or cause to be collected or picked up, any such recyclable materials. Any and each such collection in violation hereof from one or more residences or premises shall constitute a separate and distinct offense punishable as hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. No. 530, § 2, 10-2-89) 
Sec. 101/2-43. - Unlawful removal of recyclable materials. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, partnership or corporation to take, remove, collect or in any manner interfere with or disturb any recyclable materials which have been deposited outside any dwelling, business establishment or any premises within the city which have been set out for the purpose of collection. 
(Ord. No. 530, § 3, 10-2-89) 
Sec. 101/2-44. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm, partnership or corporation violating any provision of this article shall be fined not less than $50.00, nor more than $500.00 for each offense. 
(Ord. No. 530, § 4, 10-2-89) 
ARTICLE V. - UNAUTHORIZED COLLECTION OF GARBAGE AND REFUSE 

Sec. 101/2-45. - Prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, partnership or corporation to take, remove, collect or in any manner interfere with the disposal of garbage or refuse within the city, without first having obtained a written contract with the city allowing such activity. 
(Ord. No. 653, 7-1-96) 
Sec. 101/2-46. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm, partnership or corporation violating any provision of this article shall be fined not less than $50.00 nor more than $500.00 for each offense. Where a person, firm, partnership or corporation has placed within the city a dumpster, container, receptacle or collection device in violation of this article, each day that such dumpster, container, receptacle or collection device remains within the city shall be considered a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 653, 7-1-96) 
Chapter 11 - HEALTH AND SANITATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Nuisances generally, § 16-23 et seq. 
State Law reference- Health powers of the city generally, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 11-16-1 et seq.; authority of city to promulgate health regulations, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 11-20-5. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 11-1. - Uncovered garbage, refuse prohibited; declared nuisance. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit anywhere in the city any uncovered piles of refuse or garbage, or any material subject to decay, other than leaves or grass. 
(b)  Any such accumulation of refuse or garbage not tightly covered is hereby declared a nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 119, § 2, 6-1-64) 
Sec. 11-2. - Acts endangering public health prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to commit or do any act which endangers the public health or results in annoyance or discomfort to the public. 
(Ord. No. 119, § 1, 6-1-64) 
Sec. 11-3. - Specific health nuisances designated. 
    In addition to those things elsewhere in the chapter declared to be nuisances, it shall be unlawful and a nuisance for any person to: 
(1)  Obstruct or pollute any watercourse or source of water supply in the city. 
(2)  Permit any stagnant pool of water to remain or exist on any property under his or its control in the city. 
(3)  Permit any building, structure or place in the city to remain in such condition as to be dangerous to the public health in any way. 
(4)  Permit, cause or create an open drain sewer or cesspool, or any unsightly, nauseous or unhealthful condition by failing to properly dispose of sewage, or refuse in the city. 
(5)  Deposit, discard, dump, throw or discharge onto any public street or sidewalk any litter, including grass clippings or other lawn or garden waste, or anything else of an unsightly or unsanitary nature. 
(6)  Allow litter to accumulate upon real property of which the person charged is the owner or tenant in control, in such a manner as to constitute a public nuisance or in such a manner that the litter may be blown or otherwise carried by the natural elements onto the real property of another person. 
(Ord. 119, § 3, 6-1-64; Ord. No. 822, 6-7-04) 
Cross reference- Nuisances generally, § 16-23 et seq. 
Sec. 11-4. - Maintaining nuisance; authority to abate. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain the existence of any nuisance on any property under his or its control. 
(b)  The chief of police is hereby authorized to abate any such nuisance existing in the city whether or not such nuisance is specifically recognized by this chapter or other ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. No. 119, § 4, 6-1-64) 
Sec. 11-5. - Notice to abate nuisance; service of notice. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of police to serve or cause to be served personal notice upon the owner or occupant of any premises on which exists or is permitted to exist a nuisance, and to demand abatement of the nuisance within ten days. If such owner cannot be found in the city or is a nonresident of the city, written notice shall be served by a registered mail and by publication at least once in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. 
(Ord. No. 119, § 5, 6-1-64) 
Sec. 11-6. - Costs when city required to abate nuisance. 
    If the city removes or abates any condition described in this article as a nuisance by this article, the assessment of the cost of the work done by the city against the owner of the premises involved shall be in addition to all other penalties imposed for any violation or noncompliance with any provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 119, § 2, 6-1-64) 
Cross reference- Nuisances generally, § 16-23 et seq. 
Sec. 11-7. - Penalties. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article by failing, neglecting or refusing to comply with the provisions of any notice herein provided for, within ten days after the service thereof, shall be guilty of an offense punishable as provided in section 1-11. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. 119, § 7, 6-1-64) 
Secs. 11-8-11-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BOARD OF HEALTH[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Power of city to establish board of health, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 11-16-1. 

Sec. 11-19. - Created; composition. 
    There is hereby created the Mount Carmel Board of Health, consisting of the mayor and all of the commissioners. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 4-1) 
Sec. 11-20. - Chairman; ex officio clerk. 
(a)  The commissioner of health and public safety shall be chairman of the city board of health. 
(b)  The city clerk shall be ex officio clerk of said board. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 4-1) 
Cross reference- Duties of city clerk, § 2-111. 
Sec. 11-21. - Meetings. 
    The board of health shall meet at the call of the chairman or of the mayor at any time it may be deemed necessary. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 4-1) 
Sec. 11-22. - General powers and duties. 
    The powers and duties of the board of health shall be, and it shall function as follows: 
(1)  The board shall have full and complete authority to pass any orders relative to the protection of the general health of the city, which it may deem necessary, and which are not in conflict with the state laws. The board shall also enforce the laws of the state and the orders, rules and regulations of the state board of health pertaining to the public health. Such orders of the board as are published in a newspaper in the city shall be considered notice to all citizens. 
(2)  The board shall exercise general supervision over the public health of the city, and shall make diligent inquiry and examination into all matters affecting the same; and shall cause all nuisances to be abated or removed which it may deem prejudicial or obnoxious to the public health or comfort. The board shall enforce all ordinances and state laws pertaining to the sale and distribution of food and may make such sanitary and quarantine and vaccination regulations and orders as it may deem expedient or necessary to preserve or promote the same, or to prevent the introduction or spreading of any contagious, malignant, infectious, pestilential or other disease, and when they deem it necessary, shall have the power during an emergency to appoint a committee of safety, consisting of not exceeding 12 persons, resident citizens of the city, who shall perform such duties as may be required of them by the board, which committee shall have such power as may be conferred upon it by the board. 
(3)  Copies of such orders of the board as require enforcement shall be certified by the clerk; and the commissioner of health and public safety, or the mayor shall cause the same to be executed by delivering such copy to the chief of police, who shall execute all orders of the board of health or of the council, pertaining to the public health or sanitary conditions of the city. 
(4)  All nuisances shall be abated, and all quarantine and sanitary regulations shall be enforced and carried out at the expense of the guilty party or the party affected thereby, where such party is able to pay, otherwise the cost shall be borne by the city. 
(5)  It shall be the duty of every physician having or treating a patient afflicted with any contagious disease to forthwith report such fact and the nature of the disease to the city clerk, and in case such a disease exists where there is no attending physician, the person in charge of such sick person shall make such report. 
(6)  The members of the board or any person designated by them, and the chief of police, shall have free and unmolested access to all premises where it may be reasonably necessary to carry out the provisions of this section, and no person shall refuse, prevent or interfere with such access. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 4-1) 
Secs. 11-23-11-33. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - WEEDS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Note- See also § 16-25. 

Sec. 11-34. - Certain weeds declared nuisance. 
    Any weeds, grass or plants other than trees, shrubs, flowers or other ornamental plants that have been allowed to grow to a height exceeding eight inches anywhere in the city and any weeds such as jimson, burdock, ragweed, thistle, cocklebur or other weeds of like kind found growing in any lot or tract of land in the city are hereby declared to be a nuisance, and it shall be unlawful to permit any such weeds to grow or remain in any such place. 
(Ord. No. 118, §§ 1, 2, 61-64; Ord. No. 1027, 1-19-15) 
Cross reference- Nuisances generally, § 16-23 et seq. 
Sec. 11-35. - Notice to abate nuisance. 
    If the city inspector determines that a weed violation has been found, he shall issue a warning letter. The first time notices shall be mailed to any property owner whose property is currently in violation. Such letter shall allow seven days from the date of the notice to mow all high weeds on property. Said letter shall serve as a warning for the entire year. If subsequent violations are observed after receiving the first time notice, the city will immediately enter upon the properly and remove high weeds and grass in accordance with section 11-36. The city will not notify property owner every time the property is in violation. The property owner will receive only one written warning per parcel of land. This serves as a notice for the entire year. 
(Ord. No. 118, § 3, 6-1-64; Ord. No. 767, 9-4-01; Ord. No. 1027, 1-19-15) 
Sec. 11-36. - Abatement by city upon failure of owner to comply with notice; expenses. 
(a)  If the person so notified does not abate the nuisance within seven days, the city may proceed to abate such nuisance, keeping account of the expense of the abatement. In addition hereto, there shall be assed an abatement fee of $75.00 for the first abatement, a fee of $150.00 for the second abatement, and a fee of $300.00 for the third and each additional abatement within a calendar year. 
(b)  If the city removes from any lot or parcel of land in the city any obnoxious weeds or plants growing in violation of this article the expense of such removal shall be an assessment against the owner or occupant of the premises involved and shall be in addition to the penalties imposed herein for any violation or noncompliance with any provision of this article. 
(Ord. No. 118, §§ 4, 5, 6-1-64; Ord. No. 767, 9-4-01; Ord. No. 951, 5-3-10; Ord. No. 1027, 1-19-15) 
Sec. 11-37. - Penalties. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article by failing, neglecting or refusing to comply with the provisions of any notice herein provided for within ten days after the service thereof or who shall resist or obstruct the carrying out the provisions of this article shall be guilty of an offense punishable as provided in section 1-11. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. 118, § 6, 6-1-64) 
Chapter 12 - HOUSING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Duties of city inspector, § 2-144; pets prohibited in federally assisted or subsidized facilities, § 5-1; buildings and building regulations, ch. 6; zoning, app. A. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 12-1. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section: 
    Apartment shall mean a self-contained unit with private bath and cooking facilities. 
    Basement shall mean a portion of a building located partly underground, but having less than half its clear floor-to-ceiling height below the average grade of the adjoining ground. 
    Cellar shall mean a portion of a building located partly or wholly underground, and having half or more than half of its clear floor-to-ceiling height below the average grade of the adjoining ground. 
    Dwelling shall mean any building which is wholly or partly used or intended to be used for living or sleeping by human occupants; provided that temporary housing as hereinafter defined shall not be regarded as a dwelling. 
    Dwelling unit shall mean any room or group of rooms located within a dwelling and forming a single habitable unit with facilities which are used or intended to be used for living, sleeping, cooking and eating purposes. 
    Extermination shall mean the control and elimination of insects, rodents and other pests. 
    Garbage shall mean the vegetable and animal waste resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food. 
    Habitable room shall mean a room or enclosed floor space used or intended to be used for living, sleeping, cooking or eating purposes, including bathrooms, water closet compartments, laundries, pantries, foyers or communicating corridors, closets and storage spaces. 
    Infestation shall mean the presence, within or around a dwelling, of any insects, rodents or other pests. 
    Multiple dwelling shall mean any dwelling containing more than two dwelling units. 
    Occupant shall mean any person, over one year of age, living, sleeping, cooking or eating in, or having actual possession of, a dwelling unit or rooming unit. 
    Operator shall mean any person who has charge, care or control of a building, or part thereof, in which dwelling units or rooming units are let. 
    Owner shall mean any person who, alone or jointly or severally with others, who shall: 
(1)  Have legal title to any dwelling or dwelling unit, with or without accompanying actual possession thereof; or 
(2)  Have charge, care or control of any dwelling or dwelling unit, as owner or agent of the owner, or as executor, administrator, trustee or guardian of the estate of the owner. 
    Plumbing shall mean and include all of the following supplied facilities and equipment: Gas pipes, gas-burning equipment, water pipes, garbage disposal units, waste pipes, water closets, sinks, installed dishwashers, lavatories, bathtubs, shower baths, installed clothes washing machines, catch basins, drains, vents and any other similar supplied fixtures, together with all connections to water, sewer or gas lines. 
    Rooming house shall mean any building or portion of a building other than a hotel, motel, apartment hotel or residential hotel, in which sleeping accommodations not constituting an apartment are furnished at a fee for four or more persons ordinarily renting such accommodations at a specified rate for a specified time, and occupying the premises as a permanent place of abode rather than on a transient basis for a short term period of occupancy. 
    Rubbish shall mean combustible and noncombustible waste materials, except garbage, and the term shall include the residue from the burning of wood, coal, coke and other combustible material, paper, rags, cartons, boxes, wood, excelsior, rubber, leather, tree branches, yard trimmings, tin cans, metals, mineral matter, glass, crockery, etc. 
    Supplied shall mean paid for, furnished or provided by or under the control of, the owner, or operator. 
    Temporary housing shall mean any tent, trailer, or other structure used for human shelter which is designed to be transportable and which is not attached to the ground, to another structure, or to any utilities system on the same premises for more than 30 consecutive days. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-1, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-2. - Construction of certain words and phrases. 
    Whenever the words "dwelling," "dwelling unit," "rooming house," "rooming unit," or "premises," are used in this chapter, they shall be construed as though they were followed by the words "or any part thereof." 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-1, 8-22-67) 
Secs. 12-3-12-13. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 12-14-12-20. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ENFORCEMENT PROCEDURE 

Sec. 12-21. - Inspections required; right of entry. 
(a)  The city inspector and his designated agents are hereby authorized and directed to make inspections to determine the conditions of dwellings, dwelling units, rooming units and premises. 
(b)  All persons residing within the corporate limits of the city shall permit the city inspector or his designated agents to enter upon premises owned or occupied by them for the purpose of making such inspections during regular business hours on weekdays. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-2, 8-22-67) 
Cross reference- City inspector, § 2-142 et seq. 
Sec. 12-22. - Notice of violation; contents; service. 
(a)  Whenever the city inspector determines that there are reasonable grounds to believe that there has been a violation of any provision of this chapter, he shall give notice of such alleged violation to the person or persons responsible therefor. Such notice shall be in writing stating the reasons for its issuance. It shall state a reasonable time for the performance of any act it requires and shall be served upon the owner or his agent, or the occupant, as the case may require. 
(b)  Such notice shall be deemed to be properly served upon such owner or agent, or upon such occupant, if a copy thereof is served upon him personally, or if a copy thereof is sent by registered mail to his last known address, or if a copy thereof is posted in a conspicuous place in or about the dwelling affected by the notice, or if he is served with such notice by any other method authorized or required by state law. 
(c)  The notice may contain an outline of remedial action which, if taken, will effect compliance with the provisions of this chapter and with rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereto. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-3, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-23. - City inspector may issue emergency order without inspection. 
    Whenever the city inspector finds that an emergency exists which requires immediate action to protect the public health, he may, without notice or hearing, issue an order reciting the existence of such an emergency and requiring that such action be taken as he deems necessary to meet the emergency. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-3, 8-22-67) 
Secs. 12-24-12-29. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - UNFIT DWELLINGS 

Sec. 12-30. - Grounds for declaring dwelling unfit for human habitation. 
    Any dwelling or dwelling unit which shall be found to have any of the following defects shall be proscribed as unfit for human habitation or required to be brought up to standards of this chapter and shall be so designated and placarded by the city inspector or his designated agents: 
(1)  The structure is so damaged, decayed, dilapidated, unsanitary, unsafe or vermin-infested that it creates a serious hazard to the health or safety of the occupants or of the public. 
(2)  The structure lacks illumination, ventilation or sanitation facilities adequate to protect the health or safety of the occupants or the public. 
(3)  The structure, because of its general condition or location, is unsanitary or otherwise dangerous to the health or safety of the occupants or the public. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-10, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-31. - Vacation of unfit dwelling. 
(a)  Any dwelling or dwelling unit proscribed as unfit for human habitation, and so designated and placarded shall be vacated within a reasonable time as ordered by the city inspector. 
(b)  No dwelling or dwelling unit which has been proscribed and placarded as unfit for human habitation shall again be used for human habitation until written approval is secured from and such placard is removed by the city inspector. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-10, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-32. - Removal of placard. 
    No person shall deface or remove the placard from any dwelling or dwelling unit which has been proscribed as unfit for human habitation and placarded as such, except as provided in this division. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-10, 8-22-67) 
Secs. 12-33-12-43. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - MINIMUM STANDARDS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 12-44. - Units not to be occupied unless in conformance with this article. 
    No person shall occupy as owner-occupant or permit another to occupy any dwelling or dwelling unit unless it is in full compliance with all the applicable provisions of this article and the rules and regulations pursuant thereto. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-4, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-45. - Garbage disposal or storage facilities. 
    Each dwelling unit shall have adequate garbage disposal facilities or garbage storage containers, the type and location of which shall conform to the applicable provisions of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-4, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-46. - Rubbish storage facilities. 
    Each dwelling unit shall be supplied with adequate rubbish storage facilities, the type and location of which shall conform to the applicable provisions of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-4, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-47. - Means of egress. 
    Every dwelling unit shall have safe, unobstructed means of egress leading to safe and open space at ground level, as required by the laws of the state and the provisions of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-4, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-48. - Electricity. 
    Every dwelling unit shall be supplied with electricity and have at least one electric outlet in each habitable room. Electric wiring and fixtures shall be properly installed and maintained in safe working condition. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-6, 8-22-67) 
Cross reference- National Electrical Code, § 6-41 et seq. 
Secs. 12-49-12-54. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - WASHING AND TOILET FACILITIES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Water and sewers, Ch. 21. 

Sec. 12-55. - Kitchen sink. 
    Each dwelling unit shall contain a kitchen sink in good working condition and properly connected to hot and cold water lines and sewers. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-4, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-56. - Toilet facilities. 
    Every dwelling unit shall contain a toilet room which affords privacy to a person within said room and which is equipped with a flush water closet and a lavatory basin in good working condition and properly connected to a water and sewer system. The toilet shall not be within a room intended to be used for living, sleeping, cooking or eating purposes. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-4, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-57. - Bathing facilities. 
    Every dwelling unit shall contain, within a room which affords privacy to a person within said room, a bathtub or shower and lavatory basin in good working condition and properly connected to a water and sewer system. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-4, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-58. - Hot and cold water. 
    Every kitchen sink, lavatory basin and bathtub or shower required under the provisions of this division shall be properly connected to both hot and cold water lines. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-4, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-59. - Water heating facilities. 
    Every dwelling shall have water heating facilities which are properly installed and connected with the hot water lines required under the preceding paragraph, and are capable of heating water to such a temperature as to permit adequate amount of water to be drawn at every required kitchen sink, lavatory basin, tub or shower at a temperature of not less than 120 degrees Fahrenheit. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-4, 8-22-67) 
Secs. 12-60-12-65. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - LIGHTS, VENTILATION AND HEATING 

Sec. 12-66. - Window or skylight required; minimum area. 
    Every habitable room shall have at least one window or skylight facing directly to the outdoors. The minimum total window area for every habitable room shall be at least 10 per cent of the floor area of such room. Whenever walls or other portions of structures are located less than three feet from the window and extend to a level above that of the ceiling of the room, such a window shall not be deemed to face directly to the outdoors and shall not be included as contributing to the minimum total window area. Whenever the only window is the skylight type window in the top of such room, the total window area of such skylight shall equal at least 121/2 per cent of the total floor area of the room. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-5, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-67. - Ventilation required. 
    Every habitable room shall have at least one window or skylight which can easily be opened or such other device as will adequately ventilate the room. The total of openable window area in every habitable room shall be equal to at least 45 per cent of the minimum window area size or minimum skylight type window size, as required in the above paragraph, except where there is supplied some other device affording adequate ventilation and approved by the city inspector. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-5, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-68. - Bathrooms. 
    Every bathroom and water closet compartment shall comply with the light and ventilation requirements for applicable rooms prescribed in this division, except that no window or skylight shall be required in adequately ventilated systems which are kept in continuous operation and approved by the city inspector. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-5, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-69. - Heating facilities generally. 
    Every dwelling shall have heating facilities which are properly installed, are maintained in safe and good working condition, and are capable of safely and adequately heating all habitable rooms, bathrooms and water closet compartments in every dwelling unit located therein to a temperature of at least 70 degrees Fahrenheit, at a distance three feet above floor level, under ordinary minimum winter conditions. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-5, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-70. - Lighting of stairs and corridors. 
    Every public hall and stairway in every multiple dwelling containing five or more dwelling units shall be adequately lighted at all times. Every public hall and stairway in structures devoted solely to dwelling occupancy and containing not more than four dwelling units may be supplied with conveniently located light switches, controlling an adequate lighting system which may be turned on when needed, instead of full-time lighting. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-5, 8-22-67) 
Secs. 12-71-12-76. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - MAINTENANCE 

Sec. 12-77. - General requirements. 
    Every supplied facility, piece of equipment, or utility which is required under this article shall be so constructed or installed that it will function safely and effectively, and shall be maintained in satisfactory working condition. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-6, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-78. - Foundation, floors, walls, ceilings and roofs. 
    Every foundation, floor, wall, ceiling and roof shall be reasonably weathertight, watertight and rodentproof; and shall be kept in reasonably sound working condition and good repair. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-6, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-79. - Stairs and porches. 
    Every inside and outside stair, every porch, and every appurtenance thereto shall be so constructed as to be safe to use and capable of supporting the load that normal use may cause to be placed thereon; and shall be kept in sound condition and good repair. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-6, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-80. - Plumbing. 
    Every plumbing fixture and water and waste pipe shall be properly installed and maintained in good sanitary working condition, free from defects, leaks and obstructions. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-6, 8-22-67) 
Secs. 12-81-12-86. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - SPACE AND USE 

Sec. 12-87. - Floor area generally. 
    Every dwelling unit shall contain at least 150 square feet floor space for the first occupant thereof and at least 100 additional square feet of floor space for every additional occupant thereof, the floor space to be calculated on the basis of total habitable room area. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-7, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-88. - Floor area in bedroom. 
    In every dwelling unit of two or more rooms, every room occupied for sleeping purposes by one occupant shall contain at least 70 square feet of floor space, and every room occupied for sleeping purposes by more than one occupant shall contain at least 50 square feet of floor space for each occupant thereof. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-7, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-89. - Room arrangement. 
    No dwelling or dwelling unit containing two or more sleeping rooms shall have such room arrangements that access to a bathroom or water closet intended for use by occupants of more than one sleeping room can be had only by going through another sleeping room or a bathroom or water closet compartment; nor shall room arrangements be such that access to a sleeping room can be had only by going through another sleeping room or a bathroom or water closet compartment. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-7, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-90. - Ceiling height. 
    At least one-half of the floor area of every habitable room shall have a ceiling height of at least seven feet; and the floor area of that part of any room where the ceiling height is less than five feet shall not be considered as part of the floor area in computing the total floor area of the room for the purpose of determining the maximum permissible occupancy thereof. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-7, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-91. - Basement space. 
    No basement and/or cellar space shall be used as a habitable room or dwelling unit unless: 
(1)  The floor and walls are impervious to leakage of underground and surface runoff water and are insulated against dampness. 
(2)  The total of the window area in each room is equal to at least the minimum window area sizes required under section 12-66, except where there is supplied some other device affording adequate ventilation and approved by the city inspector. 
(3)  The clear inner height is at least six feet eight inches and no pipes and beams are below six feet from lower level. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-7, 8-22-67) 
Secs. 12-92-12-97. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - RESPONSIBILITIES OF OWNERS AND OCCUPANTS 

Sec. 12-98. - Cleanliness of public areas of premises. 
    Every occupant of a dwelling containing two or more dwelling units shall be responsible for maintaining in a clean and sanitary condition the shared or public area of the dwelling and premises thereof. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-8, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-99. - Cleanliness of private areas of premises. 
    Every occupant of a dwelling or dwelling unit shall keep in a clean and sanitary condition that part of the dwelling, dwelling unit and premises thereof which he occupies and controls. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-8, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-100. - Garbage and rubbish disposal. 
    Every occupant of a dwelling or dwelling unit shall dispose of all his rubbish, garbage and any other organic waste which might provide food for rodents, in a clean and sanitary manner as provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-8, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-101. - Extermination of insects and rodents. 
    Every occupant of a dwelling unit shall be responsible for the extermination of any insects, rodents or other pests therein or on the premises. Whenever infestation is caused by failure of the owner to maintain a dwelling in a rodent proof or reasonably insectproof condition, extermination shall be the responsibility of the owner. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-8, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-102. - Plumbing. 
    Every occupant of a dwelling unit shall keep all plumbing fixtures therein in a clean and sanitary condition and shall be responsible for the exercise of reasonable care in the proper use and operation thereof. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-8, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-103. - Heating. 
    Every owner or operator of a building who permits to be occupied any dwelling unit or rooming unit herein under an agreement, express or implied, to the occupants thereof, shall supply heat adequate to maintain therein from the fifteenth day of September through the thirtieth day of May of the following year, a minimum inside temperature of 70 degrees Fahrenheit at three feet above floor level based on outside design temperature in all habitable rooms, bathrooms, shower rooms and toilet rooms or compartments, between the hours of 6:30 a.m. and 11:00 p.m. and not less than 60 degrees Fahrenheit between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 6:30 a.m. in all such rooms. Provisions of this section shall not apply where the failure to maintain minimum requirements is caused by a general shortage of fuel, neglect or malicious act to the occupant, necessary repairs or alteration, or any cause beyond the control of the owner or occupant. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-8, 8-22-67) 
Secs. 12-104-12-114. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - HOTELS, MOTELS AND ROOMING HOUSES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 12-115. - Applicability of this article to hotels and motels. 
    Every provision of this article which applies to rooming houses shall also apply to hotels and motels except to the extent that any such provision may be found in conflict with the laws of the state or with the lawful regulations of any state board or agency. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-9, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-116. - Conformity with chapter required; exceptions. 
    No persons shall operate a rooming house or shall occupy or let to another for occupancy any rooming house, except in compliance with the provisions of every section of this chapter, except the provisions of sections 12-44 through 12-47 and 12-55 through 12-59, and sections 12-98 through 12-103. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-9, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-117. - Cleanliness and sanitation. 
    The owner or operator of every rooming house shall be responsible for the sanitary maintenance of all walls, floors and ceilings, and the maintenance of a sanitary condition in every other part of the rooming house; and he shall be further responsible for the sanitary maintenance of the entire premises where the entire structure or building is leased or occupied by the operator. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-9, 8-22-67) 
Secs. 12-118-12-123. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMITS 

Sec. 12-124. - Required. 
    No persons shall operate a rooming house unless he holds a valid rooming house permit issued by the city inspector in the name of the operator and for the specific dwelling or dwelling unit. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-9, 8-22-75) 
Sec. 12-125. - Application; inspection. 
    A person desiring a permit required by this division shall apply to the city clerk therefor, which permit shall be issued by the city inspector upon inspection and upon compliance by the operator with the applicable provisions of this chapter and of any rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereto. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-9, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-126. - Annual fee. 
    The annual fee for such permit shall be $2.00 per sleeping room. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-9, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-127. - Expiration date; penalty for late renewal. 
(a)  Each permit issued pursuant to this division shall expire on the first day of January of the year following the year of issuance unless sooner suspended or revoked, as provided in this division. 
(b)  Permits not renewed by the last day of January of each year shall be charged a penalty of $1.00 per month for each month overdue. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-9, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-128. - Transferability. 
    No permit issued pursuant to this division shall be transferable. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-9, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-129. - Display. 
    Each permit issued pursuant to this division shall be displayed at all times in a conspicuous place within the rooming house. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-9, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-130. - Notice of transfer or sale of business. 
    Each person holding a permit issued pursuant to this division shall give notice in writing to the city inspector within 24 hours after having sold, transferred or otherwise disposed of ownership or interest in or control of any rooming house. Such notice shall include the name and address of the person succeeding to the ownership or control of such rooming house. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-9, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-131. - Hearing on denial of permit. 
    Any person whose application for a permit to operate a rooming house has been denied may request and shall be granted a hearing on the matter before the board of appeals under the procedure prescribed in section 12-133. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-9, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-132. - Suspension; procedure. 
    Whenever the inspection of any rooming house indicates that conditions or practices exist which are in violation of any provision of this chapter or of any rule or regulation adopted pursuant thereto or of any code previously or subsequently adopted by the city council, the city inspector shall give notice in writing to the operator of such rooming house that unless conditions or practices are corrected within a reasonable period, the operator's permit issued pursuant to this division will be suspended. At the end of such period, the city inspector shall reinspect such rooming house and if he finds that such conditions and practices have not been corrected he shall give notice in writing to the operator that the operator's permit has been suspended. Upon receipt of notice of suspension, such operator shall immediately cease operation of such rooming house and no person shall occupy for sleeping or living purposes any rooming unit therein. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-9, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-133. - Hearing on suspension of permit; revocation. 
    Any person whose permit issued pursuant to this division to operate a rooming house has been suspended, or who has received notice from the city inspector that his permit is to be suspended unless existing conditions or practices at his rooming house are corrected may request and shall be granted a hearing on the matter before the board of appeals; provided, however, that if no petition for such hearing is filed within 30 days following the day on which such permit was suspended, the permit shall be deemed to have been automatically revoked. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-9, 8-22-67) 
Secs. 12-134-12-139. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - REQUIRED FACILITIES 

Sec. 12-140. - Bathing and toilet facilities. 
    At least one flush water closet, lavatory basin and bathtub or shower, properly connected to a sewer and water system approved by the city inspector and in good working condition, shall be supplied for each eight persons or fraction thereof residing within a rooming house, including members of the operator's family wherever they share the use of said facilities; provided, however, that if it is a rooming house where rooms are let only to males, flush urinals may be substituted for not more than one-half of the required number of water closets. All such facilities shall be so located within the dwelling as to be reasonably accessible from a common hall or passageway to all persons sharing such facilities. Every lavatory basin and bathtub or shower shall be supplied with hot water at all times. No such facilities shall be located in a basement except by written approval of the city inspector. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-9, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-141. - Floor area in bedrooms. 
    Each room occupied for sleeping purposes by one person shall contain at least 70 square feet of floor space, and every room occupied for sleeping purposes by more than one shall contain at least 50 square feet of floor space for each occupant thereof. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-9, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-142. - Means of egress. 
    Each rooming unit shall have safe, unobstructed means of egress leading to safe and open space at ground level, as required by the laws of the state and of the city. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 6-8, 8-22-67) 
Secs. 12-143-12-153. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - BOARD OF HOUSING APPEALS 

Sec. 12-154. - Established; composition; general qualifications of members. 
    There is hereby established in the city a board of housing appeals consisting of seven members who are qualified by experience and training to pass upon matters pertaining to zoning and building construction and all phases thereof, including but not limited to, matters relating to electrical and plumbing installations, fire prevention, housing and construction. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 1-1, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-155. - Appointment of members; terms; chairman. 
    The city council shall appoint seven members to the board of housing appeals to serve respectively for the following terms: One for one year, one for two years, one for three years, one for four years, one for five years, one for six years and one for seven years. The successor to each member so appointed shall serve for a term of five years. One of the members so appointed shall be named as chairman at the time of his appointment. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 1-2, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-156. - Removal of members for cause after hearing; vacancies. 
    The city council shall have the power to remove any member of the board of housing appeals for cause after public hearing. Vacancies shall be filled by the city council for the unexpired term of the member whose place has become vacant. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 1-3, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-157. - General duties. 
    The board of housing appeals shall hear and decide appeals from and review any order, requirement, decision or determination made by the city inspector or other official charged with the enforcement of this chapter or any other ordinance adopted by the city council relative to zoning, construction, housing or fire safety. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 1-7, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-158. - Meetings; administration of oaths; quorum. 
    All meetings of the board of housing appeals shall be held at the call of the chairman and at such other times as the board may determine. The chairman, or in his absence the acting chairman, may administer oaths and compel the attendance of witnesses. Four members of the board shall constitute a quorum. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 1-4, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-159. - Personal interest of members. 
    No member of the board of housing appeals shall pass upon any question in which he or any corporation in which he is a stockholder is interested. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 1-4, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-160. - Meetings open to public. 
    All meetings of the board of housing appeals shall be open to the public. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 1-5, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-161. - Rules and regulations. 
    The board of housing appeals shall establish rules and regulations for its own procedure not inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 1-6, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-162. - Minutes, records, rules, decisions, etc., to be public. 
(a)  The board shall keep minutes of its proceedings showing the vote of each member upon every question or if absent or if failing to vote, indicating that fact and shall also keep records of its examination and other official actions. 
(b)  Every rule, regulation, amendment or repeal thereof, every order, requirement, decision or determination of the board shall be immediately filed in the office of the board and shall be a public record. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 1-5, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-163. - Right to appeal; notice of appeal. 
(a)  An appeal may be taken by any person aggrieved by any officer, department, board or bureau of the city. 
(b)  An appeal shall be initiated by the filing of a written notice to appeal within thirty days from the date of the decision appealed. Such notice shall be filed with the board of housing appeals and shall specify the grounds thereof, except that in the case of a building or structure which in the opinion of the city inspector or the fire chief is unsafe or dangerous, the city inspector or fire chief may in his order limit the time for such appeal to a shorter period. 
(c)  The city inspector shall forthwith transmit to the board of housing appeals all the papers upon which the action appealed from was taken when notified of the appeal by the board of appeals. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 1-8, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-164. - Notice of hearing. 
    The board of housing appeals shall fix a reasonable time for hearing of the appeal and give due notice thereof to the parties and decide the appeal within a reasonable time. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 1-9, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-165. - Appearance. 
    Upon the hearing, which shall be public, any party may appear in person or by agent or by attorney. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 1-9, 8-22-67) 
Sec. 12-166. - Action by board. 
(a)  The board of housing appeals may reverse or affirm, wholly or partly, or modify the order, requirement, decision or determination as in its opinion ought to be made in the premises, and to that end has all the powers of the officer from whom the appeal is taken. 
(b)  The concurring vote of four members of the board is necessary to reverse any order, requirement, decision or determination of such administrative official or to decide in the favor of the applicant any matter upon which it is required to pass. 
(c)  Every decision of the board shall be in writing and shall indicate the vote upon the decision. A copy of such decision shall be transmitted immediately to the city inspector and a certified copy shall be sent by mail or otherwise to the appellant. 
(d)  If a decision of the board reverses or modifies a refusal, order or disallowance of the city inspector, the inspector shall take action immediately in accordance with such decision. 
(Ord. No. 170, § 1-9, 8-22-67) 
Chapter 13 - LIBRARIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Libraries generally, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 81; Local Library Act, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 81, § 1-0.1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 13-1-13-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LIBRARY BOARD 

Sec. 13-16. - Established; composition; appointment of members. 
    There is hereby established a library board to be known as the Library Board of the City of Mount Carmel, Illinois, which shall consist of nine members, who shall be appointed by the mayor by and with the consent of the city council. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 4-3) 
State Law reference- Board of directors in cities-Appointment, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 81, § 4-1. 
Sec. 13-17. - Qualification of members. 
    Members of the board of library directors shall be chosen from the residents of the city at large, with regard to their fitness for office. Not more than one member of the city council shall be at one time a member of the library board. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 4-3) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 81, § 4-1. 
Sec. 13-18. - Initial and regular terms of members. 
    Of the members of the library board first appointed, three shall be appointed for a term of one year; three shall be appointed for a term of two years; and three shall be appointed for a term of three years. Thereafter, there shall annually be appointed to the library board three members for a term of three years. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 4-3) 
Sec. 13-19. - Removal of members. 
    The mayor may, by and with the consent of the city council, as in case of other removals from office by him, remove any member of the library board for any misconduct or neglect of duty. 
Sec. 13-20. - Filling vacancies. 
    Vacancies on the library board occasioned by removals, resignation or otherwise, shall be reported to the mayor and filled in like manner as original appointments. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 4-3) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 81, § 4-4. 
Sec. 13-21. - Compensation of members. 
    The members of the library board shall serve without compensation. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 4-3) 
Sec. 13-22. - Annual meeting; organization. 
    The library board shall meet annually during the month of July and organize by the election of one of their members as president, another member as secretary and by the election of such other officers as they may deem necessary. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 4-3) 
Sec. 13-23. - Rules and regulations. 
    The library board shall make and adopt such by-laws, rules and regulations for their own guidance and for the government of the library and reading room as may be expedient and not inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter or state law. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 4-3) 
Sec. 13-24. - Powers and duties generally. 
(a)  The library board shall have charge of and conduct and operate the public library now owned by the city. 
(b)  The board shall have the exclusive control of the expenditures of all monies collected to the credit of the library fund, and of the supervision, care and custody of the grounds, rooms and buildings used and set apart for library purposes. All monies received for such library from whatever source shall be deposited in the treasury of the city to the credit of the library fund, and shall be kept separate and apart from other monies of the said city, and drawn upon only by proper officers of said library board upon properly authenticated vouchers, of the library board. 
(c)  The board shall have power to appoint a suitable librarian and necessary assistants, and a janitor, and fix their compensation and shall also have power to remove such appointees. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 4-3) 
Sec. 13-25. - Annual report to council. 
    The library board shall, on or before the fifteenth day of July of each year, make a report of the condition of their trust, as of the thirtieth day of June, to the city council. Such report shall be made in writing and shall be certified to be true, by the secretary or some other responsible officer of the board. It shall contain an itemized statement of the various sums of money received from all sources; an itemized statement of the object and purpose for which those sums of money have been expended. A statement of the number of books and periodicals available for use, and the number and character thereof circulated. A statement of the character of any extensions of library service which have been undertaken, a report shall also be filed at the same time with the proper state authority. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 4-3) 
Sec. 13-26. - Supervisory power of council. 
    The council retains supervisory power over the operation and maintenance of said library and library building, and may by a majority vote set aside any acts of the library board, and may at any time remove any or all of the members of said board with or without cause. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 4-3) 
Chapter 14 - LICENSES AND BUSINESS REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Mayor to sign licenses, § 2-102; license required for retail sale of alcoholic liquor, § 4-43 et seq.; taxation, ch. 20 
State Law reference- Authority of city to fix the amount, terms and manner of issuing and revoking licenses, 65 ILCS 5/11-60-1. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-1. - Business registrations. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to engage in, carry on, or conduct any trade, business, occupation or pursuit within the corporate limits of the city without first registering at the office of the city clerk on forms to be provided. 
(b)  Said registration form shall include, but not be limited to: 
(1)  Name of applicant; 
(2)  Title of applicant; 
(3)  Applicant's address and telephone number; 
(4)  Name of business; 
(5)  Address of business and telephone number; 
(6)  Nature of or type of business; 
(7)  Illinois Retail Occupation Tax Number (where applicable); 
(8)  Employer's identification number; 
(9)  Emergency contact person. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 10-1; Ord. No. 4, 5-10-48; Ord. No. 105, 12-17-62; Ord. No. 136, § 1, 9-7-65; Ord. No. 564, § 1, 3-16-92) 
Secs. 14-2-14-14. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SOLICITORS AND PEDDLERS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 565, § 1, adopted March 16, 1992, repealed former art. II, §§ 14-15-14-28 and added a new art. II to read as herein set out. Former art. II pertained to solicitors and derived from Ord. No. 333, adopted October 18, 1976. 

Sec. 14-15. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following words, as used herein, shall be construed to have the meaning herein set forth: 
    Business establishment shall mean and include the entire premises, including all real estate, buildings and other structures, from which or upon which any business, or a part thereof, dealing with or in any way open to the public is conducted from, or to or upon which the public is invited, whether such business be owned, operated or conducted by an individual, partnership, association, corporation, not-for-profit corporation, or any other person or entity. 
    Peddling shall mean and include any activity in which goods, wares, merchandise, candy, confections, non-alcoholic drinks, ice cream, refreshments, or other pre-packaged food items are sold, whether in or out of a building, where there is no bona fide intent to establish a permanent business. 
    Registered solicitor or peddler shall mean and include any person or persons who have obtained a valid solicitor's certificate of registration or peddler's license, as hereinafter provided and which certificate of registration or license is in the possession of the solicitor or peddler while engaged in soliciting or peddling. 
    Residence shall mean and include every separate living unit occupied for residential purposes by one or more persons, contained within any type of building or structure. 
    Soliciting shall mean and include any one or more of the following activities: 
(1)  Seeking to obtain orders for the purchase of goods, wares, merchandise, foodstuffs or services of any kind, character or description whatever, for any kind of consideration whatever; or 
(2)  Seeking to obtain prospective customers for application or purchase of insurance of any type, kind or character unless said insurance company is properly licensed to do business in the State of Illinois; or 
(3)  Seeking to obtain subscriptions to books, magazines, periodicals, newspapers or any other type or kind of publication; or 
(4)  Seeking to obtain gifts or contributions of money, clothing or any other valuable thing for support or benefit of any charitable or non-profit organization, association, corporation or project, with the exception of those described in section 14-16(c). 
(Ord. No. 565, § 1, 3-16-92) 
Sec. 14-16. - Certificate of registration and peddler's license. 
(a)  Every person desiring to engage in solicitation from persons in residences, dwelling units, or business establishments within the corporate limits of the city is hereby required to make written application for certification of registration as herein provided. 
(b)  Every person or persons desiring to peddle any goods, wares, merchandise, candy, confections, non-alcoholic beverages, ice cream, refreshments, or other pre-packaged food items, to persons in residences, dwelling units, or business establishments are hereby required to make written application for a peddler's license, as hereinafter provided. 
(c)  The following persons, firms or corporations shall be exempted from the requirements of obtaining the certificate of registration or peddler's license as provided above: 
(1)  Any person, firm or corporation having a permanent residence or office in the county. 
(2)  Any person soliciting or peddling anything which such person has personally manufactured or produced, and who maintains a permanent residence in the county. 
(3)  Any farmer, poultryman, or horticulturist soliciting or peddling his own produce. This exemption shall apply only to the county residents and shall not apply to farmers, poultrymen, or horticulturists who buy goods for resale, as well as selling their own produce grown or produced in the county. 
(4)  Any county resident soliciting, peddling, or selling tickets for any approved religious, charitable, school, educational, veteran or character-building organization. 
(5)  Fraternal or service organizations having established local chapter or centers. 
(6)  The provisions of this article shall not apply to salesmen or agents for wholesale houses or firms who solicit orders from, or sell to, retail dealers for resale, or to manufacturers for manufacturing purposes, or to bidders for public works or supplies. 
(7)  However, none of the foregoing exemptions shall relieve any person, firm or corporation from complying with any or all of the requirements of the [ILCS] with regard to retail occupational tax requirements. 
(Ord. No. 565, § 1, 3-16-92) 
Sec. 14-17. - Application for certificate of registration or peddler's license. 
(a)  Application for certificate of registration or peddler's license shall be made upon a form provided by the city clerk of this municipality and filed with such clerk. The applicant shall truthfully state in full the information requested on the application, to-wit: 
(1)  Full name and address of present place of residence and length of residence at said address, business address if other than residence, and social security number. 
(2)  Address of place of residence during past three years, if other than present address. 
(3)  Age of applicant and marital status and, if married, name of spouse. 
(4)  Physical description of applicant. 
(5)  Name and address of the person, firm, corporation, or association whom the applicant is employed by or represents and the length of time of such employment or representation. 
(6)  Name and address of employer during the past three years, if other than present employer. 
(7)  Description sufficient for identification of the nature of the soliciting or peddling in which the applicant will be engaged. 
(8)  The date, or approximate date, of the last prior application for certificate of license under this article, if any. 
(9)  Whether a certificate of registration or peddler's license issued to the applicant under this article has ever been revoked. 
(10)  Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this article, or the ordinances of any other Illinois municipality, or county, regulating soliciting or peddling. 
(11)  Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of the commission of a felony under the laws of the State of Illinois, or any other state, or the laws of the United States. 
(12)  The Illinois Retail Occupation Tax number as issued by the state department of revenue. 
(13)  Such additional information as the city clerk may deem necessary to process the application. 
(b)  All statements made by the applicant upon the application or in connection therewith shall be verified by oath or affirmation. 
(c)  The city clerk shall cause to be kept in his office an accurate record of every application received and acted upon, together with all other information and data pertaining thereto and all certificates of registration, or peddler's licenses, issued under the provisions of this article, and of the denial of applications. Applications for certificates or licenses shall be numbered in consecutive order as filed, and every certificate or license issued, and any renewal thereof shall be identified with the duplicate number of the application upon which it was issued. 
(d)  No certificate of registration or peddler's license shall be issued to any person who has been convicted of the commission of a felony under the laws of the state or any other state or federal law of the United States, within five years of the date of application; nor to any person whose certificate of registration or peddler's license issued hereunder has been previously revoked, as herein provided. 
(e)  A peddler's license shall not be issued to any person or persons that have not been properly registered with the state department of revenue, as required by statute. 
(Ord. No. 565, § 1, 3-16-92) 
Sec. 14-18. - Issuance and revocation of certificates or licenses. 
(a)  The city clerk, after consideration of the application, and all information obtained relative thereto, shall deny the application if the applicant does not possess the qualifications for such certificate or license, as herein required, and the issuance of a certificate of registration or peddler's license would not be in accord with the intent and purpose of this article. Endorsement shall be made by the city clerk upon the application of the denial of the application. When the applicant is found to be fully qualified, the certificate of registration or peddler's license shall be issued forthwith. The certificate or license shall state the expiration date thereof. 
(b)  Any application for a certificate of registration or peddler's license properly submitted shall be acted upon not later than the fifth working day following submission of such application. This period is intended, and shall be used, to all necessary investigation and inquiry required to process the application. 
(c)  Certificates and licenses issued pursuant to this article shall not be assigned or transferred, nor shall they, or either of them, be used by any person other than the person to whom they were issued; except as herein provided. It shall be unlawful for any person to transfer, loan, or permit the use of his license or certificate by any other person except as provided herein. 
(d)  Any certificate of registration or peddler's license issued hereunder shall be revoked by the city clerk if the holder of the certificate or license is convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this article, or has made a false material statement in the application, or otherwise becomes disqualified for the issuance of a certificate of registration or peddler's license under the terms of this article. Immediately upon such revocation, written notice thereof shall be given by the city clerk to the holder of the certificate or license in person or by certified mail, addressed to his/her residence address, as set forth in the application. Revocation shall be effective upon personal service of such notice upon the holder or upon deposit of such notice in the mails, postage and fees fully prepaid. 
(Ord. No. 565, § 1, 3-16-92) 
Sec. 14-19. - City policy on soliciting and peddling. 
(a)  It is hereby declared to be the policy of the governing body of this city that the occupant or occupants of each residence in this city shall determine whether solicitors or peddlers shall be, or shall not be, invited to said residence. If no determination is made as provided in section 24-21 hereof, invitation is deemed to have been extended. 
(b)  No peddler or solicitor shall cry his wares in a loud voice or use any noise producing device other than a soft chime, the limit of audibility of which shall be 100 feet from the source of such sounds, nor shall any peddler commit any breach of peace in crying his wares or soliciting the sale of his products. 
(Ord. No. 565, § 1, 3-16-92) 
Sec. 14-20. - Notice regulating soliciting or peddling. 
(a)  Every person desiring to secure the protection intended to be provided by this article may do so as herein prescribed. 
(b)  A weatherproof card, approximately three inches by four inches in size shall be exhibited upon or near the main entrance door to the residence indicating the determination by the occupant, as follows: 
"NO SOLICITORS OR PEDDLERS INVITED" 
    The letters shall be at least one-third inch in height. 
    For the purpose of uniformity the cards shall be provided in the manner prescribed by the city clerk to persons requesting at the cost thereof. 
(c)  Such card so exhibited shall constitute sufficient notice to any solicitor or peddler of the determination of the occupant of the residence of the information contained thereon. 
(Ord. No. 565, § 1, 3-16-92) 
Sec. 14-21. - Duty of solicitors and peddlers. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every solicitor or peddler upon going onto any premises in the city upon which a residence as herein defined is located to first examine the notice provided for in section 14-20, if any is attached, and be governed by the statement contained on the notice. 
(b)  Any solicitor or peddler who has gained entrance to any residence, whether invited or not, shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises when requested to do so by occupant. 
(Ord. No. 565, § 1, 3-16-92) 
Sec. 14-22. - Uninvited soliciting and peddling prohibited.
