Sec. 15-135. - Vehicles with flanges, cleats and lugs prohibited. 
    No tractor, traction engine, motor truck or other similar vehicle shall be operated across, over or along any city street if any such vehicle has on the periphery of any of the road wheels any block, stud, flange, cleat, ridge, lug or any projection of metal or wood which projects radically beyond the tread or traffic surface of the tire without a special permit therefor in writing issued by the superintendent of streets, which permit shall designate precautions to be taken to prevent damage to streets, and such vehicles shall be operated only upon such streets and in the manner designated in the permit. This prohibition shall not apply to tractors or traction engines equipped with what is known as crawler type tractors, when the same does not contain any projections of any kind likely to injure the surface of the street, nor to tractors, traction engines and similar vehicles which have upon their road wheels V-shaped, diagonal or other cleats arranged in such a manner as to be continuously in contact with the street surface. In no event shall any public street be used as an area or space for turning any tractor or other farm machinery in carrying on or performing any farming operations upon the adjacent land. Provided, that nothing in this section shall prohibit the operation of tractors, traction engines or motor trucks across any city street in order to reach adjacent lands or the use of flexible tire chains on any tractor, traction engine, motor truck or other similar vehicle being operated upon any such street. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 951/2, § 12-701. 
Secs. 15-136-15-146. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - ABANDONED, LOST, STOLEN OR UNCLAIMED VEHICLES[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference- Abandoned, lost, stolen or unclaimed vehicles, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 951/2, § 4-200 et seq. 

Sec. 15-147. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following words shall have the meanings ascribed to them: 
    Abandoned vehicle shall mean any motor vehicle or other vehicle in a state of disrepair rendering such vehicle incapable of being driven in its condition, or any motor vehicle or other vehicle that has not been moved or used for seven consecutive days or more and is apparently deserted. 
    Antique vehicle shall mean any motor vehicle or other vehicle 25 years of age or older. 
    Highway shall mean any street, alley or public way within the city. 
(Ord. No. 196, § 1, 2-3-69) 
Sec. 15-148. - Abandonment of vehicle prohibited; removal of vehicles abandoned on private property. 
(a)  The abandonment of a motor vehicle or other vehicle or any part thereof on any highway in the city is unlawful and subject to penalties as set forth herein. 
(b)  The abandonment of a motor vehicle or other vehicle or any part thereof on private or public property, other than a highway, in view of the general public, anywhere in the city is unlawful except on property of the owner or bailee of such abandoned vehicle. A motor vehicle or other vehicle or any part thereof so abandoned on private property may be authorized for removal by the chief of police after a waiting period of seven days or more has expired. 
(Ord. No. 196, § 2, 2-3-69) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 951/2, § 4-200. 
Sec. 15-149. - Possession by other than owner. 
    When an abandoned, lost, stolen or unclaimed motor vehicle or other vehicle comes into the temporary possession or custody of a person in the state, not the owner of the vehicle, such person shall immediately notify the police department when the vehicle is within the corporate limits of the city. Upon receipt of such notification, the chief of police shall authorize a towing service to remove and take possession of the abandoned, lost, stolen or unclaimed motor vehicle or other vehicle. The towing service will safely keep the towed vehicle and its contents, maintain a record of the tow until the vehicle is claimed by the owner or any other person legally entitled to possession thereof, or until it is disposed of as provided in this article. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 951/2, § 4-201. 
Sec. 15-150. - Towing of vehicles abandoned ten hours or more. 
    When a motor vehicle or other vehicle is abandoned on a highway in the city ten hours or more, its removal by a towing service may be authorized by order of the chief of police. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 951/2, § 4-202(a). 
Sec. 15-151. - Immediate removal of vehicle creating traffic hazard. 
    When an abandoned, unattended, wrecked, burned or partially dismantled motor vehicle or other vehicle is creating a traffic hazard because of its position in relation to the highway or its physical appearance is causing the impeding of traffic, its immediate removal from the highway by a towing service may be authorized by order of the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 196, § 3, 2-3-69) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 951/2, § 4-202(d). 
Sec. 15-152. - Police department records on towed vehicles. 
    When a motor vehicle or other vehicle is authorized to be towed away pursuant to this article, the police department shall keep and maintain a record of the vehicle towed, listing the color, year of manufacture, manufacturer's trade name, manufacturer's series name, body style, vehicle identification number and license plate year and number displayed on the vehicle. The record shall also include the date and hour of tow, location towed from, location towed to, reason for towing and the name of the officer authorizing the tow. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 951/2, § 4-203. 
Sec. 15-153. - Owner responsible for towing costs. 
    When a vehicle is ordered removed from either public or private property by the chief of police pursuant to this article, the owner of the vehicle shall be responsible for all towing costs. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 951/2, § 4-202(e). 
Sec. 15-154. - Nonliability of police officers and towing service personnel. 
    A police officer, towing service owner, operator or employee shall not be held to answer or be liable for damages in any action brought by the registered owner, former registered owner, or his legal representative, or any other person legally entitled to the possession of a motor vehicle or other vehicle when the vehicle was processed and sold or disposed of as provided by this article. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 951/2, § 4-213. 
Sec. 15-155. - Search of records to determine ownership of vehicle; use of information in giving notice. 
(a)  When the police department authorizes the impounding of a motor vehicle or other vehicle and does not know the identity of the registered owner thereof or other person legally entitled thereto, it will cause the motor vehicle registration records of the state to be searched by a directed communication to the secretary of state for the purpose of obtaining the required ownership information. 
(b)  The police department authorizing the impounding of a vehicle will cause the stolen motor vehicle files of the state police to be searched by a directed communication to the state police for stolen or wanted information on the vehicle. When the state police files are searched with negative results, the information contained in the National Crime Information Center (NCIC) files will be searched by the state police. The information determined from these record searches will be used by the police department in sending a notification by certified mail to the owner or legally entitled person advising where the vehicle is held, requesting a disposition be made and setting forth public sale information. Exceptions to a notification by certified mail to the registered owner or other legally entitled person are set forth in Ill. Rev. Stat., chapter 951/2, section 4-208. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 951/2, § 4-204. 
Sec. 15-156. - Identification of owner by state police; use of information in giving notice. 
    When the registered owner or other person legally entitled to the possession of a motor vehicle or other vehicle cannot be identified from state registration files or from the registration files of a foreign state, if applicable, the police department shall notify the state police for the purpose of identifying the vehicle owner or other person legally entitled to the possession of the vehicle. The information obtained by the state police will be immediately forwarded to the law enforcement agency having custody of the vehicle for notification of owner as set forth in section 15-155. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 951/2, § 4-205. 
Sec. 15-157. - Reclamation by owner. 
    At any time before a motor vehicle or other vehicle is sold at public sale or disposed of as provided in this article, the owner or other person legally entitled to its possession may reclaim the vehicle by presenting to the police department proof of ownership or proof of the right to possession of the vehicle. No vehicle shall be released to the owner or other person under this section until all towing and storage charges have been paid. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 951/2, § 4-206. 
Sec. 15-158. - Disposition of unclaimed vehicles not over seven years old. 
(a)  Whenever an abandoned, lost, stolen or unclaimed motor vehicle or other vehicle seven years of age or newer remains unclaimed by the registered owner or other person legally entitled to its possession for a period of 30 days after notice has been given as provided in this article, the police department having possession of the vehicle shall cause it to be sold at public sale to the highest bidder. Notice of the time and place of the sale shall be posted in a conspicuous place for at least ten days prior to the sale on the premises where the vehicle has been impounded. At least ten days prior to the sale, the police department shall cause a notice of the time and place of the sale to be sent by certified mail to the registered owner or other person known by the police department or towing service to be legally entitled to the possession of the vehicle. Such notice shall contain a complete description of the vehicle to be sold and what steps must be taken by any legally entitled person to reclaim the vehicle. 
(b)  In those instances where the certified notification specified in section 15-155 has been returned by the postal authorities to the police department due to the addressee having moved, or being unknown at the address obtained from the registration records of the state, the sending of a second certified notice will not be required. 
(c)  When the identity of the registered owner or other person legally entitled to the possession of an abandoned, lost or unclaimed vehicle of seven years of age or newer cannot be determined by any means provided for in this article, the vehicle may be sold as provided herein or disposed of in the manner authorized by this article without notice to the registered owner or other person legally entitled to the possession of the vehicle. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 951/2, §§ 4-207, 4-208(a). 
Sec. 15-159. - Disposal of unclaimed vehicles over seven years old as junk; antique vehicles excepted. 
(a)  When an abandoned vehicle of more than seven years of age is impounded as specified by this article, it will be kept in custody for a minimum of ten days for the purpose of determining ownership, the contacting of the registered owner by U.S. mail, public service or in person for a determination of disposition; and, an examination of the state police stolen motor vehicle files for theft and wanted information. At the expiration of the ten-day period, without the benefit of disposition information being received from the registered owner, the chief of police will authorize the disposal of the vehicle as junk only. 
(b)  A motor vehicle or other vehicle classified as an antique vehicle is excluded from the provisions of this section. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 951/2, § 4-208(b), (d). 
Sec. 15-160. - Report of disposition of impounded vehicles. 
    When a motor vehicle or other vehicle in the custody of the police department as authorized by this article, is reclaimed by the registered owner or other legally entitled person, or when the vehicle is sold at public sale or otherwise disposed of as provided in this article, a report of the transaction will be maintained by the police department for a period of one year from the date of the sale or disposal. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 951/2, § 4-210. 
Sec. 15-161. - Deposit of proceeds resulting from sale or other disposition of vehicle. 
    When a vehicle located within the corporate limits of the city is authorized to be towed away by the chief of police and disposed of as set forth in this article, the proceeds of the public sale or disposition after the deduction of towing, storage and processing charges shall be deposited in the municipal treasury. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 951/2, § 4-211(a). 
Secs. 15-162-15-172. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - PEDESTRIANS 

Sec. 15-173. - Pedestrians' right-of-way at crosswalks. 
(a)  When traffic-control signals are not in place or not in operation, the driver of a vehicle shall yield the right-of-way, slowing down or stopping if need be to so yield, to a pedestrian crossing the roadway within a crosswalk when the pedestrian is upon the half of the roadway upon which the vehicle is traveling, or when the pedestrian is approaching so closely from the opposite half of the roadway as to be in danger. 
(b)  Whenever any vehicle is stopped at a marked crosswalk or at any unmarked crosswalk at an intersection to permit a pedestrian to cross the roadway, the driver of any other vehicle approaching from the rear shall not overtake and pass such stopped vehicle. 
(c)  Whenever stop signs or flashing red signals are in place at an intersection or at a plainly marked crosswalk between intersections, pedestrians shall have the right-of-way over drivers of vehicles as set forth in this chapter. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 951/2, § 11-1002. 
Sec. 15-174. - To use right half of crosswalks. 
    Pedestrians shall move, whenever practicable, upon the right half of crosswalks. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 951/2, § 11-1005. 
Sec. 15-175. - Safety zones. 
    The city council shall have power by appropriate resolution to establish safety zones at street crossings for the safety and protection of pedestrians. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 14-15) 
Sec. 15-176. - Crossing at other than crosswalks or safety zones. 
(a)  Every pedestrian crossing a roadway at any point other than within a marked crosswalk or safety zone or within an unmarked crosswalk at an intersection shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles upon the roadway. 
(b)  Any pedestrian crossing a roadway at a point where a pedestrian tunnel or overhead pedestrian crossing has been provided shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles upon the roadway. 
(c)  Notwithstanding the provisions of this section, every driver of a vehicle shall exercise due care to avoid colliding with any pedestrian upon any roadway, shall give warning by sounding the horn when necessary, and shall exercise proper precaution upon observing any child or any obviously confused or incapacitated person upon a roadway. 
State Law reference- Local authority to prohibit pedestrian crossings at other than designated crosswalks or intersections, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 951/2, § 11-208(a)12; crossing at other than crosswalks, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 951/2, § 11-1003. 
Sec. 15-177. - Blind pedestrians. 
    Any blind person who is carrying in a raised or extended position a cane or walking stick which is white in color or white tipped with red, or who is being guided by a dog, shall have the right-of-way in crossing any street whether or not traffic on such street is controlled by traffic signals, anything in this chapter to the contrary notwithstanding. The driver of every vehicle approaching the place where a blind person, so carrying such a cane or walking stick or being so guided, is crossing a street shall bring his vehicle to a full stop and before proceeding shall take such precautions as may be necessary to avoid injury to the blind person. The provisions of this section shall not apply to a blind person who is not so carrying such a cane or walking stick or who is not guided by a dog, but the other provisions of this chapter relating to pedestrians shall then be applicable to such person. However, the failure of a blind person to so use or carry such a cane or walking stick or to be guided by a guide dog when walking on streets or sidewalks shall not be considered evidence of contributory negligence. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 951/2, § 11-1004. 
Sec. 15-178. - Soliciting rides. 
    No person shall stand in a roadway for the purpose of soliciting a ride from the driver of any private vehicle. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 951/2, § 11-1006(a). 
Sec. 15-179. - Hopping vehicles. 
    No person shall hitch onto or climb on any vehicle while the same is in motion without the consent of the person in charge of such vehicle. Riders of bicycles shall not hold onto moving vehicles or be permitted so to do. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 14-9) 
Sec. 15-180. - Pedestrian crosswalks. 
    The city council shall have power by appropriate resolution to establish pedestrian crosswalks upon streets in the city at points other than street intersections for the convenience, safety and protection of pedestrians. 
(Ord. No. 397, § 1, 6-25-79) 
Secs. 15-181-15-190. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - BICYCLES 

Sec. 15-191. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section: 
    Bicycle shall mean and include a vehicle with two tandem wheels, solid or pneumatic tires, having a steering bar or wheel, a saddle seat or seats and propelled by human power. 
    Licensee shall mean any person, who upon proper application, procures from the chief of police a license plate for a bicycle. 
    License plate shall mean a metal plate or tag issued by the chief of police bearing a license number. 
(Ord. No. 145, § 1, 6-13-66) 
Sec. 15-192. - Violation of article a misdemeanor. 
    It is a misdemeanor for any person to do any act forbidden or fail to perform any act required in this article and every violation is punishable as provided in section 1-11. 
(Ord. No. 145, § 2, 6-13-66) 
Sec. 15-193. - Responsibility of parents. 
    The parent of any child and the guardian of any ward shall not authorize or knowingly permit any child or ward to violate any provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 145, § 2, 6-3-66) 
Sec. 15-194. - License required. 
    No person who resides within the city shall ride or propel a bicycle on any street, alley or other public place or upon any path set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles unless such bicycle has been licensed and a license plate is attached thereto as provided herein. 
(Ord. No. 145, § 3, 6-13-66) 
Sec. 15-195. - Application for license. 
    Application for a bicycle license and license plate shall be made upon a form provided by the city and shall be made to the chief of police or other police officers designated by him for this purpose. 
(Ord. No. 145, § 4, 6-13-66) 
Sec. 15-196. - Issuance of license; police chief to keep records; license year. 
(a)  The chief of police, upon receiving proper application therefor, is hereby authorized to issue a bicycle license. 
(b)  The chief of police shall not issue a license for any bicycle when he knows, or has reasonable ground to believe, that the applicant is not the owner of, or entitled to possession of such bicycle. 
(c)  The chief of police shall keep a record of the number of each license, the date issued, the name and address of the person to whom issued and the number on the frame of the bicycle for which said license was issued. 
(d)  The license so issued shall be effective for one year. The license year shall be from the first day of June to the last day of May of the following year. 
(Ord. No. 145, § 5, 6-13-66) 
Sec. 15-197. - License plates-Chief of police to issue and attach. 
(a)  The chief of police, upon issuing a bicycle license, shall also issue a license plate bearing the license number assigned to the bicycle and the name of the city. 
(b)  The chief of police shall cause such license plate to be firmly attached to the frame of the bicycle for which issued. 
(Ord. No. 145, § 6, 6-13-66) 
Sec. 15-198. - Inspections; notice of defects; suspension of license. 
(a)  The chief of police, or any officer designated by him, shall inspect each bicycle before licensing the same and shall refuse a license for any bicycle which he determines is in an unsafe mechanical condition. 
(b)  The chief of police may periodically inspect any bicycle for which a license has been issued to determine the mechanical condition of said bicycle and shall notify the licensee of any defects or other conditions that would cause such bicycle to be determined unsafe. 
(c)  Any licensee, who, upon proper notification by the chief of police, refuses or fails to remedy any condition that should cause the bicycle to be determined unsafe and continues to operate said bicycle within the city shall have the license for such bicycle suspended and the license plate attached to the bicycle shall be removed and returned to the chief of police in accordance with the provisions of this article and shall only be reissued upon proper application and inspection by the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 145, § 7, 6-13-66) 
Sec. 15-199. - Removal of license plate on sale, damage of bicycle or suspension of license. 
(a)  Upon the sale of, or other transfer of ownership of, a licensed bicycle, the licensee shall remove the license plate and shall either surrender the same to the chief of police or may, upon proper application, have said plate assigned to another bicycle owned by the applicant. 
(b)  If at any time a bicycle is dismantled or damaged to such extent that it could no longer be operated within the city, the license plate attached to the bicycle shall be removed from said bicycle and returned to the chief of police within five days after the bicycle shall be so dismantled or damaged. 
(c)  Upon the suspension of any license for any reason, the licensee shall return to the chief of police, upon his request, any and all license plates that may have been issued to the licensee. Upon the removal of such suspension, the license plates shall be returned to the licensee upon proper application and inspection of the bicycles for which the license plates were being reissued. 
(Ord. No. 145, § 8, 6-13-66) 
Sec. 15-200. - Loss of license plate to be reported; replacement. 
    The licensee shall report immediately to the chief of police the loss or destruction of the license plate of the licensee and the circumstances surrounding the destruction or loss thereof, at which time, on the payment of $0.25 by the licensee, the chief of police will issue to said licensee a replacement license plate. 
(Ord. No. 145, § 9, 6-13-66) 
Sec. 15-201. - Responsibility of rental agencies. 
    A rental agency shall not rent or offer for rent any bicycle unless such bicycle is licensed and a license plate is attached thereon. 
(Ord. No. 145, § 10, 6-13-66) 
Sec. 15-202. - Penalties. 
(a)  Every person convicted of a violation of any provision of this article shall be punished by suspension of the license or licenses issued to him and the license plates attached to such bicycle shall be removed from the bicycle and returned to the chief of police or the bicycle of the licensee may be impounded for a period not to exceed 30 days. 
(b)  The parent of any child or guardian of any ward who knowingly permits the child to violate any of the provisions of this article shall be punished by a fine of not less than $10.00 nor more than $25.00. 
(Ord. No. 145, § 11, 6-13-66) 
Chapter 16 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Power of mayor to keep peace, § 2-103; sale of alcoholic liquor to minors, § 4-7; pets prohibited in federally assisted or subsidized facilities, § 5-1; prosecution for violation of motor vehicles and traffic chapter, § 15-14 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 16-1. - Vagrancy. 
    Vagrancy is hereby declared to be unlawful, and the following persons shall be deemed "vagrants": 
(a)  Abroad at unusual hours: One who wanders about the streets, alleys or other public ways or places, or who is found abroad at late or unusual hours in the night without any visible or lawful business and not giving a satisfactory account of himself; or 
(b)  Begging: One wandering abroad and begging, or who gets about from door-to-door of private homes or commercial or business establishments or places himself in or upon any public way or public place to beg or receive alms for himself; or 
(c)  Loitering: It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter, loaf, wander, stand or remain idle, either alone or in consort with others, in a public place in such manner so as to: 
(1)  Obstruct any public street, public highway, public sidewalk or any other public place or building by hindering or impeding or tend to hinder or impede the free and uninterrupted passage of vehicles, traffic or pedestrians. 
(2)  Commit in or upon any public street, public highway, public sidewalk or any other public place or building any act or thing which is an obstruction or interference to the free and uninterrupted use of property or with any business lawfully conducted by anyone in or upon or facing or fronting on any such public street, public highway, public sidewalk or any other public place or building, all of which prevents the free and uninterrupted ingress, egress and regress therein, thereon and thereto. 
(d)  Unlawful occupancy: One wandering abroad, and occupying, lodging or sleeping in any vacant or unoccupied barn, garage, shed, shop or other building or structure or in any automobile, truck, railroad car or other vehicle without owning the same or without permission of the owner or person entitled to the possession of same or sleeping in any vacant lot during the hours of darkness and not giving a satisfactory account of himself; or 
(e)  Vagrant: One who by law is declared a vagrant, whether embraced in any of the foregoing classifications or not. 
    Separability. If any subsection, sentence, clause, phrase or portion of this section is for any reason held invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct and independent provision; and such holding shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions hereof. 
    Penalty. Any person violating any provision of this section, save where another penalty is provided, shall be fined not less than $25.00 nor more than $500.00 for each offense. 
(Ord. No. 489, §§ 1-3, 5-18-87) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 489, adopted May 18, 1987, repealed §§ 16-1 and 16-2, dealing with begging and loitering, respectively, and containing no history note, and § 16-3, dealing with vagrancy and deriving from the 1947 Rev. Ords., § 8-1. Such ordinances also enacted new provisions, §§ 1-3 of which are set out herein by the editor as § 16-1; §§ 4 and 5 of the ordinance, dealing with conflict and effective date, respectively, have not been included herein. Subsequently, nonamendatory Ord. No. 493, enacted Aug. 24, 1987, has been included at the editor's discretion as § 16-2, with the exclusion of §§ 5 and 6 of such ordinance, concerning conflict and effective date, respectively. 
State Law reference- Authority of municipalities to prevent begging, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 11-5-4; authority of municipality to prevent vagrancy, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 11-5-4. 
Sec. 16-2. - Fund-raising activities on public streets regulated; penalty. 
(a)  No person, firm, corporation, or organization shall be allowed or permitted to engage in any fundraising activity or solicit for donations, pass out literature or in any other manner perform any similar type activity for civic or charitable organizations or any other organization or on their own behalf or otherwise perform such activities within, along or upon any city street, alley, intersection or right-of-way thereof, within the city limits of the city, except under the following circumstances. 
(b)  The soliciting agency shall be: 
(1)  Liable for any injuries to any person or property during the solicitation which is causally related to an act of ordinary negligence of the soliciting. 
(c)  And, in addition: 
(1)  Any person engaged in the act of solicitation shall be 18 years of age, or more and shall present a photo identification evidencing such age and shall be wearing a florescent green or orange vest. 
(2)  Shall complete a questionnaire and register with the chief of the police not less than 30 days prior to the date the fundraiser is to take place and identify the date(s) on which such fundraising activity shall take place, give the name of the organization, the address, the contact person and the names of the individuals who will be soliciting for the entity on that date together with proof of identity and other information as set out in said questionnaire. 
(3)  Fundraising shall be allowed only at intersections where all traffic is required to come to a full stop, with those intersections which are allowed for fundraising activities within the city being designated as those intersections at Fifth and Walnut Streets and Ninth and Cherry Streets and Thirteenth and Market Streets. 
(4)  No more than one organization may solicit on a given day and reservations for a given day will be made and kept at the city police department. 
(5)  Solicitation times shall be from 6:00 a.m. to 2:00 p.m. 
(d)  Any person found guilty of violating the provisions of this solicitation shall be fined not less than $25.00 nor more than $500.00 and, in addition to the person actually performing such activity, the group, organization, person or other legal entity which allows, permits, or authorizes such activity in violation of this section shall also be deemed guilty of violating this section and shall be subject to the same fine. 
(Ord. No. 575, §§ 1-3, 7-20-92; Ord. No. 890, 1-29-07) 
Note- See editor's note following § 16-1. 
Sec. 16-3. - Reserved. 
Note- See editor's note following § 16-1. 
Sec. 16-4. - Expectoration. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to expectorate on any sidewalk or on the floor of any public building. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 8-1) 
Sec. 16-5. - Selling, discharging fireworks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or discharge fireworks in the city, except caps for toy cap pistols, and such other fireworks as are permissible under the laws of this state now or hereafter in force. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 8-1) 
Sec. 16-6. - Abandoned refrigerators or iceboxes. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to abandon or discard in any place accessible to children any refrigerator, icebox or ice chest of a capacity of 11/2 cubic feet or more, which has an attached lid or door which may be opened or fastened shut by means of an attached latch, or for the manager, owner or lessee of such premises to knowingly permit such refrigerator, ice chest or icebox to remain in such condition. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 23, § 2356. 
Sec. 16-7. - Tattooing body of minor. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, other than a person licensed to practice medicine, in all its branches, to tattoo or offer to tattoo a person under the age of 18 years. 
(b)  As used in this section, to "tattoo" shall mean to insert pigment under the surface of the skin of a human being, by pricking with a needle or otherwise, so as to produce an indelible mark or figure visible through the skin. 
(Ord. No. 884, 11-20-06) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 720 ILCS 5/12-10. 
Sec. 16-8. - Unlawful advertisement; defacing lawful advertisement. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to advertise any unlawful business or article in the city, and it shall be unlawful to injure or deface any lawful advertisement or notice. 
Sec. 16-9. - Fortunetelling. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to pursue the calling of a fortuneteller or practice fortune-telling, soothsaying or the like, and receive payment in any manner therefor. 
Sec. 16-10. - Impersonating city officer or police officer. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to represent himself falsely to be an officer of the city, or exercise or attempt to exercise without authority any powers, duties or functions of any city officer, or not being a member of the police department of the city, to wear or have in his possession any police officer's badge with the intent thereby to pass himself as a police officer. 
Sec. 16-11. - Sunday amusements. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to keep open on Sunday any pool or billiard room without the consent of the city council or some officer authorized by the council to give such consent. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 81) 
Sec. 16-12. - Use of recreational vehicle as a living unit or residence; connection to city water and sewer systems. 
    An RV owned by someone other than the owner of the land upon which the RV is located shall not remain parked for a period longer than 90 days and at no time shall said RV be used as a living unit or residence nor shall it be connected to the city water and sewer systems. 
    A violation of this section shall result in a fine not to exceed $200.00 and not less than $50.00. Each day of violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
    This section shall not apply to mobile home/travel trailer parks where the city has authorized and approved such parks and uses. 
    The city inspector may, upon application, grant a permit for a 14-day exemption from this section, upon such terms and conditions as the city inspector may deem appropriate and a fee of $15.00 may be charged. Should an application be denied, then the applicant may appeal such decision to the city council. 
(Ord. No. 932, 4-6-09) 
Sec. 16-13. - Reserved. 
Sec. 16-14. - Home kitchen operation. 
    Home kitchen operations are authorized by the city, within the corporate limits of the city. 
(a)  Home kitchen operations means a person who produces or packages non-potentially hazardous baked goods in a kitchen of that person's primary domestic residence for direct sale by the owner or a family member. A home kitchen operation does not include a person who produces or packages non-potentially hazardous baked goods for sale by a religious, charitable or not-for-profit organization for fundraising purposes. The production or packaging of non-potentially hazardous baked goods for these purposes is exempt. The following conditions must be met in order to qualify as a home kitchen operation; 
(1)  Monthly gross sales do not exceed $1,000.00. 
(2)  The food is a non-potentially hazardous baked food, as provided by law. 
(3)  A notice is provided to the purchaser that the product was produced in a home kitchen. 
(4)  The food package is affixed with a label or other written notice is provided to the purchaser that includes: (i) a common or usual name of the food product (ii) allergen labeling as specified by in federal labeling requirements by the United States Food and Drug Administration. 
(5)  The food is sold directly to the customer. 
(6)  The food is stored in the residence where it is produced or packaged. 
(7)  Food handlers must complete food handler training. 
(b)  The county health department may inspect a home kitchen operation in the event of a complaint or disease outbreak. 
(c)  This section applies only to a home kitchen operations located within the corporate limits of the city and is adopted pursuant to 410 ILCS 625. 
(Ord. No. 1057, 5-9-16) 
Secs. 16-15-16-22. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - NUISANCES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Health nuisances, §§ 11-3-11-6. 
State Law reference- Authority of city to define, prevent and abate nuisances, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 11-60-2; nuisances generally, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 1001/2, § 1 et seq. 

Sec. 16-23. - Prohibited. 
    No person shall permit, cause, keep or maintain or create a nuisance within the city, or where the city has authority by statute over nuisances outside the corporate limits of the city, within the limits of such authority. 
Cross reference- Specific health nuisances designated, § 11-3; certain weeds declared nuisances, § 11-34. 
Sec. 16-24. - Acts constituting nuisances. 
    It shall be a public nuisance to: 
(1)  Cause or suffer the carcass of any animal or any offal, filth or noisome substance to be collected or deposited or to remain in any place, to the prejudice of others; 
(2)  Throw or deposit any offal or other offensive matter, or the carcass of any dead animal in any watercourse, lake, pond, spring, well or common sewer, street or public highway; 
(3)  Corrupt or render unwholesome or impure the water of any spring, river, stream, pond or lake, to the injury or prejudice of others; 
(4)  Obstruct or impede, without legal authority, the passage of any navigable river or waters; 
(5)  Obstruct or encroach upon public highways, private ways, streets, alleys, commons, landing places and ways to burying places; 
(6)  Keep or store explosives, paper, rags, hay or other combustible material in such quantity, and in such place as to constitute a hazard to persons or property in the vicinity thereof, or in violation of any state law or regulation now or hereafter in force; 
(7)  Willfully or maliciously damage or destroy any partition fence of another person lawfully erected or maintained; 
(8)  Erect, continue or use any building or other place for the exercise of any trade, employment or manufacture, which, by occasioning noxious exhalations, smoke, offensive smells or otherwise, is offensive or dangerous to the health of individuals or of the public; 
(9)  Advertise wares or occupation by painting notices of the same on, or affixing them to fences or other private property, or on rocks or other natural objects, without the consent of the owner, or if in the highway or other public place, without permission of the proper authorities; 
(10)  Permit any well drilled for oil, gas, salt water disposal or any other purpose in connection with the production of oil and gas, to remain unplugged, after such well is no longer used for the purpose for which it was drilled; 
(11)  Construct or operate any salt water pit or oil field refuse pit, commonly called a "burn out pit," so that salt water, brine or oil field refuse or other waste liquids may escape therefrom in any manner except by the evaporation of such salt water or brine or by the burning of such oil field waste or refuse; 
(12)  Permit concrete bases, discarded machinery and materials to remain around any oil or gas well, or to fail to fill any holes, cellars, slush pits and other excavations made in connection with any such well or to restore the surface of the lands surrounding any such well to its condition before the drilling of any such well, upon abandonment of any such oil or gas well; 
(13)  Permit any salt water, oil, gas or other wastes from any well drilled for oil, gas or exploratory purposes to escape to the surface, or into a mine or coal seam, or into any underground fresh water supply, or from one underground stratum to another; 
(14)  Harass, intimidate or threaten any person who is about to sell or lease or has sold or leased a residence or other real property or is about to buy or lease or has bought or leased a residence or other real property, when the harassment, intimidation or threat relates to a person's attempt to sell, buy or lease a residence, or other real property, or refers to a person's sale, purchase or lease of a residence or other real property. 
(15)  The keeping of animals under such conditions as would cause stench and or obnoxious odors, which migrate to neighboring property. 
(16)  The raking, placing or blowing of grass clippings into the streets and gutters of any public street or public sidewalk. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 8-1; Ord. No. 929, 1-26-09; Ord. No. 943, 9-21-09; Ord. No. 1000, 11-12-13) 
State Law reference- Public nuisances, acts constituting, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 1001/2, § 26. 
Sec. 16-25. - Uncut weeds, grass and shrubbery; abatement; penalty and costs. 
(a)  All weeds, high grass or shrubbery growing on or standing uncut or otherwise uncontrolled on any premises in the city are hereby declared a nuisance. 
(b)  No owner, lessee or occupant of any property within the city shall allow weeds, grass or shrubbery to grow on his property where such weeds, grass or shrubbery obstruct the vision of users of any street, road, highway, driveway or alley within the city or where such weeds, grass or shrubbery tend to detract from the beauty of the surrounding properties. 
(c)  In the event weeds, grass or shrubbery are permitted to grow and to obstruct the vision of users of any street, road, highway, driveway or alley within the city or to detract from the beauty of the surrounding properties, it shall be the duty of the superintendent of streets to give the owner, lessee or occupant of such property a written notice to abate the nuisance. The notice shall designate the property and describe the nuisance and shall direct the owner, lessee or occupant to abate the nuisance within ten days from the date of the notice. The notice may be delivered to the occupant of the property by certified mail or in person when property is occupied by an owner, lessee or other occupant. In the event said property is vacant, the notice shall be sent by certified mail to the owner or lessee of the property if the name and address of the owner or lessee can be ascertained; otherwise, the notice shall be posted on the property. 
(d)  In the event the owner, lessee or occupant fails to abate the nuisance within ten days from the date of service of the notice to abate, the superintendent of streets or other person acting under his direction may enter upon the property to abate the nuisance by causing all weeds, grass or uncontrolled shrubbery to be cut, sprayed or otherwise removed or abated. 
(e)  Any owner, lessee or occupant of property within the city who fails to abate any nuisance described in the notice to abate within the time prescribed by the notice shall be subject to a penalty as prescribed in section 1-10. In addition to such penalty, the owner, lessee or occupant who has failed to abate the nuisance shall also be liable to the city for the reasonable costs incurred by it in cutting or otherwise abating the nuisance. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 8-1) 
Note- See also § 11-34 et seq. 
State Law reference- Weed cutting, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 11-20-7. 
Sec. 16-26. - Definitions. 
(a)  For the purposes of this section, the following words, as used herein, shall be construed to have the meaning herein set forth: 
(b)  Definition of "nuisance." For the purposes of this section, the term "nuisance" is defined to mean any condition or use of premises or of building exteriors which is detrimental to the property of others or which causes or tends to cause substantial diminution in the value of property in the neighborhood in which such premises are located. This includes, but is not limited to, the keeping or the depositing on, or the scattering over the premises of any of the following: 
(1)  Lumber, junk, trash or debris. 
(2)  Abandoned, discarded or unused objects or equipment such as, but not limited to, automobiles, furniture, stoves, refrigerators, freezers, cans, containers, motorcycles, motor or mini bikes, bicycles, toys, children's vehicles, clothing bedding, mowers or building materials of any type or quantity. 
(c)  Duty of maintenance of private property. No person owning, leasing, occupying or having charge of any premises (all of whom are hereinafter collectively referred to as "owners") shall maintain or keep any nuisance thereon, nor shall any such person keep or maintain such premises in a manner causing substantial diminution in the value of other property in the neighborhood in which such premises are located. 
(d)  Exterior storage of nonoperating vehicles prohibited. No person in charge or in control of premises, whether as owner, lessee, tenant, occupant or otherwise, shall allow any partially dismantled, wrecked, junked, discarded or otherwise nonoperating motor vehicle to remain on such property longer than ten days; and no person shall leave any such vehicle on any property within the city for a longer time than ten days except that this section shall not apply with regard to any vehicle in an enclosed building or so located upon the premises as not to be readily visible from any public place or from any surrounding private property. For the purposes herein, an "otherwise nonoperating motor vehicle" shall include any vehicle not displaying a valid registration license plate with sticker, that is not currently insured, or that is not operable under the provisions of the Illinois Motor Vehicle Code. This section shall further not apply with regard to any vehicle on the premises of a business enterprise operated in a lawful place, other than in a residential district, and operated in a lawful manner, when the keeping or maintenance of such vehicle is necessary to the operation of such business enterprise; or with regard to a vehicle in an appropriate storage place or depository maintained in a lawful place and manner by the city or any other public agency or entity. 
(e)  Penalty for failure of owner to abate such nuisance. If such owners allow said nuisance to exist or fail to abate said nuisance to exist or fail to abate said nuisance, they, and each of them, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined not less than $25.00, nor more than $500.00 for each offense and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which such nuisance is permitted to exist. 
(f)  Abatement by city. Whenever said owners fail to abate said nuisance, then the city shall remove the said personalty to a location of its selection, the expenses therefor to be billed to said owners, jointly and severally, said bill to be recoverable in a suit at law. 
When said personalty has been removed and placed in storage by the city, as provided for herein, said personalty shall be sold by the city after the lapse of such time as is provided by law. If the proceeds of such sale are insufficient to pay the costs of abatement, said owners shall be liable to the city for the balance of the costs, jointly and severally, to be recoverable in a suit at law. If the proceeds are in excess of costs, the balance shall be paid to said owners, or deposited in the city treasury for their use. In the event the city is required to abate a nuisance, the owner shall be liable for all reasonable attorney's fees incurred by the city, which shall be added as costs. 
(g)  Enforcement. In addition to the other provisions for enforcement of this section, enforcement may be accomplished by the city in any manner authorized by law, and, in addition, any person who by reason of another's violation of any provision of this section, suffers special damage to himself different from that suffered by other property owners throughout the city generally may bring an action to enjoin or otherwise abate an existing violation. 
(Ord. No. 332, §§ 1-6, 10-18-76; Ord. No. 576, § 1, 9-14-92; Ord. No. 768, 9-4-01; Ord. No. 887, 12-4-06) 
Cross reference- Dumping prohibited, § 101/2-19. 
Secs. 16-27-16-36. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFENSES AGAINST ORDER 

Sec. 16-37. - Disorderly conduct. 
    A person commits disorderly conduct in violation of this Code when he knowingly: 
(1)  Does any act in such an unreasonable manner as to alarm or disturb another and to provoke a breach of the peace; or 
(2)  With intent to annoy another, makes a telephone call, whether or not conversation ensues; or 
(3)  Transmits in any manner to the fire department of the city, a false alarm of fire, knowing at the time of such transmission that there is no reasonable ground for believing that such fire exists; or 
(4)  Transmits in any manner a false alarm to the effect that a bomb or other explosive of any nature is concealed in such a place that its explosion would endanger human life, knowing at the time of such transmission that there is no reasonable ground for believing that such bomb or explosive is concealed in such place; or 
(5)  Transmits in any manner to any peace officer, public officer or public employee, a report to the effect that an offense has been committed, knowing at the time of such transmission that there is no reasonable ground for believing that such an offense has been committed; or 
(6)  Enters upon the property of another and for a lewd or unlawful purpose deliberately looks into a dwelling on the property through any window or other opening in it. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 8-1) 
State Law reference- Authority of municipalities to prevent disorderly conduct, 65 ILCS 5/11-3; disorderly conduct, elements of offense, 720 ILCS 5/26-1. 
Sec. 16-38. - Intoxication. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to be intoxicated in any street, highway or other public place, or, in such condition to disturb the peace of the public or his own or any other family in any private building or place in the city. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 8-1) 
State Law reference- Authority of municipalities to prevent intoxication, 65 ILCS 5/11-53. 
Sec. 16-39. - Unlawful assembly. 
(a)  Whenever 12 or more persons, any of them armed with clubs or dangerous weapons, or 30 or more persons, armed or unarmed, are unlawfully, riotously or tumultuously assembled in the city, it shall be the duty of each of the city police officers to go among the persons so assembled, or as near them as safety will permit, and in the name of the state command them immediately to disperse; and if they do not obey, every person refusing to disperse shall be deemed guilty of unlawful assembly. 
(b)  When persons so unlawfully assembled neglect or refuse, on command, to disperse, it shall be the duty of the police to forthwith suppress such assembly and disperse the persons composing it, in such manner as may be most expedient. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 8-1) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 20 ILCS 1815/40. 
Sec. 16-40. - Permitting unlawful assembly. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly to permit any assemblage of persons on premises owned, occupied or controlled by him for any purpose made unlawful by this chapter. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 8-1) 
Sec. 16-41. - Mob action. 
    Mob action, which is a violation of this Code, consists of any of the following: 
(1)  The use of force or violence disturbing the public peace by two or more persons acting together and without authority of law; or 
(2)  The assembly of two or more persons to do an unlawful act; or 
(3)  The assembly of two or more persons without authority of law, for the purpose of doing violence to the person or property of anyone supposed to have been guilty of a violation of the law, or for the purpose of exercising correctional powers or regulative powers over any person by violence. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 8-1) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 38, § 25-1. 
Sec. 16-42. - Assault. 
    A person commits an assault in violation of this Code when, without lawful authority, he engages in conduct which places another in reasonable apprehension of receiving a battery. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 8-1) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 38, § 12-1. 
Sec. 16-43. - Battery. 
    A person commits battery in violation of this Code if he intentionally or knowingly without legal justification and by any means: 
(1)  Causes bodily harm to an individual; or 
(2)  Makes physical contact of an insulting or provoking nature with an individual. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 38, § 12-3. 
Sec. 16-44. - Hurling missile. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to hurl any missile on any street or alley or in any public place so as to endanger the safety of others or to damage or destroy property. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 8-1) 
Sec. 16-45. - Resisting or obstructing peace officer. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly to resist or obstruct the performance of one known to that person to be a peace officer of any authorized act within his official capacity. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 8-1; Ord. No. 13, § I, 11-22-48) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 38, § 31-1. 
Sec. 16-46. - Abusing police officer. 
    No person shall, by violent, tumultuous or obstreperous conduct or carriage, disturb any police officer in the discharge of his duties, and no person shall use unseemly, profane, obscene or offensive language in the presence of a police officer; nor shall any person assault, strike or fight with any police officer in the discharge of his duties or permit such conduct in or upon any house or premises in the city owned or possessed by him or under his management and control. 
Sec. 16-47. - Refusing to aid officer. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, upon command, to refuse or knowingly fail to aid a person known to him to be a peace officer in: 
(1)  Apprehending a person whom the officer is authorized to apprehend; or 
(2)  Preventing the commission by another of any offense. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 38, § 31-8. 
Sec. 16-48. - Disturbing funeral. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, willfully or heedlessly, to interrupt or disturb a funeral assembly or funeral procession. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 8-1) 
Sec. 16-49. - Disturbing meeting. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, willfully or heedlessly, to disturb any assemblage of persons met together for religious worship, or of a show or exhibition, theater or place of amusement, or of any assemblage of persons met together for any lawful purpose. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 8-1) 
Secs. 16-50-16-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Offenses directed against property, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 38, § 15-1 et seq.; damage and trespass to property, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 38, § 21-1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 16-61. - Criminal damage to property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to commit any of the following acts: 
(1)  Knowingly damage any property of another without his consent; or 
(2)  Recklessly by means of fire or explosive damage property of another; or 
(3)  Knowingly start a fire on the land of another without his consent; or 
(4)  Knowingly injure a domestic animal of another without his consent; or 
(5)  Knowingly deposit on the land, or in the building of another without his consent, any stink bomb or any offensive smelling compound, thereby intending to interfere with the use by another of the land or building; or 
(6)  Damage any property with intent to defraud an insurer. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 8-1) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 38, § 21-1. 
Sec. 16-62. - Criminal damage to fire-fighting apparatus or equipment. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully and maliciously cut, injure, damage, tamper with, destroy or deface any fire hydrant, fire hose or fire engine, or other public or private fire-fighting equipment, or any apparatus appertaining to such equipment, or intentionally open any fire hydrant without proper authorization. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 38, § 21-1.1. 
Sec. 16-63. - Defacing or destroying apparatus and equipment of police and fire alarm system. 
    No person shall deface, destroy or in any way injure any of the boxes, poles, wires or any other apparatus of the combined police and fire alarm telephone system in the city. 
Sec. 16-64. - Damaging utility property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, except persons in the performance of their duties, to climb public utility poles, or for any person to maliciously destroy or damage the property of a utility company or of the city. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 8-1) 
Sec. 16-65. - Damage to cemetery. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to maliciously or without lawful right deface, damage, injure or destroy any public or private property, or any grave stone, marker, tree, flower or shrub in any cemetery. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 8-1) 
Secs. 16-66-16-71. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - TRESPASS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of municipalities to prevent trespass, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 11-5-72. 

Sec. 16-72. - Criminal trespass to land. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to enter upon the land or any part thereof of another after receiving, immediately prior to such entry, notice from the owner or occupant that such entry is forbidden, or to remain upon the land of another after receiving notice from the owner or occupant to depart. 
(b)  A person has received notice from the owner or occupant within the meaning of subsection (a) if he has been notified personally, either orally or in writing, or if a printed or written notice forbidding such entry has been conspicuously posted or exhibited at the main entrance to such land or the forbidden part thereof. 
(c)  This section does not apply to any person, whether a migrant worker or otherwise, living on the land with permission of the owner or of his agent having apparent authority to hire workers on such land and assign them living quarters or a place of accommodation for living thereon, nor to anyone living on such land at the request of, or by occupancy, leasing or other agreement or arrangement with the owner or his agent, nor to anyone invited by such migrant worker or other person so living on such land to visit him at the place where he is so living upon the land. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 8-1; Ord. No. 13, § I, 11-22-48; Ord. No. 222, § 3, 9-28-70) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 38, § 21-3. 
Sec. 16-73. - Criminal trespass to vehicle, aircraft or watercraft. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly and without authority to enter any vehicle, aircraft or watercraft or any part thereof of another without his consent. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 8-1; Ord. No. 13, § I, 11-22-48; Ord. No. 222, § 3, 9-28-70) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 38, § 21-2. 
Secs. 16-74-16-79. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - THEFT 

Sec. 16-80. - Elements of offense. 
    A person commits theft in violation of this Code when he knowingly: 
(1)  Obtains or exerts unauthorized control over property of the owner; or 
(2)  Obtains by deception control over property of the owner; or 
(3)  Obtains by threat control over property of the owner; or 
(4)  Obtains control over stolen property knowing the property to have been stolen by another or under such circumstances as would reasonably induce him to believe that the property was stolen and: 
(a)  Intends to deprive the owner permanently of the use or benefit of the property; or 
(b)  Knowingly uses, conceals or abandons the property in such a manner as to deprive the owner permanently of such use or benefit; or 
(c)  Uses, conceals or abandons the property knowing such use, concealment or abandonment probably will deprive the owner permanently of such use or benefit. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 38, § 16-1. 
Sec. 16-81. - Theft of lost or mislaid property. 
    A person who obtains control over lost or mislaid property commits theft in violation of this Code when he: 
(1)  Knows or learns the identity of the owner or knows, or is aware of, or learns of a reasonable method of identifying the owner; and 
(2)  Fails to take reasonable measures to restore the property to the owner; and 
(3)  Intends to deprive the owner permanently of the use or benefit of the property. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 38, § 16-2. 
Sec. 16-82. - Theft of labor or services or use of property. 
(a)  A person commits theft in violation of this Code when he obtains the temporary use of property, labor or services of another which are available only for hire, by means of threat or deception or knowing that such use is without consent of the person providing the property, labor or services. 
(b)  A person commits theft when, after renting or leasing a motor vehicle under an agreement in writing which provides for the return of the vehicle to a particular place at a particular time, he fails to return the vehicle to said place within the time specified, and is thereafter served with a written demand, or upon whom oral demand is thereafter personally made, to return said vehicle within 72 hours from the time of the service or personal communication of such demand, and he fails to return the vehicle to any place of business of the lessor within the period. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 38, § 16-3. 
Sec. 16-83. - Taking fruit, flowers and shrubbery. 
    No person shall take and carry away from any orchard, garden, yard or other premises in the city any fruit, flowers, shrubbery or other thing. 
Secs. 16-84-16-94. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - WEAPONS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Deadly weapons generally, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 38, § 24-1 et seq. 

Sec. 16-95. - Unlawful possession of firearms and firearm ammunition. 
    A person commits the offense of unlawful possession of firearms or firearm ammunition when he: 
(1)  Is under 18 years of age and has in his possession any firearm of a size which may be concealed upon the person; or 
(2)  Is under 21 years of age, has been convicted of a misdemeanor other than a traffic offense or adjudged delinquent and has any firearms or firearm ammunition in this possession; or 
(3)  Has been convicted of a felony under the laws of this or any other jurisdiction within five years from release from a penitentiary or within five years of conviction if penitentiary sentence has not been imposed, and has any firearms or firearm ammunition in his possession; or 
(4)  Is a narcotic addict and has any firearms or firearm ammunition in his possession; or 
(5)  Has been a patient in a mental hospital within the past five years and has any firearms or firearm ammunition in his possession; or 
(6)  Is mentally retarded and has any firearms or firearm ammunition in his possession. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 38, § 24-3.1. 
Sec. 16-96. - Concealed weapons. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to carry concealed upon or about his person any revolver or other dangerous or deadly weapon or instrument capable of inflicting serious bodily injury, or to flourish or display such instrument in a boisterous or threatening manner. This clause shall not apply to public officers having police power. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 8-1) 
Sec. 16-97. - Register of sales by dealer. 
(a)  Any seller of firearms of a size which may be concealed upon the person, other than a manufacturer selling to a bona fide wholesaler or retailer or a wholesaler selling to a bona fide retailer, shall keep a register of all firearms sold or given away. 
(b)  Such register shall contain the date of the sale or gift, the name, address, age and occupation of the person to whom the weapon is sold or given, the price of the weapon, the kind, description and number of the weapon, and the purpose for which it is purchased and obtained. 
(c)  Such seller on demand of a peace officer shall produce, for inspection, the register and allow such peace officer to inspect such register and all stock on hand. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 38, § 24-4. 
Sec. 16-98. - Defacing identification marks of firearms. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to change, alter, remove or obliterate the name of the maker, model, manufacturer's number or other mark of identification of any firearm. 
(b)  Possession of any firearm upon which any such mark shall have been changed, altered, removed or obliterated shall be prima facie evidence that the possessor has changed, altered, removed or obliterated the same. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 38, § 24-5. 
Sec. 16-99. - Discharging firearms or air gun in city. 
    No person shall fire or discharge any firearms or air gun in the city without written permission from the chief of police, which permission shall prescribe the limits within which such firing may be done and may be revoked at any time after it has been granted. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 8-1) 
Secs. 16-100-16-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - MINORS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Sale of alcoholic beverages to persons under 21 years of age, § 4-7; receiving precious metals and gems from minors, 14-65. 

Sec. 16-111. - Entering, frequenting, remaining in billiard, poolroom. 
    It shall be unlawful for: 
(1)  Any person under the age of 16 to enter, frequent, loiter or remain in any room or establishment which is occupied and used as a billiard or poolroom unless such person is accompanied by a parent or a legal guardian; and 
(2)  Any person under the age of 18 to enter, frequent, loiter or remain in any room or establishment which is occupied and used as a billiard or poolroom during school hours on any day school is in session or to remain in any establishment after 10:00 p.m. local time unless such person is accompanied by a parent or a legal guardian. 
(Ord. No. 199, § 1, 4-28-69) 
Sec. 16-112. - Permitting minor to remain in billiard or poolroom. 
    It shall be unlawful for the proprietor, manager, operator or other person in charge of any such billiard or poolroom to allow or permit any person to enter, frequent, loiter or remain in any such establishment in violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 199, § 2, 4-28-69) 
Sec. 16-113. - Proprietors of billiard, poolrooms to post notice to minors. 
    It shall be unlawful for any proprietor, manager or operator of any such billiard or poolroom or hall to operate such establishment unless there is posted in a conspicuous place, so that the same can be read from outside the premises, a notice substantially as follows: 
"PERSONS UNDER THE AGE OF 16 YEARS ARE FORBIDDEN BY CITY ORDINANCE TO ENTER OR BE ON THESE PREMISES UNLESS ACCOMPANIED BY A PARENT OR A LEGAL GUARDIAN." 
(Ord. No. 199, § 3, 4-28-69) 
Sec. 16-114. - Curfew for persons under 17 years of age-Established. 
(a)  Definitions. As used in this section, unless the context requires otherwise, the following words or phrases shall mean: 
    City curfew hours means the period of 11:00 p.m. on any Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday or Thursday until 6:00 a.m. on the following day; and 12:01 a.m. until 6:00 a.m. on any Friday or Saturday. 
    Court means the Second Judicial Circuit, Wabash County, Illinois. 
    Custodian means: 
(1)  A person who under court order is the custodian of the person of a minor; or 
(2)  A public or private agency with which the court has placed a minor; or 
(3)  A person acting in the role of a parent by reason of a private agreement, arrangement, custom or habit. 
    Emergency means an unforeseen combination of circumstances or the resulting state that calls for immediate action. The term includes, but is not limited to, fire, natural disaster, automobile accident, medical emergency or any situation requiring immediate action to prevent serious bodily injury or loss of life. 
    Establishment means any privately owned place of business to which the public is invited, including but not limited to any place of amusement or entertainment. 
    Guardian means: 
(1)  A parent; or 
(2)  A person who under court order is the guardian of the person of the minor; or 
(3)  A public or private agency on with which the court has placed the minor. 
    Minor means any person under 17 years of age. 
    Parent means a person who is a natural parent, adoptive parent, or stepparent of another person. 
    Public place means any place to which the public or a substantial group of the public has access and includes, but is not limited to, streets, highways, public ways, sidewalks, and the common areas of schools, hospitals, apartment houses, office buildings, transport facilities and shops. 
    Responsible adult means a person at least 18 years of age, authorized by a parent, guardian or custodian to have the care and custody of a minor. 
    Serious bodily injury means bodily injury that creates a substantial risk of death, serious permanent disfigurement or protracted loss or impairment of the function of any bodily member or organ. 
(b)  Curfew restrictions. 
(1)  It is unlawful for any minor to be present in any public place or on the premises of an establishment within the city during city curfew hours. 
(2)  It is unlawful for any parent or guardian or custodian of a minor to knowingly permit, or by insufficient control to allow, the minor to be present in any public place or on the premises of any establishment within the city during city curfew hours. 
(3)  It is a defense to prosecution under section (b)(1) or (b)(2) or (c) (hereinafter) that the minor was: 
a.  Accompanied by the minor's parent, guardian, custodian or responsible adult; 
b.  On an errand at the direction of the minor's parent, guardian or responsible adult; without any detour or stop; 
c.  In a motor vehicle involved in interstate travel with the consent or authorization of a parent, guardian or custodian; 
d.  Engaged in, going to or returning home from an employment activity without any detour or stop; 
e.  Involved in an emergency; 
f.  On the sidewalk abutting the minor's residence; 
g.  Engaged in, going to or returning home from an official school, religious, or other recreational activity supervised by adults, sponsored by the city, a civic organization, or other similar activity that takes responsibility for the minor; 
h.  Exercising First Amendment rights protected by the United States Constitution; or 
i.  Emancipated pursuant to law. 
(c)  Establishment restrictions. It is unlawful for any owner, operator or any employee of an establishment to allow a minor to be present or to remain upon the premises of the establishment in violation of paragraph (b) above during curfew hours. It is a defense to prosecution under this subparagraph if the owner, operator or employee of an establishment immediately upon discovery of a minor reasonably believed to be in violation of paragraph (b) notified the police department that a minor was present on the premises of the establishment during curfew hours and refused to leave the establishment after being advised to do so by the owner, operator or employee. 
(d)  Enforcement. 
(1)  Every member of the police department while on duty is hereby authorized to temporarily detain any minor violating the provisions of this article (regardless of whether a citation is immediately issued) until the parent, custodian or guardian of the minor shall take him or her into custody, but such officer shall immediately upon taking custody of the minor reasonably attempt to communicate with the parent, custodian or guardian of the minor. A parent, custodian or guardian must take custody of the minor within one hour of the time of notice or be subject to a charge of $25.00 per hour as hereinafter provided. 
(2)  Whenever a police officer witnesses or has knowledge based on reasonable grounds of a violation of this section by any person, such person may be issued a citation. A citation or complaint may be made to a police officer by any person. 
(3)  A citation issued hereunder this shall be in writing and shall: 
a.  State the name of the person being cited and the person's address, if known; 
b.  Set forth the specific section of this section which was violated, the date of the violation and a brief description of the violation; 
c.  Be signed by the issuing police officer or complaining party. 
In each instance where a citation is issued to a minor for violation of this article a minor's parent, custodian or guardian shall be provided a copy of the citation notifying the parent, custodian or guardian of the charge made against the minor. 
(4)  A minor cited for a violation under this article must attend a court hearing on the citation and must be accompanied at the hearing by his or her parent, guardian, custodian or other adult person having the legal care and custody of the minor. If any such person fails to attend any court hearing with the minor, and unless the interest of justice would otherwise be served, the court may continue the hearing and shall issue a notice or a rule to show cause to the person directing that said person to appear at the continued hearing with the minor. Failure of the person to thereafter fail to appear shall subject such person to sanctions for contempt of court as determined by the court. 
(e)  Penalty. 
(1)  Any person who violates any provision of this article shall upon conviction thereof be fined not less than $5.00 nor more than $200.00; and a separate offense shall be deemed to have been committed upon each day on which such violation occurs or continues. 
(2)  In lieu of or in addition to a fine, a minor may be ordered to attend counseling or to perform ten hours of court approved community service during times other than the minor's hours of school attendance and/or the minor's parents, guardian, custodian or other adult person having legal care or custody of the minor may be ordered to attend a parenting class or a series of parenting classes or other counseling approved by the court. 
(3)  In addition to any penalty imposed pursuant to (1) or (2) above, the minor's parents, guardian, custodian or other adult person having legal care or custody of the minor may be ordered to pay all amounts imposed as civil liability under paragraph (f) hereinafter. 
(f)  Civil liability. If a minor is detained for a period of time in excess of one hour which requires the supervision of the minor by personnel of the city police department, the parent, guardian, custodian or other adult having the legal care and custody of the minor shall be jointly and severally liable for the costs therefor. The parent guarding, custodian or other adult having the legal care and custody of a minor who has committed any offense of this article shall be assessed and billed for the costs; the costs shall be recoverable in any action enforcing any provision of this article or in a separate civil action. In addition, failure to pay the costs shall constitute a violation of this article and subject the violator to the penalties described within paragraph (e) above. In the event any action is filed the liable party shall be responsible for all court costs and any reasonable attorney's fees incurred by the city in collecting. 
(g)  City costs. In addition to the penalties provided herein, the city shall be entitled to recover all court costs, fees and city attorney fees paid by the city to enforce this article. 
(Ord. No. 186, § 1, 7-68; Ord. No. 679, 7-14-97; Ord. No. 750, 2-5-01; Ord. No. 764, 9-4-01) 
Secs. 16-115, 16-116. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 750, adopted February 5, 2001, amended the Code by repealing former §§ 16-115 and 16-116 in their entirety. Former § 16-115 pertained to violation of curfew by parents and guardians. Former § 16-116 pertained to authority of police. Both sections derived from Ord. No. 186, adopted July 22, 1968. 
Sec. 16-117. - Parental responsibility for certain acts of minors. 
(a)  Definitions. As used in this section, unless the context requires otherwise, the following definitions shall apply: 
(1)  "Property" shall include any real estate, and the improvements thereon, and all tangible personalty. 
(2)  "Parent" shall include the lawful father and mother of a minor child, whether by birth or adoption. 
(3)  "Legal guardian" shall include a foster parent, a person appointed guardian of a person, or given custody, of a minor, except a person appointed guardian, or given custody of a minor, under the Juvenile Court Act of the State of Illinois. 
(4)  "Minor" means a person who is above the age of 11 years, but not yet 19 years of age. 
(5)  "Acts of vandalism" shall include, but shall not be limited to, any of the following acts: 
a.  Maliciously, recklessly or knowingly damaging or destroying any property of another person without that person's consent; or 
b.  Maliciously, recklessly or knowingly by means of fire or explosive device damaging, debasing or destroying any property of another person; or 
c.  Maliciously, recklessly or knowingly starting a fire on land of another person without his consent; or 
d.  Maliciously, recklessly or knowingly depositing on the land or on the building of another person, without his consent, any stink bomb or any offensive smelling compound which thereby interferes with the use and occupancy by another of the said land or building; or 
e.  Maliciously, recklessly or knowingly and without authority entering into or obtaining control over any building, house trailer, motor vehicle, aircraft or water craft, or any part thereof, of another person without that person's consent. 
(b)  Parental responsibility. The parent or legal guardian of an unemancipated minor residing with such parent or legal guardian shall be presumed, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, to have failed to exercise proper parental responsibility, and said minor shall be deemed to have committed the acts described above with the knowledge and permission of the parent or guardian, in violation of this section, upon the occurrence of the events described in subsections (1), (2) and (3) below: 
(1)  An unemancipated minor residing with said parent or legal guardian shall either be adjudicated to be in violation of any ordinance, law or statute prohibiting willful and malicious acts causing injury to a person or property, or shall have incurred nonjudicial sanctions from another official agency resulting from an admission of guilt of violation of any ordinance, law or statute prohibiting willful and malicious acts causing injury to a person or property; and, 
(2)  Said parent or legal guardian shall have received a written notice thereof, by certified or registered mail, return receipt requested, or by personal service with certificate of personal service returned, from the chief of police of the city or his designated representative, following said adjudication or nonjudicial sanction; and
