(3)  If at any time within one year following receipt of the notice set forth in (b)(2) above, said minor is either adjudicated to be in violation of any ordinance, law or statute as described in (b)(1) above, or shall have incurred nonjudicial sanctions from another official agency resulting from an admission of guilt of violation of any ordinance, law or statute as described in (b)(1) above. 
(c)  Any person convicted of any violation of the provisions of this section shall be fined not less than $25.00, nor more than $500.00, for each such offense. 
(Ord. No. 389, §§ 1-3, 12-11-78) 
Editor's note- Section 16-117 is derived from Ord. No. 389, §§ 1-3, which ordinance did not expressly amend this Code. 
Secs. 16-118-16-127. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - GAMBLING[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of municipality to suppress gambling and gambling houses, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 11-5-1. 

Sec. 16-128. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them: 
    Gambling device is any clock, tape machine, slot machine or other machine or device for the reception of money or other thing of value on chance or skill or upon the action of which money or other thing of value is staked, hazarded, bet, won or lost or any mechanism, furniture, fixture, equipment or other device designed primarily for use in a gambling place. A "gambling device" does not include: 
(1)  A coin-in-the-slot operated mechanical device played for amusement which rewards the player with the right to replay such mechanical device, which device is so constructed or devised as to make such result of the operation thereof depend in part upon the skill of the player and which returns to the player thereof no money, property or right to receive money or property. 
(2)  Vending machines by which full and adequate return is made for the money invested and in which there is no element of chance or hazard. 
    Lottery is any scheme or procedure whereby one or more prizes are distributed by chance among persons who have paid or promised consideration for a chance to win the prizes, whether the scheme or procedure is called a lottery, raffle, gift, sale or some other name. 
    Policy game is any scheme or procedure whereby a person promises or guarantees by any instrument, bill, certificate, writing, token or other device that any particular number, character, ticket or certificate shall in the event of any contingency in the nature of a lottery entitle the purchaser or holder to receive money, property or evidence of debt. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 38, § 28-2. 
Sec. 16-129. - Acts constituting gambling. 
(a)  A person commits the offense of gambling when he: 
(1)  Plays a game of chance or skill for money or other thing of value, unless excepted in subsection (b); or 
(2)  Makes a wager upon the result of any game, contest or any political nomination, appointment or election; or 
(3)  Operates, keeps, owns, uses, purchases, exhibits, rents, sells, bargains for the sale or lease of, manufactures or distributes any gambling device; or 
(4)  Contracts to have or give himself or another the option to buy or sell, or contracts to buy or sell, at a future time, any grain or other commodity whatsoever, or any stock or security of any company, where it is at the time of making such contract intended by both parties thereto that the contract to buy or sell, or the option, whenever exercised, or the contract resulting therefrom, shall be settled, not by the receipt or delivery of such property, but by the payment only of differences in prices thereof; however, the issuance, purchase, sale, exercise, endorsement or guarantee, by or through a person registered with the secretary of state pursuant to section 8 of the Illinois Securities Law of 1953, (Illinois Revised Statutes, chapter 1211/2, section 137.8), or by or through a person exempt from such registration under said section 8, of a put, call or other option to buy or sell securities which have been registered with the secretary of state or which are exempt from such registration under section 3 of the Illinois Securities Law of 1953, is not gambling within the meaning of this paragraph; or 
(5)  Knowingly owns or possesses any book, instrument or apparatus by means of which bets or wages have been, or are, recorded or registered, or knowingly possesses any money which he has received in the course of a bet or wager; or 
(6)  Sells pools upon the result of any game or contest of skill or chance, political nomination, appointment or election; or 
(7)  Sets up or promotes any lottery or sells, offers to sell or transfers any ticket or share for any lottery; provided, however, that this subsection shall not apply to any lottery established by the state and conducted pursuant to state authority; or 
(8)  Sets up or promotes any policy game or sells, offers to sell or knowingly possesses or transfers any policy ticket, slip, record, document or other similar device; or 
(9)  Knowingly advertises any lottery or policy game or drafts, prints or publishes any lottery ticket or share, or any policy ticket, slip, record, document or similar device, or any advertisement of any lottery or policy game; or 
(10)  Knowingly transmits information as to wagers, betting odds, or changes in betting odds by telephone, telegraph, radio, semaphore or similar means; or knowingly installs or maintains equipment for the transmission or receipt of such information; except that nothing in this paragraph prohibits transmission or receipt of such information for use in news reporting of sporting events or contests. 
(b)  Participants in any of the following activities shall not be convicted of gambling: 
(1)  Agreements to compensate for loss caused by the happening of chance including without limitation contracts of indemnity or guaranty and life or health or accident insurance; and 
(2)  Offers of prizes, award or compensation to the actual contestants in any bona fide contest for the determination of skill, speed, strength or endurance or to the owners of animals or vehicles entered in such contest; and 
(3)  Pari-mutuel betting as authorized by the law of the state; and 
(4)  Manufacture of gambling devices, including the acquisition of essential parts therefor and the assembly thereof, for transportation in interstate or foreign commerce to any place outside the state when such transportation is not prohibited by any applicable federal law; and 
(5)  The game commonly known as "bingo," when conducted in accordance with Illinois Revised Statutes, chapter 120, sections 1101 through 1107. 
(6)  Video gaming terminals where the licensee has obtained the necessary permits and licenses in the state and has complied with the Illinois Video Gaming Act for video gaming terminals shall not constitute gambling. 
(Ord. No. 978, 6-11-12) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 38, § 28-1. 
Sec. 16-130. - Seizure of gambling devices and gambling funds. 
(a)  Every gambling device which is incapable of lawful use is contraband and shall be subject to seizure, confiscation and destruction by the city. As used in this section, a "gambling device which is incapable of lawful use" includes any slot machine, and includes any machine or device constructed for the reception of money or other thing of value and so constructed as to return on chance to the player thereof money, property or a right to receive money or property. 
(b)  Every gambling device shall be seized and forfeited as contraband to the county. Any money or other thing of value integrally related to acts of gambling shall be seized and forfeited as contraband to the county. 
(c)  If, within 60 days after any seizure pursuant to subsection (b), a person having any property interest in the seized property is charged with an offense, the court which renders judgment upon such charge shall, within 30 days after such judgment, conduct a forfeiture hearing to determine whether such property was contraband at the time of seizure. Such hearing shall be commenced by a written petition by the city, including material allegations of fact, the name and address of every person determined by the city to have any property interest in the seized property, a representation that written notice of the date, time and place of such hearing has been mailed to every such person by certified mail at least ten days before such date, and a request for forfeiture. Every such person may appear as a party and present evidence at such hearing. The quantum of proof required shall be a preponderance of the evidence, and the burden of proof shall be on the city. If the court determines that the seized property was contraband at the time of seizure, an order of forfeiture and disposition of the seized property shall be entered. A gambling device shall be received by the city attorney, who shall effect its destruction, except that valuable parts thereof may be liquidated and the resultant money shall be deposited in the general fund of the county wherein such seizure occurred; money and other things of value shall be received by the city attorney and, upon liquidation, shall be deposited in the general fund of the county wherein such seizure occurred. Such order of forfeiture and disposition shall, for the purposes of appeal, be a final order and judgment in a civil proceeding. 
(d)  If a seizure pursuant to subsection (b) is not followed by a charge pursuant to subsection (c), or if the prosecution of such charge is permanently terminated or indefinitely discontinued without any judgment of conviction or acquittal: 
(1)  The city attorney shall commence an in rem proceeding for the forfeiture and destruction of a gambling device, or for the forfeiture and deposit in the general fund of the county of any seized money or other things of value, or both, in a court having jurisdiction; and 
(2)  Any person having any property interest in such seized gambling device, money or other thing of value may commence separate civil proceedings in the manner provided by law. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 38, § 28-5. 
Secs. 16-131-16-141. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - LITTERING 

Sec. 16-142. - Prohibited on public property. 
    No person, or the agent or employee of any person, shall throw, drop, place, deposit, discard or let fall, or cause such to be done, on any public street, highway, roadway, thoroughfare, sidewalk, pathway, lawn, park, parkway, waterway, stream, brook, parking lot, cemetery or other public place or public building within the city any paper, glass, plastic, wood, metal, solid or liquid vegetable or animal compound, rubbish, garbage, waste, effluent, junk, debris, litter, any solid, or any combination thereof, other than in a trash receptacle or official landfill site of the city. 
Sec. 16-143. - When prohibited on private property. 
    No person, or the agent or employee of any person, shall throw, drop, place, deposit, discard or let fall or cause any littering prohibited by this article on public property, or any private property within the city where the litter is likely to blow, flow, move, drain, scatter or be blown, moved, drained or scattered onto public property or public water under normal or predictable weather or environmental conditions in the city; however, this section does not apply to home garbage disposals, or to commercial garbage disposals where permits have been issued by the city. 
Secs. 16-144-16-154. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - OFFENSES AGAINST MORALS[8] 
Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of municipality to suppress bawdy houses and obscene publications, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 11-5-1; authority of municipality to prevent prostitution, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 11-5-4; sex offenses generally, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 38, § 11-1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 16-155. - Public indecency. 
(a)  Any person age 17 years or older who performs any of the following acts in a public place commits a public indecency, which is a violation of this Code: 
(1)  An act of sexual intercourse; or 
(2)  An act of deviate sexual conduct; or 
(3)  A lewd exposure of the body done with intent to arouse or to satisfy the sexual desire of the person; or 
(4)  A lewd fondling or caress of the body of another person of either sex. 
(b)  "Public place" for purposes of this section means any place where the conduct may reasonably be expected to be viewed by others. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 8-1) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 38, § 11-9. 
Sec. 16-156. - Public bathing. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to bathe in any public place open to public view unless clothed in an adequate garment. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 8-1) 
Sec. 16-157. - Prostitution. 
    Any person who performs, offers or agrees to perform any of the following acts for money commits an act of prostitution in violation of this Code: 
(1)  Any act of sexual intercourse; or 
(2)  Any act of deviate sexual conduct. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 8-1) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 38, § 11-14. 
Sec. 16-158. - Keeping a place of prostitution. 
    Any person who has or exercises control over the use of any place which could offer seclusion or shelter for the practice of prostitution or performs any of the following acts keeps a place of prostitution in violation of this Code: 
(1)  Knowingly grants or permits the use of such place for the purpose of prostitution; or 
(2)  Grants or permits the use of such place under circumstances from which he could reasonably know that the place is used or is to be used for purposes of prostitution; or 
(3)  Permits the continued use of a place after becoming aware of facts or circumstances from which he should reasonably know that the place is being used for purposes of prostitution. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 8-1) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 38, § 11-17. 
Secs. 16-159-16-164. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - OBSCENITY[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of municipality to prohibit sale or exhibition of obscene or immoral publications, pictures or illustrations, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 11-5-1; obscenity generally, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 38, § 11-20; harmful material, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 38, § 11-21. 

Sec. 16-165. - Definitions. 
    As used in this division, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them: 
    Distribute shall mean to transfer possession of, whether with or without consideration. 
    Harmful material. Material is "harmful" if, to the average person, applying contemporary standards, its predominant appeal, taken as a whole, is to prurient interest, that is a shameful or morbid interest in nudity, sex or excretion, which goes substantially beyond customary limits of candor in description or representation of such matters, and is material the redeeming social importance of which is substantially less than its prurient appeal. 
    Knowingly shall mean having knowledge of the contents of the subject matter, or recklessly failing to exercise reasonable inspection which would have disclosed the contents thereof. 
    Material shall mean any writing, picture, record or other representation or embodiment. 
    Obscene. Material shall be "obscene," if, considered as a whole, its predominant appeal is to prurient interest, that is, a shameful or morbid interest in nudity, sex or excretion, and if it goes substantially beyond customary limits of candor in description or representation of such matters. Material shall be obscene even though the obscenity is latent, as in the case of undeveloped photographs. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 38, §§ 11-20(b), 11-21(b). 
Sec. 16-166. - Acts constituting obscenity enumerated. 
    A person commits obscenity in violation of this Code when, with knowledge of the nature or content thereof, or recklessly failing to exercise reasonable inspection which would have disclosed the nature or content thereof, he: 
(1)  Sells, delivers or provides, or offers or agrees to sell, deliver or provide any obscene writing, picture, record or other representation or embodiment of the obscene; or 
(2)  Presents or directs an obscene play, dance or other performance or participates directly in that portion thereof which makes it obscene; or 
(3)  Publishes, exhibits or otherwise makes available anything obscene; or 
(4)  Performs an obscene act or otherwise presents an obscene exhibition of his body for gain; or 
(5)  Creates, buys, procures or possesses obscene matter or material with intent to disseminate it in violation of this section, or of the penal laws or regulations of any other jurisdiction; or 
(6)  Advertises or otherwise promotes the sale of material represented or held out by him to be obscene, whether or not it is obscene. 
(7)  Breeds animals open to the public view. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 8-1) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 38, § 11-20(a). 
Sec. 16-167. - Distribution of harmful material. 
    A person who, with knowledge that a person is under 18 years of age, or who fails to exercise reasonable care in ascertaining the true age of such a person, knowingly distributes to or sends or causes to be sent to, or exhibits to, or offers to distribute or exhibit any harmful material to that person, is guilty of a misdemeanor. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 38, § 11-21(a). 
Sec. 16-168. - Falsifying age to obtain harmful material. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person under 18 years of age to falsely state, either orally or in writing, that he is not under the age of 18 years, or to present or offer to any person any evidence of age and identity which is false or not actually his own for the purpose of ordering, obtaining, viewing or otherwise procuring or attempting to procure or view any harmful material. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 38, § 11-21(f). 
Sec. 16-169. - Tie-in sales of obscene publications to distributors. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or any agent, officer or employee thereof, engaged in the business of distributing books, magazines, periodicals, comic books or other publications to retail dealers, to refuse to furnish to any retail dealer such quantity of books, magazines, periodicals, comic books or other publications as such retail dealer normally sells because the retail dealer refuses to sell, or offer for sale, any books, magazines, periodicals, comic books or other publications which are obscene, lewd, lascivious, filthy or indecent. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 38, § 11-22. 
Sec. 16-170-16-178. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - SCRAP METAL MERCHANTS 

Sec. 16-179. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following term shall have the meaning indicated in this section: 
    Scrap metal merchant shall mean any entity (person, firm, company, partnership, association, or corporation) who purchases products containing ferrous or nonferrous metals for recycling or resale. Ferrous metals contain iron, for example, mild steel, high-carbon steel, stainless steel and iron. Non-ferrous metals for example, aluminum, brass and copper or any other metal alloy containing these materials. 
(Ord. No. 970, 12-27-11) 
Sec. 16-180. - Cash payments. 
    For all purchases of scrap metal paid for in cash, the scrap metal merchant shall obtain the following information from the seller of the products containing ferrous or non-ferrous material. 
(1)  A complete and accurate description of all property taken, purchased, or received by such merchant in the regular course of business, 
(2)  The date and time of the purchase, 
(3)  The correct legal name, date of birth and place of residence, including city and state, 
(4)  A photograph of such person, 
(5)  A copy of the driver's license, or if not available, a copy of the individual's military identification, passport, or other approved state identification number, 
(6)  License plate number of the vehicle delivering the material, 
(7)  The amount paid for the property and the name of the employee handling the transaction. 
(Ord. No. 970, 12-27-11) 
Sec. 16-181. - Check payments to corporations or businesses. 
    Except as provided in subsection (7), for all purchases of scrap metal from a corporation or business and paid for by pre-numbered check drawn on the regular bank account of the scrap metal merchant and made payable to the legal name of the corporation or business, the scrap metal merchant shall obtain and maintain on file, the following information from the seller of the products containing ferrous or non-ferrous metals. 
(1)  A complete and accurate description of all property taken, purchased, or received by such merchant in the regular course of business, 
(2)  The date and time of the delivery, 
(3)  The Federal Employer Identification Number of the payee on the check (FEIN), 
(4)  The name and full address of the driver delivering the product, 
(5)  License plate number of the vehicle delivering the material, and 
(6)  The amount paid for the property and the name of the employee handling the transaction. 
(7)  In the event the scrap metal is delivered in a vehicle belonging to the scrap metal merchant and driven by an employee of the scrap metal merchant, the scrap metal merchant shall only be required to maintain the information required by subsections (1), (2) and (6). 
(8)  In the event any of the above is not available and on file at the scrap metal merchant's office, the information obtained shall be the same as required for a cash purchase. 
(9)  Checks may not be converted to cash by a scrap metal merchant or by any related entity. 
(Ord. No. 970, 12-27-11) 
Sec. 16-182. - Time of purchase record requirements. 
    Every scrap metal merchant shall keep the information required in the above either in writing or in a retrievable electronic format at such merchant's place of business. Such records shall be made at the time of the purchase of the property and in no event later than close of the business day subsequent to the time of purchase. Such information shall be delivered to the city police department weekly. 
(Ord. No. 970, 12-27-11) 
Sec. 16-183. - Record keeping period. 
    Records required by this article shall be maintained by the scrap metal merchant at such merchant's place of business for not less than two years following the date of transaction. 
(Ord. No. 970, 12-27-11) 
Sec. 16-184. - Legal age to purchase required. 
    No purchases shall be made from persons not of legal age. 
(Ord. No. 970, 12-27-11) 
Sec. 16-185. - Record exemptions. 
    The following types of property and/or transactions are not subject to the record keeping requirements of this section: 
(1)  Recyclable food and beverage containers. 
(2)  Transactions involving materials purchased directly from a regulated public utility. 
(Ord. No. 970, 12-27-11) 
Sec. 16-186. - Hold notice. 
    When a police officer has reasonable cause to believe that any property received by a scrap metal merchant is stolen, the police officer may place a hold notice upon the suspected stolen property. The identified property upon which a hold notice has been placed must be held by the scrap metal merchant at such merchant's place of business for 30 calendar days unless released sooner by authority of the police chief or his designee. After 30 calendar days, unless other disposition is authorized by the police chief or his designee, the hold is automatically released and scrap processor may dispose of the property. 
(Ord. No. 970, 12-27-11) 
Sec. 16-187. - Police access. 
    Every scrap metal merchant and every person employed by them in the conduct of their business shall admit to any and every part of the business premises at any time any law enforcement officer or other official designated by the chief of police of the city to examine, photograph, or copy any goods, articles, things, books, or other records on the premises to determine compliance with this article, and to search for and to place a hold upon any article known or believed by such officer or official to have been stolen. 
(Ord. No. 970, 12-27-11) 
Sec. 16-188. - Violations. 
    Any scrap metal merchant who shall conduct business in violation of any of the provisions of this article shall be subject to a fine of not more than $500.00 per violation, or a term of imprisonment of not more than 90 days or by both a fine and imprisonment, plus legal fees. Every transaction conducted by a scrap metal merchant in violation of the provisions of this ordinance shall be deemed a separate violation. 
(Ord. No. 970, 12-27-11) 
ARTICLE XI. - CANNABIS 
OFFENSES 

Sec. 16-189. - Definitions. 
    All terms and phrases used herein shall have the same meaning as ascribed to them in the Cannabis Control Act (720 ILCS 550/1 et. seq.) and the Drug Paraphernalia Control Act (720 ILCS 600/1 et al.) 
(Ord. No. 1059, 9-26-16) 
Sec. 16-190. - Offense of possession of cannabis. 
    A person commits the offense of possession of cannabis within the incorporated area of the city or areas of primary local police enforcement by the police department as defined by intergovernmental agreement between the police department and as approved by the board of commissioners and the city council by knowingly possessing not more than ten grams of any substance containing cannabis unless permitted or authorized to do so pursuant to the Cannabis Control Act (720 ILCS 550/4). 
(Ord. No. 1059, 9-26-16) 
Sec. 16-191. - Offense of possession of drug paraphernalia. 
    If a person violates section 16-190 and is in possession of any drug paraphernalia during the violation of section 16-190, the drug paraphernalia shall be seized and the person shall be subject to a separate civil law violation. 
(Ord. No. 1059, 9-26-16) 
Sec. 16-192. - Violations, penalties. 
(a)  Any person violating section 16-190 and/or section 16-191 shall be subject to a mandatory fine of $200.00 per violation. 
(1)  The $200.00 fine shall be paid in the office of the county circuit clerk by the date provided on the citation. 
(2)  The county circuit clerk shall distribute the proceeds of the fine within 30 days after the deposit of the same as follows: 
County clerk's office ..... $10.00 
Guardian Center child advocacy center ..... 10.00 
County drug court program ..... 15.00 
County states attorney drug enforcement fund ..... 10.00 
Office of the state's attorneys appellate prosecutor ..... 10.00 
County states attorney's office ..... 10.00 
County crimestoppers ..... 10.00 
Wabash County project success ..... 10.00 
Law enforcement agency that issued the citation ..... 115.00 
(Ord. No. 1059, 9-26-16) 
Sec. 16-193. - Jury demand. 
    Any person with a citation for violation of section 16-190 and/or section 16-191 of this article may demand a jury trial by filing a jury demand and paying a jury demand fee when entering his or her appearance, plea, answer to the charge, or other responsive pleading. 
(1)  The prosecuting entity must prove the ordinance violation by a preponderance of the evidence, meaning it is more likely true than not that the violation occurred. 
(2)  In any trial for violation of section 16-190 and/or section 16-191 of this article for possession of cannabis or possession of drug paraphernalia that is punishable by only a fine, cannabis shall only be admitted into evidence based upon: 
a.  A properly administered field test; or 
b.  Opinion testimony of a peace officer based on the officer's training and experience as qualified by the court. 
(3)  If the defendant is found in violation of this article at trial the court shall impose the fine authorized by this article and court costs shall be imposed. In addition to the fine and court costs, the court may impose restitution and/or other appropriate penalties in consideration of the evidence and information offered by the parties in consideration of the penalties and/or conditions sought. 
(4)  Either party shall have the right to appeal any final judgment entered in a Code violation case pursuant to Illinois Supreme Court Rule 303. 
(Ord. No. 1059, 9-26-16) 
Sec. 16-194. - Default judgment. 
    A default judgment may be entered in the event the person fails to appear in court or answer the charge made on the date set for the defendant's court appearance or any date to which the case is continued. An arrest warrant may issue if the defendant fails to appear at any hearing. 
(Ord. No. 1059, 9-26-16) 
Sec. 16-195. - Seizure. 
    Any person violating section 16-190 and/or section 16-191 shall have the cannabis and/or drug paraphernalia in their possession seized by the law enforcement agency that issued the citation. 
(Ord. No. 1059, 9-26-16) 
Sec. 16-196. - Forfeiture. 
    By paying the $200.00 fine in the office of the county circuit clerk, any person violating section 16-190 and/or section 16-191 is forfeiting as contraband any cannabis and/or drug paraphernalia seized to the law enforcement agency that issued the citation. 
    The provisions of this article are severable. The invalidity of any portion of this article shall not be considered to invalidate the remainder. 
    Any ordinance in direct, express conflict with this article is hereby repealed to the extent of such conflict. 
    No provision of this article shall prevent the county state's attorney from prosecuting any matter which is a criminal violation under the laws of this state under a separate misdemeanor or felony case. 
(Ord. No. 1059, 9-26-16) 
Chapter 161/2 - OIL AND GAS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 371, § 1, adopted March 13, 1978, amended this Code by adding provisions designated ch. 22, §§ 22-1-22-24, which provisions were redesignated by the editors as ch. 161/2, §§ 161/2-1-161/2-24, in order to preserve the alphabetical arrangement of chapters within the Code. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 161/2-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this Code, the following terms when used in this chapter are hereby defined as follows: 
(a)  Well or wells: The term "well" or "wells" as used herein shall be construed to mean the hole or holes which is, or are, drilled or put down for the purpose of mining for and producing petroleum and natural gas, or either of them, within the city limits of the city, or wells which are physically located outside the city limits but produced from formations lying under the city limits. 
(b)  Person: The term "person" shall mean and include both the singular and plural and shall also mean and include a natural person, individual, firm, co-partnership, association, corporation, society, syndicate or any other organization or combination of persons or individuals. 
(c)  Oil: The term "oil" shall mean and include petroleum. 
(d)  Gas: The term "gas" shall mean and include natural gas. 
(e)  Block: The term "block" shall mean any outlot as shown on the original plat of the city, except as hereinafter provided, and in the area shown on said original plat laid out in lots, each group of eight in lots surrounded by public streets shall constitute a block; each of the numbered blocks in Glick and Hinde's addition to the city shall constitute a block. Each of the lettered lots of Ficklin's Addition to the city shall constitute a block. Each of the lettered blocks in the subdivision of the commons in the city shall constitute a block. In Sunnyside and Westover Heights, McDowell's and Hinde's addition to the city, a block shall consist of the areas in such additions bounded by and separated from each other by public streets. 
(f)  City: The term "city" shall mean the City of Mount Carmel, Illinois. 
(g)  City clerk: The term "city clerk" shall mean the clerk of the city. 
(h)  Mayor: The term "mayor" shall mean the mayor of the city. 
(i)  Council: The term "council" shall mean the council of the city. 
(j)  Permittee: The term "permittee" shall man the person to whom a permit has been granted under the terms of this Code. 
(k)  Lessee: The term "lessee" shall mean a person holding an oil and gas lease on real estate in the city. 
(l)  Owner: The term "owner" shall mean the owner of real estate in the city. 
(Ord. No. 371, § 1, 3-13-78; Ord. No. 672, 5-19-97) 
Sec. 161/2-2. - Occupation declared hazardous. 
    It is hereby declared that the business of drilling for, obtaining and producing and marketing oil and gas in the corporate limits of the city is a hazardous and dangerous occupation and business, and that it is necessary in the public interest and for protection of the health of the inhabitants of the city and the prevention of danger from fire, explosions, dangerous conditions, and the prevention of public nuisances that said occupation be regulated within the city. 
(Ord. No. 371, § 1, 3-13-78) 
Sec. 161/2-3. - Permit required. 
    It shall be, and is hereby, declared to be unlawful for any person to drill or to commence to drill a well for oil and gas, or either, in the corporate limits of the city, or to lay or to commence to lay, install, or maintain any pipeline or make any excavation in any part of the streets, alleys, highways, parking spaces or sidewalk areas or other public property in the city, or to erect or use a tank or tanks for the storing or transportation of oil or gas within the corporate limits of the city without a permit so to do first having been granted to such person as provided in this Code. 
(Ord. No. 371, § 1, 3-13-78) 
Sec. 161/2-4. - Application for permit. 
    Before any permit for the drilling of any well or the laying of any pipeline shall be issued, a written application therefor, signed by the applicant or some duly authorized person in his behalf, shall be filed with the city clerk. Applications for the drilling of a well shall be made on forms to be provided by the city and shall state the block and exact lot or location thereon where the proposed well is to be drilled and there shall be attached thereto a map or plat of such block showing the lots contained therein and the dimensions thereof, and be accompanied by a statement setting forth the owners of the respective lots or parts of lots in such block, on which plat shall be shown the exact location of the well proposed to be drilled, which shall be near the center of such block if feasible. Said applications shall also be accompanied by a duly certified, sworn or photostatic copy of all leases or contracts with the owners of real estate in such block owned or controlled by the applicant, and also a statement of other leases not owned by the applicant covering any portion or portions of such block so far as known, setting forth the lessor and lessee of such respective leases. Every such application for the laying of a pipeline across or along any of the streets, alleys, parkways or public grounds of said city shall set forth the name of the owner of such pipeline and the use or purpose to which the same shall be devoted, the size, beginning and terminus thereof and the depth at which the same is proposed to be laid, and the interference, if any, that is proposed or will be necessitated by such laying, with paved streets, sidewalks, parkways, telephone or lighting lines, water and gas mains, sewers, and other property of the city or, of any public utility. All applications shall be verified before an officer authorized to administer oaths. If it is made to appear, either by such application or by other satisfactory proof, that an applicant for permission to drill a well is the owner of, has under his control, either as owner or lessee, or both, all of the property within the block upon which it is proposed to drill such well, the permit may be granted for drilling such well without notice. If such applicant is not the owner of or does not have under his control for drilling purposes as owner or lessee, or both, all real estate, exclusive of streets and alleys in the block on which it is proposed to drill a well, and does not have the consent of all of the owners or lessees of real estate in such block, then before a permit is granted, such applicant shall after filing his application with the city clerk give not less than five days' notice of a hearing thereon to all persons interested in the real estate in such block, either as owners or as lessees, either by publishing a notice one time in a public newspaper, published in said city, or by posting notices thereof in not less than five public places within the city, one of which notices shall be posted at the city hall, one at the front door of the court house and two at public places within such block. Such notice shall fix the time and place for the hearing on such application on a Monday evening at the hour of 4:30 p.m. before the council, at one of its regular meetings and shall describe the block on which it is proposed to drill and the exact location of such well, and the name of the applicant. Proof of giving such notice shall be filed with the city clerk at or before the time of hearing specified in such notice. The council shall at the time designated in such notice, or at some later date to which the hearing may have been postponed, conduct a hearing on such application at which all persons interested may be heard and may introduce the sworn evidence of witnesses and such documentary evidence as may be pertinent, which evidence shall be preserved on the request of the council and may be taken and preserved by any interested person. If taken by an interested party, a copy thereof shall be filed with the city clerk. 
    All permits for the laying of pipelines may be granted by the council without notice. 
    All permits shall, after the same have been ordered to issue, be signed by the mayor or acting mayor, and attested by the city clerk under the corporate seal of the city. 
(Ord. No. 371, § 1, 3-13-78) 
Sec. 161/2-5. - Number of permits. 
    Only one permit shall be granted to drill to each oil leasing stratum on a single block as defined in this Code, except in cases where it is made to appear to the council that an additional well or wells are necessary to properly protect real estate situated in any block against improper and unfair drainage from any well or wells on adjoining real estate, in which event the council may permit the drilling of such additional well or wells as may be necessary to prevent such improper and unfair drainage through wells on adjoining lands, provided that on blocks as herein defined that greatly exceed in size an area of 400 feet square, additional permits may be granted if necessary for the proper development of such blocks. This section shall not apply to the hydraulic reserve, and to outlying areas in the city that are not platted into city lots or blocks. 
(Ord. No. 371, § 1, 3-13-78) 
Sec. 161/2-6. - Permit to minority interest. 
    In the event that the owners of the major portion of the real estate or of the major portion of the leasehold interest covering the real estate, or both, in any one block shall not have applied for permission to drill a well on such block, then any owner of real estate or a leasehold interest less than a major interest therein may make application for a permit to drill a well on such block, on giving notice of a hearing on such application as hereinbefore provided. If at such hearing the owners of the major interest of real estate or leases or both in such block shall make application for a permit to drill on such block, permission shall be granted to the holders of such major interest, otherwise permission to drill may be granted by the council to any owner of real estate or of a leasehold interest covering real estate in such block, subject, however, to all of the other terms and conditions of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 371, § 1, 3-13-78) 
Sec. 161/2-7. - Insurance and bonds. 
    No permit for the drilling or putting down of any well shall be issued until the applicant shall have procured public liability insurance in an amount of not less than $50,000.00, and property damage insurance in an amount not less than $100,000.00, and filed certificates showing that such insurance has been obtained and is in force, with the city clerk, with each application for a drilling permit on a block; provided that in such portions of the city where it is unlikely that property damage may result the council may reduce the amount of such property damage bond below the amount above specified. No permit shall issue to drill a well or lay a pipeline until the applicant shall have filed with the city clerk a bond running to the city in a penal sum of not less than $5,000.00, conditioned that such applicant shall abide by and comply with all of the provisions of this Code and shall save and keep harmless the said city against any claims and demands of any nature whatsoever that may be made against it arising out of the operations of said applicant, and that the permittee will in all respects comply with the provisions of section 161/2-15 of this Code. 
    All such bonds shall be signed as surety by a bonding or indemnity company authorized to do business in the state and shall be approved by the council. All such bonds shall be kept in full force and effect during the operations of the permittee and certificates showing that such insurance is in effect shall be kept on file with the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 371, § 1, 3-13-78) 
Sec. 161/2-8. - Participation by owners. 
    In case the whole of the real estate in any block is covered by leases held by any permittee, such leases shall be deemed to have been unitized, and each owner of real estate in such block shall participate in the royalty interest in oil or gas produced from any well or wells drilled on such block in the proportion that the area owned by each such owner bears to the entire area of such block exclusive of streets and alleys. 
    Owners of real estate in any block who have not made a lease shall be entitled to receive as royalty out of any well or wells drilled on such block such proportion of the average royalty, which shall not be less than one-eighth of the total production, reserved in the leases held by the permittee in such block as the area owned by such non-leasing owner bears to the entire area of such block, exclusive of streets and alleys. 
    Any owner of real estate in any block who may have leased to a lessee other than the permittee shall be entitled to receive as royalty out of any well or wells drilled on such block such proportion, as determined by the royalty reserved in the lease of such owner of the products of such well or wells, as the area owned by such owner bears to the entire area of such block, exclusive of streets and alleys, provided that the royalty reserved in the lease of such owner shall not be greater than the then prevailing and customary royalty in said field. 
    The elections of owners under the provisions of this section shall be exercised by filing the same in writing with the city clerk, and delivering or mailing a copy thereof to the permittee operating on the block in which the real estate of such owner is located. 
(Ord. No. 371, § 1, 3-13-78) 
Sec. 161/2-9. - Participation by lessee. 
    Any lessee holding a lease or leases covering part of a block on which a permit to drill a well shall have been granted to some other person by the council or any owner of real estate in such block who has not made a lease on his real estate in such block may elect to participate in the proportion that the area of such lessee or owner bears to the area of such block, exclusive of streets and alleys, in the working interest in the well or wells drilled or to be drilled on such block by the person to whom a permit has been granted to drill on such block under the provisions of this Code by complying with the following conditions, by the person so desiring to participate: 
(a)  Notice of such election to participate shall be given by the person so desiring to participate by filing a written election with the city clerk, and serving a copy thereof on such permittee either in person or by mailing a copy thereof by registered mail to the post office address of such permittee. 
(b)  The permittee shall give any prospective participant who has given notice of intention to participate an itemized statement of the amount expended by him in drilling and equipping the well or wells on such block, and shall permit examination of his records by such prospective participant to verify the correctness of such statement. If the permittee and the participant are unable to agree upon the amount to be contributed by such participant, the amount shall be determined by arbitration or by appropriate court proceedings. The amount the person so electing to participate shall be required to pay the permittee shall be an amount equal to such proportionate part of the amount expended up to that time by such permittee in the drilling of a well or wells on such block and in equipping the same for the production of oil or gas, exclusive of any amount that may have been paid by such permittee for any lease or leases in such block held by him, and exclusive of all operating costs, as the area in such block owned or held under lease by the person so desiring to participate bears to the entire area of such block, exclusive of streets and alleys. 
Within ten days after the amount the person so electing to participate has been determined, such person so electing to participate shall pay or tender such amount to such permittee, if he can be found by a reasonable effort, and if he cannot be found, then by placing the same in the hands of the treasurer of the city for the use and benefit of such permittee. 
(c)  Within ten days after giving such notice of election, such person so desiring to participate shall make and file with the city clerk a bond running to the permittee executed by a surety company authorized to do a surety business in the state in an amount not less than 11/4 times the estimated amount that such participant will be required to contribute as his proportionate share of the cost of future development on such block, conditioned that said participant will pay to the permittee, his heirs, executors, administrators or assigns, his proportion of the cost of future development and cost of operation and maintenance of the leasehold interest of the permittee in such block and of the operations thereunder. 
(Ord. No. 371, § 1, 3-13-78) 
Sec. 161/2-10. - Mandatory election to participate. 
(a)  Any permittee to whom a drilling permit has been granted, who does not hold leases covering the entire block on which he has been granted a permit to drill a well, may, if he so elects, at any time before the completion of such well, require the owner or owners of the unleased portion and/or of the underlying oil and gas of such block, and/or the holder or holders of leases on the portion of such block not covered by leases held by such permittee, to exercise his or their rights to elect whether or not he or they will participate in the cost of the development of such block and the future operation thereof for the production of oil and gas therefrom in the manner following: 
(1)  Such permittee shall file with the city clerk a written instrument signed by him or his duly authorized agent, stating such election and setting forth in detail the block on which he has been granted a permit to drill and the exact location of the well he proposes to drill thereon, and the depth or formation to which such permittee proposes to drill such well, which instrument shall be accompanied by sworn or certified copies of the leases held by him in such block, and a certificate of some competent abstracter of titles showing the ownership of the fee title, and of the underlying oil and gas and of leasehold interests, on the portion of such block on which permittee does not hold leases. Said instrument of election shall also be accompanied by a sworn statement setting forth the post office address of all of the fee owners and of underlying oil and gas, and the owners of leasehold interests as set forth in said abstracters certificate, if known, and if any such address cannot be ascertained by making diligent inquiry, said sworn statement shall so state and shall give the last known address of such person or persons. 
(2)  Upon the filing of said written election with the accompaniments as aforesaid, the mayor of the city shall by written endorsement thereon, set a date for a hearing thereon, on some date not less than seven days thereafter. Upon such date of hearing being fixed, the permittee shall cause a written notice of such hearing to be served upon each person so named in said abstracter's certificate and sworn statement of addresses whose post office address is given either in person, or by registered mail, such notice to be served or mailed at least five days before the date of such hearing. In case the post office address of any of such owners or lessees is unknown, a notice giving the time, place and purpose of such hearing addressed to such person or persons whose address is unknown, shall be published not less than five days before such date of hearing, at least one time in a public newspaper of general circulation published in the city, and a copy thereof sent by United States mail to the last known address of such owner or lessee as set forth in the sworn statement hereinbefore mentioned. Proof of such serving and mailing of notices shall be made by the affidavit of the person so serving or mailing the same, and proof of publication shall be made by the certificate of the publisher of the paper in which the notice was published. Such affidavit and certificate shall be filed with the city clerk on or before the date fixed for such hearing. If notice of such hearing shall not have been so given, such hearing may be continued by the mayor or council of the city from time to time until notice shall have been given to the interested parties as hereinbefore required. 
(3)  On the date fixed for such hearing, or on such later date to which such hearing may have been continued, the council of the city shall conduct a hearing thereon. On or before the date of such hearing any owner of real estate in such block on which the permittee does not hold a lease or of oil and gas underlying the same, or any holder of a lease on any real estate in such block on which permittee does not hold a lease, if such owner or lessee desires to participate as a leasehold owner in the well proposed to be or being drilled by the permittee, file his election in writing to so participate, in which he shall set forth the area in square feet and a full description of the real estate owned by him or on which he has a lease or leases, or under which he owns the oil and gas in such block, a sworn or certified copy of such lease or leases or conveyance of the underlying oil and gas shall accompany such written election. The permittee shall, not less than two days before such hearing, file with the city clerk a sworn, itemized estimate of the total cost of drilling and equipping the well proposed to be drilled on such block by the permittee. The cost of drilling and of equipping shall be set up separately in such estimate. The person or persons so desiring to participate may severally accept said estimate as correct by filing their written acceptance thereof with the city clerk, or if they are not willing to so accept the same, and are unable to agree with the permittee as to the amount of such estimated cost, then such question of estimated cost shall be by the council referred to three arbitrators, whose fee shall be $25.00 each, and shall be paid by the permittee. One of said arbitrators shall be selected by the permittee and one by the person or persons so electing to participate, which two shall select a third arbitrator. If the parties are unable or fail to so select arbitrators the council may appoint them. The decision of said board of arbitrators shall be filed with the city clerk and shall be final. Within five days after said estimate of cost being so determined, either by acceptance, agreement or by arbitrators, and the filing of the same with the city clerk, the person or persons who have so elected to participate shall pay to the treasurer of the city such proportionate part of such estimated cost as the area owned or held under lease, or under which the oil and gas is owned by such person or persons bears to the area of the block in which such well is proposed to be or is being drilled, exclusive of streets and alleys. Such participant shall also, within the same time, file with the city clerk a bond running to the permittee, executed by a surety company authorized to do a surety business in the state, in an amount not less than one and one-fourth (11/4) times the proportionate part of such estimated cost of said well that such participant is required to pay hereunder, conditioned that said participant will pay to the permittee, his heirs, executors, administrators or assigns, his proportion of the cost of the future development of said block for the production of oil and gas and the cost of future operation and maintenance thereof. 
(4)  If the well so drilled by the permittee is not drilled to the maximum depth specified in the statement filed by the permittee hereunder, the participant or participants shall be entitled to a rebate out of the amount so deposited by him or them to cover drilling costs, with the city treasurer in such proportion as the total actual depth of such well bears to the total depth as set forth in the estimated cost, and if such well is not productive, and is not equipped by the permittee, then the amount so deposited by such participant or participants to cover equipment shall be refunded to him or them. If the permittee completes such well, either as a producer, or as a dry hole, he shall be entitled to have paid to him the amounts so deposited with the city treasurer by the participant or participants, subject to rebates or refunds to the participants as hereinbefore set forth. The city treasurer shall accept as conclusive evidence of the depth to which a well is drilled the affidavit of the contractor drilling such well, or a sworn statement of a disinterested party who has measured its depth, or a certified or sworn copy of an electrical log reading of such well extending to the bottom of such well. 
(5)  The permittee for any block shall have the right to develop and operate such block for oil and gas, to the exclusion of all owners of real estate or other holders of leases, or participants, being accountable to them, however, for such interest in the production from such block to which they are respectively entitled under this Code. The permittee shall have a lien on the share of such production of any participant who fails to make payment of any sum or sums that may become due from him or them to the permittee under the terms of this or any other section of this Code or otherwise. 
(6)  If permittee after production is found fails, refuses or neglects to complete such well, or to equip the same, or at any time abandons the same, then the participant or participants under section 161/2-9 or 161/2-10 of this Code shall have the right to and may take over the working interest in such block, and thereafter develop and operate the same and permittee shall have no further interest therein. 
(7)  Any owner or owners of the fee or of the underlying oil in any block, or any holder or holders of an oil and gas lease or leases in any block, who, after proceedings shall have been had under the provision of this section by the permittee to require him or them to exercise his right to participate in the leasehold interest in such block, shall fail to avail himself or themselves of the right to so participate, shall thereafter have no right to participate in such leasehold interest under section 161/2-9 of this Code, or otherwise, and shall have no share in the oil and gas or either produced by the permittee in such block that belongs to the working of leasehold interest. 
(8)  Any participant under this section or under section 161/2-9 of this Code shall by himself, or his agent appointed in writing, during business hours and in the presence of the permittee, have access to the records of such permittee pertaining to the cost of development and operation by the permittee on such block, the amount of production therefrom, and the proceeds derived from sale of oil and gas, or either, therefrom, which records shall be kept by permittee and shall be available at some place in the city. 
(9)  All bonds required by this or any other section of this Code shall be kept constantly in force by the party required to furnish the same; a failure so to do shall be ground for suspension of such rights under this Code of the person under obligation to furnish the same, until such bond requirements are met by such person. 
(Ord. No. 371, § 1, 3-13-78) 
Sec. 161/2-11. - Permit fees. 
(a)  All applicants for permit to drill a well shall pay to the city clerk, at the time of making such application, the sum of $100.00 as a fee to apply on the cost and expense of the administration of this Code, of which amount the sum of $75.00 shall be refunded if the application is not granted. All applicants for permits to lay a pipeline longitudinally along any street or alley shall pay at the time of making such application a fee of $0.25 per rod, but in no event less than $10.00 to cover the cost of expense of the administration of this Code, of which amount 75 percent shall be refunded if the application is not granted, provided that no permit shall be required to cross an alley within the block on which a permittee is drilling or operating a well. 
(b)  In addition to the above, any applicant, person, firm or corporation obtaining a permit to drill a well shall pay an additional fee of 1/32 of 7/8 overriding royalty of the production from said well, and this section shall be authority for the purchaser of oil and gas produced from any well to pay to the city 1/32 of 7/8 of the production as a continuing fee. Should the oil and gas purchaser not consider this sufficient authority, then in that event, the acceptance of a permit to drill a well shall automatically obligate the lessee or his assigns to execute any instrument necessary, such that the city shall receive a 1/32 of 7/8 overriding royalty of the production from the well. The overriding royalty shall apply only to oil and gas leases executed after the effective date of this amendment. 
(Ord. No. 371, § 1, 3-13-78; Ord. No. 672, 5-19-97) 
Sec. 16-12. - Annual fee. 
(a)  On or before the fifteenth day of April of each year, the owner of each producing oil well in the corporate limits of the city, which well was completed before the first day of such year, shall pay to the city an annual fee, to cover the cost of administering this Code, based upon the average daily production of such well during the months of January, February and March of such year, as follows: 
(1)  For wells from which the average daily production for such period was in excess of ten barrels, the sum of $50.00. 
(2)  For wells from which the average daily production for such period was not in excess of ten barrels and more than six barrels, the sum of $25.00. 
(3)  For wells from which the average daily production for such period was six barrels or less, the sum of $10.00. 
(b)  Each such owner shall file with the city clerk a sworn statement by some person having knowledge of the facts, or a copy for the runs from such well, furnished by the purchaser of the oil from such well, showing the production from such well for such three-month period, which shall be taken as evidence of such production, and shall be taken as the basis. 
(c)  Each owner of a pipeline laid upon, along or across any public street, alley or public way in the city shall, on or before the fifteenth day of April of each year, so long as such pipeline remains, pay to the city at the rate of $0.10 per rod for the amount of pipe so owned by such owner, to apply on the expense of administering this Code. The city may cancel the permit of any pipeline owner to maintain his pipeline who fails to pay such amounts at or before the time the same becomes due by giving five days written notice to such owner of his agent, served either in person or by United States mail. 
(Ord. No. 371, § 1, 3-13-78) 
Sec. 161/2-13. - Character of materials. 
    All equipment and materials used in the drilling of wells, or in equipping or operating the same, and all tanks, pipelines, valves and fittings shall be of standard design and quality such as are in common use by the petroleum industry, and shall be installed and maintained in accordance with standard practices in such industry. No wooden derricks shall be used. Suitable hand fire extinguishers in good working order shall be provided and kept in each derrick while a well is being drilled. 
(Ord. No. 371, § 1, 3-13-78) 
Sec. 161/2-14. - Compliance with law. 
    All drilling operations, equipping of wells, producing and marketing of oil and gas, plugging of wells and all materials used and work done in connection with exploring for, producing and marketing petroleum products shall be in conformity with state and federal laws pertaining thereto, and if any of the provisions of this Code conflict with state and federal law this Code shall be ineffective to that extent. 
(Ord. No. 371, § 1, 3-13-78) 
Sec. 161/2-15. - Obstruction of streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for any permittee to drill any oil or gas well within any of the streets or alleys of the city or to block or encumber or close up any street or alley in any drilling or production operation, or lay pipelines, except pursuant to a special permit by order of the council, and then only temporarily. 
(Ord. No. 371, § 1, 3-13-78) 
Sec. 161/2-16. - Interference with public property. 
    No excavation shall be made in any street or alley or in any public place, nor shall any sidewalk, or the paving on any public street, or any water pipe, water main, fire hydrant, storm or sanitary sewer, or street lighting equipment be interfered with in any manner, except by permit of the council or the head of the department of the city having the same under his jurisdiction. All excavations that may be made shall be filled by the person making the same, and all sidewalks and street paving, water pipe, water main, fire hydrants, storm or sanitary sewers or street lighting equipment that may be interfered with shall be by the person so interfering therewith restored to their former condition or to such altered condition as may be directed by the council or by the head of the department having jurisdiction over the same. 
(Ord. No. 371, § 1, 3-13-78) 
Sec. 161/2-17. - Tanks. 
    No tanks or other facilities for the storage of oil produced from any well or wells within the city shall be kept, erected or maintained within the business or closely built up residential sections of the city, having a capacity in excess of 500 barrels; and no wooden tanks for such purpose shall be erected or maintained within the city. All pipelines along or across streets or alleys shall be buried. 
(Ord. No. 371, § 1, 3-13-78) 
Sec. 161/2-18. - Interpretation. 
    Neither this chapter, nor any permit issued hereunder, shall be interpreted to grant any right or license to the permittee to enter upon or occupy in any respect, in drilling or production operations, any land, except upon the written consent of the owner; nor shall it limit or prevent the free right of any property owner to contract for the amount of royalty to be paid with respect to his own real estate for production from any well on such owners' real estate, or for damages, rights or privileges with respect thereto, all subject, however, to regulations as set forth in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 371, § 1, 3-13-78) 
Sec. 161/2-19. - Operation. 
    In operating by virtue of any permit issued under this chapter all water, oil, gas or waste produced or arising from such operations shall be piped or otherwise conveyed or removed from the corporate limits of the city, except in connection with the ordinary use of a slush pit. No waste, sludge or water shall be permitted to empty into any sanitary sewer. All excavations in, or use of the streets or alleys under such operations, shall be under the direction of the department of streets and alleys of the city, and shall be done without unnecessary obstruction of the streets and without cost or expense to the city. 
(Ord. No. 371, § 1, 3-13-78) 
Sec. 161/2-20. - Prevention of escape of gas. 
(a)  All operators of oil or gas, or oil and gas wells in the corporate limits of the city, from which deleterious gas, commonly known to the oil industry as "sour gas," escapes, shall by some efficient means, so far as is possible, prevent the escape of such gas or deleterious fumes therefrom into the atmosphere from any such well or wells, and from tanks or pipelines to which any such well or wells may be connected. 
(1)  All operators shall be responsible in damages to the person injured for all injury to property or person caused by allowing gas or fumes therefrom from any well to escape into the atmosphere. 
(2)  Failure to comply with the requirements of this section shall subject the offender to the penalties prescribed by Ordinance 10-E, and in addition thereto, the mayor of the city, or the council of the city may, by resolution, order any well or wells that are operated in violation of this section closed and operation thereof discontinued, until the requirements of this section are complied with. 
(Ord. No. 371, § 1, 3-13-78) 
Sec. 161/2-21. - Restoration. 
    Within 30 days after any oil or gas well within the limits of the city shall have been completed for production of oil or gas, or within 30 days after the same shall have been completed in cases where the same is abandoned for the reason that a dry hold is found, the permittee shall fill the slush pit with dirt and level off the surface and such permittee shall not unnecessarily allow any accumulation of sludge, oil or other offensive or dangerous substances to accumulate, and shall so far as is reasonably possible keep his premises in a sanitary and sightly condition. 
(Ord. No. 371, § 1, 3-13-78) 
Sec. 161/2-22. - Inspection. 
    Any officer, policeman or employee of the city designated for that purpose, shall have the right and privilege at any time to enter upon the premises covered by any permit issued under this chapter, for the purpose of making inspections to determine if the requirements of this Code are being complied with, or the requirements of any other Code of said city relating to the health and safety of persons and property within the city. 
(Ord. No. 371, § 1, 3-13-78) 
Sec. 161/2-23. - Penalties. 
    Any person, who, either himself or through his agent, servant or employee, shall violate any provisions of this chapter, shall, upon the conviction thereof, be subject to a fine of not less than $25.00 and not more than $200.00, and each day such violation is continued or any structure maintained or permitted to exist in violation of this chapter shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 371, § 1, 3-13-78) 
Sec. 161/2-24. - Saving clause. 
    If any part or section of this chapter, or any regulation or requirement herein shall be held to be invalid by any court of competent jurisdiction, such invalidity shall not affect the validity of any other part or section, or other regulation or requirement herein. 
(Ord. No. 371, § 1, 3-13-78) 
Chapter 17 - PLANNING AND ZONING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Flood damage prevention, ch. 91/2; zoning ordinance, app. A. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL (RESERVED) 

Secs. 17-1-17-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PLAN COMMISSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to create a plan commission, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 24, § 11-12-4. 

Sec. 17-16. - Created; purpose. 
    In order that adequate provisions be made for the preparation of a comprehensive community plan for the guidance, direction and control of the growth and development or redevelopment of the city and contiguous territory not more than 11/2 miles beyond the corporate limits and not included in any municipality, a plan commission is hereby created as a department of the city government under the authority of state law. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 4-7; Ord. No. 116, § 1, 4-20-64) 
Sec. 17-17. - Composition. 
    The plan commission established by this article shall consist of ten members, with the mayor being an ex officio member. The other nine members shall be appointed by the mayor on the basis of their particular fitness for duty on the plan commission, subject to the approval of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 116, § 2, 4-20-64; Ord. No. 409, § 1, 6-9-80) 
Sec. 17-18. - Terms of members; filling vacancies. 
(a)  The members of the plan commission established by this article who are city officers serving ex officio shall serve during the term of their respective city offices. 
(b)  Of the remaining nine members, three shall serve until April 30, 1981, three until April 30, 1982 and three (3) until April 30, 1983. Upon the completion of these initial terms, each appointed member shall serve for a period of three years, or until a successor takes office. 
(c)  Terms of office of the members of the plan commission appointed to serve the original terms mentioned above shall be determined by lot. All vacancies on the plan commission shall be filled by appointment for the remainder of the unexpired term of office only, in the same manner as for original appointments. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 4-7; Ord. No. 116, § 3, 4-20-64; Ord. No. 409, § 2, 6-9-80) 
Sec. 17-19. - Compensation. 
    All members of the plan commission shall serve as such without compensation, except that, if the city council deems it advisable, they may receive such compensation as may be fixed from time to time by the council and provided for in the appropriation ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 116, § 3, 4-20-64) 
Sec. 17-20. - Organization; rules and regulations. 
    The plan commission shall elect such officers as it may deem necessary and adopt such rules and regulations of organization and procedure as it may deem necessary and proper in carrying out the work of the commission. 
(Ord. No. 116, § 4, 4-20-64) 
Sec. 17-21. - Records. 
    The plan commission shall keep written records of its proceedings, which records shall be open at all times to public inspection. 
(Ord. No. 116, § 4, 4-20-64) 
Sec. 17-22. - Annual report. 
    The plan commission shall file an annual report with the mayor and city council setting forth its transactions and recommendations. Such report shall be submitted to the council at the first regularly scheduled meeting thereof in January. 
(Ord. No. 116, § 4, 4-20-64) 
Sec. 17-23. - Powers and duties. 
    The plan commission shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  To prepare and recommend to the city council a comprehensive plan for the present and future development or redevelopment of the city and contiguous unincorporated territory not more than 11/2 miles beyond the corporate limits of the city and not included in any other municipality. Such plan may be adopted in whole or in separate geographical or functional parts, each of which, when adopted shall be the official comprehensive plan, or part thereof, of the city. Such plan shall be advisory, except as to such part thereof as has been implemented by ordinances duly enacted by the council. All requirements for public hearing, filing of notice of adoption of adoption with the county recorder of deeds, and filing of said plan and ordinances with the city clerk shall be complied with as provided for by law. 
(2)  To provide for the health, safety, comfort and convenience of the inhabitants of the city and contiguous territory. Such plan or plans shall establish reasonable standards of design for subdivisions and for resubdivisions of unimproved land and of areas subject to redevelopment in respect to public improvements as herein defined and shall establish reasonable requirements governing the location, width, course and surfacing of public streets and highways, alleys, ways for public service facilities, curbs, gutters, sidewalks, street lights, parks, playgrounds, school grounds, size of lots to be used for residential purposes, storm water drainage, water supply and distribution, sanitary sewers and sewage collection and treatment. The requirements specified herein shall become regulatory only when adopted by ordinance. 
(3)  To designate land suitable for annexation to the municipality and the recommended zoning classification for such land upon annexation. 
(4)  To recommend to the city council from time to time, such changes in the comprehensive plan or any part thereof as may be deemed necessary. 
(5)  To prepare and recommend to the council from time to time plans and recommendations for specific improvements in pursuance of the official comprehensive plan. 
(6)  To give aid to the officials of the city charged with the direction of projects for improvements embraced within the official plan or parts thereof, to further the making of such improvements, and generally to promote the realization of the official comprehensive plan. 
(7)  To arrange and conduct any form of publicity relative to its activities for the general purpose of public understanding. 
(8)  To cooperate with municipal or regional planning commissions and other agencies or groups to further the local planning program and to assure harmonious and integrated planning for the area. 
(9)  To exercise such other powers germane to the powers granted under authority of state law. 
(Ord. No. 116, § 5, 4-20-64) 
Sec. 17-23. - Subdivisions generally; official map. 
(a)  At any time, before or after the formal adoption of the official comprehensive plan by the city council, an official map may be designated by ordinance, which map may consist of the whole area included within the official comprehensive plan or one or more separate geographical or functional parts, and may include all or any part of the contiguous unincorporated area within 11/2 miles from the corporate limits of the city. 
(b)  All requirements for public hearing, filing of notice of adoption with the county recorder of deeds, and filing of said plan and ordinances including the official map with the city clerk shall be complied with as provided by law. 
(c)  No map or plat of any subdivision or resubdivision presented for record, affecting land within the corporate limits of the city, or within contiguous territory which is not more than 11/2 miles beyond the corporate limits, shall be entitled to record or shall be valid unless the subdivision shown thereon provided for standards of design and standards governing streets, alleys, public ways, ways for public service facilities, street lights, public grounds, size of lots to be used for residential purposes, storm and flood water run-off channels and basins, water supply and distribution, sanitary sewers and sewage collection and treatment, in conformity with the applicable requirements of this Code and other ordinances of the city, including the official map. 
(d)  Nothing contained herein shall be deemed to alter or modify any of the requirements of the zoning ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 116, § 6, 4-20-64; Ord. No. 409, § 3, 6-9-80) 
Sec. 17-24. - Improvements. 
    The city clerk shall furnish the plan commission for its consideration a copy of all ordinances, plans and data relative to public improvements of any nature. The commission may report in relation thereto if it deems a report necessary or advisable, for the consideration of the council. 
(Ord. No. 116, § 7, 4-20-64) 
Sec. 17-25. - Personnel; technical services. 
(a)  The plan commission may, at the discretion of the city council, employ a paid secretary or staff, or both, whose salaries, wages and other necessary expenses shall be provided for by adequate appropriation made by the council from the public funds. 
(b)  If the plan commission shall deem it advisable to secure technical advice or services, it may be done upon authority from the city council and appropriations by the council therefor. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 4-8; Ord. No. 116, § 8, 4-20-64) 
Chapter 18 - POLICE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Power of mayor to enforce laws and ordinances, § 2-95; power of mayor to keep peace, § 2-103; release of prisoners by mayor, § 2-104; departments of employment, § 2-207; board of fire and police commissioners, § 2-240 et seq.; duty of police department to enforce traffic laws and regulations, § 15-3; abandoned, lost, stolen or unclaimed vehicles, § 15-147 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 18-1-18-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - POLICE DEPARTMENT 

Sec. 18-16. - Established. 
    There is hereby established as a department of the city, the police department. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 4-5) 
Sec. 18-17. - Composition. 
    The police department shall consist of the chief of police and such subordinate police officers and other personnel as the city council may from time to time prescribe. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 4-5) 
Sec. 18-18. - Chief of police. 
(a)  There is hereby created the office of chief of police, who shall be appointed by the mayor, with the advice and consent of the city council. 
(b)  The chief of police shall be the executive head of the police department. 
(c)  The chief of police shall post such bond for faithful performance and shall receive such compensation as the city council shall from time to time prescribe. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 4-5; Ord. No. 87-A, § 2, 1-31-58) 
Sec. 18-19. - General duties and powers of the chief of police. 
    The chief of police shall: 
(1)  Take charge of the operation of the police department and all equipment, supplies and property belonging thereto; 
(2)  Control and supervise the officers of the police department and see that they faithfully perform the duties assigned to them and report to the mayor and health and safety committee of the council any dereliction of duties on the part of such officers; 
(3)  Make a monthly report to the council; 
(4)  Submit to the city council an annual report of the needs of the police department and the sum of money he considers necessary to operate the department for the succeeding fiscal year; 
(5)  Confer at least once every three months with the council or a committee of the council on the policies and operations of the police department. 
(1947 Rev. Ords., § 4-5) 
Sec. 18-20. - Duties and functions of the police department generally.
